DOC.HEAD: Reports Say Engine Failure Caused Indian Plane Crash
DOC.TEXT: Engine failure caused the crash of an Airbus-320 airliner last month in southern India, killing 92 people, news reports said Monday. A total of 146 people were on board the plane when it crashed Feb. 14 at Bangalore. The news agency reports, quoting unidentified sources, said the plane did not respond to a computer command or direct control of the pilots when it deviated from the its flight path during descent. Press Trust of India and the United News of India said the commands were given simultaneously after the plane started to go down. ``There was sufficent time for the ill-fated aircraft to pull up,'' Press Trust quoted one source as saying. The news agencies said the commands to bring the plane back under control were given seven seconds before the crash. The news agencies said their sources had access to the readout of the Digital Flight Recorder and the Cockpit Voice Recorder. The devices log all changes in altitude, speed and direction, as well as conversation among cockpit crew. The aircraft was purchased by the Indian Airlines three months before the crash. The plane was manufactured by Airbus Industrie, a European consortium based in Toulouse, France.

DOC.HEAD: They Came to Spring Break to Build, Not Party
DOC.TEXT: While hundreds of thousands of college students on spring break come to Florida to party in the sun, a few came to build homes for the homeless. Seventeen American University students from Washington are spending their vacation building homes for two needy families in Brevard County as part of the Habitat for Humanity program. ``This group really wants to work,'' said Joy Willard-Williford, project director for the South Brevard Habitat for Humanity. ``They came with their hammers and tools and their nail aprons on. They were all decked out.'' The eight men and nine women, who arrived from the nation's capital on Sunday, did want to know _ like most college students _ how far they would be from Daytona Beach, said Ms. Willard-Williford. ``I said, `Ah-hah, that is why they are really here. They just wanted to go to the beach,''' she said. But she discovered the students were uninterested in bikinis and beer: They wanted to attend an Amnesty International rally. They are only taking off on Thursday, when half plan to head for the beach and the other half to Disney World. The Habitat for Humanity chapter at American University has more than 200 members and about 50 are spending their spring break building homes in various communities, said Kate Hochberg, 20, a group leader. ``It's very good for the young, idealistic types,'' Ms. Hochberg said. ``It's something you can actually do to contribute.''

DOC.HEAD: Sub-Sahara Has Bumper Harvest, but Problems Persist
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Timbuktu was lucky last year. It rained, the locusts stayed away and, with some help from the outside, farmers produced one of the best harvests in half a century. Farmers in nearly all the countries that hug the southern Sahara Desert's harsh border produced similar bumper crops that filled graneries and children's bellies from Senegal east to Niger. The good fortune of 1988 and 1989, welcome as it is, also illuminates the profound problems facing these poor nations struggling to feed themselves _ problems that range from a birthrate that outpaces production to a marketplace that stacks the deck against even the hardest-working farmer. Experts note that, even with the bountiful harvest in most countries, sub-Saharan Africa imported nearly 9 million tons of cereal grains in 1988. ``Nonetheless, the 500,000-ton grain surplus is spectacular news,'' said U.S. Ambassador Robert Pringle. ``Now everyone is wondering how to export what they have grown.'' Abduleh al Kalifa, hip-deep in a field of emerald-green wheat rippling in a desert wind near Timbuktu, doesn't worry about exporting. He just wishes he could sell his surplus 30 miles away, in Timbuktu. ``Five years ago there was no rain, nothing to eat,'' said Kalifa, 36, already middle-aged in a nation where the average life expectancy is 49. ``Foreigners gave us everything. These last two years, the harvests were good. We have hope and two warehouses are full. ``We have more than we can eat, more than we can store and we can't sell the rest,'' he said. ``How can we get our grain to town if there are no roads? How can we compete with grain from other countries? How can we earn enough money to buy food when there is another drought?'' Mali's last drought left its mark on the children. Two-year-olds are solid and round, but children born in the drought of 1984-1985 are spindly, apt to suffer from chronic malnutrition. ``If you are malnourished, a few good meals will make you feel better, but you are still malnourished,'' said Leo DeVos, director of the United Nations Children's Fund in Mali. ``The whole country is like these children. It will take more than a couple of good harvests to put the country back on its feet. ``Still, it's nice to see the green,'' he said. ``It is the color of hope.'' When UNICEF arrived five years ago with emergency food, the government was in chaos, people were starving and huge numbers of refugees arrived in cities each day from the barren countryside. Enormous need remained when the crisis ended, so UNICEF and others stayed on to help. The United States, which spends about $30 million a year in Mali, now helps entrepreneurs and small farmers. West Germany built warehouses for reserves and a highway that spans a nation as large as Texas and California combined. France, Italy and others fight the advance of the desert, dig wells, organize cooperatives and help in dozens of other ways. UNICEF has concentrated on Timbuktu, a once-mysterious oasis that still evokes romance and adventure. Centuries ago, Timbuktu was a crossroads of caravans, a center of learning and a garden in the desert, where the river ran deep and trees hung heavy with fruit. Now, the advancing desert has tied a noose of dunes around it and many donors have written the city off as a lost cause. With funds donated by Italian labor unions, UNICEF installed pumps to make use of Niger River water and drilled wells to tap ground water for irrigation. ``We wanted to set an example, to show what could be done in even the most precarious situation,'' DeVos said. One result of the five-year project was the field where Kalifa and his neighbors grew a 15-ton grain surplus, little of which can be sold. The Malian government used to have price controls, which kept food costs down and made urban voters happy, but discouraged farmers because of the low return on their labor. Controls were abolished at the insistence of the World Bank and International Monetary Fund. International donors and lenders also demanded that Mali eliminate protectionist measures and subsidies to farmers. Their message was simple: No open markets, no aid. ``We have a long-term commitment to food aid, in return for which we ask that the entire cereal market be freed,'' said Dennis Brennan, director of the U.S. Agency for International Development in Bamako. With the market wide open, rice from Thailand and Louisiana costs less in the Timbuktu bazaar than grain grown down the road. ``The little guy works like crazy to grow something, pulling grain from soil that is poor, in primitive conditions and in a climate that is never favorable, even when there is no drought,'' said Giovanni Fiore, director of UNICEF's Timbuktu project and an Africa veteran. Then, when the farmer produces a surplus, there are no buyers. No one in the villages has any cash and consumers in Timbuktu buy whatever is cheapest. ``It comes from Europe or the United States where farmers receive subsidies,'' Fiore said. ``How can a Malian compete? He has no subsidy. All he has is taxes and the high cost of the pump, gasoline, oil, fertilizer, all of which has to be imported at double, triple, 10 times the cost to an American. ``Meanwhile, the donors tie aid to an open market in which farmers from developed countries can sell their surplus. So our farmers eat what they can, store a little, which will last a year or two, and when there is another extended drought, there will be famine.''

DOC.HEAD: Inner-City Teen-agers Come to Terms With Death _ and Life _ at The Wall
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: The kids go to Chez Vous to roller skate and gossip, to share sodas and stories. And for a safe haven from the gunfire of the streets. Now they also come to weep at ``The Wall,'' a stark memorial inscribed with the names of 65 teen-agers who have died in recent years on Boston's streets. ``They come over and see the names of friends and relatives,'' said Dorcas Dunham, who with her husband runs the inner-city roller skating rink. ``They're starting to see the reality and they're crying out.'' They're seeing death in a black-and-white list that grows longer every day, a list that includes the names of gang members gunned down by their rivals and innocent kids caught in the crossfire. The war has claimed 28 lives in Boston aleady this year. If the pace continues, The Wall will soon be filled. No one wants to start another. The memorial hangs in a corner at the 50-year-old rink in the city's Dorchester section. It's housed behind a reinforced door and around the corner from one of the city's busiest police precincts. The teen-age skaters are all frisked for weapons and agree to play by the rules: no gum, no smoking, no fighting, no profanity. The Rev. Bruce Wall, a minister and youth counselor, tacked the names of four more victims to the list Saturday afternoon. When the kids came in Saturday night, they looked 8 feet up and noticed the additions. ``They come in and go for their skates and start looking for their friends,'' said Wall, who is also a Juvenile Court clerk magistrate. ``Then they stop and stare ... and stare.'' Faces go with these names. ``It's like you can almost see the kids remembering them, their classmates and friends,'' said John Dunham, who with his wife keeps tabs on as many as 350 teen-agers on a busy night at the rink. ``They're overwhelmed and then they seem, like, broken with despair,'' said Dunham. They're tired of seeing friends' faces on the evening news and hearing ``that another one bit the dust,'' he said. Dunham said he sees it in the way the kids' shoulders slump as they read the words scrawled across the memorial: ``Dedicated To Those Youth Who Died Before Their Time.'' Sometimes he stands back a few feet and just watches the emotions and tears wash over the teen-agers' faces. ``Some of them don't even come to skate anymore. They just come to look at The Wall,'' Dunham said. ``They're learning about respecting life ... and that there are no second chances.'' Audrey Moore knows there are no second chances. Her 11-year-old sister, Tiffany, is on the list. Tiffany was shot down by a stray bullet one summer day two years ago as she sat on a mailbox in her neighborhood. ``I talk to the gang members and try to get through,'' she said. ``I know none of them want to see one of their own on The Wall. Maybe this will make them stop and think.'' Dunham said he thinks the message is getting through. He watches the kids leave the rink at night, cutting a wide path around the groups that hang outside looking for trouble after closing. He has seen fights start erupting inside the rink and has seen them cut short when a kid stands up and points toward The Wall. ``They say, `Don't you all see that? Look at all our friends _ dead,' and then things get real quiet,'' he said. ``We're planting a seed of hope here.'' That's what it's all about, activists said. The memorial is about dealing with death and staking a claim to life. It's one piece of a bigger effort to turn things around in these tired communities, where people sleep on their floors to stay out of the line of fire at night. The effort includes an anti-drug hotline, crimewatches and classes on civil rights for the youngers who are stopped and searched for arms. It includes meetings and marches, one of which was held on The Wall's inauguration day March 3. ``The idea for The Wall has a lot to do with the Vietnam War Memorial,'' said Dunham, who put up the memorial with his wife and Rev. Wall. ``That was a battle and so is this, even if a lot of the kids don't know it.''

DOC.HEAD: Jerusalem: The Emotional Center of the Storm
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Two days after Israel's army captured east Jerusalem in 1967, Defense Minister Moshe Dayan ordered removal of all barriers dividing the Holy City's Arab and Jewish sectors. Dayan's decisive action ended a division that existed since the Jewish state was founded in 1948. He brushed aside fears of some Israeli officials that fighting would break out between Arabs and Jews, recalling in his biography that he told them, ``we could deal later with whatever problems may arise.'' On Tuesday, 23 years later, the sensitive problem of Jerusalem was largely to blame for the collapse of Israel's coalition government in a dispute between Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's Likud bloc and the center-left Labor Party. Labor accepted U.S. proposals to include east Jerusalem Arabs in a Palestinian delegation to peace talks with Israel. Likud was opposed, fearing Israel's control of all Jerusalem could be called into question. The dispute reached a crisis when Shamir hardened his stance after a comment by President Bush equating the Jewish suburbs around Jerusalem with settlements in the occupied West Bank. ``I hear the voices coming today from Washington on the issue of Jerusalem, things that enrage every Jew in Israel, and I have to react,'' the 74-year-old Shamir angrily declared. Bush had said nothing to change American policy, which has never recognized the annexation of the Arab sector into Israel's ``eternal, undivided capital'' after the land was seized from Jordan in the 1967 war. But the American president reignited an issue that is the most emotional one of the entire Israeli-Palestinian conflict: Jerusalem is a city holy to both Jews and Moslems. For Jews, it is at the heart of Israel's very existence, the site of King Solomon's ancient temple, the symbol of God's promise to return the Jews from exile. While many Israelis can accept trading the West Bank and Gaza Strip for peace, few are willing to give up any part of Jerusalem. Even those who are not deeply religious think of the city as theirs. In the hilltop, fortress-like suburb of Gilo that Israel has built on captured territory south of the city, laborer Menachem Ben-Tlulia was asked his views of living on ``occupied'' land. ``I don't understand all this politics,'' said Ben-Tlulia, who immigrated six years ago from Morocco. ``I feel like I live in the city of Jerusalem, our city, all of it.'' In East Talpiot, another suburb once in Arab territory, Shlomo Einstein complained about Bush comparing parts of Jerusalem to the settlements where Jews live among the 1.7 million Palestinians of the West Bank and Gaza. ``I don't feel like I live in a settlement,'' said the 56-year-old psychologist. ``Areas outside Jerusalem are settlements.'' Gilo and East Talpiot are among seven neighborhoods built by Israel on 18,000 acres of Arab land it annexed. On Tuesday, Housing Minister David Levy, a Likud member, laid the cornerstone for a new development to house 3,500 Israelis. The Hebrew daily Haaretz wrote that building of the Jewish suburbs was ``based on a policy intended to emphasize the constant Israeli presence in all areas within the boundaries of Jerusalem's jurisdiction.'' Now, 120,000 of Jerusalem's 340,000 Jewish residents live in these suburbs, virtually surrounding the city's 140,000 Palestinian residents. For Palestinians, Jerusalem also is a religious and political heritage. The Dome of the Rock mosque, built in the 7th century, stands on the spot where Moslems believe Mohammed ascended to heaven. For Palestinian Christians, the city is a living reminder of Jesus' crucifixion and resurrection. The leading Palestinian families _ the Husseinis, the Nashashibis, the Nusseibehs _ have lived in Jerusalem for centuries. The PLO's Parliament-in-exile, founded in east Jerusalem in 1964, declared two years ago that the city was the capital of its would-be Palestinian state. Sari Nusseibeh, a Palestinian professor of philosphy, echoes Israeli politicians when he says the question of Jerusalem ``is not subject to negotiations.'' ``East Jerusalem is the capital of the occupied Palestinian state,'' Nusseibeh said. ``The unilateral action of Israel having annexed it does not change the historical facts and the political facts.'' Housing Minister Levy was just as determined when he inaugurated the new Jewish suburb Tuesday in east Jerusalem. ``Building determines our future here,'' he said. ``This is our united capital. Jerusalem is the heart of every Jew, eternally.'' For most of the past 23 years, the Arab-Israeli dispute over Jerusalem remained largely beneath the surface. But it burst forth at the start of the Palestinian uprising 27 months ago. East Jerusalem's Palestinians joined those in the occupied lands in resisting Israeli rule. In the first year of the revolt, police found 1,229 illegal Palestinian flags flying in Jerusalem. The slayings of four Israelis and six Palestinians in the city have been linked to the uprising.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Subcommittee Hears Testimony on Compensation for Uranium Miners
DOC.TEXT: A bill to compensate poisoned uranium miners brought ``a day of hope'' to long-neglected workers who provided the raw material for American's burgeoning nuclear programs, former U.S. Interior Secretary Stewart Udall said Tuesday. Udall spoke at a hearing on a bill co-sponsored by Sen. Pete Domenici, R-N.M., to establish a $100 million trust fund for the workers _ many of them Navajo Indians _ who worked uranium mines in New Mexico, Arizona, Colorado and Utah between 1947 and 1971. ``I support compensation for the uranium miners, both Indian and non-Indian, because of the service they performed for our nation,'' Domenici said. ``In the course of that service, a number of them suffered from very, very serious diseases. It is time that we recognize that fact and set to work righting the wrong that began more than 40 years ago.'' He said 250 to 350 uranium miners or their beneficiaries would receive compensation under the bill, which would provide $100,000 awards to miners suffering lung cancer and other diseases. For more than 20 years, according to testimony, the miners dug uranium ore without warnings from their employers or the government. They breathed radioactive dust, ate their lunches deep in the mineshafts and even drank contaminated mine water. The bill also would compensate with $50,000 each residents of Nevada and Utah who can prove they were exposed to radiation fallout from nuclear testing. ``The bill in a small way will make up for the mistakes made in the early days in the uranium mines,'' Domenici said. `We could never replace the ones that died or those who are ill, but this is a giant step.'' Udall, who once sued the government on behalf of injured miners, said the government's treatment of the Navajos was especially grievous. ``The government not only didn't warn them, it was flagrant malpractice to do what they did,'' Udall said. He said the hearing of the Senate subcommittee on mineral resources development and production before 600 people at a high school gym, brought ``a day of hope'' to the Navajo community. Navajo interim Chairman Leonard Haskie said the Public Health Service conducted a study in 1949 of radiation and knew then the dangers to the miners. ``In order to proceed with its study, PHS decided not to tell miners of the hazards for fear that many miners would quit, which would interrupt the production of uranium,'' Haskie said. ``Families continue to be exposed because many mines are still open. Children play in them.'' Susan Dawson, assistant sociology professor at Utah State University, said miners were never informed of the dangers or their rights under state worker's compensation laws when they became ill. ``One Navajo foreman said mine owners told him not to tell the workers about the dangers of radiation,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: `Seven Years of Hell': Police Say Stalker Killed Ex-Gay Lover
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: At twilight in a black-top parking lot, Jeffrey Dryfka fell dead with a .25-caliber bullet through the back. So ended ``Seven Years of Hell,'' the title of his unfinished journal. Through Dryfka's writings, telephone records and tales from the back streets of south Florida, police pieced together a bizarre tale of obsession in which Dryfka was allegedly stalked by a former homosexual lover. The man had boasted the hunt would end in death, authorities said. ``This guy said he would not rest until Jeff Dryfka was dead,'' said Detective John Donadio. ``If he couldn't have him, no one could. It's much weirder than the movie `Fatal Attraction' because it's true.'' Last week, a grand jury indicted James Charles Barfield, 47, for first-degree murder in the Feb. 17 slaying. Prosecutors will seek the death penalty. ``The poor victim was hounded,'' said Broward State Attorney Brian Cavanagh. The story of Dryfka, 26, and Barfield, which began with small talk on a park bench, illuminates a shadowy side of south Florida. Each night young runaways, prostitutes and junkies _ and those who prey off their weaknesses _ bargain and barter away under the bug-encircled street lamps. ``This is a good lesson of how someone can get caught up in the sick side of society without even knowing it at first,'' Donadio said. The beginning of Dryfka's journal describes how at 18 years old he was sent from the home of his mother and stepfather in San Diego to his father's apartment in West Palm Beach. ``I had the perfect life,'' he wrote of San Diego. ``I had a pool in the backyard, a skateboard, friends and girlfriends.'' But in Florida, he was lonely. His father worked at sea for a salvage company. Dryfka began hanging out at a park where he could buy marijuana. He befriended Barfield, a chain-smoking man with a limp who lived off welfare and disability checks, and over the strong objections of his family, soon moved in with him. Barfield spent 16 years in prison for convictions including sodomizing a 13-year-old boy at gunpoint, said Donadio. From 1982 to 1989, Dryfka exchanged sex for housing and money, some of which was spent on cocaine and marijuana. Police say Dryfka tried for years to leave, but each time Barfield would find him and persuade him to return. On Sept. 18, Dryfka moved out for good. He told Barfield he was moving back to San Diego, but remained in Florida, dyed his hair blond, painted his pickup truck black and began dating a woman. Barfield took a bus to San Diego and discovered Dryfka was not there. He then began a string of threatening telephone calls to Dryfka's family, making at least 150 calls to Dryfka's mother from September to January, Donadio said. Barfield sometimes demanded money. ``He'd say stuff like, `You want to see your next birthday?''' said Donadio. ``Then he'd laugh. He has this Charlie Manson-type laugh. ... This guy is totally wacko.'' During the hunt, Barfield posed as a police officer, a banker and other officials, authorities said. Knowing Dryfka's social security number, credit cards and date of birth helped persuade others to give out information. The break came Feb. 3 when Barfield contacted Palm Beach County probation officials who were monitoring Dryfka after he violated probation on cocaine possession charges. They told him Dryfka turned in an ankle bracelet that's used for tracking violators ordered confined to their homes. Dryfka knew Barfield was getting close. On Feb. 15, the day he had gotten engaged, a car sped by and the driver shouted at him. ``He knew that was Barfield,'' said Donadio. ``His girlfriend _ who was very naive about the whole thing _ was traumatized, to say the least.'' The next day, Dryfka told his landlord he wanted his fiancee to have all his possessions if he was killed. Police say Barfield took a cab to an air-conditioning repair company where Dryfka worked, and let the air out of a tire on Dryfka's truck. Dryfka drove about a half-block before realizing the tire was flat. When he got out, he was shot in the back. Dryfka's father has since moved to West Virginia. His fiancee now lives somewhere in the Northeast, police said. ``So many lives messed up by this one guy,'' said Donadio. ``I'm sure this was the farthest thing from Jeffrey's mind that first day he met Barfield.'' The subtitle of Dryfka's journal: ``I have my own life, too.''

DOC.HEAD: Border Woes Have Plagued Poland Since 1772
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: Poland's borders are again an issue in European politics, as they have been during peace and war for more than 300 years. This time, Poland is wary that a united Germany will want to change frontiers established after the German defeat in World War II and reopen the ``Polish Question'' that has vexed European diplomacy for centuries. In 1688, Poland stretched from the Baltic Sea almost to the Black Sea and its territory encompassed much of what is now the Ukraine and Byelorussia. A century later, a united Poland and Lithuania came under pressure from Russia, Austria and Prussia and was systematically dismembered in three stages between 1772 and 1795, when Poland ceased to exist. The country was not established again until 1919. The traditional fragility of Poland's borders and the need to guarantee them was behind Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki's determined campaign to win a place at talks on German reunification. In the 20th century, Europe has been reshaped three times around Poland: after World War I, in the secret 1939 Ribbentrop-Molotov Pact and in 1945 at meetings of the victorious Allies in Yalta and Potsdam. Through it all, Poles have endured borders that were seldom of their own choosing and have become obsessed with the issue. ``People who live on islands, or on half continents of their own, find difficulty in comprehending the territorial obsessions of land-locked nations,'' historian Norman Davies wrote of Poland in ``God's Playground, A History of Poland.'' ``Never having faced the prospect of ceding Kent to Germany or California to the U.S.S.R., they tend to look with quizzical unconcern, if not contempt, on those who would lay down their lives for an inch of ground or for a dotted line on a map.'' After Russia, Prussia and Austria erased Poland in 1795, Poles kept alive dreams for their own state. Their chance came in 1919 after the World War I collapse of the three partioning powers. The separated parts of Poland united to establish their own government. President Woodrow Wilson of the United States had made an ``independent and autonomous Poland with free, unrestricted access to the sea'' one of his Fourteen Points in the postwar settlement. Through a combination of negotiations, plebiscites and military actions that lasted until 1922 and managed to alienate all its neighbors, Poland carved out a saddle-shaped territory with a narrow corridor to the Baltic dividing the main body of Germany from East Prussia. The oddly contoured country bordered Romania in the extreme southeast and included Vilnius, the heavily Polish-populated city in Lithuania. Though shrunken, Poland was roughly similar in outline to the Poland that existed in 1772. The re-establishment of an independent state caused bitterness in Germany and the Soviet Union. The main irritant was the so-called Polish corridor to the Baltic guaranteed by the victorious World War I powers at Versailles. It made the German city of Danzig (now Gdansk) at the mouth of the Vistula River into a ``free city'' under protection of the League of Nations, with Poland and Germany sharing some administrative responsibilities. The German government of the 1920s and Adolf Hitler's regime of the 1930s agitated to get Danzig and to recover its ``historic lands'' in the corridor. After incorporating Austria in 1938 and Czechoslovakia in early 1939, Danzig and the Polish corridor became Hitler's target. The green light to invade came on Aug. 23, 1939, when Foreign Minister Joachim von Ribbentrop of Germany and Foreign Minister Vychaleslav Molotov of the Soviet Union signed a secret pact splitting Poland between them. Nine days later, Hitler launched the invasion of Poland that began World War II. The Soviets occupied the country's eastern half on Sept. 17. The Polish state again vanished and the peaceful border between Germany and the Soviet Union lasted until June 22, 1941, when Hitler invaded the Soviet Union. At an Allied conferences at Yalta and Potsdam in 1945, Stalin insisted on keeping most of the territory he had gained in eastern Poland in 1939. In all, the Soviet Union claimed 46 percent of prewar Poland, or 71,288 square miles. To compensate Poland, the Allies approved the transfer to the Soviet-dominated Polish government of 40,480 square miles of formerly German territory. Although Poland was technically on the winning side of the war, it lost about one-fifth of its territory and came under control of a Soviet-assembled government and the Red Army. Communist domination lasted until 1989, when the Solidarity movement forced partially free elections that brought Mazowiecki to office. Because no formal peace treaty establishing the western frontier was ever signed, the status of the Polish-German border on the Oder and Neisse rivers described in the Aug. 2, 1945, Potsdam agreement has remained somewhat nebulous. The Potsdam agreement itself said the Oder-Neisse line was to exist only ``pending the final determination of Poland's western frontiers.'' Meanwhile, millions of ethnic Germans fled or were expelled, while Poles from the Soviet-annexed eastern territories flooded in. Formerly German cities like Stettin and Breslau were renamed Szczecin and Wroclaw. East Germany, under Stalinist control, recognized the Polish border in 1950. West Germany, in a treaty signed by then-Chancellor Willi Brandt, recognized it in 1970. But Kohl, apparently concerned about political supporters who do not want to renounce claims to the area, has hestitated to commit a reunited Germany to the Oder-Neisse line. He has said it is a matter for a freely elected government that unites East and West Germany.

DOC.HEAD: London Fashion: Short, Sporty by Day; Slinky by Night
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: The fall fashion message from London is short, sporty by day and slinky by night, with flashes of British wit and individuality. The mood among designers, however, is uncertain. Top designers Katherine Hamnett and John Galliano skipped London to show in Paris. Two other big names, Rifat Ozbek and Jaspar Conran, opted for videos instead of catwalk shows, and fewer buyers stopped off in London en route from Milan to Paris. Nonetheless, there was still some of that old wacky madness that put London on the fashion map. Vivienne Westwood, the mother of punk garb, captivated the audience with a collection ranging from classic tailored tartan suits to fake fur-trimmed bloomers worn with Old Master-print corsets. A Lycra-clad dancing troupe dressed as haute couture pigs opened the show based on barnyard characters of country life. Bodymap did a vision of drag-queen club life in their sexy sportswear collection. Britain's designers of the year, Workers For Freedom duo Richard Nott and Graham Fraser, showed a collection Nott described as ``spare feminity,'' which featured bikinis over striped body suits, one of the key fall looks from London. London Fashion Week, which ends Tuesday, has spread out even further with designers showing all over town and the trade show featuring about 250 exhibitors at the Olympia 2 exhibition hall. At Olympia, accessories from hats to bracelets seemed hotter than clothes. ``I think largely because of high interest rates and the high cost of living, women can't afford to buy another outfit, so they're buying accessories,'' said Beverley Mann, 28, one of the design duo of the costume jewelry firm Flash Harry. Melanie Lazlo of Obsession, another costume jewelry firm, said: ``London is kind of a melting pot for a wide range of accessories ranging from the weird and wonderful to the Channel-type classic.'' Many fashion designers said the number of buyers was down. ``It's much quieter than it was last year,'' said David Sassoon of Belville Sassoon-Lorcan Mullany, one of London's top eveningwear designers. ``I think stores everywhere are having a hard time,'' he said. ``Where money's tight, they want selling clothes. They don't want jokes. ... They don't want over the top things they might have indulged in previously.'' Benny Ong, another leading designer whose soft, sensual clothes sell internationally, agreed that the economic situation was keeping buyers away from London. ``That's why it's important at those times when the economic situation is not so hot to go for color _ to pick yourself up,'' he said. ``Power-dressing has also changed to something more feminine and confident.'' Edina Ronay, bucking the trend with her first catwalk show, said her business was up and insisted London was ``not going to fall flat on its face because two people show in Paris,'' Her collection of suits and parkas in orange, ochre and olive, fur-trimmed and brocade hooded jackets and skin-tight gold lame and black tops and body suits won high marks for wearability. There were plenty other wearable clothes as well. Bruce Oldfield, who designs many of Princess Diana's dresses, incorporated the sporty spirit in his hooded, printed parkas, luxurious velvet bodysuits, sequined sweatshirts and a gold-sequined bomber jacket with pants. Caroline Charles did a ``Eurochic'' collection featuring Romanian peasant embroideries and folksy tapestry and fringing alongside her snappy city suits and slinky evening dresses. Ozbek abandoned his summer white for dazzling colors _ another fall theme _ in hooded tops, tunics, cropped bomber jackets and leggings and body suits in dazzling sequins, stretch velvet and gold lame. Conran found his inspiration in ``the off-duty ballerina,'' with body-hugging catsuits topped by cropped leather jackets and quilted bronze bomber jackets. Helen Story, one of the up-and-coming young designers, had fun with a soccer-for-women look, again featuring hooded bomber jackets and soccer shorts with her signature fringing.

DOC.HEAD: Coup Attempt Weakens President Najib, But His Fall Seen Unlikely
AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Last week's attempt to topple President Najib has brought the Soviet-supported leader to his lowest point since he was installed in 1986. But despite his setback and a brush with death when bombs fell 12 feet from his office, Najib seems unlikely to fall. In thwarting the coup attempt by Defense Minister Shaw Nawaz Tanai, Najib once again demonstrated his ability to juggle allegiances within the party and come out on top. No other leader has yet emerged _ or been permitted to emerge _ with a following that rivals Najib's. He has also made an effort to expand his predominantly urban base to the countryside. Najib has made overtures to minorities, such as various ethnic groups and the Shia Moslems, who make up 18 percent of predominantly Sunni Moslem Afghanistan. There is likely to be even more disunity and bloodshed following the attempt to overthrow him. About 1.5 million Afghans already have died in the 12-year-old civil war, which saw nine years of direct Soviet intervention, three coups and numerous purges. Efforts to end the war between the government and U.S.-backed Moslem guerrillas are expected to take a back seat as Najib tries to consolidate his own position. Faced with questionable loyalty in the armed forces, Najib is expected to turn to tribal militia leaders for military support, foreign diplomats and Afghan officials say. In exchange, the tribal leaders will undoubtedly demand more autonomy from the central government. ``We expect the already high level of lawlessness in the countryside to rise,'' one foreign diplomat said, speaking on condition he not be identified further. Even if the military regains Najib's trust, its firepower and manpower have been weakened. Diplomats estimate that 10 fighter jets and numerous other military aircraft were lost during the mutineers' bombardment of Kabul and the government's retaliation. Bagram air base, a major center of the coup plot, was virtually destroyed, according to most assessments. In addition, hundreds of high-ranking officers and elite commandos are believed to have been killed on both sides. Sultan Ali Keshtmand, who as chairman of the council of ministers is the country's de facto prime minister, met the heads of foreign diplomatic missions in Kabul on Saturday and pleaded for aid. ``We have been severely weakened by the coup,'' a senior Asian diplomat quoted Keshtmand as saying. Keshtmand requested food, medicine and greater political support, the diplomat said. Najib's position also has been hurt within his own People's Democratic Party of Afghanistan, which is split between Najib's Parcham or ``Flag'' faction and the more hawkish Khalq or ``Masses'' faction. Tanai, who led the March 6 coup attempt, was a prominent Khalqi and Najib apparently was forced to make concessions to other Khalqis in exchange for their support during the coup attempt. The diplomats, all speaking on condition of anonymity, said this was illustrated by the president's subsequent Cabinet reshuffle. Najib purged Tanai and at least four other top Khalqis from the party after the attempted coup, but he promoted two others _ Lt. Gen. Mohammad Aslam Watanjar and Raz Mohammad Pakteen. Both Watanjar and Pakteen could ultimately prove troublesome because they are thought to have little loyalty to Najib. Watanjar, the former interior minister, succeeded Tanai as defense minister. Watanjar persuaded most of the army's 15th armored division, which he once commanded, to abandon its initial support for Tanai, Eastern European diplomats and two Afghan government sources said. Pakteen was given Watanjar's old job in the Interior Ministry, which is responsible for the country's intelligence agencies. He appears to be largely a figurehead, the diplomats said. Najib, former head of the dreaded KHAD secret police, actually controls the ministry, they added. The failed coup also exacerbated the already bitter splits among the mujahedeen, or Islamic holy warriors, who have been trying to oust Najib and his predecessors since shortly after the party grabbed power in a 1978 coup. Extreme fundamentalist Gulbuddin Hekmatyar embraced the coup, and his people now are trying to strike deals with Tanai, according diplomatic sources in Kabul and in neighboring Pakistan where the mujahedeen are based. But other mujahedeen groups, including some of the staunchest fundamentalists, have distanced themselves from the coup, saying they find no difference between Najib and Tanai. An Eastern European diplomat in Kabul said there was a possibility Tanai might be persuaded to take command of the stalemated mujahedeen offensive against Khost, his home turf. If Tanai, a gifted military tactician, succeeds in taking Khost, it would give the anti-Najib forces an important staging area for attacks deeper into Afghanistan and closer to Kabul. ``We could see Afghanistan carved up more than it already is,'' the Eastern European diplomat said. Still, none of the diplomats and military experts interviewed in Kabul said he thought the rebels were capable of toppling Najib. ``The stalemate will continue,'' one of the military experts said. ``It will just get bloodier.''
EDITOR'S NOTE: John Pomfret is a Hong Kong-based correspondent who has covered Asia since 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Railroad Crew Shoos Moose Away From Deadly Trains
DOC.TEXT: Leaning out the window of a pickup doing 35 mph, its siren whooping, Jack Burton aimed his shotgun and fired a blank that exploded near a galloping moose framed in the headlights 20 yards ahead. ``She's moved over,'' Burton yelled. ``Let's get ahead of her.'' Highballing through the moonlit Susitna Valley in a one-ton pickup equipped to ride the rails, Burton and Ken Hightower were on night moose patrol for the Alaska Railroad. They were shooing moose from the rails on the Anchorage-to-Fairbanks run, where 603 of the lumbering animals have been killed so far this winter _ more than twice the winter average. The reason: the deepest snow in 25 years. The moose are hungry and worn out from staggering for food through snow deeper than their legs are long. When one of the animals stumbles across the plowed railroad tracks where the walking is easy, it tends to remain until the moose patrol scares it off or a train runs it down. ``They can handle any other situation, probably, but they don't do too well against the iron horse,'' said Bill Collins, a state wildlife biologist. Many of the moose are killed after dark, when they come out to feed. The railroad has been trying for five years to find a way to stop killing moose. This year the effort has cost $337,000 in expenses and train delays, spokeswoman Vivian Hamilton said. The number of moose killed by the railroad may not seem like much out of a local population of 15,000, but every animal counts, Collins said. He expects 90 percent of the calves born last fall to die before the heavy snows melt. State wildlife officials and volunteers have begun putting out hay for the moose, even though the animals have trouble digesting it. ``By feeding them they are trying to keep them from wandering back and forth across the highway and the railroad,'' Collins said. ``Once you start feeding them, they tend to stay put.'' Leaving a shed, Burton and Hightower headed toward Eklutna, then left the highway and drove over squeaky snow through the Tanaina Indian village of 50 people with its Russian Orthodox church of logs and hand-hewn onion domes. At milepost 142 they jockeyed the pickup onto the rails and jacked in the steel dollies that let it run like a train. Burton loaded a shotgun with ``kracker'' shells _ blanks that explode with a small flame but have no shot. On the citizens band radio, an engineer reported his freight train had gone by milepost 139. ``Roger that, we're at 142 and rolling at 35,'' Burton answered, matching the speed of the train. Several miles later, the eyes of a moose reflected the spotlight long before its huge brown bulk materialized out of the darkness. When the moose saw the pickup, it ran, loping along the middle of the tracks rather than going into the deep snow to let it pass. ``Normally they will fight or flee,'' Collins said. ``If they fight they are in trouble. If they flee they are still in trouble.'' That's where Burton's version of the squeeze play comes in. With Hightower at the wheel and Burton riding shotgun, the pickup followed the moose. Finally the animal strayed and Hightower gunned the engine, slowly passing it. Ahead was a railroad bridge, where Hightower parked the truck to block the moose from trying to cross. If it got on the bridge, the moose would fall between the ties, breaking its legs or pitching head first into the creek to drown. ``We're stopped at the bridge,'' Burton radioed to the freight. Minutes later the freight approached and slowed to a stop, the engine headlight and numbers shining. Caught in a squeeze between the train and the truck, the moose tossed its head and reluctantly walked down a trail cut through the 8-foot-high snow berm by volunteers from a snow-machine club. ``Good moose,'' Hightower said.

DOC.HEAD: US `Ought Not to Gloat' Over Foreign Policy Successes
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Lithuania's declaration of independence from the Soviet Union poses the most serious threat in 70 years to the unity of the communist state but leaves the United States able to offer little but the most muted applause. The fear: Too much encouragement to tiny Lithuania could provoke a Soviet crackdown, do serious damage to President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's program of economic and political reform and even weaken his tenacious grasp on power. And since there is little the United States could do to affect the outcome in Lithuania and in other independence-minded Soviet republics, there might be real danger in trying. Secretary of State James A. Baker III set the tone for U.S. policy in Capitol Hill testimony last week, saying that the United States ``ought not to gloat too much over our success.'' ``It is not overly productive to stick a stick in their eye just for the hell of it,'' Baker said. ``The fear is that the unraveling of the Soviet Union is not necessarily a success for us,'' said Ilya Prizel, professor of Soviet studies at the Paul H. Nitze School of Advanced International Studies at Johns Hopkins University. ``If it ends up in a civil war, how do you deal with a civil war in a superpower that sits on thousands and thousands of nuclear weapons?'' Prizel asked. The administration's careful litany on Lithuania, as delivered by the White House and State Department on Monday, goes like this: _The United States recognized the independence of Lithuania and two other Baltic states in 1922 after the victors in World War I carved them out of the fallen Russian empire. _That diplomatic recognition has never been withdrawn. _The United States never accepted the secret non-aggression 1940 deal between Germany's Adolf Hitler and Soviet leader Joseph Stalin folding Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia into the Soviet empire. _It still regards their transformation into Soviet republics as illegal. _But in the last analysis, Washington is prepared to recognize Lithuania diplomatically and exchange ambassadors with it only if negotiations with Moscow give it the attributes of a nation-state. ``We would want any recognition to take into account a final government that was in control of its own destiny, and much of that has yet to be negotiated with the Soviet Union,'' said White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater. Diplomatic recognition would follow ``once that government is in effective control of its territory and capable of entering into and fulfilling international obligations,'' said State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler. ``I think it's a prudent and correct policy,'' Prizel said. ``We cannot jump in ahead of the Soviet Union. We should understand that we can provoke the Soviets, but we cannot deter them.'' ``Do you want to encourage the Lithuanians to a point where the Russians crack down; then what do you do?'' he asked. ``You might bring a terrible fate down upon them.'' Prizel's conclusion: ``I think the best thing to do is to lie as low as we can and let the situation evolve in a way that Moscow does not find provocative.'' ``It's one thing for a Soviet leader to get rid of the outer empire in Eastern Europe,'' he said. ``But it's quite a different thing to preside over the disintegration of the Soviet Union.'' But others believe that granting independence to Lithuania and the other Baltic states is unlikely to lead to such a drastic result. Stasys Lozoraitis Jr., acting chief of the Lithuanian legation here, which has been maintained with U.S. cooperation for the last half-century, says he believes Moscow will erect barriers to full independence but will ultimately agree. Rozanne L. Ridgway, former assistant secretary of state for European affairs, said on public television's ``MacNeil-Lehrer NewsHour'' that she believes the Soviets will eventually see the wisdom of granting Lithuania independence. If Gorbachev does not ``paint himself into a corner by using the wrong words,'' she said, ``I think in the end you will see an independent Lithuania.''
EDITOR'S NOTE: Lawrence L. Knutson has covered foreign affairs on Capitol Hill for The Associated Press.

DOC.HEAD: Teen-ager Accidentally Killed by Buddy
DOC.TEXT: A teen-ager who borrowed two of his father's guns because a older boy was picking on him was shot in the face and killed by a friend while fooling around with the weapons, police said. ``This is a very careless, negligent, tragic act, especially with young kids,'' said police Capt. Thomas Burke. ``Guns should be stored in a locked place, with ammunition kept in a separate locked place.'' Chad MacDonald died Sunday, a day after the shooting at his home. He would have turned 16 on Monday. His 14-year-old friend, who was not identified, was arraigned Monday on juvenile charges of murder and weapons possession. He was released to his parents' custody. MacDonald's parents said their son had taken his father's 9mm semiautomatic pistol and a .357-caliber Magnum revolver to his room without permission because he had been frightened by an older boy. Debra MacDonald said she and her husband had filed several complaints with police because her son had been repeatedly harassed by the older youth. Burke said the 14-year-old, who was sleeping over in preparation for Chad's birthday party, told authorities he took the semiautomatic from a dresser and fired at MacDonald after he had pointed the revolver at him and said ``bang.'' As an 8-year-old, Chad received a National Heroism Award from the Boy Scouts for summoning help for his mother when she suffered collapsed lungs. Glenn MacDonald said the family harbored no ill feelings toward the boy accused of killing his son. ``He is destroyed,'' the father said. ``He has to live with this the rest of his life.'' Chad was described by his high school principal as ``your everyday high school student.'' Counselors and nurses helped distraught students at West Springfield High School cope with the shooting. ``We are trying to help the students and the family get through this crisis with as little scarring as possible,'' said Principal George F. Bauman.

DOC.HEAD: 360,000 Truckers Could Lose Driving Privileges, Report Says
DOC.TEXT: Up to 360,000 truckers could lose their driving privileges if states don't step up their plans to comply with a new federal commercial driver's license law, congressional investigators say. The General Accounting Office said Monday that 33 states may not comply with a federal law that requires truck drivers to take tests and obtain federally approved commercial driver's licenses by April 1, 1992. The law aims to get unsafe drivers off the road by requiring them all to meet national standards. However, the Federal Highway Administration official overseeing the program said the states are doing ``a terrific job'' and that all plan to meet the deadline. A quirk in the law gives states until October 1993 to establish testing and licensing programs, but the shorter deadline for drivers to have the licenses makes it necessary to set up programs 18 months earlier. The commercial driver's license law was prompted by the 4,500 annual highway fatalities involving large trucks. Trucks account for 4.5 percent of the traffic and 10 percent of the fatalities nationwide. Before Congress passed the law, several states required only ordinary driver's licenses for truckers and others had inconsistent requirements, leading some drivers to go shopping for lenient states. The GAO study, which assesses conditions as of October 1989 when states were surveyed, said 13 states indicated they cannot meet the April 1992 deadline. An additional 20 states plan to test and license between one-fourth and one-half of their drivers in the final three months before the deadline, which the study said probably is impossible. Jill Hochman, chief of the highway agency's standards review division, said seven states already are issuing the new commercial driver's licenses . They are Arizona, California, Maryland, New Hampshire, Utah, Virginia and Washington. Michigan started but temporarily suspended its program because of a computer problem, she said. Twenty-seven other states plan to issue licenses before the end of the year, Ms. Hochman said, and 10 states have not yet passed commercial driver's license laws. Ms. Hochman said a limitation in the GAO report is that conditions in a state can look different depending on which official answers the survey. ``The states have been making terrific progress,'' she said. ``Nobody said it's going to be easy, but they all plan to meet the deadline and I'm certainly not going to challenge their plans.'' Most states plan to test and license all of their drivers over a two-year period rather than the four years permitted in the legislation that implemented the law, the GAO study said. GAO also said most states are having problems in making changes in their driver's license computer systems so they can hook into a national databank of information on all drivers. Ms. Hochman said the Federal Highway Administration has been working with states to help them set up the computer system. GAO researcher Ron Wood said the 13 states that indicated they could not meet the April 1992 deadline for all truckers to be licensed are Arizona, Hawaii, Michigan, Minnesota, Mississippi, Nevada, New Jersey, Oklahoma, Wyoming, Rhode Island, Kentucky, Wisconsin and Massachusetts. Wood said the 20 states that plan to issue an unusually large share of licenses in the final three months before the deadline are: California, Oregon, Illinois, Florida, Iowa, Alabama, Alaska, Indiana, Kansas, Missouri, Montana, Nebraska, New Hampshire, New Mexico, Ohio, Pennsylvania, South Carolina, Tennessee, Utah and Vermont. The 10 states that have not yet passed commercial driver's license laws, according to the highway administration, are Alaska, Iowa, Kentucky, Massachusetts, New Jersey, Oklahoma, Pennsylvania, Rhode Island, Vermont and New York. The District of Columbia also has yet to pass such a law.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Administration Wants to Help `Bring Democracy to Haiti'
With PM-Haiti Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration says it stands ready to help a provisional government ``bring democracy to Haiti'' after hastening the departure of a deposed ruler for the second time in four years. Lt. Gen. Prosper Avril flew out of Homestead Air Force Base near Miami for an undisclosed refuge on Monday, barely seven hours after a U.S. Air Force C-141 transport plane evacuated Avril and his family from Port-au-Prince. With Maj. Gen. Herard Abraham, the army chief of staff, expected to turn authority over today to a civilian provisional president, the administration urged ``all Haitians (to) work together in a spirit of reconciliation'' to achieve free elections and respect for human rights ``as rapidly as possible.'' ``The United States shares these goals and is prepared to help the provisional government bring democracy to Haiti,'' State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said. A week of bloodshed that left at least 24 dead in the streets of Haiti brought an end to Avril's 18-month rule in the Western Hemisphere's poorest nation. Administration officials said Avril's downfall came after he staged a crackdown in January that led to the arrest of some opposition leaders and forced others into exile. ``This was just a tremendous error on Avril's part. All of Haitian society ... (became) galvanized against him,'' said an administration source who asked not to be identified. ``He just became more and more isolated.'' The White House said Avril requested U.S. help in leaving Haiti during a weekend meeting with U.S. Ambassador Alvin P. Adams. ``We had discussions with him about the transition. ... (There) was a feeling of some obligation to help him leave and facilitate a peaceful transition,'' said White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater. He said Avril was granted only ``a temporary sanctuary here.'' An Air Force spokesman said Avril left Homestead by ``personally arranged transportation'' but provided no other details. In February 1986, the United States dispatched another Air Force jet to carry Jean-Claude ``Baby Doc'' Duvalier into exile in France, ending 29 years of dictatorship under the Duvaliers, father and son. Avril, 52, chief of the Presidential Guard and a former Duvalier adviser, declared himself president in September 1988. He foiled a reported coup attempt last April and declared the state of siege Jan. 20 after the mysterious slaying of an army colonel. ``We are hopeful for a smooth transition to democracy in Haiti and are encouraging that effort,'' Fitzwater said. Haitians are scheduled to vote in local elections in April and in presidential elections in October and November. The United States is providing $41.4 million in humanitarian and development assistance to Haiti through private voluntary and non-governmental agencies. It cut off $78 million in direct aid after the massacre of 34 voters in aborted elections Nov. 29, 1987. The United States did provide $10 million in emergency food assistance to the Port-au-Prince government last year. Fitzwater said the United States would have to see ``tangible evidence of progress and a transition to democracy and to respect for human rights'' before direct aid is resumed.

DOC.HEAD: Rural Community Development Bill Up for House Vote
DOC.TEXT: Decaying rural communities could look to a new government office within the Agriculture Department for development help if a bill up for a House vote this week becomes law. The measure would create a rural development administration for programs currently carried out by the Farmers Home Administration, such as water and sewer, business and industry, and loan and grant programs for community facilities. Money now placed in three funds for each of those categories could be pooled for one purpose, based on community needs. For example, if the big need were improved water and sewer facilities, all the money could go for that. If the community had adequate public works, the funds could be used to lure business and industry. Rep. Glenn English, D-Okla., who coauthored the bill with Rep. Tom Coleman, R-Mo., said the idea is to give communities more power and flexibility with existing federal money. The bill is scheduled for a floor vote Wednesday. The Senate passed a significantly different rural development bill last summer. Lawmakers believe some kind of development bill is needed to save communities that are losing jobs and population because of the decreasing number of farms around the country. Under the House bill, rural communities would have to prepare local or regional economic plans that would be submitted to a state review panel in order to get development money. The bill doesn't say exactly who should prepare the plans, but it calls for participation by local government, business, industrial, financial, transportation, utility, labor, agriculture and educational institutions. The state review panel would then rank the applications for projects, with special priority required for declared health emergencies. Each state would get a grant of up to $100,000 to pay the costs of the review panel. The bill also establishes a technical assistance unit within the Rural Electrification Administration that would allow borrowers to defer payment on certain loans for up to 10 years if the loan is invested in rural development projects. Other key provisions include: _``Action teams'' to help communities dependent on forestry to diversify. _A rural development information-gathering and dissemination center to help communities exchange ideas for successful projects. _$50 million in each of the fiscal years 1991 through 1993 for competitive grants to non-profit institutions that establish centers for rural technology or development. _More help from the Agricultural Extension Service for business development. _Grants from the Cooperative State Research Service for research on non-food uses of agricultural commodities. The Bush administration objects to several provisions in the bill, including the forest community ``action teams,'' the deferring of REA loans and the establishment of state review panels, which it says encroaches on the president's authority to decide how federal development money should be spent.

Animal rights activists who attack farms and research labs to set animals free would be breaking federal law if a bill being considered by the House Agriculture Committee is enacted. ``We're talking about terrorism against farmers,'' Rep. Charles Stenholm, D-Texas, said during a recent hearing. Stenholm introduced a bill called the Farm Animal and Research Facilities Protection Act last fall that has wide support in the House. It sets penalties of up to three years in jail and $10,000 in fines for anyone who damages or disrupts an enterprise involving animals. The Bush administration's Office of Science and Technology Policy says a federal law is needed because the research involving use of animals ``is of immense value to the welfare of the citizens of this country and the federal government must ensure that the environment in which research is conducted, and the persons pursuing such research, are free from threats of violence, intimidation and debilitating distractions.'' Paul Maloney of the Justice Department, however, said state laws are sufficient for prosecuting the crimes committed by activists who break into labs or farms to set animals free. In testimony before a House Agriculture subcommittee, local law enforcement officers said a federal law is needed to make sure the FBI uses its resources and authority to go after the groups that operate nationally.

DOC.HEAD: Witness in Racial Attack Refuses to Cooperate, Charged With Murder
DOC.TEXT: A witness in the white-on-black slaying of a teen-ager in the city's Bensonhurst section backed out of a deal with prosecutors and decided to face murder charges rather than testify against his friends. Brooklyn District Attorney Charles J. Hynes said John Vento, 21, who was being held in protective custody, changed his mind about cooperating and was arrested Monday. He was ordered held for arraignment on a charge of murder. Seven other young white men from Bensonhurst have been charged in the slaying Aug. 23 of Yusuf Hawkins, a black 16-year-old who was shot after he went with three friends into the mostly white neighborhood to look at a used car. Hynes said he still has a ``trial ready'' case without Vento. However, a prosecutor speaking on condition of anonymity characterized Vento's defection as ``a major blow.'' ``He was in the middle of the group, and he was going to testify,'' the prosecutor said. Vento, who admitted taking part in the attack, at first agreed to testify against his friends in exchange for a pledge he would not be charged. He disappeared in December but surrendered to the FBI in Dayton, Ohio, last week after his absence forced a month's delay in the start of the first trial. The defendants are being tried in groups. After meeting with the district attorney, Vento's lawyer, Gerald DiChiara, said Monday that Vento ``has reasons I could not argue against'' and ``is very concerned for everything _ his family, himself.'' The first trial is set for April 2.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Down In Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 32,620.57, down 747.66 points, or 2.24 percent on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Tuesday.

DOC.NOTE: For release at 10:30 a.m. EST; time set by source
DOC.HEAD: Panel Says Defense Budget Doesn't Reflect Diminished Threat
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's defense budget is an ``excessively cautious and inordinately expensive response'' to the rapidly diminishing Soviet threat, a bipartisan group of U.S. military experts said today. The administration's fiscal 1991 budget calls for full-scale strategic modernization with procurement of the B-2 stealth bomber, two land-based nuclear missile systems and the Strategic Defense Initiative. But the disintegration of the Warsaw Pact requires a restructuring of the U.S. military, starting with a reasonable goal of a 50 percent reduction in defense spending by the year 2000, the group said in a 27-page report. ``Changes in the world must be reflected in the defense budget, and U.S. national security can be supported with a steady, sustained decrease in defense budgets over the next 10 years,'' the report said. The panel, headed by Lawrence J. Korb, a former assistant secretary of defense in the Reagan administration, recommended halting production of the B-2 bomber at 15 planes, canceling plans to move the multiple-warhead MX from fixed silos to railroad cars and limiting spending on SDI to no more than $3 billion a year. In its report, ``Restructuring the U.S. Military: Defense Needs in the 21st Century,'' the panel also proposed that the United States seek a ban on multiple-warhead, intercontinental ballistic missiles, stop the purchase of Trident submarines at 17 and cancel production of the C-17 cargo plane. The panel suggested cutting active forces Army divisions from 18 to 10, reducing the Navy's carrier battle groups from 14 to nine and halving the Air Force's active tactical air wings from 24 to 12. It said the number of troops U.S. stationed in Europe should be cut from the current 305,000 to about 100,000. Bush's $292 billion defense budget for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1 calls for a nearly $1 billion increase in spending on SDI, $5.5 billion for the B-2 bomber and more than $3 billion on the MX and single-warhead Midgetman missiles. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney has said no major cuts in spending or changes in defense strategy should be considered until new U.S.-Soviet arms control treaties are completed. ``A good deal of prudence is in order,'' Cheney told Congress last month. But the panel said the administration's ``proposals for only slight reductions in defense programs and budgets over the next five years reflect an excessively cautious and inordinately excessive response to the changing security environment.'' It proposed reductions in defense spending averaging 6.7 percent annually for a 50 percent cut in the next decade. The current budget is a 2 percent reduction from last year after adjusting for inflation. The Defense Budget Task Force of the Committee for National Security and the Defense Budget Project produced the report. The committee and the project are independent, non-profit organizations. Members of the panel included former CIA Director William Colby, retired Rear Adm. Stanley S. Fine, former Navy budget director; and Paul Warnke, a former director of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Minimize Importance of KGB Defector
DOC.TEXT: A KGB defector who recently surfaced after a decade in hiding was a technician with ``no access to serious secret information,'' a Soviet official says. Nevertheless, Sergey B. Chetverikov, minister-counselor at the Soviet embassy, said Monday that he had lodged a ``strong protest'' about the case of Victor I. Sheymov at a meeting with Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence Eagleburger. Chetverikov said the involvement of U.S. intelligence in smuggling Sheymov, his wife, and his 5-year-old daughter out of the Soviet Union in 1980 was a ``gross violation of rules of international law, which is, in fact, an act of state terrorism.'' The State Department had no immediate comment on the case. At a news conference, Chetverikov confirmed that Sheymov, 43, ``did indeed work at some point within the system of the Committee for State Security,'' the full name of the KGB. He said Sheymov graduated from Bauman Technical School in Moscow as a mechanical engineer and was employed by the KGB as a ``coding equipment maintenance technician.'' ``His responsibilities, however, allowed him no access to serious secret information, including documents,'' the official added. Chetverikov also complained about some of the allegations that Sheymov made at a news conference March 2. Sheymov said he was present in the Warsaw station of the KGB in 1979 when a cable arrived from Moscow ordering what he believed to be the initial stages of a plot to assassinate Pope John Paul II. ``Totally untenable and malicious from beginning to end is his assertion about the Committee for State Security's involvement in the affair relating to the attempt on Pope John Paul II's life,'' Chetverikov said. He said CIA officials knew ``very well that the KGB had not and could not have anything to do with this heinous crime.'' Allegations have long circulated about possible Soviet involvement in a plot to kill the pope after he was wounded by a Turkish gunman in 1981. No connection with Moscow has ever been firmly established, however. Chetverikov also said ``hints about the KGB's involvement in organizing the attempt on the late President Zia ul Haq of Pakistan can also be described as wild fiction.'' Zia was killed when his plane blew up in 1988. Sheymov also said in the late 1970s the Soviet Union had two sources inside the State Department able to deliver secret information on U.S. policy and negotiating positions. The department has refused to comment on that assertion. Chetverikov accused U.S. intelligence of promoting Sheymov to undermine improved relations between the Soviet Union and the United States. Those who brought Sheymov to the United States ``were directly involved in the attempts to call attention to the Sheymov story through mass media, in an apparent pursuit of the objectives which run counter to the dynamic process of normalization of US-Soviet relations emerging during the years of perestroika (restructuring),'' he said. Sheymov said at his news conference that he was looking for a publisher for a book he has written. Despite the protest, Chetverikov said he doubted Moscow would retaliate in any way against the United States. ``I guess we are beyond that stage,'' he said. The Soviet official also said he did not know where Sheymov lived or what charges he would face in the Soviet Union if he ever returned. Sheymov has become a U.S. citizen since his defection a decade ago.

DOC.HEAD: FAA Order Would Modify DC-10 Hydraulics
DOC.TEXT: The government wants airlines flying the DC-10 to make some changes in the plane's hydraulic system to avoid the kind of crash that killed 112 people in Iowa last year. The Federal Aviation Administration on Monday tentatively issued an ``airworthiness directive'' requiring modifications that the agency said would enable pilots to steer the plane even if hydraulic lines are severed in the plane's tail section. The order, which becomes final after a period for several weeks for public comment, resulted from the July 19, 1989, crash of a United Airlines DC-10 at the Sioux City, Iowa, airport where it was making an emergency landing with 295 people aboard. Investigation into the crash continues, but pilots said they lost hydraulic steering control after the plane's tail engine exploded. The FAA order follows changes recommended in the airliner by its manufacturer, McDonnell Douglas Corp. ``The change would preserve enough hydraulic fluid following damage to the system to enable the flight crew to safely fly and land the airplane,'' the FAA said. Airlines would have six months to make the modifications in the 10-series of DC-10s and a year for all other DC-10 models. Investigators into the Iowa crash have said they believe flying debris from the explosive tail engine failure severed all three of the jetliner's independent hydraulic systems that control flight. The FAA-ordered modification would require devices in the hydraulic system to keep fluid from leaking out in the event the lines in the tail section, where the hydraulic systems come the closest together, are cut. With the change, the pilot would still lose control over the rudder, which turns the airliner, and the elevators, which control climb and descent. But other control surfaces, including the ailerons, which make it possible to keep the wings level, would remain operable, the FAA said. Crew members of the United plane said their only means of steering the aircraft and controlling descent was to selectively accelerate the remaining wing engines. The FAA earlier ordered an ultrasonic inspection of all DC-10 engine fan disks for a possible microscopic defect in the metal that investigators said may have caused the engine failure.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Fall Sharply
DOC.TEXT: The key index on the Tokyo Stock Exchange fell again Tuesday afternoon and registered the eighth-largest single-day loss in its history, while the dollar was higher against the Japanese yen. The 225-share Nikkei Stock Average lost 747.66 points, or 2.24 percent, ending the day at 32,620.57. Added to Monday's 624.89-point loss, the Nikkei has lost 1,372.55 points in two days. The dollar was changing hands at 152.13 yen as of 3:00 p.m. (1 a.m. EST). It opened higher at 152.82 yen, up 0.82 yen from Monday's close at 152.00 yen, and ranged between 151.95 yen and 152.88 yen during the afternoon session. The price of the benchmark No. 119 Japanese government bond plunged to 86.15 points, down 0.34 points from Monday's close at 86.49. Its yield rose from the previous day's 7.24 percent to 7.31 percent by 3:00 p.m. Analysts blamed plunge in stock prices on the decline in the Japanese yen and speculation that the Bank of Japan would raise key interest rates. Market players have long expected the central bank to hike its official discount rate, which now stands at 4.25 percent after three increases last year. They say a hike of as much as 1 percent is likely to take place as soon as Bank of Japan Governor Yasushi Mieno returns from a trip to Europe Thursday. The Nikkei had fallen more than 540 points at midmorning in part prompted by computer-aided selling by arbitrageurs, said Kazuhiro Nomura, a dealer with New Japan Securities. Arbitrage is a tactic used to profit from the spread between the spot and future markets. Large-scale, computer-aided arbitrage selling has been blamed for the market's recent volatility. Last month the Tokyo Stock Exchange asked major securities firms to refrain from arbitrage when the index is falling, but dealers said many investors seemed to ignore the request.

DOC.HEAD: Copper Miners Begin Strike for Higher Wages
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of miners employed by the country's largest copper company walked off the job demanding higher wages and ignoring a no-strike agreement reached in September, company and union officials said. A spokesman for the U.S.-owned Southern Peru Copper Corp. said 3,000 workers at the Cuajone mine in the southern Andes and the Ilo refinery on the southern Pacific coast began striking Monday. The 2,500 workers at the company's Toquepala mine's continued to work, said the spokesman, who commented on condition of anomymity. Reynaldo Fernandez, secretary general of the union at Ilo said the Toquepala workers were considering whether to join the strike. Southern workers agreed in September not to strike for one year in exchange for monthly bonuses, which at that time amounted to about $200 a month. However Peru's hyperinflation, which last year reached nearly 3,000 percent, has cut the value of the monthly bonus to about $39 a month. The miners are now demanding the agreement be scrapped and for monthly wages to be increased to $400, Fernandez said. Last year, Southern produced about 200,000 tons of copper, two-thirds of the country's total output.

DOC.HEAD: Marketing Analyst Pleads Guilty in Pentagon Documents Case
DOC.TEXT: A Grumman Corp. official is the latest in a series of individuals and defense contractors to plead guilty to unlawfully obtaining and distributing classified Pentagon documents. Harry Kotellos, who pleaded guilty Monday to a felony conspiracy count, faces a maximum penalty of $250,000 in fines and five years in prison when he is sentenced May 18 for his actions from 1980 through 1985 as a senior marketing analyst for Grumman. The plea agreement submitted to U.S. District Judge Claude Hilton is contingent on Kotellos' full cooperation in the probe into the illegal trafficking in classified Defense Department documents. ``Mr. Kotellos was a significant player in the tightly knit group which acquired and distributed some very sensitive DOD information,'' said Michael J. Costello, special agent in charge of the Defense Criminal Investigative Service's Washington field office. ``... We have attempted to reach the inner core of the network and neutralize it.'' The documents involved were those that summarize the resources the Pentagon is planning to spend in future years, said Richard Smith, Costello's assistant. The case also involved Air Force budget documents, according to court papers. Kotellos, 53, is a West Point graduate and retired Air Force lieutenant colonel who has worked for Grumman since 1980, said his attorney, Plato Cacheris. Investigators would not say whether Grumman itself was under investigation, but company spokesman Larry Hamilton said: ``Grumman is engaged in discussions with the government as to the consequences to the company of Mr. Kotellos' plea. Since this matter continues to be under review, the company cannot comment on these discussions.'' The criminal investigative service has been conducting an investigation _ code-named Operation Uncover_ since the mid-1980s into illegal transfers of Pentagon documents to defense contractors. Four major defense contractors and several individuals have pleaded guilty to been convicted of charges resulting from Operation Uncover: _Hughes Aircraft Co. pleaded guilty last Friday and agreed to pay a total of $3.67 million in fines and restitution. _GTE Government Systems Division pleaded guilty in 1985 and paid about $300,000. _The Boeing Co. pleaded guilty last November and paid fines and restitution of $5.2 million, and Boeing employee Richard Lee Fowler was convicted last December of all counts of a 39-count indictment. _RCA Corp. pleaded guilty and was ordered Feb. 5 to pay fines and restitution of $2.75 million. Former RCA employee Leonard Kampf and current RCA employee Ronald Stevens each pleaded guilty to one felony count and face sentencing April 6. The conspiracy count against Kotellos said he acquired classified documents from a government employee who was not authorized to release them; getting classified documents from Fowler of Boeing; sharing classified documents with other defense contractors and obtaining such documents from them; and destroying some of the documents in his fireplace at home. Court papers did not identify the government employee. Smith declined to reveal the name or to say whether that person was under investigation. A source close to the investigation said he believed prosecutors ``may have a problem with the statute of limitations'' in the case against the government employee because of a lack of information of wrongdoing after 1984. But Smith said: ``In a continuing conspiracy, the last overt act that an individual or corporation does in furtherance of that conspiracy can continue the life of the statute of limitations.'' The 1985 actions enabled prosecutors to go after Kotellos, Smith said. Kotellos was placed on administrative leave with pay from his job Monday morning, Grumman's Hamilton said.

DOC.HEAD: City Hopes to Recapture Tourist-Mecca Image
DOC.TEXT: This is the city that says it knows how, the one where tourists love to leave their hearts. But while most of the physical damage from the Oct. 17 earthquake has been repaired, community leaders are not sure how to fix the damage done to San Francisco's reputation for warm if eccentric hospitality. From cable cars to Chinatown, Fisherman's Wharf hotels to theaters and museums, commercial and cultural business has been reported way down since the quake.
