That may be changing, thanks to time and fading memories, promotions, ad campaigns and a realization by the business community that it must also deal with skyrocketing air fares, recession fears and increasing competition. ``The earthquake is a very good excuse for everything,'' said John Marks, president of the San Francisco Convention and Visitors' Bureau. ``But there are many other factors that are causing the momentary bump'' in tourism. Many tourist-oriented cities across the country are experiencing similar sluggishness, he said. The Visitors' Bureau is spending more on national advertising this year than ever before. Its budget is $1 million, up $400,000, Marks said. ``We believe that time is our greatest ally, and the more time that expires after Oct. 17, the less likely the impact of the quake is going to affect the decision of the traveler,'' said Marks. Helping to influence those decisions are discount room rates. The Mark Hopkins, for example, is offering $205 rooms for $99. At The Ramada at Fisherman's Wharf, rooms are $59 rather than the standard $120. While San Francisco hotel occupancy rates stood at about 70 percent last year, the break-even point for the average hotel, they dropped by as much as 10 percent in the first two months of 1990. ``I can't decide which is the greatest problem _ concern about the economy or about another earthquake,'' said Oscar Vahidi, general manager of the Ramada. Adding to the problem of earthquake-queasy tourists, the city saw a 7 percent growth in hotel rooms last year, and 1,400 more rooms are scheduled to come on the market around the end of the year. Near the wharf, Kathy Paver, spokeswoman for the Pier 39 complex of boutiques and restaurants, said business is comparable to that of the same time last year. Hundreds of hungry and lovesick sea lions frolicking in the bay, feasting on tourists' handouts, have generated even bigger crowds, she said. But at The Cannery nearby, spokesman Chris Martin said business is off as much as 20 percent at some shops and restaurants. ``I don't think they're going to be back to normal until the double-deck freeways that are out of commission are back on track,'' he said. The California Transportation Department said the quake-damaged Embarcadero Freeway _ which took an average of 80,000 cars daily from the San Francisco-Oakland Bay Bridge to the Financial District, Chinatown and the wharf _ could be back in operation by September. ``Part of the problem is people just don't know how to get around the city,'' Martin said. Even the romantic cable car is in a slump. Municipal Railway spokesman George Newkirk said average daily ridership before October was 11,000 to 13,000. Today, 8,000 to 10,000 take the $2 rides on the rolling landmarks, he said. Businesses are preparing a celebration April 10-22 featuring dedication of a restored cable car, a parade, an Easter egg hunt at Fisherman's Wharf, a merchants' fair and an Earth Day extravaganza. A campaign by the California Arts Council is raising money for art organizations hurt by the quake, which killed 67 people, injured thousands and caused about $10 billion in damage. At San Francisco's American Conservatory Theater, the nation's largest regional theater company with about 200 employees, spokeswoman Carla Befera said attendance has been down 40 percent since the company's Geary Street theater was closed for quake repairs. Plays have been performed at other theaters. ``When you're moved out to the center of the Financial District ... it really affects your sales,'' she said. ACT, which needs about $14 million overall to handle repairs and seismic upgrading, hopes to move back to the Geary in the middle of the 1991-92 season. ``So the rest of this season, we live as gypsies,'' Befera said. San Francisco Museum Society director Harry Parker said attendance slipped at one point to about half the normal 50,000 visitors per month. He said attendance appears to be picking up. But whatever the financial or physical costs, a survey of 300 area residents commissioned by Japanese groups developing earthquake reaction plans for their nation about a month after the quake showed only 7 percent considered moving. ``It's like this is a fact of life, and the benefits of living in California outweigh the fear of even more devastating earthquakes,'' said Polly Smith of Plog Research Inc.

DOC.HEAD: Sponsors Hoping Warm Weather Won't Wreck Cherry Blossom Festival
DOC.TEXT: Sponsors of the annual Cherry Blossom Festival say they hope unseasonably warm weather hitting the nation's capital will not cause the trees to bloom too early for the celebration. ``Even though the weather forecasts are good _ drat it _ and the cherry blossoms look like they may come out early, we're still hopeful,'' National Park Service spokesman Al Dale said. April 1 is the scheduled start of the 78th annual festival commemorating the gift of the 3,000 trees to the United States by the mayor of Tokyo in 1912. Temperatures ranging from the mid 60s to the upper 80s are expected for the rest of the week. The earliest the trees have ever blossomed was March 20, but forecasters say it could be even earlier this year _ probably March 15. The delicate pink and white blossoms last four to five days after they peak. ``If things go according to our estimates, by April 1, the program may just be the Japanese Tree Festival, because the blossoms will have come and gone,'' National Weather Service meteorologist Jim Belleville said.
DOC.HEAD: FAA Inspectors Not Trained to Stop Drinking Pilots, Congressman
DOC.TEXT: Says

Some inexperienced Federal Aviation Administration inspectors don't have the training to prevent intoxicated crews from flying airliners, says the chairman of the House aviation subcommittee. An FAA inspector in Fargo, N.D., allowed a Northwest Airlines jet to take off last Thursday despite a tip that the crew had been drinking for more than six hours. ``The system could fail again the same way,'' Rep. Jim Oberstar, D-Minn., said Monday after meeting with FAA Administrator James Busey. Busey told Oberstar that ``he was going to get their (inspectors) training upgraded to deal with situations like that,'' said FAA spokeswoman JoAnn Sloane. Sloane could not provide any details of how the inspectors training would be improved. ``The FAA is going to act on this quickly or we're going to burn their behind,'' Oberstar said. The three crew members on the flight from Fargo to Minneapolis were arrested upon landing last Thursday when blood tests showed excessive alcohol levels. Their licenses were revoked. The Fargo inspector didn't detain the crew members because they didn't smell of alcohol and didn't appear to be impaired, said Oberstar. The inspector interviewed the men and observed them for more than an hour while they prepared for departure, Oberstar said. The FAA had said that the Fargo inspector did not have the authority to stop the plane from taking off under North Dakota law and that the tip didn't constitute evidence of intoxication. However, Oberstar said Northwest or any other airline would have voluntarily grounded the flight had it been warned of the allegations.
DOC.HEAD: Soviets Got $481 Million in U.S. Wheat Subsidy
DOC.TEXT: U.S. subsidies on wheat sold to the Soviet Union totaled $481 million over a 29-month period, according to a General Accounting Office report. The subsidies are collected by U.S. exporting companies, which then ship to the Soviets and other foreign buyers at less than market prices. The object is to help U.S. farm products compete with growers in other countries whose exports receive government subsidies. The program is aimed especially at competition from the 12 countries of the European Economic Community, where France and West Germany are big exporters of wheat. Detailed figures in the report, made available recently, cover Oct. 1, 1986, through Feb. 28, 1989. During that period, the total subsidies to all exporters amounted to $2.3 billion. Total sales of U.S. products helped by the subsidies were $6.8 billion, of which $5.5 billion was for sales of wheat. Five countries were the biggest wheat buyers under the program: the Soviet Union, China, Algeria, Egypt and Morocco. Critics say the subsidized sales discourage those governments from paying better prices to their own farmers, and that the bread from the wheat is so cheap that some feed it to animals.
DOC.HEAD: NYNEX Asks FCC To Dismiss Record Fines and Refunds
DOC.TEXT: The NYNEX Corp. has asked the Federal Communications Commission to throw out more than $36 million in fines and refunds to be paid by two subsidiaries because they did not pass along to ratepayers the inflated cost of equipment. In legal papers filed Monday, NYNEX said telephone ratepayers were not overcharged as a result of transactions between Materiel Enterprises Co., an unregulated NYNEX affiliate, and New York Telephone Co. and New England Telephone and Telegraph Co. Last month, the FCC levied fines totaling $1.4 million against New York Telephone Co. and New England Telephone and Telegraph Co. and ordered them to refund about $35 million to customers. The fines were the largest federal penalty ever imposed on a telephone company and involved alleged $118.5 million in overcharges made to the two subsidiaries by Material Enterprises Co., which was established in 1983 to provide equipment and services to the two phone companies.

DOC.HEAD: `Red October' Continues to Lead at Box Office; `House Party' Strong
DOC.TEXT: ``The Hunt for Red October'' stayed afloat at No. 1 at the box office, and the new low-budget comedy ``House Party'' made big money. ``Red October,'' the Sean Connery-Alec Baldwin submarine thriller, sold $14.1 million in tickets at the nation's theaters over the weekend, according to figures released Monday by Exhibitor Relations Co. In second place was the new romantic comedy ``Joe vs. the Volcano,'' pairing Tom Hanks and Meg Ryan in a story of a man on one last, fiery fling. The film collected $9.3 million in its debut weekend. ``House Party,'' a new comedy released by New Line Cinema, makers of the ``Nightmare on Elm Street'' slasher films, netted $4.6 million for third, even though it is playing only in limited release on 520 screens. Rob Lowe, returning to Hollywood after several ill-famed homemade videos, finished in fourth with ``Bad Influence.'' The drama had ticket sales of $3.8 million. ``Born on the Fourth of July'' director Oliver Stone won the top prize from the Directors Guild of America on Saturday, but the film continued to fade at the box office. It finished eighth with a take of $1.5 million. Here are the top movie ticket sales for Friday through Sunday as tallied by Exhibitor Relations, with distributor, weekend gross, number of theater screens, average per screen, total gross and number of weeks in release. Figures are based on a combination of actual box-office receipts and studio projections where actual figures are not immediately available. 1. ``The Hunt for Red October,'' Paramount, $14.1 million, 1,665 screens, $8,444 per screen, $37.7 million, two weeks. 2. ``Joe vs. the Volcano,'' Warner Bros., $9.3 million, 1,802 screens, $5,134 per screen, $9.3 million, one week. 3. ``House Party,'' New Line, $4.6 million, 520 screens, $8,867 per screen, $4.6 million, one week. 4. ``Bad Influence,'' Epic, $3.8 million, 1,297 screens, $2,946 per screen, $3.8 million, one week. 5. ``Driving Miss Daisy,'' Warner Bros., $3.5 million, 1,432 screens, $2,421 per screen, $65.3 million, 13 weeks. 6. ``Hard to Kill,'' Warner Bros., $2.7 million, 1,498 screens, $1,774 per screen, $37.2 million, five weeks. 7. ``Madhouse,'' Orion, $1.8 million, 1,545 screens, $1,184 per screen, $15.9 million, four weeks. 8. ``Born on the Fourth of July,'' Universal, $1.5 million, 1,206 screens, $1,205 per screen, $61.8 million, 12 weeks. 9. ``Glory,'' Tri-Star, $863,225, 803 screens, $1,075 per screen, $21.5 million, 13 weeks. 10. ``Revenge,'' Columbia, $820,242, 887 screens, $925 per screen, $14.4 million, four weeks.

DOC.HEAD: City to Pay Estates of Children Killed in MOVE Confrontation
DOC.TEXT: The city has agreed to pay $500,000 to the estates of each of five children who died after police bombed the radical group MOVE's headquarters five years ago. The settlement, approved by a federal judge Feb. 28, was confirmed Monday by Charisse R. Lillie, city solicitor under Mayor W. Wilson Goode. Five children and six adult MOVE members were killed in 1985 during the battle between MOVE and police officers trying to arrest members of the armed, back-to-nature group. Police dropped a bomb on MOVE's fortified home, setting off a fire that destroyed 61 row houses. The children, whose bodies were pulled from the rubble, ranged in age from 9 to 14. One or both parents of each child were imprisoned for their MOVE activities. Jim Beasley, an attorney for the children's estates, said the city could not have defended its case in court. ``There was just no way that anyone was going to come into a courtroom and explain to a jury that this is something that should have happened or was anticipated in happening and could be justified,'' he said. The settlement brings to at least $25 million the estimated cost to the city of the MOVE disaster, including rebuilding of the homes. Ten cases stemming from the confrontation are still pending, including one filed by the family of Michael Ward, a boy who survived the bombing.

DOC.HEAD: Teams Vote to Keep Football Replay Officials, With Reservations
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Longer version on sports wires
DOC.TEXT: Pro football voted to continue allowing referees to check disputed calls against the instant replay, but allowed the judges only two minutes to watch a tape and barred them from listening to TV sportscasters. Twenty-one of the 28 National Football League teams Monday approved the use of replays for another year. The replays began on a trial basis for the 1986-87 season and have been voted on each year since. The procedure allows referees to request a review of the videotape on plays where a call from the field may have been in error. Many teams expressed unhappiness over the delays caused by the replays. According to NFL figures, the delays averaged 1 minute, 55 seconds, although some reviews took four or five minutes. Next year, if a play isn't overturned in two minutes, it is assumed to stand. NFL Commissioner Paul Tagliabue overcame resistance to renewing replay by also agreeing to ensure that replay officials won't hear the opinion of TV commentators while using network tape in reviewing plays. Tagliabue said he didn't become an ardent supporter of replay until Saturday, when he watched tapes of the 65 plays overturned by replay last season. ``What I saw were 65 errors that were rectified,'' he said. ``Any time you're able to rectify a mistake, I think you should do it.'' Voting against replay were Buffalo, Cincinnati, Kansas City, Phoenix, Chicago, Tampa Bay and the New York Giants.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Israel's Coalition Cabinet Collapses
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 4-5 `But he ... coalitions resulted' with 3 grafs to UPDATE with Shamir to try to survive confidence vote. Picks up 6th pvs, `The government ...'
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir on Tuesday fired Vice Premier Shimon Peres, collapsing the 15-month coalition government in a dispute over starting peace talks with Palestinians, Israel army radio said. The rest of the Cabinet ministers from Peres' center-left Labor Party resigned after Shamir, leader of the rival Likud bloc, dismissed Peres as finance minister. On Monday, Peres won the approval of the Labor Party's Central Committee to bring down the government after accusing Shamir of leading Israel into ``the desert of indecision'' about peace talks with Palestinians. Shamir spokesman Yossi Achimier said on army radio Tuesday that the prime minister was now turning his attention to surviving a no-confidence vote in Parliament on the motion Labor is expected to file on Thursday. If successful, Shamir's conservative Likud bloc would be able to rule without Labor. With the governing coalition broken up, elections are likely. The last two elections were indecisive and tenuous Likud-Labor coalitions resulted. The government crisis began last month when Labor demanded the Cabinet approve proposals by Secretary of State James A. Baker III that had been under consideration since October. On Sunday, Shamir refused to allow the decision-making Inner Cabinet to vote on the plan, which involves arranging preliminary Israeli-Palestinian peace talks in Cairo. Labor supports the Baker proposals, but Likud says the provision for including residents of Arab east Jerusalem in the talks could threaten Israel's declared sovereignty over the area. Likud also opposes participation by exiled Palestinians on grounds that could provide an opening to the talks for the Palestine Liberation Organization, which Israel views as a terrorist organization. The Israel-Palestinian talks are meant to lead to eventual elections in the Israeli-occupied territories, with their final status decided later. Israel seized the West Bank, Gaza Strip and East Jerusalem in the 1967 Middle East war.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks And Yen Fall Further
DOC.TEXT: A wave of arbitrage selling set off the fourth-largest decline this year in the Tokyo Stock Exchange's chief index today, while the Japanese yen fell to its lowest level against the dollar in Tokyo in exactly three years, traders said. The 225-share Nikkei Stock Average dropped 747.66 points, or 2.24 percent, ending the day at 32,620.57, its lowest level since March 28, 1989, when it closed at 32,306.36. Following a combined decline of 1,372.55 points today and Monday, the Nikkei index has lost nearly 6,300 points, or 16.2 percent, since the beginning of this year. The dollar closed at 152.67 yen, up 0.67 yen from Monday's 152.00-yen finish. After opening higher at 152.82 yen, it ranged between 151.95 and 152.88 yen during the day. Dealers said the yen's weakness and a plunge in Japanese government bond prices led to massive arbitrage selling that in turn contributed to the Nikkei's eighth-largest single-day loss in history. The yen's weakness discouraged bond investors and caused the price of benchmark No. 119 Japanese government bonds to plunge to 86.06 points, down 0.43 points from Monday's close of 86.49, dealers said. The yield rose from the previous day's 7.24 percent to 7.324 percent, the highest level in five years. ``Share prices kept falling in the afternoon as the dollar remained above the 152-yen level,'' said Yasumasa Shinagawa, a dealer with Yamaichi Securities Co. ``Participants discarded issues while nobody bought them back.'' Shinagawa said arbitrage trading, in which participants profit from price gaps between the spot and the futures markets, accelerated the Nikkei's plunge in afternoon trading. Analysts have blamed computer-aided large-scale arbitrage trading for recent market plunges. They say such trading can control the market direction, especially when overall volume is low. Today only 400 million shares traded hands on the market's first section, up slightly from Monday's 370 million. Other dealers said persistent speculation over a hike in the official discount rate hike also contributed to the plunge. Japanese financial markets have been fluctuating nervously in recent weeks because a hike in the central bank's key interest rate that was expected after last month's general election has not materialized. Now investors expect the hike _ of as much as 1 percentage point, according to local news reports _ to take place as soon as Bank of Japan Governor Yasushi Mieno returns from a trip to Europe on Thursday, dealers said. The official discount rate now stands at 4.25 percent after three hikes last year. Local news reports today said Mieno hinted at the possibility of an imminent hike in the nation's key lending rate to commercial banks. The dollar opened higher in Tokyo following an overnight upswing on overseas markets, and then weakened marginally in the morning after intervention by the Bank of Japan, traders said. But the dollar rose back in the afternoon session as market players bought the U.S. currency, said a trader with Mitsui Bank, who spoke on condition of anonymity. He said the dollar would have risen higher without the Bank of Japan's intervention. It was the dollar's highest finish in Tokyo since March 13, 1987, when it closed at 153.48 yen. Traders said the central bank sold at least 1 billion yen ($6.6 million) in an effort to stem the dollar's rise against the yen.

DOC.HEAD: Mongolian Communists Meet To Discuss New Shape Of Leadership
DOC.TEXT: Communist leaders met today to debate the shape of a new government for this longtime Soviet client state, and a spokesman said reformers were winning over the few remaining conservative opponents. Before resigning Monday, the Politburo of the ruling Communist Party agreed to abolish the party's constitutional guarantee on power, hold a special party congress to choose a new leadership and hold early elections this year for a new legislature to rewrite the constitution. ``It is a crucial moment for the party,'' Foreign Ministry spokesman Tepbishiin Chimeddorj said today. He said today's special meeting of the party's 120-member Central Committee could produce a new Politburo and even change its structure and name. He said it was too early to give details of the form the new leadership of the world's second-oldest Communist country would take. The sparsely populated pastoral country of 2 million people lies between the Soviet Union and China. Chimeddorj said Central Committee members, meeting for a second day, had been arguing behind closed doors about the reform proposals and ``practically nobody'' opposed them. ``In general, we can say in the Central Committee there are radicals and conservatives. They are arguing, but the viewpoints of the conservatives also are changing,'' he said. Mongolian officials did not rule out the possibility that the officials who tendered their resignations Monday might be re-elected. Party General Secretary Jambyn Batmonh and the four other members of the Politburo resigned Monday, but he remains chairman of the Parliament and head of state. His government titles were not affected by Monday's announcement. Members of Mongolia's fledgling opposition said the Politburo moves were only a first step toward democracy. Since the beginning of the year, opposition demonstrations have pushed Mongolia's sleepy reform process into high gear. ``A political struggle has started, and it is only the first victory, said Batsukh (single name is cq), an activist in the New Progressive movement. The movement today announced formation of a new wing, the National Progressive Party, to join two earlier established opposition parties _ the Democratic Party and the Social Democratic Party. The National Progressive Party's leaders said they differ from the other two opposition groups mainly in their demand for an immediate transformation of Mongolia's centralized economy into a market economy. Opposition parties are pressing for legislative elections to be held in June or July. Mongolia in the early 1920s was the original Soviet satellite and has borrowed heavily from Soviet experience and popular culture. Drab Soviet-style apartment buildings dot the capital, people drive Soviet-built cars past traffic police dressed in Soviet-style uniforms and, just as in Mongolia's northern neighbor, buyers queue up to make purchases. Until recently, a statue of Stalin stood along one of the capital's main streets, a monument to the Soviet leader Mongolians revered for helping them fight Japanese invaders. But the reforms Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev unleashed on Eastern Europe have had an effect in Mongolia, as well. There is a new emphasis on learning languages other than Russian and the country gradually has begun opening to the outside world. In Washington, the State Department on Monday welcomed the Mongolian government's opening to opposition demands. State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler pointed to the Mongolian opposition movement that surfaced in recent months and mounted peaceful rallies for democracy. The Central Committee on Monday set a special party congress for April 10, at which a new Central Committee will be chosen. Batmonh said the new group should be younger and in favor of reform. He called for early legislative elections, but did not specify a date. One of the tasks of the new Parliament will be to approve a new constitution, and work on the draft has started. One of the goals of the new constitution will be to separate the roles of party and government. Batmonh also called for renewed efforts to rehabilitate people wrongly punished in past political purges.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Indicates Ruling Against UPI in Photo Exchange Suit
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge said he was inclined to let Reuters end its picture exchange agreement with United Press International. A decision was expected today. Judge Peter K. Leisure on Monday was weighing a request from UPI for a preliminary injunction barring Reuters from pulling out of the agreement. Reuters has said the agreement is not meeting its expectations; UPI maintained that allowing Reuters to pull out would cause UPI irreparable harm. The agreement, reached in 1984, called for UPI to supply Reuters with pictures from the United States, while Reuters provided UPI with pictures from other countries. It was to run for 10 years beginning in 1985. After more than two hours of oral arguments Monday, Leisure said he was prepared to rule against UPI in the dispute between the two news services. But UPI's lawyers asked that Dr. Earl Brian, UPI chairman, be allowed to testify on the impact of such a ruling. After Brian testified, the judge said he would issue his ruling today. Brian said that after Reuters announced Feb. 16 that it was canceling the contract and interrupted the exchange for four hours, UPI began negotiations for a photo exchange with the French news service Agence France-Presse. ``We were unable to reach any agreement save the supply of photographs by AFP for three months,'' Brian said. ``We have not accepted it.'' He said a survey of 36 of UPI's major clients revealed that some newspapers said they would drop the UPI photo service if the Reuters canceled. Brian said a loss of foreign photos also could result in clients dropping UPI's news service. If the injunction is not granted, Brian said, UPI will go forward with its negotiations with AFP. After Brian's testimony, Leisure extended a temporary restraining order that bars Reuters from canceling the contract until next Monday ``to enable UPI lawyers to make whatever applications are needed'' to an appeals court. UPI lawyer Mitchell Karlan said UPI would appeal if Leisure denied the injunction.

DOC.HEAD: On the Light Side
DOC.TEXT: After 52 years of separation, Joseph and Elizabeth Pipkin are ready to tie the knot again. They originally wed in 1932 in Oklahoma, but the marriage ended after six years and two children, and they went their separate ways _ she to Illinois, he to Oregon. ``We were just too young,'' said Mrs. Pipkin. That won't be a problem this time. Both were 77 when they took their vows again Saturday, although in Pipkin's view, there's still plenty of time. ``My dad married at 78,'' he said. ``He lived to 105.'' Their daughter, Evelyn Pipkin, kept in touch with her father through the years and toiled to bring the couple back together. ``He never did get over her,'' Evelyn Pipkin said. ``I always had the feeling he loved her, even when he married my stepmother. He never had any more children.'' When Mrs. Pipkin's third husband died last winter, Evelyn suggested her parents get together for old times' sake. A Christmas card from Mrs. Pipkin led to long letters and phone calls. On Monday, they were married at the Assembly of God Church in nearby Meadowbrook.

A government watchdog group surprised officials by inviting people who don't normally get the red carpet treatment to a public reception and dance put on for lawmakers. William Hauda, executive director of Common Cause in Wisconsin, said Monday he distributed 2,000 fliers announcing the event to senior citizen centers, homeless shelters and fraternity houses. ``I'm sure our lawmakers will benefit immensely from this contact with homeless, hungry and needy citizens,'' Hauda said. Under state ethics law, lawmakers and state officials are prohibited from accepting anything of value, including food and drink, unless the same is offered to the general public. A notice of the event was published in the classified section of Madison newspapers. ``We felt that the tiny notice ... wasn't sufficient notice,'' Hauda said. ``We thought that we should help get the word out.'' Superior Mayor Herb Bergson, who is hosting the do, said he was angry Common Cause did not tell him about the fliers. ``I didn't find out until late afternoon, so we couldn't get more food,'' he said. But Jeff Wendorf, a university extension employee who helped plan the event, said the additional guests were welcome. ``We come down here to share the hospitality of northern Wisconsin, and will do just that,'' Wendorf said. ``When the food runs out, it runs out. It's first come, first served.''

DOC.HEAD: Boston's 10-Year `Big Dig' Gets Under Way
DOC.TEXT: The digging is under way on the Big Dig, a 10-year project to cut another tunnel under Boston Harbor and replace the city's elevated highway with an underground one. Groundbreaking was held Monday on the $4.4 billion project, without which officials say Boston could someday develop 14-hour gridlock. Because of the construction, however, traffic will get much worse before it gets any better, and the demolition work may unleash an onslaught of rats. Under the plan, a third tunnel will be built under the harbor and the more than 30-year-old Central Artery, the rusty, six-lane elevated highway through the city, will be replaced with an 8- to 10-lane underground expressway. The project underwent two years of planning, drafting and approvals. If all goes according to plan, it will be complete in 1998. Rodents washed over the city's South End in 1984 during construction on an expressway. In an effort to avert a similar assault, the state has undertaken an anti-rat plan, including early baiting and inspection aimed at controlling the millions of rats whose habitats will be destroyed by the project.

DOC.HEAD: Balmy Weather Prevails in East, Cooler in West
DOC.TEXT: Summer-like weather continued throughout much of the eastern United States today, but in parts of the West snow was a reminder that it still is March. The National Weather Service said temperatures up to 25 degrees above normal could be expected in much of the East through midweek. Temperatures overnight never dipped below the 50s in much of the northern central United States. On Monday, record highs were set in nearly 100 cities _ up to 95 in Baltimore, 19 degrees above the city's century-old record for the date. Other record highs broken or tied for the date included Augusta, Ga., 88; Chicago 81; Detroit 75; Kansas City 77; and Minneapolis 69. But the warm air flowing over snow and frozen ground created dense fog from North Dakota into Michigan. Flooding caused by a combination of rain, rapidly melting snow and frozen ground subsided by early today in Wisconsin and Minnesota. Flooding also eased in Texas, Oklahoma and Arkansas, which were hit by violent storms during the weekend. In the West, snow fell this morning in Great Falls, Mont. On Monday, heavy snow closed Interstate 80 in the Lake Tahoe area of Nevada because of many accidents. Snowfall of up to 2 to 4 inches also was reported Monday in Colorado, Montana, North Dakota, Utah and Arizona. Showers and thunderstorms were scattered over east central California, while rain was scattered over North Dakota and Minnesota. Rain also reached from northeast New York state across the central coast of New England, while rainshowers and thunderstorms extended from the upper half of the Texas Gulf Coast across southeast Texas and southern Louisiana. Galveston, Texas, reported one and one-third inches of rain during the six hours ending 7 p.m. EST.
