DOC.HEAD: Allstate Will Sue to Block N.J. Insurance Reform
DOC.TEXT: Allstate Insurance Co. threatened a court challenge moments after Gov. Jim Florio signed a law to lower auto premiums by 20 percent for New Jersey motorists, who pay the second-highest rates in the nation. ``This will strike a blow for the working people who have been oppressed by this unfair tax we call auto insurance,'' the governor said Monday. Florio promised that the auto insurance reform package, which moved through the Legislature and back to his desk within 45 days of its unveiling by the new governor, will save motorists $222 a car by next March. Florio's bill cuts auto insurance bills by eliminating the Joint Underwriting Association, a state-operated pool for high-risk drivers that has piled up a $3.1 billion debt. A $222-per-car annual fee charged every motorist to keep the pool from bankruptcy will be dropped. The law requires the insurance industry to pay $1.4 billion of the JUA debt. Florio said that insurance companies, which at one point had assigned more than half of New Jersey drivers to the JUA, bilked the poorly operated pool and must now pay the money back. The law bars insurers from charging higher premiums to make up the cost of paying off the JUA debt. Insurers said, however, they are not to blame for the state-created pool and promise to block the measure in court within a month. ``We believe the bill is unconstitutional,'' said Allstate Vice President Edward Young. ``It takes our stockholders' assets to pay for a deficit we didn't create.'' At an average of $1,000 per car, insurance rates in New Jersey are second highest in the nation, behind Massachusetts, according to a survey by A.M. Best Co., which rates the stability of insurance companies. Young said Allstate will consider pulling out of New Jersey because of the new law. ITT Hartford Insurance Group, which has a very small part of the New Jersey market, also said it would stop selling auto insurance for independent agents and brokers. Florio said New Jersey will ``adapt'' if insurers leave. ``This is a fair system for all, including the industry,'' he said. ``For some of the companies to literally say they're going to pick up their bat and ball and go play somewhere else is by definition childish.'' Under the law, the JUA will be replaced by a much smaller assigned risk plan, motorists will pay higher registration fees and professions that benefit from auto accidents _ doctors, lawyers and body shops _ will pay $100 license fees to help pay the JUA debt. The insurance industry challenged, with some success, reforms in California, where voters in 1988 passed an initiative rolling back auto premiums 20 percent. Last week, California's insurance commissioner announced premiums will be cut more than 20 percent in Los Angeles County, where a third of Californians live, but will be raised in all but two other counties.

DOC.HEAD: Shop in Historic Building Collapses; 1 Dead
DOC.TEXT: A plaster ceiling caved in and dropped two tons of debris on customers at a croissant shop in the majestic Ansonia Hotel, killing a woman and injuring 12 other people. Passersby and a homeless man who sells books on the sidewalk in front of the ground floor shop helped pull out the survivors Monday. ``They were really good. The men got the women out first,'' said police Officer Robert Schelhorn. ``We thought the building was falling,'' said Elvin Rodriguez, a clerk at a nearby bookstore. ``First it was like a vibration, then glass breaking _ and then a big boom.'' The sidewalk bookseller, Benjamin Montalvo, was ``pulling a lot of people out. He went in a couple of times,'' Rodriguez said. None of the injuries were considered life threatening. Fire Department spokesman John Mulligan said the collapsed area was 250 square feet and weighed about two tons. The plaster ceiling in the ornate Beaux-Art building had been covered with a suspended ceiling and the combined weight apparently caused the collapse, Mulligan said. ``It's an old ceiling _ decorative molding, heavy plaster with metal leaves holding it all together _ it just gave way,'' said Buildings Commissioner Charles Smith. The Ansonia, a 17-story residential building built in 1904, occupies a full city block on Broadway. In earlier years its residents included Enrico Caruso, Arturo Toscanini, Lily Pons, Florenz Ziegfeld, Theodore Dreiser, Sol Hurok, Igor Stravinsky and other celebrities. Arts figures favored the hotel because its heavy construction made it soundproof. More recently the Ansonia has witnessed bitter landlord-tenant squabbles. In 1988 its owners were fined $400,000 for illegal removal of asbestos.

DOC.HEAD: Paul McCartney Gives A Quarter Million to Fight Cancer, Pollution
DOC.TEXT: Former Beatle Paul McCartney, who on Wednesday closes out his first tour of Japan in 24 years, has donated $250,000 to fight cancer and help clean up the earth. Half of the funds will go to the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York and the other half to the Japanese chapter of the environmental group Friends of the Earth, tour publicist Fiona Hurry said today. ``As we all know, cancer causes great suffering, and I have great respect for all those who try to lessen the pain as best they can,'' McCartney said in a statement. ``I also have hope that one day science and medicine will find a way to beat cancer forever.'' The 47-year-old rock'n'roller has been using his world tour, which began in Oslo in September, as a platform to promote the activities of Friends of the Earth. ``When I was a boy, I would never have believed it if someone had told me that one day we'd have a hole in the sky _ in the ozone layer _ that there would be acid in our rain, that the seas wouldn't be clean enough to swim in and the air not fit enough to breathe,'' McCartney said. ``All I am trying to do on this world tour is to hopefully make people think about how we're wrecking this world and ask them to challenge their politicians to act,'' he said. It was the first time McCartney has toured Japan since he performed with the Beatles in 1966. A planned Japan tour in 1980 was derailed when the singer was arrested at Tokyo's airport for possession of marijuana and later deported. His current band, which includes his wife Linda on keyboards and percussion, today played the last of six concerts at the Tokyo Dome, an indoor baseball stadium. His show features elaborate light and laser effects, more than a dozen Beatle hits including ``Hey Jude,'' ``Let it Be'' and ``Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band,'' and several cuts from McCartney's latest album, ``Flowers in the Dirt.'' The tour will travel to the United States, Brazil, and back to Europe, where it is to end in April.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Up, Gold Down
DOC.TEXT: The dollar rose against major foreign currencies today morning in thin, cautious European trading. Gold prices were lower, fueled by the dollar's continued strength, traders said. ``The market is fundamentally pro-dollar, but the market is cautious because of possible central bank intervention,'' said one trader with a foreign bank in Milan, Italy. Dealer said many traders were on the sidelines waiting for the scheduled release of U.S. retail sales figures later today. If the figures show the U.S. economy is not slowing as much as economists believe it is, the dollar could move higher, dealers said. Uncertainty about the German mark prior to Sunday's East German elections, relatively low Japanese interest rates, and worries about political instability in Japan have made the dollar a safe haven currency, they said. ``There is a fundamental weakening of the yen,'' said Tim Potter, a senior dealer at Goldman Sachs in London. In Tokyo, where trading ends as Europe's business day begins, the dollar rose 0.67 yen to a closing 152.67 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at a higher rate of 152.75 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Monday: _ 1.7147 West German marks, up from 1.7110 _ 1.5270 Swiss francs, up from 1.5235 _ 5.7965 French francs, up from 5.7800 _ 1.9275 Dutch guilders, up from 1.9190 _ 1,266.05 Italian lire, up from 1,263.75 _ 1.1795 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1787 In London, the dollar rose against the British pound and was quoted at $1.6012, compared with $1.6100 late Monday. Gold opened in London at a bid price of $398.50 a troy ounce, down from $400.65 bid late Monday. At midmorning, the city's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended price of $397.35. In Zurich, the bid price was $397.50, down from $401.10 late Monday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell $1.94 to close at a bid $399.08. Silver fell in London to a bid price of $5.05 a troy ounce, from Monday's $5.13.

DOC.HEAD: Officials Say Deletions of Homosexual Holocaust References a Misunderstanding
DOC.TEXT: The state asked the corporate sponsor of an exhibit on the Holocaust to delete references to homosexuals from educational materials accompanying the exhibit. The materials, including an article on the repression of homosexuals by Nazis, were prepared by Orem-based Geneva Steel for teachers planning field trips to the exhibit, ``The World of Ann Frank 1929-1945,'' to open here March 25. Utah school board guidelines state the ``acceptance of or advocacy of homosexuality as a desirable or acceptable sexual adjustment or lifestyle'' may not be taught in Utah. Geneva Steel removed the article on homosexuals at the urging of school board officials, said Geneva employee Kathy Bryson. ``We were specifically told never to mention the homosexuals,'' she said. School Superintendent James Moss on Monday authorized Geneva Steel to restore the deleted article, saying his intention earlier had been misunderstood. But he said there would be a ``question in a teacher's mind of sensitivity to state rules and laws ... and that any material dealing with homosexuality would need to be approached very carefully by teachers to ensure that they conform to those guidelines.'' The deleted article includes two pages detailing the treatment of homosexuals after Adolf Hitler's rise to power in 1933. Homosexuals were rounded up and sent to concentration camps where they were castrated or exterminated. A third page shows a pink triangle, the symbol the Nazis forced homosexuals to wear, surrounded by the words ``Gays Against Facism.'' It contains a brief history of the adoption of the symbol by the gay liberation movement in the 1970s. Michele Parish-Pixler of the American Civil Liberties Union said Moss had waffled on the issue, leaving teachers unsure where they stood. One of the problems with ``putting censorship laws on the books and adopting them into policies'' is such a practice makes everyone afraid, ``And that's what we're talking about here is fear,'' she said. Religious, human rights and gay rights groups met privately with Moss on Monday and then announced they would hold a ceremony to honor homosexual victims of the Holocaust when the exhibit opens. When first alerted, Moss said he wondered why the issue was raised at all. ``Homosexuality is not a major feature of the Holocaust,'' he said during the weekend. ``I think the major focus that certainly needs to be focused on continuously was the religious and cultural prejudice.'' Moss amended his statement Monday, saying he was quoted out of context. ``There has never been any question in our minds about the importance of including the material about the treatment of homosexuals in the Holocaust,'' he told reporters Monday. ``Homosexuals were poorly treated in the Holocaust, as were Jews, as were gypsies, as were artists, as were a variety of groups.'' Geneva Chairman Joseph A. Cannon, who sits on the national campaign board of the National Holocaust Museum in Washington, had said he was unaware that anything was being excluded from the teaching materials. ``My hobby is history. And I don't like fooling around with history,'' he said. ``I really don't think we ought to do something that ignores a pretty significant element of the Holocaust.''

DOC.HEAD: Report: Covenant House Hindered Investigation Into Murdered Client
DOC.TEXT: Covenant House officials thwarted investigations into the murder of a young man who appeared prominently in the shelter's publications, New York Newsday reported today. Covenant House, the largest shelter organization for runaways, denied knowing the victim, Sean Russell, 23, when a private investigator inquired about his murder last year, Newsday said. Months later, acting Covenant House president Frank Macchiarola discovered internal memos discussing a possible cover-up, he told Newsday. The memos contained allegations Russell was involved with a drug and prostitution ring operating from shelter facilities, he said. Macchiarola had been named last month to replace the Rev. Bruce Ritter, Covenant House's founder, who resigned after allegations of sexual misconduct with young runaways. Covenant House is the world's largest network of shelters for teen-agers. Macchiarola resigned after the trustees of the charity obstructed his attempts to investigate Russell's death, he told Newsday. Officials of the embattled charity declined to comment Monday, Newsday said. According to an account pieced together by Newsday, Russell had become romantically involved with a 27-year-old woman. On Oct. 20, her ex-lover, Donald Holden, 45, tied up and raped the woman, fatally stabbed Russell and then committed suicide by slashing his own throat. Russell appears on page one of the organization's annual report for 1989, and is featured in the charity's official calendar, which is received by thousands of contributors. According to Newsday, shelter officials deceived a private investigator, Michael Lipowski, dispatched to look into Russell's death. Lipowski told Newsday that a lawyer for Covenant House and one of its counselors, Paul Bates, flatly denied that Russell had any association with the organization. Bates acknowledged Monday that he was Russell's counselor but refused to discuss the young man's life or death, Newsday said.

DOC.HEAD: 2 Clergymen Hanged, 4 Other People Killed in Kashmir
DOC.TEXT: Moslem militants hanged two clergymen and dumped their bodies in a rice field, accusing them of spying on Kashmiri separatists for the Indian government. Officials said the bodies of the two Moslem priests were found Monday in Phulwama, about 30 miles southeast of Srinagar, the center of the four-decade-old separatist campaign. The officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, also said one person was fatally shot by militants who suspected him of being a police informer. The shooting occurred when curfew was lifted Monday night. Curfew was reimposed today at 9 a.m. after the 14-hour relaxation to allow night celebration of a Moslem festival. At least 180 people have died in the latest round of violence that flared Jan. 20 following a government crackdown on the movement for predominantly Moslem Jammu-Kashmir's independence from mostly Hindu India. The Hezbul Mujahedeen, or the Party of the Islamic Holy Warriors, claimed responsibility for the slayings of the two clergymen in telephone calls late Monday night to reporters in Srinagar. The party is the second-largest militant group in Kashmir. ``We interrogated (the priests) and punished them because they were agents of the intelligence bureau of India,'' said a man claiming to be the group's spokesman who did not wish to be identified. He said the two men were hanged Sunday night. A third Moslem clergyman was burned to death after the ``interrogation,'' he said, but the claim could not be immediately confirmed. The two men who were hanged were kidnapped about a week ago, he said. Gov. Jagmohan of Jammu-Kashmir state confirmed the two deaths but did not say if the militants were involved. Jammu-Kashmir is India's only state with a Moslem majority. The secession movement has been alternately simmering and flaring since 1947 when the old princely state of Kashmir, then governed by a Hindu ruler, merged with India. Moslem militants had earlier demanded union with neighboring Pakistan, an Islamic nation, but in the past year have demanded independence and the status of a neutral country. Pakistan also claims the state because of its predominantly Moslem population and has twice gone to war with India over the region. Pakistan now controls the western part of the state, while the larger portion is governed by India. About 64 percent of the Indian Jammu-Kashmir's 6 million people are Moslem. Nationwide, Moslems comprise 12 percent of India's 880 million people, while Hindus account for 82 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Pascal-Trouillot Set Precedent for Women as Lawyer, Judge
RETRANSMITTING a0460 to break first graf into two. ^Eds: It is pronounced Ehrt-ah Pahs'-kahl Truh-yoh'
With PM-Haiti, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) _ In the 1970s, Ertha Pascal-Trouillot campaigned for equal rights for women when it was illegal for a married woman to have a bank account or buy property without her husband's written approval. The law has since been changed. Women are no longer ``legal minors'' in Haiti. And the 46-year-old Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot is no longer just an author and lawyer. After the fall of dictator Jean-Claude ``Baby Doc'' Duvalier in 1986, she was appointed to the 12-member Supreme Court, becoming the first and only woman to sit on the body. She was to be inaugurated president today, becoming the first woman to lead this troubled 186-year-old Caribbean nation. Before being appointed to the Supreme Court, she was the first woman named to the executive committee of the Haiti's Bar Association and to the Appeals Court. Throughout, she has maintained a reputation for political independence. Francois Latourte, a former justice minister, said he ``highly recommended'' her to the Supreme Court after studying her record. ``She was a distinguished and competent judge, a remarkable woman,'' said Latourte. ``I did not hesitate to recommend her as the first woman justice.'' She is the author of several books about law. Her best-known work, ``The Judicial Status of Haitian Women in Social Legislation,'' was written in 1973, two years after graduation from law school. She is a member of the Association of French-Language Writers. ``She has had a meteoric career,'' said Ernst Malbranche, former president of the Haitian Bar Association. She is the widow of Ernst Trouillot, a distinguished lawyer who presided over the Port-au-Prince Bar Association until his death last year. The couple had one daughter. The horror of the harsh Duvalier family rule touched Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot in the late 1960s. Her brother, jazz guitarist Alix Pascal, was shot in the back in Port-au-Prince during a rehearsal. The assailant was a Tonton Macoute, the feared secret police of Francois ``Papa Doc'' Duvalier, Jean-Claude's father and predecessor. Left paralyzed, he now lives in New York City. When opposition parties nominated Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot on Monday to become provisional president, she took the news in stride. ``She was shocked but she expected it. We had told her,'' said Jean-Claude Roy, a leading member of the Unity Assembly opposition coalition.

DOC.HEAD: Tens of Thousands Relocated to Control Dissent
DOC.TEXT: Burmese military authorities have moved tens of thousands of people from the cities to outlying areas in an effort to control political dissent, two Western diplomats said today. ``They are getting rid of potential flash points,'' one diplomat said. ``Some areas were more active than others during the demonstrations and the army wants to have people where it can easily control them.'' One diplomat, citing reports from the new settlements before the government recently stopped allowing visits, said ``certainly in many cases the move was involuntary.'' ``From the estimates that we have built up we would say that the total figure would be up to half a million people countrywide,'' the other diplomat said. The relocations began early last year, said the diplomats, who were reached in Rangoon by telephone and spoke on condition of anonymity. They said the action apparently was aimed partly at breaking up blocs of anti-government sentiment in the cities, where millions of people took to the streets two years ago to demonstrate against the authoritarian rule of Gen. Saw Maung. The general seized power in a September 1988 coup, and his troops suppressed the demonstrations, killing hundreds of people. The movements also may be an attempt to influence voting patterns in the scheduled May 27 election, which are to be the first multiparty polling in three decades, the diplomats said. Authorities already have barred Aung San Suu Kyi and other opposition leaders from running in the election. The diplomats said many of the new settlements had no running water or electricity, and some were malaria-infested. Armed soldiers often supervised the relocations, herding people into trucks, they said. They said most of the people were moved from the capital, Rangoon, but others were moved from the northern cities of Mandalay and Taunggyi to outlying areas. ``In Rangoon it is very extensive,'' one diplomat said. ``People are ordered by the military to dismantle their houses at their own cost.'' In Bangkok last week, Burma's minister of health and education, Pe Thein, said the relocations were for ``sanitary'' reasons. ``We want Rangoon to be a good clean city and these are just squatters,'' he said. Citizens have held small-scale demonstrations despite restrictions, and one diplomat cited reports of protests in Mandalay at the beginning of March involving up to 200 Buddhist monks. The protesters had demanded the release of opposition leaders and other dissidents, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Man Jumps Into Sea With Five Children In Suicide
DOC.TEXT: A man jumped into the sea with his five children in an apparent suicide attempt, and he and three of the children died, a news agency reported today. The man clutched the children, taking them by surprise, and jumped off a pier Monday at Port Elizabeth on the southeast coast, the independent South African Press Association said. Two of the children were rescued, but the man and the other children drowned despite efforts to save them, the report said. The man's name was not given. Police have not established any reason for the incident, the report said.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Expected to Seek $300 Million for Nicaragua
DOC.NOTE: EDs: LEADS with 5 grafs, Bush to announce aid package today, call to Mrs. Chamorro, comment from Quayle; picks up 5th graf pvs, On Capitol ...
DOC.TEXT: President Bush is seeking a quick $300 million aid infusion to help salvage Nicaragua's war-battered economy and to solidify the political ground under president-elect Violeta Chamorro, administration sources say. Vice President Dan Quayle said in Asuncion, Paraguay, this morning that he told outgoing Nicaraguan President Daniel Ortega the aid package ``will take the fighters and try to make them farmers.'' Bush scheduled a morning news conference to announce the aid package. He was expected to press Congress to enact the emergency appropriation by April 25, when Mrs. Chamorro is to be inaugurated in her country's first peaceful transition to a democratically elected government. Bush also is expected to announce the lifting of U.S. trade sanctions that have been in place since May 1, 1985, said the sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Mrs. Chamorro, leader of the 14-party coalition that upset President Daniel Ortega of the leftist Sandinista Party on Feb. 25, will inherit a country whose economy has been devastated by a decade of mismanagement and war. Bush called Mrs. Chamorro on Monday to brief her on the package, a source said. On Capitol Hill, Bush's aid proposal will fall into place behind a pending $500 million request for emergency money for Panama, which has been bogged down in disputes about how the new aid will be funded and how it will be used. ``After 10 years of trying to destroy Nicaragua, we do have a responsibility to help democracy,'' said Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., chairman of the Senate Appropriations subcommittee that doles out foreign aid. ``I may well agree with whatever the president's policy is there. But I don't think it is wise to be raising expectations by promising money we don't know whether we have,'' Leahy said. The $300 million request will be paid for, like the supplemental money bill for Panama, through commensurate cuts in various Pentagon accounts in the current fiscal year. The request includes about $30 million to help pay costs of relocating some 10,000 Contra rebels and tens of thousands of family members from their camps along the Honduran border to homes inside Nicaragua, administration sources said. Supplementing that amount will be roughly $10 million left over from a humanitarian aid program for the rebels and from an international oversight panel set up to help the Central American peace process. In addition to the demobilization money for the U.S.-backed rebels, Bush will ask for emergency agricultural aid to help Nicaraguan farmers meet May planting deadlines, the sources said. Some of the money also could be used to repatriate other Nicaraguan refugees who fled the country during the Sandinistas' 10-year rule, the sources said. The package also will include money to help the country buy oil, which in the past has been supplied through Cuba. The incoming government fears that the Sandinistas will have exhausted the country's stocks of oil by the time they turn over power, officials said. U.S. aid would help Nicaragua buy oil from other sources, presumably Mexico and Venezuela, said one senior administration official. Money for planting, oil purchases and Contra demobilization, plus smaller amounts for medical and technical economic assistance, would make up roughly half of the $300 million package, the sources said. The other $150 million, which has not yet been as clearly defined, would go to help Nicaragua pay off overdue international financial obligations and to encourage economic development, they said. Bush also may outline the need for additional money for Nicaragua, probably somewhat less than $300 million, in the fiscal year that begins Oct. 1, the sources said. The money request reflects needs outlined in meetings that Francisco Mayorga, the leading economic strategist for the new Chamorro government, held last week with U.S. officials in the administration and on Capitol Hill. The administration hopes the urgency of the Nicaraguan request will help provide some momentum for its stalled aid request for Panama. The Panama measure has been delayed by arguments with Congress over which defense accounts were being cut to fund it, and over the size of the request. Panamanian President Guillermo Endara, installed after the U.S. invasion that ousted dictator Manuel Noriega in December, is on a hunger strike perceived partly as a protest over the slow pace of U.S. aid to his country. State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler noted Monday that $55 million in aid already was being used in Panama to rebuild damage from the invasion, create public works jobs and help establish a police force.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Declares Lithuanian Secession Illegal
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to ADD reax from lawmakers. Pick up 6th graf, `The Soviet...' INSERTS 4 grafs after 13th, `Gorbachev offered,'' to ADD quotes. Pickup 14th pvs, `On Monday...'
DOC.TEXT: Mikhail S. Gorbachev today called Lithuania's declaration of independence ``illegal and invalid'' but urged patience, saying Moscow's relations with the Baltic republic would continue unchanged for now. He said a commission was studying how to respond to Lithuania's action. In comments to the Congress of People's Deputies, Gorbachev indicated that Lithuania's independence drive is likely to encounter formidable resistance. He said the Kremlin would not begin negotiations with the three Baltic republics on the independence they are seeking. ``We cannot talk about negotiations,'' he said. ``You carry out negotiations with a foreign country.'' But several lawmakers said it was likely Gorbachev would soften his positon. The Soviet leader told the 2,000 deputies that Premier Nikolai Ryzhkov and a commission were studying the Lithuanian ``situation.'' On Sunday, Lithuania's legislature reclaimed the sovereignty the nation lost 50 years ago. Gorbachev won applause from the Congress when he said the Kremlin would not give in to demands to negotiate independence with republics seeking independence, including the other two Baltic states _ Latvia and Estonia. The Lithuanians want recognition as a sovereign state and the start of talks on secession. On Monday, the Estonians called for talks with Moscow on independence. All three republics were forcibly annexed in 1940. At one point, calling the Lithuanians ``comrades,'' Gorbachev paused and then said, ``I think they are comrades.'' The Soviet leader made a point of welcoming the presence of Lithuanian deputies at the Congress. But Lithuanian deputy Vaidotas Antanaitis said they now considered themselves observers. Antanaitis read excerpts from the declaration of independence, together with appeals for recognition of their sovereignty. He said Lithuania wants good relations with Moscow, and called for negotiations. Gorbachev offered no reaction. Another Lithuanian deputy, Algimountas Chekuolis, said he believed the Soviet leader would soften his position. ``Gorbachev is a realist,'' he said. ``He'll change his stand.'' Ingrik Toome, a deputy and premier of Estonia, said Estonians and Latvians were upset by Gorbachev's statement there would be no negotiations, but added that the Soviet leader might not yet have fully explained his position. ``So far, many of his political steps have shown that he has to start these negotiations,'' Toome said. The Lithuanian Communist Party chief, Algerdis Brazauskas, told reporters he met with Gorbachev early today, and ``there were no reproaches, contacts have not been broken.'' Brazauskas lost the post of Lithuanian parliament president last weekend. On Monday, conservative Politburo member Yegor K. Ligachev ruled out the use of force against the republic of 3.7 million people. ``We will not use force,'' he declared, ``We must resolve this by political means.'' In January, Red Army troops stormed the Azerbaijani capital of Baku to put down unrest fueled by independence demands, killing dozens. In April 1989, troops killed at least 19 people in Tbilisi, the capital of Georgia, during an independence demonstration. In order to make Sunday's declaration a reality, Lithuania must resolve a daunting array of questions, including matters of territory, compensation, the status of thousands of Soviet soldiers, ownership of factories and land, and control of the police and KGB. ``Hope and joy must dissolve into determination to work for Lithuania,'' the republic's new president, Vytautas Landsbergis, told the Lithuanian legislature in its capital of Vilnius on Monday. ``We must work very hard.'' The Tass news agency said Lithuanian legislators declared that their sons no longer need serve in the Soviet Army and appealed to Gorbachev to ensure the welfare of Lithuanian soldiers until negotiations start on mustering them out. Lithuanians said they expected at least a partial economic blockade by the Soviet side, which supplies all of the fuel to the republic. Foreign Ministry spokesman Gennady I. Gerasimov asserted Monday that Lithuania cannot go it alone in the world market. ``Lithuania is not self-sufficient, if only because it receives energy at subsidized prices,'' he said. A barrel of oil costs $15.70 on the world market, but the Lithuanians get a barrel for less than a dollar from the Soviets, he said. A week ago, Gorbachev demanded in talks with Brazauskas that the republic pay 21 billion rubles in hard currency _ about $34 billion _ for Soviet investment in factories and infrastructure during the past half-century. The Soviet leader also suggested Lithuania might have to hand over the Baltic port of Klaipeda, a key city that the independent republic would need to carry out foreign trade. But Algimontas Chekuolis, a leader of the pro-independence Lithuanian political movement Sajudis, said in an interview at the Congress that the Kremlin also owes. The Kremlin should pay 300 billion rubles to compensate for 300,000 people who were killed, imprisoned or exiled by Stalin and his successors, and for the economic havoc caused by a half-century of Soviet mismanagement. The Congress of People's Deputies was called into session in Moscow to consider a strong, new presidency that Gorbachev wants to establish. Lithuanians rushed their new legislature into session to declare independence before Gorbachev could be elected to that post.

DOC.HEAD: Talks Resume in Teachers Strike
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with three grafs to UPDATE with talks resuming this morning. DELETES reference to strike in fourth day; strike began last Wednesday. Picks up 5th graf, `Caperton met...'. ADDS byline.
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Gaston Caperton and union leaders resumed talks today in the state's first teachers strike, which has forced the cancellation of classes for half of the public school students. Caperton spokesman G.C. Morse said no agreement had been reached in Monday's talks but the two sides were closer to a settlement. The strike began last Wednesday in a dispute over wages and benefits. Teachers stayed away from class Monday despite a warning from the governor that they could be fired for striking in violation of state law. No immediate disciplinary action was taken. Union leaders have said they won't go back to work until Caperton calls a special legislative session to consider pay raises; the governor said he won't consider calling a special session until the teachers go back to work. In West Virginia, pay scales for teachers are set by the Legislature. Caperton met with Kayetta Meadows, president of the 16,000-member West Virginia Education Assocation, and Bob Brown, head of the 3,000-member West Virginia Federation of Teachers. Union officials said they had agreed not to discuss the content of the talks. Caperton was to make a ``major policy address'' on education tonight, his office said in a statement. It didn't say if the speech was strike-related, and his spokesmen were unavailable late Monday. Pickets spread to 46 of the state's 55 counties Monday. Classes were canceled in 29 counties, leaving nearly 150,000 of the state's 328,000 public school students at home. About 3,000 of the state's teachers are not unionized. Teachers picketed in shorts and T-shirts throughout the state, which enjoyed a sunny, 80-degree day. At Charleston's Capitol High School, only about 400 of the school's 1,300 students showed up. ``We've been wasting our time,'' said Shawna Adkins, a sophomore. ``All we do is watch movies, and we can do that at home.'' Outside Caperton's office, Keith Geiger, president of the National Education Association, addressed about 1,000 teachers. ``This isn't fun, but it is necessary,'' said Geiger, whose union is the parent of the WVEA. ``You must stick together until a resolution is there. It is not the time for individual decisions on how you should operate.'' West Virginia teachers average about $21,900 per year, less than in any state except Arkansas and South Dakota, according to the National Education Association. In Ohio County in the northern panhandle, classes were canceled after it was discovered most of the district's 47 buses had flat tires, said Superintendent H. Lawrence Jones. He said it was unclear who was responsible.

DOC.HEAD: Senator's Widow Claims Navy Doctors' Malpractice Led To Suicide
DOC.TEXT: The anger U.S. Sen. John East felt against Navy doctors when he committed suicide in 1986 was unjustified, a government attorney said in opening arguments of a wrongful death lawsuit brought by his widow. East was cured of a serious thyroid disorder with synthetic drugs 11 months before the North Carolina Republican asphyxiated himself with carbon monoxide, Assistant U.S. Attorney Susan Ringler said Monday. Priscilla East, 58, of Greenville, N.C., contends her husband believed the doctors' failure to diagnose his condition for several years had caused his mental and physical powers to deteriorate. Her $3.5 million claim is believed to be the first wrongful death lawsuit against the government by the family of a U.S. senator. ``Not every death is someone else's responsibility,'' Ringler said. ``The evidence in this case will demonstrate that the only one responsible for John East's death was John East himself.'' Ringler also disputed the claim that hypothyroidism dulled East's mental abilities, saying he led an active life until his death. East left a suicide note on June 29, 1986, saying doctors at Bethesda Naval Medical Center outside Washington, D.C., ``ruined my health'' by failing for years to diagnose his hypothyroidism. The disease occurs when the thyroid gland fails to produce the hormones necessary to maintain the body's metabolism. Mrs. East's attorney argued that East suffered from a series of symptoms, including fatigue and inability to sleep, for two years while under the care of Rear Adm. Freeman Cary, who was then attending physician at the U.S. Capitol. Mrs. East's attorney said Cary did not diagnose the thyroid problem. Cary is not named in the lawsuit. Survivors cannot sue individual military doctors but can file claims against the government. It was not until April 1985, when East fell into a near-fatal coma caused by hypothyroidism, that the correct diagnosis was made, according to court documents. Until then, Cary had recommended psychiatric treatment and other medical tests, attorneys on both sides said. Ringler said East saw his own doctor during his first 2{ years in the Senate, and when he did consult the attending physician's office, did not describe symptoms that could have led to a proper diagnosis. On the stand, East's widow painted a picture of an intelligent, vigorous former Marine who fought polio as a young man and relentlessly pursued his professional and political goals until he became sick in 1983. Her voice broke repeatedly when she described his struggle against the polio that paralyzed his lower body in 1955. After undergoing a spinal tap, he told her from a stretcher, ``You know, Pris, everything will be all right,'' she recalled. U.S. District Judge Walter Black Jr. is hearing the case without a jury. The trial is expected to last several weeks.

DOC.HEAD: Quayle Says Paraguay `Moving Along the Road of Democracy'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Top 5 grafs new with Quayle quote; editing throughout to tighten.
DOC.TEXT: Vice President Dan Quayle said today he pressed Paraguayan President Andres Rodriguez for progress on human rights and is convinced Rodriguez ``is dedicated to democracy.'' Quayle met with opposition political leaders and planned a second meeting later in the day with Rodriguez. The vice president, fresh from talks with President Daniel Ortega on a peaceful transfer of power in Nicaragua, said he pressed for progress on human rights in his first meeting with Rodriguez, shortly after his arrival Monday night from Santiago, Chile. ``I have already talked to him about human rights and the advancement of democracy,'' Quayle told reporters when asked about a State Department report that criticizes Paraguay for continued human rights problems. ``I'm convinced he is dedicated to democracy,'' Quayle said of Rodriguez. ``He's certainly moving along the road of democracy,'' the vice president said before meeting with opposition leaders representing various political parties. No other U.S. president or vice president has visited Paraguay since the 1950s, when Richard Nixon stopped there as vice president. Quayle and his wife, Marilyn, were honored Monday night in a gala dinner at the palace of Rodriguez, who gave the Quayles a pair of young spotted jaguars. The jaguar is native to Paraguay. Rodriguez is the former armed forces general who overthrew military dictator Gen. Alfred Stroessner in February 1989. Rodriguez won the election he called in May in a country where political diversity was squelched in the 34-year Stroessner regime. Quayle's message during his brief stay here is to praise the move toward democracy but also urge continued progress toward democratization, said the vice president's chief of staff, Bill Kristol. Although the Rodriguez government has taken significant steps to reverse repression that was prevalent under Stroessner, the Bush administration wants to see greater strides, according to the 1990 State Department report on human rights in Paraguay. The country's armed forces under Rodriguez have been used to forcibly remove poor squatters from farmland, and government corruption remains a serious problem, the report said. While some human rights violations have been recorded, the State Department said they do not appear to be systemic or reflective of government policy. About 200 anti-American protesters demonstrated peacefully against Quayle's visit in the central part of Asuncion, but Quayle did not see them. Earlier Monday, Quayle met for 1{ hours with Nicaragua's Ortega as both attended a lunch hosted at the presidential palace by Chile's newly inaugurated president, Patricio Aylwin. Quayle said Ortega promised there will be a peaceful transition of government when he hands over the presidency on April 25 to Violeta Chamorro, the U.S.-backed candidate who defeated the leftist Ortega in the Feb. 25 election.

DOC.HEAD: Barry Returning to Washington for Press Conference Today
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS new 3rd graph, During his ... to show that Barry's support has eroded.
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Marion Barry, arrested in January on a charge of possession of cocaine, is returning to the nation's capital after seven weeks of substance abuse treatment. A mayoral spokeswoman, Vera Jackson, ended speculation about the mayor's whereabouts, saying he would hold a news conference in Washington later today. Barry has been enrolled in treatment centers in Florida and South Carolina since his arrest on the charge of possession of crack cocaine. During his absence, Barry's political support has eroded, with the city's non-voting delegate to Congress, Walter Fauntroy, entering the mayoral race, and top supporters, including the co-chairman of Barry's campaign finance committee, joining the Fauntroy camp. The mayor's whereabouts were the subject of much speculation but no answers Monday as his aides tried to learn whether he had checked out of the South Carolina substance abuse program to return to the nation's capital. ``I would say he is in South Carolina, but I don't want to put my foot in my mouth,'' said Barry spokeswoman Lurma Rackley. ``I have no reason to believe that he is elsewhere, but he could be in transit right now. I don't know anything definitive yet, but there's no reason to believe he is out there in limbo somewhere.'' Madelyn Andrews, a spokeswoman for City Administrator Carol B. Thompson, said her office didn't know Barry's whereabouts, ``although we feel confident we could contact him through the treatment center if we had to.'' Thompson is handling the day-to-day chores of the running the government, but she is not authorized to sign legislation or approve spending bills. A Thompson aide, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the city administrator had been unable to locate Barry on Monday and was ``incredibly irritated.'' ``She is trying to run things, but no one can find him,'' the aide said. ``That is truly frustrating.'' Top government officials had predicted the mayor, who has been enrolled in two substance programs since shortly after being arrested in January on a drug charge, would return to the city last weekend. But Barry did not return to Washington on Saturday or Sunday. Rackley said she believed Barry was still at the Fenwick Hall Hospital outside Charleston, S.C., where he has been enrolled since Feb. 23. Rackley said Barry can always be reached ``because he travels with security, and the security officers are police, and the police department can always contact them.'' ``There would be no reason for anyone to look for him today, because there are no burning issues,'' she said. ``I do not know where he is,'' said Corporation Counsel Herbert O. Reid Sr., a longtime Barry confidant.

DOC.HEAD: Shamir Fires Peres, Governing Coalition Collapses
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to UPDATE with Shamir comments, denying radio report he may resign, other details. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir fired Vice Premier Shimon Peres today in a dispute over peace talks and all the Cabinet members of Peres' Labor Party quit, collapsing the 15-month-old coalition government. Peres' dismissal and the resignations do not take effect for 48 hours, leaving room for a last-ditch compromise. ``Things could happen, the situation can change,'' Shamir said on Israel radio. But reconciliation seemed remote as Labor leaders ruled out further contacts with Shamir's right-wing Likud bloc. ``The compromises... are behind us, not before us,'' Peres said. The collapse of the coalition sent party leaders searching for alliances to form a new government before a planned no-confidence vote in Parlaiment Thursday. Both Likud and the center-left Labor Party are seeking alliances with small religious parties, who hold a swing vote. If the no-confidence motion fails, Shamir could remain prime minister by forming an alliance with the smaller parties. If it passes, Shamir remains head of a caretaker government until a new government is formed by either Labor or Likud. The dispute is over Labor's support of a U.S. proposal to hold peace talks in Cairo with a Palestinian delegation. The delegates would discuss plans for elections in the occupied territories on self-rule for the Palestinians. Likud objects to involving the 140,000 Arabs in east Jerusalem in the elections. In a radio interview, Shamir said he acted to preempt Labor's efforts to muster a majority for Thursday's Parliament vote. He said the Jerusalem issue was the main obstacle. ``These differences of opinion are not so small...they exist and firstly about Jerusalem, an issue about which we are very sensitive, especially these days when we hear voices from the United States,'' Shamir said. The remark was an allusion to recent statements by U.S. leaders, including President Bush, suggesting Jerusalem could be negotiable in peace talks and Bush's criticism earlier this month of building Jewish neighborhoods in east Jerusalem. Both Labor and Likud maintain that Jerusalem is not negotiable, but Labor favors a compromise: allowing Jerusalem Palestinians to vote elsewhere in the disputed lands. Israel radio said today that Shamir also considered submitting his resignation before Thursday, but the premier denied it. After leaving the Cabinet, Peres raised the possibility of avoiding new elections by forming a Labor-led government with ultra-Orthodox and left-wing parties. The balance of power is held by two ultra-Orthodox religious parties who have seven of the 120 seats in the Knesset, or parliament. Labor and its allies control 55 seats, while Likud and its partners control 58. Explaining the prime minister's decision to expel Labor from the coalition, Shamir spokesman Yossi Achimier said his boss ``wants only one thing: to prevent a Palestinian state.'' Labor Communications Minister Gad Yacobi said Shamir's decision to end the coalition ruined prospects for a Palestinian-Israeli dialogue: ``The prime minister has closed the door on the peace process...for this he bears heavy national responsibility.'' Palestinians described the collapse as a setback for Israel's plan to hold elections in the occupied territories as a first step in resolving the Palestinian problem. Bethlehem Mayor Elias Freij said ``I believe Israel has killed its own peace plan ... and this will have very dangerous repercussions throughout the Middle East.'' Freij alluded to predictions that without an active process Arab-Israeli tensions would increase and result in violence, both in the occupied territories and from radical Palestinian groups abroad. Baruch Askarov, an aide to Peres, said today's Cabinet session began with stormy arguments between the two sides and then Shamir announced the dismissal of the Labor leader. The other Labor ministers then submitted resignations prepared in advance, he said. Peres' dismissal came after the Labor Party's 1,300-member Central Committee voted Monday night to give the party's leaders the power to pull out of the government if progress was not made in the Middle East Peace process. Likud argues that accepting the U.S. peace plan would mean implicitly recognizing the Palestine Liberation Organization and bringing into question Israeli control over Arab east Jerusalem, which was annexed after its seizure with the occupied lands in the 1967 Middle East war. More than 660 Palestinians have been killed by Israelis in a 27-month-old uprising against occupation of the West Bank and Gaza Strip. Nearly 200 Palestinians have been killed by fellow Arabs, most on suspicion of collaborating with Israel, and more than 40 Israelis have died.

DOC.HEAD: Amnesiac May Have Lived Separate Lives
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with three grafs to RECASTS to DELETE reference to impostor. Picks up 4th graf, `He was...'.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto KX1
DOC.TEXT: John Doe the amnesia victim: Is he Melvin Wolf, the Texas repairman who disappeared last year? Is he Jim J. King, the California insurance man who vanished 12 years ago? Or some mysterious combination of both? The case began in October, when police in Topeka, Kan., found the man wandering without identification. He said he didn't remember who he was or how he came to be there. He was known only as John Doe until Feb. 10, when relatives who saw him on television identified him as 53-year-old Melvin Wolf, a small-appliance repairman who disappeared in August from his sister's home in Angleton, Texas. Wolf's family has taken the man in and, short of fingerprinting, there seems little doubt that Doe was Wolf _ at least for much of his life. On Feb. 28, a Topeka TV station reported that Wolf maintained the separate identity of Jim J. King, a successful insurance salesman from Burbank, Calif., who hasn't been seen since 1978. On March 6, a third identity surfaced _ that of Robert J. Hart, a Denny's restaurant employee in Washington, D.C. ``I was just now accepting that I'm Melvin Wolf. Now I don't know who I am again,'' the man said recently. Police haven't had time to run down the Hart story, but Burbank police spokesman Sgt. Don Goldberg said authorities believe Wolf and King are the same person. Goldberg said investigators were still seeking dental records or other proof. King's wife, Ann, reported him missing March 31, 1978, under ``suspicious circumstances.'' An investigation turned up nothing but King's car, found abandoned two months later in a Burbank parking lot, Goldberg said. Authorities investigated King's insurance dealings for any misconduct, Goldberg said, but did not find enough evidence to charge the man. The investigation is still open. Burbank police have been searching for Mrs. King since reports that King might be Wolf surfaced recently. So far, they haven't found her. The man who could be King is about 6 feet tall with white hair, a weathered face and a rural accent. Wolf _ or King _ left Topeka on Feb. 28 to stay with Wolf's relatives in Angleton. Wolf's sister, Donna Caskey, said the family had lost track of him for many years before he turned up in Angleton in 1986. During much of that lost time, they heard stories that Wolf was living in California, Caskey said last month. The mysterious man and his Angleton relatives have refused to give interviews since the reports of his multiple identities. Rick Selig, a therapist at the Topeka Psychiatric Clinic, said the man suffered from psychogenic amnesia _ a total memory loss normally brought on by an extremely stressful event. The question, Selig said, is what caused the amnesia. Selig is trying to find out through hypnotherapy. The Pentagon says Wolf joined the Army in 1953 and was stationed in West Germany from 1957 to 1960. He left the service in 1961. Employees of a Prudential Life Insurance Co. office in Los Angeles said they recognize the man as King, their lost colleague. They said they had assumed that King was abducted and killed in 1978. Prudential employee Eugene Bullington said watching a TV report ``was like seeing someone come back from the dead.'' Herb Pierce, who hired King in the Prudential office in 1969, said King and his wife had two children. Burbank police have no record of the children, Goldberg said. WIBW-TV in Topeka, whose reports led to the man's unfolding identities, reported that employees at a Denny's in the Washington area called claiming they had worked with someone who resembled Wolf and went by the initials R.J. Denny's personnel files showed that a Robert J. Hart began working at the restaurant on April 7, 1978 _ a week after King disappeared from Burbank. Hart moved in September 1979 to Phoenix, where he worked at another Denny's until May 1980, WIBW reported. Although Wolf, King and Hart had different Social Security numbers, they listed the same birthplace, West Allis, Wis., and the same high school in Johnson Creek, Wis., WIBW has reported. The school says its records show that none of the three men studied there. Wolf's birthday is Sept. 27, 1936; King and Hart each listed their birthdays as Sept. 26. But the years were different: King said he was born in 1940 and Hart in 1943. Selig said his patient had been making slow progress in remembering technical information Wolf would have known, such as appliance electronics. But he said Wolf had no ``big bang'' of revelations about his life. ``It's kind of preposterous to him how he could have done all this stuff,'' Selig said. ``It's frightening to him. It's confusing.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Says Voters Shouldn't Hold Past Marijuana Use Against Candidates
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said today that past use of marijuana should not be used against a political candidate. Bush was asked during a news conference about the Texas gubernatorial primary election today in which questions of drug use have been raised. Democratic candidate Ann Richards has lost ground in public opinion polls after refusing to answer questions about possible past drug use. The president said the importance of such an issue ``is a matter for the voters to decide, but in my view if somebody used marijuana some time ago and is not into anything of that nature, why no, I don't think that should be used against them.'' . After his statement on marijuana, Bush was asked about past use of stronger drugs by a political candidate. ``You're getting me involved in the Texas primary, something I don't want to do,'' he responded. ``This is election day in Texas,'' Bush said, adding that he had voted in the Republican primary but declining to say for whom. ``I hope everybody understands,'' Bush said. Of the general election, he said, ``I'll be involved but I'm not going to fine tune that.''

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 1st item in PM-Names, a0421, to RECAST and DELETE reference to skirt.
DOC.TEXT: Kim Basinger declared herself ``just a proud Georgian'' as she picked up an award honoring her film roles and her purchase of the Georgia hamlet of Braselton. State employees put the phones on hold and hung on the actress' every word as she was named an ``Outstanding Georgian'' during a ceremony Monday in the office of Secretary of State Max Cleland. She is a native of Athens. Miss Basinger, star of ``Batman'' and ``9{ Weeks'' said her plans for Braselton are still being developed and she can't talk too much about them. In the past she has discussed building recording and film studios. She met with the Georgia Department of Banking and Finance concerning her purchase of the Bank of Braselton, spoke to young cancer patients at a hospital and appeared Monday night at a fund-raiser for Cleland's re-election campaign.

Here is the text of President Bush's news conference Tuesday: President Bush: Well, we began this administration by saying that the day of the dictator is over, and now restless millions have spoken and have elected or prepare to elect new governments, their governments. As long as we live, the images of this revolution, the revolution of '89, will be with us _ the playwright president in Prague, the tumbling of the Berlin Wall, crumbling of a Romanian dictatorship. But this revolution leaves us with a new challenge: how to best support newborn democracies. This challenge is utterly unlike the task of rebuilding Europe after the Second World War, for no single great plan will do. We need a flexible approach, one that will meet the needs of each country we seek to help. Today, I want to speak about how we can best help two democracies in our hemisphere: Panama and Nicaragua. We should take great pride in the way in which our leadership, Congress and the administration, helped the democratic spirit take hold in these two countries. But this is no time to bask in self-praise. These nations need our help to heal deep wounds inflicted by years of strife and oppression, years of loss and deprivation. And we must act and act soon to help the peoples of these new democracies in two great and historic tasks: reconstruction and reconciliation. I've taken an important step today. As a demonstration of our resolve to be part of the process of reconciliation, I just signed an Executive Order to end the economic embargo against Nicaragua. Americans are determined to help the people of Nicaragua. And next, I'm asking the Congress and the American people to join me in crafting a bipartisan agreement to help both countries. After all, bipartisanship did work well last year to put the focus on free elections and end the fighting in Nicaragua. Bipartisanship also helped bring an end to the tyranny in Panama. And we need to work again in that same spirit to put together an assistance program for both countries. I'm proposing the creation of a fund for democracy to assist in the reconstruction and development of these two countries. And I'm requesting the Congress to approve by April 5 a package of assistance of $800 million for these two countries using funds from the defense budget. This package consists of $500 million for Panama, already requested in that Jan. 25 proposal to Congress, along with $70 million for refugees, and an additional $300 million for Nicaragua. I'm asking the secretary of state and the secretary of the treasury to work together on the economic assistance aspects of these packages and, of course, to consult with the U.S. Congress. In addition, under existing authorities, I'm initiating immediate action to provide $21 million of previously appropriated economic aid principally for food and humanitarian assistance. I also will be sending to the Congress in the future a budget amendment for an additional $200 million in fiscal '91 for Nicaragua, consistent with the approach that we've taken this year. Moreover, I've instructed the secretary of defense and Dick Darman at OMB to begin negotiations immediately with the Congress on mutually acceptable offsets from the defense budget that can be used for this democracy fund without having an unacceptable impact on national security. I further propose that in the event that an agreement on offsets cannot be reached by March 27. The Congress authorized me to select offsets from the defense budget, and should neither of these alternatives prove to be workable, I am prepared, because of the dire need for these funds, to ask for a waiver of the Budget Act to allow this critical program to proceed on the required timetable. I urge the Congress to move quickly and also urge in the strongest terms that it not add any extraneous requests _ items to this request. It is urgent to advance the prospect for democracy and reconciliation in Nicaragua and Panama. Damage to both economies has been great. We must help and we want to help. Our help is needed swiftly to bring about demilitarization and advance the whole Central American peace process. If bipartisanship prevails we will be able to meet this goal and respond to the expectations of our neighbors.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Heat Wave Brings Temperatures 20 Degrees Above Normal
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts one graf after the 3rd to update with early record temp; SUBS 10th graf, ``Workers in ....,'' to CORRECT Ohio to Indiana; SUBS 12th graf, `The speed...'. to recast and CORRECT that speeding water was along North Fork River.
DOC.TEXT: A high-pressure system pumping tropical air over the eastern United States today broke hundreds of heat records, spread deadly fog over highways and left budding trees vulnerable to the nip of a late frost. ``I played golf yesterday, and I said then I was playing again today,'' said Gene Novak, a real estate manager in Baltimore, where the temperature hit 95 on Monday. ``What the heck? My boss is away.'' The National Weather Service forecast summery weather again today in most of the country east of the Mississippi. Temperatures up to 25 degrees above normal were expected through midweek. Grand Rapids, Mich., got an early start on today's summerlike trend _ its temperature at midnight tied the record high for today's date at 68. Monday's high in Baltimore broke the city's 100-year-old record by 19 degrees, and from North Dakota to Georgia it was a good day for sunbathers and fishermen. Record highs were recorded in more than 100 cities. In the nation's capital, the high of 87 was the warmest on record for any day in March. The warmth threatened to make Washington's cherry trees bloom too early for the annual Cherry Blossom Festival, scheduled to begin April 1. In South Carolina, peach farmers worried that a late frost could nip the budding peach blossoms. ``They are not far enough along to be out of damage,'' said Henry Nunnery of the York County Extension Office. Dense fog caused by the warm air flowing over snow and frozen ground was reported from North Dakota into Michigan, reducing visibility to zero in places and delaying planes at airports Monday. In Green Bay, where the day's reading of 70 broke the old mark by 15 degrees, a 100-foot-long ``white wall'' of fog and paper-mill smoke caused a flaming, 52-vehicle pileup that killed three people and injured 30. A combination of rain, rapidly melting snow and frozen ground caused flooding elsewhere in Wisconsin and in Minnesota, although officials said it had subsided by early today, as did floodwaters in Texas, Oklahoma and Arkansas. Workers in Danville, Ill., near the Indiana line, built a floodwall late Monday to protect the Inter-State Water Co., whose pumps were disabled when Lake Vermilion overflowed its banks during the weekend. Surgery at two Danville hospitals was canceled, and schools were closed until Thursday, when water is expected to be restored, said Donald Crews, disaster relief coordinator for the Vermilion County Red Cross. Just north of Lake Vermilion, flooding on the North Fork River destroyed more than a dozen cabins and mobile homes and damaged others. Water rushing down the river moved some mobile homes like ``floating projectiles,'' Crews said. ``I understand we're supposed to get more rain in the next two to three days. Who knows what that's going to bring,'' said Crews. Highs broken or tied for the date included Augusta, Ga., 88; Cape Hatteras, N.C., 78; Charleston, W.Va. 87; Chicago 81; Cincinnati 76; Cleveland 75; Columbia, S.C. 88; Detroit 75; Harrisburg 81; Indianapolis 76; Kansas City 77; Louisville, Ky., 78; Milwaukee 76; Minneapolis 69; Philadelphia 83; Pittsburgh 78; Raleigh, N.C., 90; Richmond 89; St. Louis 84; Washington 89; Wilmington, Del., 85

DOC.HEAD: Bush Says Pursuing All Leads in Attempt to Get Hostages Freed
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said today he is pursuing all leads in efforts to secure the release of U.S. hostages in Lebanon, even those ``going around in back alleys.'' ``When the whole story comes out on this, you are going to be very, very fascinated with the details, very fascinated,'' he told reporters at a White House news conference. Bush's aides confirmed last week that the president fell victim to a hoax when he accepted a telephone call from a man purporting to be Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani. The conversation took place several weeks ago, aides said. The president took the call after a man identifying himself as an Iranaian official contacted the White House to say that Rafsanjani wanted to talk about the American hostages in Lebanon. The captives are thought to be held by pro-Iranian Moslem Shiites. At his news conference, Bush refused to provide details of what his administration is doing on behalf of the eight Americans held in Lebanon. But he said: ``There are things that go on, going around in back alleys and trying to find out information, and we've got to do that. I owe it to the families of those people and to those people themselves that are held hostage.'' The Bush administration's official policy on the hostages is that it will not negotiate with the hostage-holders or their patrons. At the same time, officials say they are willing to talk with anyone about the hostages. ``Good will begets good will,'' Bush said. Eight Americans are among 18 Westerners thought to be hostages in Lebanon. The longest held American hostage, Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, will mark his fifth year in captivity on Friday. Bush said administration officials had not been trying to reach Rafsanjani, who has recently made statements indicating he would like to see the hostages freed soon. ``He's got some political problems at home and we understand that,'' Bush said of Rafsanjani. Earlier, Marlin Fitzwater, Bush's spokesman, said officials did not know who initiated the call but he did not rule out that it was perpetrated by a faction inside the Iranian government. While administration officials have said they were encouraged by Rafsanjani's statements, they say they have no reason to believe the hostages are on the verge of freedom.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON: ... our neighbors.
DOC.TEXT: Let me save the details for congressional briefings and give you the three broad categories of assistance; aid for democracy, for development, and for demilitarization. We want to help democratic institutions take root in each country, but democracy begins with the rule of law and respect for human rights. It needs the support of courts that are fair and free of every influence but the law. It needs the support of police forces that are upright and honest, and it needs our support. Development and demilitarization, they go hand in hand. They start when we provide textbooks for children, when we create thousands of new jobs, when the hand that held a gun guides a plow. In short, as we demobilize the military we must mobilize the market. This is a great and historic task but we are inspired by the courage of our neighbors. We are close, very, very close to a hemisphere that is completely democratic, a compass of freedom that spans half the world from Alaska to Argentina. And facing this enormous challenge, we are not alone. Other nations can and must help, but only America can take the lead on this one. I stand prepared to work with the Congress to do our part for reconstruction and reconciliation for democracy. And now, I'd be glad to respond to questions, and Helen, I believe you have the first one. Q: Thank you, Mr. President. Your warm reception of the Rostenkowski plan, does that mean you're ready to negotiate tax increases and a freeze on Social Security benefits, things you have never gone for in the past? A: No, it doesn't. Q (Off mike.) A: The answer is no. Follow up. Q: Follow up? A: Yeah. Q:You are not willing to negotiate, or what is your -- A: Overall feeling? Look, I think he, without rancor, without a lot of rhetoric, made a very broad proposal. We've made a proposal - the administration. We now would like to hear from the budget process on the Hill, what their proposal is, and then we'll talk. But I - perhaps, as I told some reporters yesterday, I was being receptive though not knocking the things in it we don't like - and there are plenty - I was somewhat colored by the way in which Chairman Rostenkowski approached this, and with the, I think, evident good will on his part and determination to try to break the ice and move the process forward. We -- Q: You're not saying whether you would go for a tax increase or -- A: No, I'm not for a tax - let me - Q: - how about a freeze on Social Security? A: Well, there's a lot of things I'm not for that are in his proposal, a lot, including taxes. Yeah, Terry? Q: Mr. President, the United States has never recognized the forced incorporation of Lithuania into the Soviet Union. Now that Lithuania has declared its independence, the United States seems to be moving tentatively toward full recognition. Is that because we're afraid of offending Mr. Gorbachev or don't want to alienate him? A: It's because we want to see the evolution of the control of the territory there, and also, we want to see peaceful resolution to this question. Q: Well, do we still regard Lithuania as a captive nation, along with the other Baltic States? A: We might not use that word, but we never have regarded Lithuania as incorporated into the Soviet Union. That's been our policy. And we rejoice as people are permitted the free expression that we take for granted in this country, and clearly, I think there's a great deal of interest in this concept of working it out - Lithuanians working it out with the Soviets to achieve what they want. And so we're not standing in that way, but in terms of recognition, there is a standard of control of one's territory that we are - that I've been advised should guide this. Yeah, right here - go across and then back. Q: Mr. President, are you considered about the apparent reluctance of the contras to disband? And what can you do about it? A: Yes, I am concerned about it. I talked to - and I'm also concerned about certain military action by the Sandinistas. But I am also encouraged, Brit, and I am encouraged because yesterday I talked to Dan Quayle and he told me of his visit with Ortega, where Ortega seemed concerned about -- seemed willing to transfer the Defense Ministry, seemed willing to transfer the Interior Ministry, and was open about the discussion of reducing - I want to be careful here I don't overstate it -- but reducing military action on both sides. There is a United Nations vehicle that can be helpful, ONUCA. U-N-U-O-C-A? STAFF: O-N. A: O-N. ONUCA. O-N-U-C-A, which is - could have a useful role to play in the separation of forces and in getting done what Violeta Chamorro wants, which is to both sides start laying down their weapons. That ONUCA -(chuckles) - has got - has support from other leaders in this hemisphere. Carlos Andres Perez I believe supports it. I know Mrs. Chamorro wants us to give more support to this, so I will be - I've asked the State Department to look into that immediately. So I'm less concerned than I was about the peaceful transfer of power, including the military, but I think to the degree both sides can start laying down weapons and moving towards the kind of market economies we are talking about, and with less reliance on military, it's better. So I can't say I'm not concerned, but I am encouraged the way it's going so far. Q: Mr. President, do you regret the other day raising the issue of settlements in East Jerusalem? A: No, I don't regret it. I think - I think all the speculation and commentary of the last 10 days have blown things way out of proportion. What I was doing was reiterating United States policy. But let me say this. Right now in Israel, there's internal developments taking place in the political scene there, and I do not want to look.
