DOC.HEAD: Haitian Exiles Celebrate End of Avril's Leadership
With PM-Haiti Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Haitian exiles in Florida aren't sure about the woman chosen interim president of their homeland following the departure of a military leader, but they will go along with the majority, a community leader says. Haiti's latest ex-leader, Lt. Gen. Prosper Avril, left Haiti on Monday aboard an Air Force plane which brought him to Florida, where he apparently spent only a few hours before leaving for an undetermined location. A U.S. government official, speaking on condition he not be identified, said Avril left Florida. About 300 exiles gathered late Monday, according to police estimates. Many expressed cautious optimism about the latest government change which they hope will bring democracy to their Caribbean homeland. They were trying to learn more about Ertha Pascal-Trouillot, the Supreme Court judge designated by an opposition coalition to head a provisional civilian government in Haiti. The Rev. Gerard Jean-Juste, a longtime leader in the south Florida exile community that numbers at least 150,000, claimed Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot had ties to the former regime of dictator Jean-Claude ``Baby Doc'' Duvalier. But he added, ``If the Haitian people accept her, we will accept her. We will be very cautious.'' Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot's brother, jazz guitarist Alix Pascal, was shot in the back in Port-au-Prince in the late 1960s by a Tonton Macoute, the feared secret police of Francois ``Papa Doc'' Duvalier, Jean-Claude's father and predecessor. Pascal now lives in New York City. A group of Haitian exiles demonstrated briefly Monday afternoon outside the U.S. attorney's office, calling for an indictment of Avril. Dozens more gathered outside the Haitian Refugee Center in Miami's Little Haiti neighborhood, listening to radio reports and speakers. Most speakers called for Avril's capture, trial in Haiti and execution for allegedly ordering the slayings of civilians and opposition leaders. The Haitian military has been linked to shipments of South American cocaine to Florida, but there was no indication that U.S. authorities might charge Avril. ``As far as any charges are concerned, this office will attempt to bring an indictment if there is sufficient evidence and information to justify it. We strongly suggest that anyone that has such information turn it over to the DEA,'' said Diane Cossin, executive assistant to U.S. Attorney Dexter Lehtinen. The overall mood in Little Haiti seemed more anxious than boisterous after four years of instability and dashed hopes in their homeland. The mood contrasted with near-riotous celebrations that broke out on Feb. 7, 1986, when Duvalier fled Haiti to end his family's 29-year rule. ``Everybody is happy, but we are still watching,'' said Pierre Joseph, 30, who said he's been in Florida 10 years. ``Nothing changed yet. Maybe if we have elections, then it will change.''

DOC.HEAD: North Says He Saw Poindexter Tear Up Presidential Finding
DOC.NOTE: EDs: LEADS with 8 grafs North under cross-examination; picks up 4th graf, ``Not the ...
With LaserPhoto WX6
DOC.TEXT: John Poindexter's lawyer attempted today to undermine Oliver North's damaging testimony by confronting him with previous, conflicting statements he made in the Iran-Contra scandal. In cross-examining the former White House aide, Richard Beckler brought out North's earlier assertions that he was ordered to conceal his activities from Poindexter and others in 1984 and most of 1985. North testified at a pre-trial hearing three months ago he had been told to disclose his Contra-related activities only to then-national security adviser Robert McFarlane and then-CIA director William Casey. On Monday, North testified that ``I can't think of any'' information he kept from Poindexter, who didn't become national security adviser until the end of 1985. On Monday, North also testified that he watched Poindexter destroy a politically embarrassing presidential document. The destruction of the presidential paper depicting U.S. involvement in a straight arms-for-hostages deal with Iran was the most damaging testimony North gave Monday during his second day on the witness stand at Poindexter's trial. Today, on cross-examination, Beckler brought out that a succeeding presidential paper contained much the same language about U.S. hostages. The language in a succeeding paper ``indicates that one of the missions'' in the Iran arms sales ``was to ... further the release of American hostages,'' Beckler said. North readily agreed. On Monday, Iran-Contra prosecutor Dan Webb asked North, ``You were present when John Poindexter in his office ... ripped (the paper) into shreds?'' ``Not the way you describe,'' said North. ``You ... saw'' the former national security ``tear up the original finding?'' Webb asked. ``Tear it in two,'' replied North. ``He threw it in a waste basket behind his desk or put it in a burn bag?'' asked Webb. ``I think he just put it on his desk,'' replied North. The finding approved a November 1985 shipment of Hawk missiles to Iran. On the same day that he destroyed the finding, Poindexter told some House and Senate intelligence committee members he hadn't found out about the Hawk shipment until January 1986. ``Admiral Poindexter was well aware (of the Hawks shipment) ... he was aware because you kept advising him about it. Wasn't that right?'' asked Webb. ``Yes,'' replied North. President Reagan on Nov. 13, 1986, denied that the U.S. government was swapping arms for hostages, Webb noted, as he told North: ``This document (the finding) on its face made Ronald Reagan out to be making a false statement to the American people.'' ``I guess so,'' North replied. On cross-examining North, Poindexter's lawyer Richard Beckler tried to portray North as a mid-level staffer who was remote from the national security adviser. ``There are many things you did not tell your superiors,'' Beckler suggested while questioning the ex-National Security Council aide. ``I can't think of any right now,'' North replied, and later added, ``I tried to keep my superiors apprised.'' Until he was confronted with testimony he gave at his own trial last year, North maintained he didn't know his superiors were loath to use the finding as justification for the Hawks shipment. ``If I did, I surmised it,'' North said initially. Later, he agreed with his earlier testimony, in which he said ``the political people up the line from me, to include Admiral Poindexter ... did not want that finding to be used as a justification for what had happened in 1985.'' U.S. District Judge Harold Greene rebuked North several times for ``quibbles'' with Webb over minor facts and for repeatedly failing to remember significant ones. ``Almost every time a question is asked, he says he can't recall,'' the judge complained of North, who had been declared a hostile witness. ``It's like pulling teeth.'' North also said Poindexter approved his retrieving highly classified documents from National Security Council files on Nov. 21, 1986, which North then proceeded to alter and destroy with help from his secretary, Fawn Hall. North said former national security adviser Robert McFarlane directed him to make the changes in memos which North had written to McFarlane detailing North's military assistance to the Contras. ``Did you find'' McFarlane's request ``at all bizarre, strange?'' Greene asked North. ``These were his (McFarlane's) documents,'' replied North. ``These were not personal documents ... Mr. McFarlane's house mortgage,'' said Greene. ``You don't think that is at all strange?'' ``I think it was futile,'' said North. ``I'm not asking futile,'' said Greene. ``Is this what goes on at the National Security Council all the time? ``No, your honor,'' said North. Among the documents destroyed was a handwritten note by Poindexter suggesting that something be done to stop a Nicaraguan-bound shipload of military equipment.

DOC.HEAD: Winner of MTV Contest Crashes Car That Was Prize
DOC.TEXT: A man who won a $25,600 BMW in an MTV promotional contest was seriously injured in a one-car crash that demolished the car, authorities said. John D. Rogers, 23, was in critical condition in Grant Medical Center in Columbus after Sunday's one-car accident in which he lost control on a curve. The car went over an embankment, flipped over and Rogers was thrown out. It was not known if he was wearing a seat belt, said Lt. Dave Large of the Ross County Sheriff's Department. Rogers won the car in January in a contest sponsored by the cable music channel. He also won $150,000, which he put in a bank while continuing to work at odd jobs, his mother said.

DOC.HEAD: Testing of Experimental AIDS Vaccine to be Expanded
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 12th graf pvs, Directors of..., with two grafs to clarify that uninfected people are being sought only for California study, not FDA trials; picks up 13th graf pvs, Two other...
DOC.TEXT: Testing of an experimental vaccine on California AIDS patients will be expanded and extended to individuals who are infected with the AIDS virus but have not developed symptoms of the disease. The Food and Drug Administration on Monday granted permission for further testing of the vaccine developed by Dr. Jonas Salk. The vaccine, which uses an inactivated virus, is being tested as a treatment for AIDS rather than as an agent to prevent someone from acquiring the fatal disease, which destroys the body's ability to fight infection. Researchers are trying to find out whether the inactivated virus will cause the body to produce specific cells, called T cells, that destroy other cells infected with the human immunodeficiency virus, or HIV. They hope that by stimulating the immune system's response to HIV, the vaccine might halt or reverse spread of the virus in newly infected people _ those who have the virus but have not developed symptoms of AIDS or AIDS-related complex. ``This vaccine is for treatment'' of AIDS, said Dr. Janet Woodcock, director of the FDA's division of biological investigational new drugs. ``Use of this to prevent acquiring (AIDS) is a totally different question.'' But she added: ``Trials like this in the HIV-infected could yield information that could help design trials for the uninfected.'' Work has been accelerating on developing a vaccine to prevent AIDS, but such a vaccine is at least 10 years away from being marketed, she added. Under the FDA-approved plan, initial testing will involve about 60 people. During a 36-week trial, researchers will test different doses of the vaccine. The California trials, which is testing individuals who have AIDS, were approved under a state law that allows such testing strictly within California. FDA permission was required for the sponsor, Immune Products Ltd. of San Diego, to expand the trials to testing centers outside California. Directors of the California study are seeking Roman Catholic priests and nuns as volunteers to take the vaccine as a control group because of their celibate lifestyles. If any of those volunteers developed AIDS, it would be because the vaccine was flawed. In the FDA-approved trials, only people already infected with the virus will be able to participate in the testing. Two other vaccines, both genetically engineered, have been approved for human testing in HIV-infected individuals. The first, approved in August 1987, was made from an insect virus and developed by MicroGeneSys Inc. of West Haven, Conn. The second, made from the vaccinia virus and developed by Bristol-Myers-Squibb Co. of New York, was approved for human trials in November 1987. A genetically engineered vaccine uses pieces of the virus that are replicated and do not contain anything that could be infectious. Unlike those two, the Salk vaccine uses an inactivated virus that has been partially stripped of its envelope or surface proteins. Salk used a similar technique in developing the polio vaccine. Using an inactivated virus in an uninfected person carries the risk that some traces of the virus may still be live and could infect the person being vaccinated.

DOC.HEAD: Homes, School Evacuated After Acid Spill
DOC.TEXT: A tractor-trailer rig rolled over on Interstate 295 today, spilling hydrochloric acid that forced the evacuation of nearby homes and school offices while authorities sealed off the area and began a cleanup. By late morning, the leak had been plugged, according to a fire dispatcher. Nearby residents in Portland and Falmouth were evacuated because of the potential for toxic fumes from the acid, also known as muriatic acid, but officials had no immediate estimate of how many people left. ``We haven't been keeping count,'' said Portland Police Lt. Jim Stanhope. Authorities also had no estimate of the amount of acid spilled or how concentrated it was. The driver of the truck and a passerby who stopped to help her were taken to Maine Medical Center, but they were soon released, said state Department of Public Safety spokesman Stephen McCausland. The truck was owned by Road and Sea Transport Inc., of Hampden, and was headed for Rhode Island, said a company dispatcher, Steve Morgan, who said he had no additional information.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Adds last graf on further aid.
DOC.TEXT: Here are major elements of President Bush's aid package for Nicaragua and Panama. OVERALL FUNDS. Bush coupled a $300 million aid package to help Nicaragua speed the transition to democracy with a renewed request for $500 million in aid to Panama. He requested the Panama money earlier this year, but it got sidetracked in Congress on other issues. The Nicaragua and Panama money would be diverted from unspecified Pentagon programs. An existing $21 million would be used for emergency aid to Nicaragua, including food. Some of it would be used to help re-integrate the Contra rebels. TRADE. The president lifted a five-year-old trade embargo against Nicaragua. He also took steps to allow Nicaragua to resume shipping sugar to the United States and to make that nation eligible for duty-free treatment for a variety of other products. SUPPLIES. Some $60 million would be earmarked for providing critical agricultural supplies, petroleum and medical supplies. EMPLOYMENT PROGRAMS. $10 million would help pay for ``emergency employment programs,'' including ones designed to help turn soliders into farmers. RESETTLEMENT. Some $45 million would go toward helping speed the repatriation and resettlement of the U.S.-backed Contra forces and other refugees, and an additional $1 million would be used for technical assistance in restructuring the economy. INTERNATIONAL FINANCE. Some $50 million would be used to help Nicaragua pay off debt to the International Monetary Fund and other international financial institutions. An additional $75 million would go toward helping to prop up the Nicaraguan currency to help restructure the economy and aid the country with its balance-of-payments imbalance. PROJECTS. About $60 million would help pay for such projects as bridge, road and highay repair and refurbishing schools and hospitals. FURTHER AID. Bush said he would later propose an additional $200 million to be used in the fiscal year that begins next Oct. 1, with details to be announced later

DOC.HEAD: Voters Picking Gubernatorial Nominees in Texas
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts two grafs after the 8th graf, ``Mudslinging has...,'' to update with comment from Bush on drug issue. Picks up 9th graf, `In recent...'.
DOC.TEXT: Three Democrats waged a bare-fisted struggle for the gubernatorial nomination in today's primary, while a millionaire oilman making his first run for office was expected to win the GOP nomination outright. The final pre-election poll showed former Gov. Mark White, Attorney General Jim Mattox and Treasurer Ann Richards in a dead heat for the Democratic nomination, with Clayton Williams gaining more than half the Republican vote. Turnout was brisk this morning in Dallas and Fort Worth, and fair in Houston, said officials at polling places. In El Paso, voting was light in the first hour of balloting, said El Paso County election clerk Robert Rodriguez. The secretary of state's office predicted a turnout of 2.1 million to 2.6 million of the 8.3 million eligible voters, who can vote in either primary. Each party's choice needs more than 50 percent of the vote to avoid a runoff. Williams said if he wins outright and the Democrats are forced into a runoff April 10, he will relax and ``have some fun watching each of the Democrats murdering on each other.'' The winner in November will succeed Republican Gov. Bill Clements, who is retiring. Ms. Richards, known for her caustic keynote speech at the 1988 Democratic National Convention in which she said then-Vice President Bush was ``born with a silver foot in his mouth,'' held a slim lead in the latest poll. Mudslinging has been the mainstay of the Democratic campaign. Ms. Richards accused her rivals of profiteering from public service; they lashed out at her for refusing to say whether she has used illegal drugs. Bush, who maintains a residence in Houston, told reporters in Washington today that he voted in the Texas primary, and that he felt a candidate's past drug use should not necessarily be held against him or her. ``I think that's a matter for the voters to decide,'' Bush said. ``But in my view, if somebody used marijuana, some time ago, and is not into anything of that nature, why, no, I don't think that should be held against them.'' In recent days, Ms. Richards questioned how White could afford to move into a $1.3 million Houston estate after leaving the governor's mansion in 1987. She attacked Mattox for accepting $200,000 in contributions from Danny Faulkner, whose trial on charges of heading a scheme that cost lending institutions $500 million ended in a hung jury. Mattox, campaigning Monday in the Dallas neighborhood where he grew up, called Ms. Richards' charges ``scurrilous'' and said her refusal to answer the drug questions had led her ``into a really gutter-style campaign.'' White said he would have challenged Ms. Richards to a fistfight if she were a man. ``Everything she said is the greatest pack of lies I've ever heard,'' he said. Ms. Richards, a recovering alcoholic, has refused in three debates to answer yes or no when asked if she'd used illegal drugs. She said if she answered it might discourage people with drug problems from seeking help. A Houston Chronicle-Dallas Morning News poll published Sunday showed Richards favored by 28 percent of people who said they'd vote Democrat. The poll gave Mattox 25 percent and White 24 percent. The margin of error was 4.5 points. Williams, who describes himself as ``just a country boy,'' warned his supporters against complacency after the final poll showed him leading No. 2 Republican Kent Hance 55 percent to 13 percent. Two other GOP hopefuls _ Jack Rains of Houston and Dallas lawyer Tom Luce _ received 8 percent each. The margin of error was 5 points. ``I've been talking about those guys getting lost in my dust. I want to be sure our voters don't get lost in the dust,'' said Williams. His $8 million, television-savvy campaign included nearly $6 million from his own pocket. Voters were asked to choose nominees for dozens of other offices. In the U.S. Senate primary, Republican incumbent Phil Gramm was unopposed, and state Sen. Hugh Parmer faced Harley Schlanger, a follower of extremist Lyndon LaRouche, on the Democratic side. State GOP Chairman Fred Meyer said his party was focusing on the Democrat-controlled Legislature, which will control redistricting after the 1990 census. The census is expected to add three or four seats to Texas' 27-member congressional delegation.

DOC.HEAD: Freight Engine Rams Amtrak Train; 31 Injured
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 6 grafs to UPDATE injured total to 31, 2 grafs to UPDATE injuries, quote from police official, track cleared and service resumed; picks up 6th graf pvs: `Three passenger ...; DELETES final graf, `He said ... to remove outdated time estimate on track clearing.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto RA1
DOC.TEXT: A freight engine rammed an Amtrak train sitting at a station early today, injuring 31 people, officials said. Amtrak's northbound 19-car Silver Meteor, which runs from Florida to New York City, was about to leave with 471 passengers when it was hit at 1:23 a.m. by the engine pulling 96 freight cars, said Amtrak spokeswoman Pat Duricka. All of the injured were aboard the passenger train, said Lindsay Leckie, a spokesman for CSX Transporation, operator of the freight locomotive. ``It slammed me into the seat in front of me and then threw me back in my seat,'' said Mary Lou Henley of Lackawana, N.Y. Police Capt. Larry Wells said 31 people were treated at hospitals and were discharged to continue their journey. ``Most complaints were of back pain, neck injury and we had a few nosebleeds,'' Wells said. Wells said that by late morning the track had been cleared and rail service had resumed through the station. Three passenger coaches derailed but didn't turn over, Ms. Duricka said from Amtrak headquarters in Washington. The cause of the accident was not immediately known. Leckie said he didn't know how fast the locomotive was going, but one passenger said she had heard it was only mvoing at 3 mph. The passengers included college students returning from Florida vacations and 22 members of a high school French club destined for Canada from Red Springs. The club members from Flora McDonald Academy boarded the train in Fayetteville, said headmistress Elma Averitte. One student suffered whiplash but rejoined students on buses to New York, she said. ``We just had a student who was terrified of train rides and we assured her nothing would happen,'' Ms. Averitte said. ``We've got another group leaving for London today, but they're flying.'' ``It really wasn't that bad,'' said a 17-year-old member of the group, who gave only his first name, Jonathan. ``The girls freaked.'' Leckie said there were no injuries to the three-man crew of the switch train, a locomotive use to move freight cars around yard. He said the cars were being taken to a siding for cleaning and probably were empty. Most of the passengers boarded chartered buses en route to their destinations or to Washington, where they could board northbound trains, said Amtrak supervisor Sam Wilson.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
First Woman Inaugurated President of Haiti
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 14 grafs to recast, ADD details, quotes. Pick up 11th graf pvs, `But the...'
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) _ Supreme Court Judge Ertha Pascal-Trouillot was inaugurated by the army today to head Haiti's first civilian-led government since the fall of dictator Jean-Claude Duvalier in 1986. Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot becomes the first woman president in the Caribbean nation's tumultuous 186-year history. She was inaugurated a day after military leader Lt. Gen. Propsper Avril, pressured by widespread protests, resigned and left the country. The new president will serve with a 19-member advisory council until after the country's first free elections, which could take place in three to six months. ``I have accepted this heavy task in the name of Haitian women,'' Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot said. Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot, who was the only woman on the 12-member Supreme Court, was inaugurated by Maj. Gen. Herard Abraham, the army chief of staff, at the National Palace. The ceorse said. ``It's going better than we expected,'' Morse said. ``But we don't want to unduly raise expectations.'' The strike began last Wednesday in a dispute over wages and benefits. Teachers stayed away from class Monday despite a warning from the governor that they could be fired for striking in violation of state law. No immediate disciplinary action was taken. Union leaders have said they won't go back to work until Caperton calls a special legislative session to consider pay raises; the governor said he won't consider calling a special session until the teachers go back to work. In West Virginia, pay scales for teachers are set by the Legislature. Caperton met with Kayetta Meadows, president of the 16,000-member West Virginia Education Assocation, and Bob Brown, head of the 3,000-member West Virginia Federation of Teachers. Union officials said they had agreed not to discuss the content of the talks. Caperton was to make a ``major policy address'' on education tonight, his office said in a statement, but he postponed it until Wednesday because of the talks with the teachers. Pickets spread to 46 of the state's 55 counties Monday. The Department of Education said schools were closed today in 25 counties, open in 19 and mixed in 11 others. The number of teachers and students affected was not immediately available, said education spokeswoman Carolyn Spangler, but on Monday the strike idled nearly 150,000 of the state's 328,000 public school students. About 3,000 of the state's teachers are not unionized. Teachers picketed in shorts and T-shirts throughout the state, which enjoyed a sunny, 80-degree day. At Charleston's Capitol High School, only about 400 of the school's 1,300 students showed up. ``We've been wasting our time,'' said Shawna Adkins, a sophomore. ``All we do is watch movies, and we can do that at home.'' Outside Caperton's office, Keith Geiger, president of the National Education Association, addressed about 1,000 teachers. ``This isn't fun, but it is necessary,'' said Geiger, whose union is the parent of the WVEA. ``You must stick together until a resolution is there. It is not the time for individual decisions on how you should operate.'' West Virginia teachers average about $21,900 per year, less than in any state except Arkansas and South Dakota, according to the National Education Association. In Ohio County in the northern panhandle, classes were canceled after it was discovered most of the district's 47 buses had flat tires, said Superintendent H. Lawrence Jones. He said it was unclear who was responsible.

DOC.TEXT: Q: My Nicaragua question is, you are not proposing to Congress exactly where to cut in the defense budget, you're basically leaving that to them. Why don't you tell them where they should cut specifically? A: On offsets? Q: Yes. A: From the defense budget? Q: Why don't you say, ``Here's a B-2, take it and'' _ A: We are, we are doing that. And what I'm saying to them is _ Q: Where? A: Well, that's in negotiation up there. But what I've also said here is, ``If you're not willing to do it, give me the authority on March 27 and it'll be done like that.'' I am willing to do it. Q: Where? A: We're going to take the hits. We're negotiating with Congress now. Q: Why not tell the American people? A: We'll tell them on March 27, if they turn it to me. And right now, I don't know how much of it's confidential, but I'll let the Secretary of Defense answer the question. But we're _ there's _ I don't see any great secrecy in this. What we're trying to do is to give the Congress the ball and say, ``Here's what we recommend. Now, you, you know, tell us what you want to do, but don't go making a lot of add-ons. Do it the way we feel is necessary to keep the focus on Nicaragua and Panama.'' I think Congress has a very legitimate role here. But if they're not willing to fulfill it _ Lesley, we have no problem giving you a list that would take care of it just like that, but I think it's the Congress's role now to work with our people. Q: Why does Gephardt get under your skin so much? You've got an _ I don't know _ 80 percent approval rating. He makes a speech attacking you, and _ A: Well, what have I said? Now what would make you think _ (laughter) _ that he gets under my skin? Q: Well, he says you're not a strong leader _ A: Oh, I know _ Q: _ and all the people around you at the White House _ A: I know, that's so discouraging, but what _ (laughter) _ but what _ (with a laugh) _ but why do you think it gets under my skin? Q: (Off mike.) A: The honest answer is _ I know you won't believe this _ it doesn't. It doesn't. I think we're going in the right direction. We're talking substance and policy. I think the _ many in the Congress think that we are being responsive. But look, I expect that, I expect that kind of political criticism. But I think if you want to talk about the substance of his ideas, do I think it's a good idea to loan money to the Soviet Union today? No. We have no request for food aid to the Soviet Union _ do you just want to put it on a ship and send it over there? No, I don't think that's a particularly brilliant idea. But I don't want to knock the man, maybe he'll come upon a good idea one of these days. Yeah? (Laughter.) Q: The Nicaraguans and the Panamanians are expecting aid very soon. They are in urgent need of the aid _ A: Exactly. Q: _ and the Panamanians say that they cannot wait any longer. What can you do besides Congress? When can they expect something? A: I'm going to have this question replayed on Capitol Hill, because you're absolutely right, there is a sense of urgency. And I would like to take the opportunity here to encourage the movement in the Congress. We sent a proposal up on Panama. Now let's get going on it. Now we are coupling it with Nicaragua. Now let's going on it. The _ there is an urgency in Nicaragua, too. But Panama? Very urgent. And so we are going to _ we're going to keep _ keep pushing. But I think you are right on target with that hypothesis. Yes?

DOC.HEAD: Dense Fog Blamed in Flaming Pileup That Kills Three
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last three grafs, `Brown County...' to UPDATE with victim's identities. No pickup. ^By ROBERT IMRIE
DOC.TEXT: A ``white wall'' of fog and paper-mill smoke was blamed for a flaming, 52-vehicle pileup that killed three people and injured 30. ``It was just horrible, terrible. To hear the brakes squeal, the gas tanks explode, to hear the people screaming,'' said Harry Suppanz, 35, of Sturgeon Bay, a passenger in a truck that crashed and burned Monday morning. The chain-reaction collision took place on the Tower Drive Bridge, which carries Interstate 43 over the Fox River. Police Lt. Bob Boncher said an unprecedented combination of fog and smoke from three paper mills created a 100-foot-long ``white wall'' that reduced visibility to less than 10 feet. ``It was just like driving into a milk bottle,'' said fire Capt. Rolland Becker. Boncher said the crash started at 6:48 a.m. when two cars and a truck apparently slowed down because the drivers could not see once they hit the cloud. Crashes continued for 3 to 5 minutes before the smoke and fog lifted. ``Five minutes after I got there, you could see plain as day,'' Boncher said. Investigators said the combination of fog and smoke has never before occurred on the bridge, which opened in 1980. The line of smashed cars stretched about 450 feet. ``There were tires exploding and occasionally a gas tank was blowing,'' Becker said. Deputy Traffic Chief Robert Kreuser said more cars than normal would have been on the bridge because one of the city's four other spans over the Fox River was closed for repairs. He said the closed bridge normally carries 20,000 vehicles a day. The victims were killed in separate cars and were in the middle of the pileup, said Brown County Coroner Genie Williams ``I couldn't believe it when I saw only three did die,'' she said. ``It was amazing that many people got out.'' Police Capt. Larry Gille today said the victims had been identified as Jennie M. Strnad, 20, of Green Bay; Susan M. Chriske, 40, of Green Bay; and Terrance I. Mellberg, 40, of Manitowoc.

DOC.HEAD: New Knoxville Art Museum Names Director
DOC.TEXT: Richard Charles Muhlberger of the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York City has been appointed the first director of the $10.5 million Knoxville Museum of Art. Muhlberger, 52, of Springfield, Mass., was unanimously approved Monday by the museum's board, interim director Leigh Hendry said. Since 1987, Muhlberger has been vice director in charge of education at the Metropolitan Museum. Previously, he was director of the Museum of Fine Arts and the George Walter Vincent Smith Art Museum, both in Springfield. Muhlberger, who is finishing three books for the Metropolitan, is expected to start his new post in June. The Knoxville museum will have a grand opening March 25.

DOC.HEAD: Blind Man Arrested in Bank Robbery
DOC.TEXT: A blind man who handed a threatening note to a bank teller and collected $105 was arrested after he asked her to help him leave the building, police said. She refused. And 27-year-old Jeffery Lee Flournoy was taken into custody Monday by police who waited outside the busy downtown Bank of America branch in this northern California city. He was booked on suspicion of robbery. ``The first thing he asked is, `Are you the police?''' Lt. Reginald Garcia said. The branch manager called police while Flournoy, wearing dark glasses and using a cane, was in the bank. Garcia said the note to the teller read, ``I have a bomb so give me your money or the bomb goes off.'' There was no bomb. Flournoy made no attempt to flee when confronted by police. ``I think it really was his intention to get caught. As he was being led away, he said he had done it to publicize the plight of the homeless and handicapped,'' Garcia said.

DOC.HEAD: Report: AIDS Benefactor Fires Servant for Having Disease
DOC.TEXT: The servant of a socialite who helps raise funds to benefit AIDS patients says he was fired after contracting the disease, a newspaper reported Tuesday. For seven years, Tony Deleu worked as a cook, butler and maid for Frances Scaife in her 19-room co-op apartment on Manhattan's East Side, the New York Post reported. In a lawsuit filed last week in Manhattan Criminal Court, Deleu, 47, charged that Scaife sacked him once she found out he had been diagnosed with AIDS. Deleu charged that Scaife never paid into his health or unemployment insurance fund, leaving him destitute. He is seeking $1.5 million in damages and expenses. Mrs. Scaife's attorney, Jay Cohen, denied Deleu's charges. ``The claim she fired him over AIDS is baseless,'' Cohen said. ``She didn't know he had AIDS. She let him go because he couldn't perform his duties.'' Mrs. Scaife, 55, is the estranged wife of Richard Mellon Scaife, an heir to the Mellon family fortune. She is listed in the Social Register, is a friend of first lady Barbara Bush, and serves on a committee of the Pittsburgh AIDS Taskforce, the newspaper said.

DOC.HEAD: Medieval Museum Planned For Cathedral City
DOC.TEXT: A major museum focusing on life in medieval France is to be built next to the historic cathedral in Chartres, according to a plan presented Tuesday to Premier Michel Rocard. Chartres Deputy Mayor Georges Lemoine said after meeting with Rocard that the museum would feature exhibits dealing with religious art, literature, the Crusades, and daily life in the Middle Ages. He suggested the museum could be a center for symposiums on the Middle Ages and for performances, perhaps including concerts of Gregorian chants.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON: ...Yeah, Maureen?
DOC.TEXT: Q: Mr. President, last week, we learned that you were so concerned about the hostages that you were willing to take a questionable call, and it might have been from the Iranian president, and then, of course, you found out it wasn't. In response, Rafsanjani made a statement saying that you have been trying to get a hold of him for a month. Did you actually then try to place a call t the real person, or could you clarify _ A: I don't know where he got that. I saw that statement, and it was _ it was _ there were no truth in it. Our trying to contact him for a month _ it'd be very easy to do. I responded to an incoming call. I think the bottom-line is, you have to say, would you do it again based on the information you had? And I'd say, yeah, I probably would. It may be difficult for somebody to get through again, but _ (laughter) _ but what's wrong with reaching out and touching someone when the hostages are at stake? The hostages are at stake here, and what's wrong with trying? And I _ look, I feel this all the time. I've talked about this, that I will go the extra mile. And when the whole story comes out on this, you all are going to be very, very fascinated with the details, very fascinated. Q: Tell us! Q: What is _ A: But I'm just telling you that it is important _ it is very important to run down every avenue in terms of these hostages, and I would be remiss if I didn't. And there are things that go on, going around in back alleys and trying to find out information, and we've got to do that. I owe it to the families of those people and to those people themselves that are held hostage. Q: Can I follow up, Mr. President? A: Yeah. Q: If you didn't try to reach him for a month, can you say whether you or anyone acting on your behalf did try to reach him at all? A: Have we been trying to reach Rafsanjani? Q: Have you tried, yes? A: No, other than this one _ one phone call that turns out to be a hoax. Q: So, as far as you can tell, what he was saying just didn't make any sense? A: Yeah, it's very much like the rhetoric that they use from time to time. He's got some political problems at home, and we understand that. The main thing is can we move forward and get the hostages out. And I will repeat, good will begets good will. And I think that _ I think that I am satisfied that even in this instance the officials there know that nobody is trying to set them up or anything of that nature. I am interested in saving American lives. Q: Mr. President, I understand that TASS is reporting this morning this morning that the Soviet Parliament has granted President Gorbachev the expanded powers he wants and has been requesting. I am interested, sir, if you side with those within the Soviet Union who fear that there are not sufficient checks and balances on this new presidential system, that it could result in a more totalitarian Soviet Union? How do you feel this might affect your dealings with Gorbachev and whether you envision extending this fund for democracy, perhaps one day, to the Soviet Union itself? A: I speak _ I answer that by saying I stay out of the internal affairs and deliberations of the Soviet Union. And they are going through a process of reform, which we support in broad terms, perestroika. They are going through a process of glasnost, which is openness, which we support. And it would be very inappropriate for the President of the United States to start passing judgment as that process of perestroika, democratization, if you will, moves forward. And so, yes, the Soviets have created a new post of president, I hear, but that's their business. And we will work with the _ in this instance, President Gorbachev. As you know, I think we have a reasonably good relationship there, respectful one, and I'm going to continue to work with him. Q: Can you say, sir, whether you think that as you continue to work with him, that will be affected in any way by these changes that have taken place or is it going to be as it has been between you and Mr. Gorbachev, and would you see involving the Soviet Union in this Fund For Democracy? A: Involving, you mean asking them to give money to _ Q: No, no, no, no, no. Including them, making them _ if not currently, as Gephardt has suggested _ perhaps one day a beneficiary of this Fund For Democracy.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON: ...For Democracy.
DOC.TEXT: A: I think the answer is to help in a technical way as best we can for moving _ helping the Soviets move towards market economies and free markets and those kinds of consideration. I think that's the next step we ought to take. And I _ you know, there's discussion of an Eastern Development Bank. The question is out there whether the Soviets should be members of that bank or not, and as a matter of fact, we have some deliberations going on as to what the U.S. position should be right now. I'm not prepared to state it, but I've been spending some time on this question. But it's _ that's an idea that was surfaced by Francois Mitterrand, I believe. So there are all kinds of ways in which down the road we could work with the Soviet Union. But I think what they need now from us is know-how and technical knowledge, that kind of thing. Yeah, Dave? Q: Mr. President, after your meeting in Palm Springs with Prime Minister Kaifu, he took a real beating in the Japanese Diet, and I wonder if in retrospect, were there any misunderstandings in your conversations? He was accused in Japan by his critics of having made some concessions or reached a level of detail in your discussions that some in Japan were unhappy with. Could you _ is there any clarification needed about what came out of Palm Springs? A: You know what? I think those reports just highlight the sensitivity of the situation in Japan and I think as far as I'm concerned the talks were very good. We followed up, incidentally, with close to an hour with Mr. Takeshita yesterday and covered the same broad agenda. I didn't go into every specific, but I'm convinced that both Mr. Kaifu left Palm Springs and Takeshita will leave Washington with a far better understanding of the problems that we face. And hopefully, I have a better understanding of theirs. So I think I'm aware of the criticism against him at home, but I think that I would just go back to the statements he made when he left Palm Springs, which I viewed as very constructive. Q: Just one followup. You said in a speech the day after you got back to the Electronics Association that you had discussed telecommunications with him, and that apparently came as a surprise to some people in Japan. Was that a brief discussion, a lengthy one? A: A broad discussion of several categories and the only _ I don't know in terms of the amount of time, but all these were _ we left the details of all of these categories that are so well-known as differences between the US and Japan to the experts. In fact, I think Bob Mosbacher will be going there soon, if he's not already on his way. And so it was more broad in general but categories mentioned, yes. Q: Do you still expect the summit with Mr. Gorbachev will take place in Washington the last two weeks of June? A: We've got to get that set soon in terms of pin down the dates and the place. But in terms of expectation, yes. Ellen? Q: Mr. President, the announcement no one wants to hear, the delay of baseball's opening day is imminent. Is there anything that you as the ``First Fan'' can do _ (laughter) _ to bring the sides closer together to prevent a tragic delay of the baseball season? A: You know, I made a comment on that yesterday and I misspoke, because I said, ``strike,'' and we, understandably, got some calls from some of the ballplayers saying, ``Hey. That's not technically what the situation is, please.'' Yes, I'm a ball fan and I want to go to the opening game someplace. Last year I went to the American League. This year I would like to the National League, if possible. I don't know whether it's going to work, maybe going to end up in Baltimore. But I want to see _ I don't want to intervene _ we've already taken a battle on that up there on another labor matter _ have the federal government intervene. But I would simply appeal to both sides to get the matter resolved so the American people can hear that cry, ``Play ball again.'' Yeah, Ellen?

DOC.HEAD: Karpov, Timman Adjourn Fourth Game
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 6-7 ``Karpov varied ...'' with 2 grafs to DELETE reference to king, and clear garble; SUBS grafs 9-10 with 1 graf to recast.
DOC.TEXT: Anatoli Karpov and Jan Timman adjourned their fourth game Tuesday in the World Chess Championship Candidates Final match after 61 moves. The two players will resume play Thursday with Timman to move. Grandmasters analyzing the game were divided in their assessment of the position. Ian Rogers of Australia believed Timman, playing black, was in a better position, but Im Ligterink and Grandmaster Oleg Romanishin said it was unclear. Karpov's second believed Timman had a slight advantage after 30 moves. The position was so complex that Karpov was in serious time trouble after 51 moves. The players had to make 40 moves each in the first two hours and another 20 moves in an hour. Although they managed to meet the two time controls, experts believe the players missed the best possible continuations. In the opening, the two grandmasters followed the Gruenfeld Defense, which they played in the second game. Karpov varied on move 9 by castling, instead of moving Bg5. This was seen as an improvement from the second game and Timman had to defend a very difficult position. But the Dutch grandmaster managed to equalize on move 25 when he put his pawn on e5, offering a pawn on the d-file. Karpov declined, apparently thinking it too dangerous to accept the sacrifice. The winner of this match will move on to meet Garri Kasparov for the world title in Lyons, France in October. Karpov leads the series 2-1, having won the first game and drawn games 2 and 3. Karpov and Timman are to play a 12-game match. The winner will be the first player to reach a score of 6{ points. For Wednesday's game 5, Timman will play white.

And do you view that as a useful means of expressing the plight of the Panamanian people as they wait _ A: Well, I have not talked to him since the fast began, and I did note with interest some very supportive statements out of him after the fast began, supportive of our administration and what we're trying to do. And one of the problems a lot of congressmen say they're having is that foreign aid at this time is not a high priority for a lot of people. What do you _ do you think an appeal, first of all, to ordinary Americans is necessary? And what do you say to people who think that perhaps what may be seen as the first part of a peace dividend is going overseas? A: I think you put your finger on a good point. I think they see a lot at stake for us in a totally democratic hemisphere and the success of democracy in Nicaragua. Q: Do you feel we particularly owe it to the people of those two countries, given our military activities in both Nicaragua and Panama? A: Do we owe _ do we owe support? Q: Do we owe money? A: I don't think _ I think we're _ well, we've lifted the embargos and we've released the funds; so to the degree there's anything owed, we're trying to comply with that. But what I'm proposing here is an investment in democracy. I don't think anybody would say _ you know, argue _ have the American people try to believe that we owe it. But it's the right thing to do. And we want to see Violeta Chamorro supported and we want to see the Panamanian democracy succeed. So, that's the way I'd phrase it. Q: Mr. President _ Q: Let me ask you about one _ Q: Mr. President _ A: I have a meeting with the Congress at 10:45, and I don't want to get _ I mean 9:45. 9:45. Sorry, accept the correction, please. Q: It's primary day in Texas, Mr. President. Can you tell us two questions? One _ A: Now we're talking. (Laughter.) Q: _ for whom you voted in the Republican primary. Can you go back over it for us? A: This is election day in Texas. I did vote in the Texas Republican primary. I will not tell you who I voted for. I hope everybody understands. Otherwise, we'd have a quiz around here of who we voted for earlier on. It's not a proper question to _ to reveal.

Q: What about the differences reported between Secretary Cheney and CIA Director Webster over the threat assessment if _ A: Just a minute. Q: _ in the event that Gorbachev is thrown from power? A: Just one minute on that one. As I have said before _ (laughter and the president laughs) _ I don't see any real disagreement here. (Laughter.) No _ (laughs) _ I tried to answer that yesterday and I expect I didn't _ didn't lay it to rest. But I don't think anybody believes, including Cheney, that the Soviet system is going to go back to where it was in _ you know, before 1980 and the middle of the '80s. But there are differences when you go to try to predict with accuracy, based on intentions. And so, I've talked to them now and I feel that they are pretty close together. And I _ it's difficult when you have a fast changing world and yet you take a position like I do: We must retain a credible defense. Then, you get into a big debate, well what is ``credible,'' and I think that's what you are seeing here. So, I can tell you, having talked to these gentlemen, I don't think that there is this enormous defense difference between the intelligence community _ and I say ``community,'' or _ and the Secretary. I think we have come up with a prudent, well thought out defense plan. And there will be changes, I am sure, after our cooperation with and consultation with Congress. But, believe me, these are not diametrically different views that you are reading about. Q: Mr. President? A: Shall we end with this one? I really do have a 9:45. What are you going to do with those? There has been some indication that you have already given 1,000 tanks from Europe, out of that surplus, to Egypt. If you keep on giving these _ and selling them on credit, these arms that we have, you're going to keep on creating wars in the Third World and other nations. A: One of the _ Q: Mr. President, would you do this at the microphone? A: Right here? This is a depart _ (laughter). One of the things that is part of the negotiations on CFE is destruction of weapons, and so that is _ and we're talking about significant numbers. And I had a meeting yesterday with Jim Woolsey, our CFE negotiator, and he was spelling out for me just the mechanical difficulties of doing this. But, nevertheless, we are determined that that will be the approach that's taken with these massive numbers of weapons. We still have security needs that we feel are enhanced by transfer of military equipment, sales of military equipment to friendly countries. But, we're _ so the policy will remain as it is, but we will go forward with the destruction where that is a part of the policy. Thank you all very much. Thank you.
