Congress Approves New Presidency
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs to UPDATE with quote, clarify that Supreme Soviet did not consider the party role and property measures. Pick up 11th pvs, `Lithuanians had...'
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Congress of People's Deputies today approved Mikhail S. Gorbachev's plan for a stronger presidency, a post the Soviet leader says is essential to hold the country together as his reforms go forward. The Congress, the country's top legislative body, also scrapped the clauses of the constitution that guarantee the Communist Party's leading role in society, which would create a multiparty system. It also legalized private ownership of factories. ``We are standing before the greatest, most meaningful step in the history of our government,'' Gorbachev told the parliament. ``This is the first step toward a Western political system,'' said deputy Fyodor Burlatsky. Later today, the deputies were expected to nominate Gorbachev to a four-year term as president, then decide whether the Congress or the public would elect the new president. It is expected that after the initial four years, the term would become five years and the president would be popularly elected. The lawmakers approved the measure on the presidency by a vote of 1,817 to 133, with 61 abstentions, the official Tass news agency said. A two-thirds majority of the 2,250-member Congress of People's Deputies was required for the motion to pass. Deputies broke into applause when the bill passed. The measures on the presidency had earlier been approved by the Supreme Soviet, the smaller parliament that handles day-to-day business, after making significant alterations. The vote on scrapping the party's leading role passed in the Congress by a vote of 1,771 to 164, with 74 abstentions. Gorbachev has argued the more powerful presidency is needed to keep the Soviet Union intact as he presses ahead with his reforms while facing a crumbling economy and growing independence movements. Lithuanians had been so dismayed by the proposal on the more powerful presidency that they rushed to declare independence before it passed on Sunday. Estonia, Latvia and Georgia have all taken moves in that direction. His victory on the proposal came despite a boycott by a group of progressive deputies worried about placing too much power in the hands of one person in a country with a history of dictatorship. The vote on the presidency bill also was boycotted by representatives of several independence-minded republics, who said the president would be too strong for the loose federation of independent nations they see as the future Soviet Union. Abstaining had the same effect as voting no, because Gorbachev was struggling to put together the two-thirds majority needed for constitutional amendments. To succeed today, Gorbachev backed off some demands that had disturbed legislators from some republics, who felt he would have too much power. Those demands included the president's right to declare on his own a state of emergency and to suspend the parliaments of the republics. The presidency bill creates a chief executive who can propose legislation, veto laws passed by the Supreme Soviet legislature, declare war or martial law, and overrule cabinet members. Vice President Anatoly Lukyanov said Monday it also clearly separates executive and legislative powers for the first time. The historic change in Article 6 of the Soviet Constitution drops language defining the Communist Party as the ``leading and guiding force of Soviet society and the nucleus of its political system, of all state organizations and public organizations.'' The new article reads, ``The Communist Party of the Soviet Union, other party, trade union and youth organizations, other social organizations and mass movements, shall participate, through their representatives elected to the Soviets of People's Deputies as well as in other ways, in shaping the policies of the Soviet state and in running the state and social affairs.'' An effort to drop the words ``Communist Party'' from the article entirely received 1,067 votes in favor to 906 against but fell short of the necessary two-thirds majority. Earlier today, Gorbachev said a legislative commission was studying the Lithuanian independence declaration and that he would consider the status quo not to have changed ``until the entire situation is cleared up.'' ``We welcome the fact that deputies from all the republics, including Lithuania, are in attendance,'' he said. On Monday, another member of the Communist Party's ruling Politburo, Yegor K. Ligachev, said Moscow would not use force in Lithuania. Soviet Vice President Anatoly Lukyanov introduced the latest draft of the presidency proposal Monday by promising, ``There is no reason to believe that the institution of the presidency would lead to alleged authoritarian power.'' Lukyanov said the bill creates checks and balances between the executive and legislative branches of power. He said it allows Congress to recall the president for breaking the law and restricts the passage of legislation to the Congress and the Supreme Soviet, the standing legislature. The current constitution allows the leadership of the Supreme Soviet _ which Gorbachev heads _ to issue decrees. Throughout Monday, deputies huddled with Gorbachev and each other seeking compromises. Several of the independence-oriented republics have adopted constitutional amendments allowing them to suspend Soviet laws on their territory. Gorbachev supporter Sergei Alexeyev argued that the Soviet Union is ``in a paralysis of power,'' and ``the presidency is the only way to transfer the real power from the (Communist) party to the government.'' If the presidency issue is resolved positively, ``we can get down to drafting a new constitution immediately which will confirm human rights, democracy and conversion to a market economy,'' Alexeyev said. But Yuri Afanasyev, a leader of a group of progressive deputies, urged that the presidency be adopted only in conjunction with a new constitution, direct election of the president, real opposition parties and freedom of the press.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Names Amend to Communications Post
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Tuesday named Deborah Amend, a Republican campaign official, as a special assistant for communications. She has worked at the National Republican Congressional Committee since 1985, most recently as a deputy campaign director. She is a former press secretary to Rep. Clay Shaw, R-Fla., and a deputy press secretary to Sen. Bob Packwood, R-Ore.

DOC.HEAD: Five Children Killed in Apartment Fire
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with quotes from witnesses, neighbor, firefighters and public officials, further details. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A predawn fire that drove back would-be rescuers killed five young children on the second floor of their apartment while horrified neighbors in their housing project watched helplessly. ``That little boy was standing in the window. He was burning and he was yelling, `Help me, Help me,' said neighbor Angela Briggs. ``He was beating on the window.'' The Somerset Circle apartments fire was reported at 2:34 a.m. by a passing Town of Madison police officer who attempted to enter the unit but was driven back by smoke, heat and fire, said Police Chief Wayne Romeis. Residents of the rent-subsidized complex also tried to enter the apartment. ``There were a couple the officers had to physically restrain from going in,'' Romeis said. Firefighters entered the burning townhouse and carried out the children but could not revive them, officials said. Lysundra Alawiye said the children lived with their 28-year-old mother, Cheryl Robinson. ``They were very nice kids,'' she said. The victims, all brothers and sisters, included Derek Robinson, 9; Kenneth Jones, 5; Ebony Robinson, about 3; Mark Robinson, an infant; and an unidentified girl, age 20 months. Police did not know whether any adults were in the apartment before the fire broke out. Romeis said the mother refused to give officers a statement. Town of Madison Fire Chief Keith Tveit said the fire apparently began in a kitchen at the rear of the apartment and engulfed the first floor. Firefighters brought the fire under control in about 90 minutes, Tveit said. The fire destroyed the end apartment of the building's six two-story units. Tveit, who estimated damage at $75,000, said a fire wall prevented the blaze from spreading, but there was smoke and water damage to the adjacent unit. Romeis said local authorities and the state fire marshal were investigating the cause of the fire. Max Uttech, director of public works for the town of Madison, said the building had been inspected in recent weeks by his department and by the Dane County housing authority, and no violations were reported. Tveit said town records showed smoke alarms in the complex were working when they were inspected by Dane County officials Feb. 8. He said fire officials did not immediately know if they worked today.

DOC.HEAD: Mongolian Communists Go Into Overtime
DOC.TEXT: The Central Committee of Mongolia's Communist Party met late into the night on Tuesday as a record number of members vied to make speeches on proposed sweeping political changes. Foreign Ministry spokesman Tepbishiin Chimeddorj said most of the Central Commmitee's more than 120 members had lined up to make speeches, forcing its special plenary session into overtime. The meeting, which began Monday, was expected to continue through Wednesday and possibly even Thursday. The committee is expected to ratify the ruling Politburo's decisions Monday to abolish the party's constitutional guarantee on power, replace the Politburo and party General Secretary Jambyn Batmonh, hold early legislative elections and write a new constitution. Chimeddorj said reformists and conservatives in the leadership were debating the dramatic moves, and those in favor far exceeded opponents. Mongolia's fledgling opposition groups, whose demonstrations since January accelerated this pastoral country's retreat from Stalinist-style communism, held separate meetings Tuesday to plan strategies and improve their organization in preparation for the expected legislaltive elections. ``We have a lot of work to do,'' said Nandad Orkmon, a member of the executive committee of thte Social Democrat movement. ``I am studying right now the American system. I have some English books and I am also studying the systems of other Western countries. Still, we don't understand exactly how they work.'' The Social Democrats, along with Mongolia's two other opposition parties _ the Mongolian Democratic Party and the National Progressive Party that was formed only Tuesday _ said it was too early to name candiates for the legislature or presidency. Another Social Democrat leader, R. Gonchigdorz, said it was impossible to analyze what was going in inside the closed Central Committee meeting of the ruling party. Some opposition party members suggested it was only the aging members of the ruling Communist Party who were dragging their feet on reform. However, none was able to identify these members by name. The internal workings of the party have been secret for so many decades that nobody is sure how the factions are lined up, they said. Chimeddorj has said it too soon to give details on what form the new national leadership would take. Chimeddorj said Central Committee members had been arguing behind closed doors about the reform proposals and ``practically nobody'' opposed them. ``In general, we can say in the Central Committee there are radicals and conservatives. They are arguing, but the viewpoints of the conservatives also are changing.'' The Social Democrats and other opposition parties are pressing for legislative elections to be held in June or July. Chimeddorj said the Central Committee was considering whether to ask the legislature, the Great People's Hural, to hold a vote of confidence on Batmonh, who also is president, and Premier Dumaagiyn Sodnom. Both the New Progressives and Social Democrats expressed support for Batmonh continuing as president during what they referred to as a transition period, during which democratic institutions are to be established. A small group of members of the official Communist Party's youth league held a small demonstration Tuesday outside the league's headquarters. Speakers said they opposed the youth league's close ties with the party. About 200 people listened to the hour-long rally, but there was little applause. One demonstrator, a student who identified himself only as Batbold, said, ``all the young students and workers want radical reform in the youth league, but the league's Central Committee wants only to change the name.'' He said he and many other youth league members planned to turn in their membership cards and form an alternative youth organization.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Ends Trade Embargo Against Nicaragua
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS new 19th graf, Defense Department, with Pentagon statement on sources of funds.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush today lifted a five-year trade embargo against Nicaragua and asked Congress to provide $300 million quickly to help speed the transition to democracy. He said the funds should come from the Pentagon budget. Bush also renewed his call for $500 million in assistance to Panama, where an American invasion force installed a new government last December. He said both Central American nations ``need our help to heal deep wounds'' after years of political and economic struggle. Bush's 45-minute news conference coincided with a vote by the Soviet Congress granting Mikhail Gorbachev stronger powers as president. Bush said it would be ``very inappropriate'' for him to pass judgment on the process of reform in the Soviet Union. It was the first time in 10 days that Bush had met with reporters, and in fielding numerous questions, he said: _He remains opposed to higher taxes and Social Security limitations to eliminate the budget deficit. But he said he was ``prepared to negotiate'' with congressional Democrats over a deficit-cutting plan. _``Every president'' wants to see interest rates lower, but he denied the existence of a ``bubbling war'' with Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve. _He was disappointed that the Communist government in China has not made progress toward democratic reforms but said ``I have no regrets'' about the administration's China policy. _Appealed to major league owners and ball players to settle their labor dispute ``so the American people can hear that cry `play ball' again.'' _Said a long-ago use of marijuana shouldn't disqualify a political candidate. The question arose in the context of a political flap in Texas where Ann Richards, who is seeking the Democratic gubernatorial nomination, has refused to say whether she ever used illegal drugs. Bush also showed his zest for political combat when he said of House Democratic leader Richard Gephardt, a frequent critic, ``I don't want to knock the man. Maybe he'll come up with a good idea one of these days.'' Bush was asked about the telephone call he held several days go with the man who he thought _ incorrectly _ was Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani. The president admitted it was a ``hoax,'' but said, ``What's wrong with reaching out and touching someone.'' ``The hostages are at stake,'' he said. Bush said things are going on in ``back alleys'' involving the fate of the eight American hostages. He stressed his determination to do all he could to free them. The longest held hostage, Associated Press reporter Terry Anderson, will mark his fifth anniversary in captivity on Friday. The president opened his news conference by announcing that he had lifted the five-year trade embargo that former President Reagan had imposed against the Sandinista government of Daniel Ortega. Ortega was defeated in last month's elections by opposition candidate Violetta Chamorro. Ortega told Vice President Dan Quayle in Chile on Monday that he would abide by the results of the elections and permit an orderly transition to democracy. Bush called for creation of a ``Fund for Democracy'' to assist Nicaragua and Panama. He also said he will seek an additional $200 million in economic assistance for Nicaragua in fiscal year 1991, which begins Oct. 1. The $300 million would be for immediate use. Bush afterwards briefed Republican congressional leaders on his aid package. Rep. Duncan Hunter, R-Calif., chairman of the House GOP Research Committee, said the president expressed concern on getting the U.S. aid to those who need it the most. Defense Department spokesman Pete Williams said $81 million of the money for Nicaragua would come from deferral of construction at bases being considered for closing, $83 million from a freeze of civilian personnel of the department, $11 million from cancellation of repair work on the turret of the USS Iowa, $69 million from savings due to improvements in the engines of KC-135 airplanes, $30 million from delay in submitting an anti-submarine warfare package, $18 million from not going ahead immediately with a proposed mobile armored reconaissance vehicle, and $9 million from an abandoned plan for replacement of NATO frigates. The president never mentioned the Contras, the rebels who received millions of dollars from the United States during the Reagan administration. But his aid request includes about $45 million to help pay costs of relocating some 10,000 Contra rebels and tens of thousands of family members from camps along the Honduran border to homes inside Nicaragua. Bush urged Congress to speed the aid on its way by April 5 and to assist the administration in identifying Pentagon programs that could absorb the needed reductions ``without having an unacceptable impact on national security.'' At another point, however, he said he was prepared to submit a list of suggested Pentagon cuts on his own. ``It will be done like that,'' he said, snapping his fingers for emphasis. Bush's plan for aid to Panama has been bogged down in Congress over the issue of which programs would lose money to finance the assistance. Bush called Mrs. Chamorro on Monday to brief her about the aid package, a source said. The president paid tribute to the extraordinary worldwide move toward democracy in 1989, and said the drive for freedom ``leaves us with a new challenge, how best to support newborn democracies.'' ``These nations need our help to heal deep wounds,'' he said. On other topics, Bush responded with a blunt ``no'' when asked whether he would freeze Social Security benefits or raise taxes to reduce the federal deficit. A senior House Democrat made such proposals last weekend as part of a comprehensive deficit-cutting plan. Bush said his administration had an encouraging response to the plan by Rep. Dan Rostenkowski, D-Ill., because it showed ``evident goodwill.'' He said that despite his distaste for some specifics, he was ``prepared to negotiate'' with Congress to reduce the deficit. ``There's a lot of things that I'm not for that are in his proposal. A lot including taxes,'' the president said. Asked if the administration would recognize a drive for independence by the Soviet Republic of Lithuania, Bush said, ``We want to see the evolution of the control of the territory there.'' Bush said the Soviet Union had not requested direct U.S. aid and he criticized Gephardt for proposing such assistance. Responding to Gephardt's criticism that he was running an administration guided by public opinion polls, Bush said, ``I don't want to knock the man. Maybe he'll come up with a good idea one of these days.'' On a sensitive economic issue, Bush also declined to be drawn into speculation about whether he would reappoint Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, whose term expires next year. Some members of the administration have said Federal Reserve concerns about inflation have kept interest rates relatively high. ``Look, every president would like to see interest rates lower, there's no question,'' Bush said. ``There's no bubbling war with Alan Greenspan.'' He said such disputes over economic policy are common in every administration. Asked about the major league baseball dispute, Bush said, ``Yes I'm a ball fan and I want to go to the opening game some place,'' he said. But he quickly added he didn't want to have the federal government intervene'' in the decision by owners to lock players out of spring training camps. Even before Bush formally unveiled the Nicaragua aid package, there was support in Congress for the assistance. ``After 10 years of trying to destroy Nicaragua, we do have a responsibility to help democracy,'' said Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., chairman of the Senate Appropriations subcommittee that doles out foreign aid. critical agriculture, petroleum and medical supplies; $10 million for emergency employment programs; $50 million to help Nicaragua pay off debts to the International Monetary Fund and other financial institutions; $75 million to help support Nicaragua's currency as part of economic restructuring; $60 million for infrastructure projects including major bridgem highway, school and hospital repairs, as well as the $45 million for the repatriation and resettlement of the Contras. The White House said $21 million left over from programs to assist the Contras and monitor the Nicaraguan elections would be used for emergency aid to Nicaragua while the larger package goes through Congress.

DOC.HEAD: Shuttle Atlantis Resumes Trip Back to Florida
DOC.TEXT: The space shuttle Atlantis' journey back to Kennedy Space Center in Florida resumed today despite poor weather along the flight route, NASA officials said. A modified Boeing 747 with Atlantis bolted atop took off from Biggs Army Airfield in far western Texas en route to a refueling stop at Columbus Air Force Base in Mississippi, said NASA spokesman Bruce Buckingham. A military transport plane took off 45 minutes ahead of the shuttle transport to check on the weather, Buckingham said. Forecasters reported rain, poor visibility and low clouds along much of the route, Buckingham said. Rain is a threat to the shuttle's exterior heat-insulating tiles. Based on weather observations during the three-hour refueling stop at Columbus, a decision was to be made whether to continue on to Cape Canaveral, Fla., a two-hour flight, Buckingham said. The shuttle and its transport landed at Biggs on Sunday for refueling after leaving Edwards Air Force Base, Calif., where Atlantis landed March 4 following a 4{-day military mission. Buckingham said the delays would not affect Atlantis' next flight scheduled in July, another secret Pentagon mission.

DOC.HEAD: Butcher Regains Leads After Crossing Ice
DOC.TEXT: Three-time winner Susan Butcher pushed into the lead of the Iditarod Trail Sled Dog Race again today during the treacherous crossing of ice-covered Norton Sound on the Bering Sea. And after a short rest she and her team took off on the final 171 miles of the 11,058-mile race from Anchorage to Nome. Race observers expect the winner to reach Nome on Wednesday evening. Of the 70 teams that began the race in Anchorage on March 3, seven have scratched and another was disqualified because of sick dogs. Butcher left the Shaktoolik checkpoint late Monday eight minutes behind defending champion Joe Runyan, but had passed him by the end of the nighttime 30-mile ice crossing today and had built a 55-minute lead. The mushers head out onto the ice of Norton Sound trying to save time and miles, but it is one of the most dangerous segments of the race. Open water leads in the ice can force time-consuming detours, or swallow an unwary team. ``Once they get onto the (Bering Sea) ice, they can expect sudden storms and an ample supply of wind,'' Gail Somerville, an Iditarod spokeswoman in Anchorage, said Monday night. Named for an abandoned gold-mining town along the trail, the Iditarod was started in 1973 to commemorate the 1925 emergency delivery of life-saving diphtheria serum from Anchorage to Nome by sled dog teams. The winner will get $50,000 and the rest of a $200,000 purse will be split among the next 19 finishers.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Replaces dropped number in 6th graf `Q: Mr. President ...' to 80 percent, sted 0 percent.
DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON: ...hypothesis. Yes?
DOC.TEXT: Q: Mr. President, there was a report last week that you are so angry and upset at the Fed's failure to lower interest rates that you wouldn't reappoint Chairman Greenspan next year when his term ends. Can you comment on whether there is any thought you've given yet to the question of reappointing Mr. Greenspan, and the level of frustration you do feel about interest rates? A: No, there is no discussion of that nature at all. I didn't _ I _ sure, I saw the report. I saw some speculation someplace. Maybe it was on a _ on the TV. But I have no _ that's never been discussed with me. Now, if the question is am I happy with interest rates? Look, every president would like to see interest rates lower. There's no question. I don't _ I don't knock the concern that some have on inflation. A president has to be concerned about inflation, too. But there is no bubbling war with Alan Greenspan, and that's what I got from what commentary I heard that there was _ but, you know, going back a few years here, it's ever been thus, hasn't it? When there's a _ when there are some differences it's always built into a conflict between the president and the chairman of the Fed, and I don't want to get into that game because I don't _ I don't feel that way. Q: But is there a particular feeling at this point that the Fed is dragging its feet somewhat in getting interest rates down? A: I think some feel that way, and I think some probably agree with the concerns of the inflationary concerns that have been expressed. So _ but I'm not in a mode _ a Fed-bashing mode. I also think it's very sensitive in terms of markets and everything else for _ to even go as far as I have done trying to say very little _ (scattered laughter) _ and succeeding only moderately. Yes? Q: Mr. President, you've been at near historical public approval ratings now for well into your first term, 80 percent or more. And my question is whether you believe in spending some of this popularity on something controversial like, say, what specifically do you like about Rostenkowski's proposal, or just hoarding it? You know, what's the goal? A: I don't believe it, is one thing. I don't believe in polls that much. Q: Well, I guess the question is, you know, are you saying _ A: Talk to Nicaragua's man _ talk to Ortega's man. Probably gainfully unemployed right now for missing it by a jillion points. But, these things come and go, seriously. And I learned this _ do you know where I learned it? Back in _ back in Illinois in 1980. I don't remember why, but I remember Vic Gold lecturing me on hanging your hat on polls. That's not what _ what I _ that's not the way I try to call the shots on the policy. You just raised the questions about China. If I had my finger in the wind, I might have done that one differently. I might have done differently about going to Cartagena if I had put my finger in the wind in terms of polls. But, that's not the way I run this administration. And so, I _ I know some think so, but that's not _ that's not the point. And so, I am not going to dwell on them because tomorrow it may be very different, and then I'll have to constantly say, ``Hey, wait a minute.'' Q: (Inaudible) _ along for one more question? Does it become a possibility though that when you're at like 80 percent, that that almost becomes an end in itself at some point, I mean, at such an extraordinary level? A: You mean, pull the rip cord and get out? Q: Well, I mean _ (Laughter.) A: What do you mean? (Laughter.) Q: Well, when you're 80 percent it would be tempting, I would think, just to simply protect that lead, sort of fall on the ball. A: No. I don't _ that _ please believe me, that doesn't _ doesn't guide the decisions we take, and I have given you a couple of examples, and I'm trying to do the best I can for the country and to work with the Congress. And I _ there's a lot of areas where I have not succeeded near as well as I would like to. But, I don't live by the polls. Yeah _ Maureen?
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Afghanistan Says Rebels Attack Strategic City of Khost
DOC.TEXT: U.S.-backed rebels attacked the strategic southern city of Khost, killing at least two soldiers, and government troops responded with Soviet-made Scud rockets, a government spokesman said Tuesday. It was not clear whether the attack was related to last week's failed coup attempt by former Defense Minister Shah Nawaz Tanai, who is from Khost, located near Afghanistan's border with Pakistan. He is popular in the region. East European diplomats said they were concerned Tanai, who fled to Pakistan after his coup failed, would unite with the U.S.-backed guerrillas to take the city, giving the rebels a foothold in Afghanistan. Unconfirmed reports from Pakistan said Tanai began negotiations with the government commander for the Khost region. Government spokesman Naqib Sameer said soldiers had been ``courageously defending'' three positions around Khost for three days. He also acknowledged the government suffered at least two casualties. There was no word on guerrilla casualties. Sameer said rebel forces were attacking security posts from all directions and were shelling the city, an indication the guerrillas might be closing in on Khost. Witnesses said about six Soviet-made surface-to-surface missiles were fired south from Kabul over the last day. Sameer said some of the 45-foot-long missiles were aimed at Khost. The government also reported increased fighting near Jalalabad, the scene of an unsuccessful guerrilla assault last spring after the withdrawal of Soviet troops from Afghanistan. Again it was unclear whether the fighting near Jalalabad was related to Tanai's coup attempt. In a statement apparently released by Tanai in Pakistan, the former defense minister said he was planning to unite with the guerrillas to topple President Najib, who was installed in 1986. Tanai is known as a shrewd commander and generally is considered responsible for Afghanistan's successful defense of Jalalabad against guerrilla attacks. Soviet troops were stationed in Afghanistan for about a decade and installed the current Communist-led government. The last Red Army troops were withdrawn in February 1989. Soviet aid has increased following the coup attempt. More than 30 transport planes, each loaded with 25 tons of weapons and medicine, land daily at Kabul's airport, Eastern European diplomats said. The government also said 4,200 tons of goods from the Soviet Union have reached Kabul by land in the last three days.

DOC.HEAD: Lithuania's U.N. Membership Not Likely Soon
DOC.TEXT: Lithuania, which has declared its independence from the Soviet Union, won't be eligible to join the United Nations for a long time, U.N. officials and diplomats said. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar said Monday that he was ``monitoring the situation'' in the Baltic republic and had no comment on the possibility of U.N. membership. The new Lithuanian government has not made any moves to join the United Nations and faces lengthy negotiations with the Soviet Union on secession. Lithuania still does not control its territory, nor can it enter into international obligations until it is free from Moscow. Both territorial control and the ability to carry out international treaties are considered by many observers to be qualifications for genuine statehood and U.N. membership. The Soviet Union does not recognize Lithuania's declaration of independence and seeks more than $32 billion in compensation from it. The world body has 159 members. Namibia, which becomes independent on March 21, is expected to become the 160th state. U.N. membership is open to all peace-loving states which accept the U.N. Charter and are considered by the general membership to be willing and able to carry out its obligations. A state shall be admitted to the United Nations with a two-thirds vote of the General Assembly and the recommendation of the 15-member Security Council. The Soviet Union is one of five permanent members of the council with veto power and could block membership. The other four are the United States, Britain, China and France. Margers Pinnis, spokesman for the Baltic Appeal to the United Nations, said Tuesday that U.N. membership was unlikely until Lithuania settled more pressing security and economic issues. But he said his organization would help convey information between Lithuania and the world body. ``I remind members of the United Nations,'' he said, ``that the nations of Africa and the world in general were and are instrumental in establishing Namibia as an independent state and in making many U.N. members viable and independent.'' ``I see no reason why the Baltic states should not be recipients of similar political and moral support, since there are many precedents in previous U.N. actions,'' he said in an interview.

DOC.HEAD: Two Guards Killed In Attack on Armored Truck
DOC.TEXT: Thieves using explosives and an assault rifle robbed a security company's armored car Tuesday, killing two guards and wounding a third, police said. The armored vehicle had just left a depot of the company, Securiposte, carrying an undisclosed amount of money, when a car drove across its path and forced it to halt, according to police in the Mediterranean port city. One of the thieves placed an explosive device at the rear of the armored vehicle. The blast killed one of the guards, and a second was killed and a third seriously injured in an exchange of gunfire with the hooded attackers, police said. The thieves fled in two cars with several sacks of money, at one point firing at the driver of a car pursuing them, police said. A police official, Marcel Morin, described the holdup as ``an act of terrorism.'' A similar attack took place in Marseille in 1984, with robbers using explosives so powerful that the armored car's cargo was destroyed and three people were killed. There have been 10 successful holdups of armored cars in France since 1985, including one on March 1 near the eastern city of Mulhouse in which $6.9 million was stolen.

DOC.HEAD: Prominent Romanian Contrasts Japanese, U.S. Influence in East Europe
DOC.TEXT: A leader of the Romanian revolution predicts that for the next decade Eastern Europe will be a ``semi-colony'' of Western Europe. Silviu Brucan, a leading member of the Romanian National Salvation Front, also says the U.S. government is ``impotent'' to influence developments in the region. In a speech Monday night, Brucan described as ``peanuts'' the economic assistance the United States has given to Poland, and said Western European nations were becoming much more involved in the region. He drew a sharp distinction between the role being played by the U.S. government and American corporations. Some American enterprises have announced major investments in the area. Brucan also said ``Japan is the natural partner of the Soviet Union'' and could greatly contribute to its development if those countries normalize relations. He said the Soviet Union should return the northern Kurile Islands to Japan to pave the way for a peace treaty formally ending World War II between the two countries. The Soviets occupied the Kuriles in the last days of the war, and this has strained relations between the two countries. Brucan said improved relations with Japan would alter Moscow's balance of power with Washington and enable the Soviet Union to strengthen its bargaining position with the United States by ``playing the Japanese card.'' He stressed the potential of Japanese technical and economic assistance. ``What Japan could do in Siberia nobody else could do,'' he said. Speaking at a small private dinner with American businessmen and journalists, Brucan said the former one-party Communist countries of Eastern Europe had fallen behind technologically and ``for the next 10 years are doomed to be a semi-colony of Western Europe.'' He said this semi-colonial status could be reduced or eliminated if the Social Democratic Party wins the next election in West Germany and the Labor Party wins the next elections in Britain. He said both would be more sympathetic to Eastern European economic development than their conservative opponents. Brucan, a former Romanian ambassador to the United States and the United Nations, became one of the leaders of the provisional government that took over after the fall of dictator Nicolae Ceausescu last December. He resigned from the Front's formal leadership in January but remains one of its leading figures. Brucan said Romania and other Eastern European countries should look at Sweden and Austria for economic models. He said they should adopt a system in which ``the market sets productions, but the state watches over the distribution of income to prevent vast disparities between the rich and the poor.'' Brucan, a founding member of the Romanian Communist Party, said the dissolution of Communist parties in Eastern Euriope and elsewhere is inevitable. He attributed this to the ``scientific-technical revolution'' that changed the class structures on which communism is based and reduced the role of manual workers in industry and society.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Barry Admits Dependency on Two Prescription Drugs, Won't Resign
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs; new material
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Marion Barry today publicly acknowledged a ``chemical dependency'' to alcohol and two prescription drugs, but said he won't resign while fighting federal cocaine and perjury charges. ``I'm back. I feel good about myself,'' the mayor said in his first extended public appearance since he was arrested and left the city for substance abuse treatment in Florida and South Carolina. Barry read a lengthy statement that made no mention of cocaine. Nor did he say directly whether he intends to seek a fourth term as mayor. He said his campaign manager would make an announcement soon about this fall's campaign. ``My political organization is still intact, notwithstanding some defections,'' Barry said. Several top Barry campaign officials have switched their support in the mayoral race to Walter Fauntroy, the city's non-voting delegate on Capitol Hill. Barry did not answer reporters' questions. The mayor said he was diagnosed at a Florida treatment center as being dependent on alcohol, Valium and Xanax. Valium and Xanax are both commonly prescribed to treat anxiety. He said he would attend treatment sessions once or twice a day, as well as therapy sessions with others who are addicted. He implored the news media to ``respect my privacy and the privacy of other recovering people.'' As for his trial, Barry said, ``I'm going to turn the outcome of this over to God, my attorney'' and the judge and jurors in the case. ``The truth will come out in the trial,'' he said. He said, ``I want to continue to serve this community.'' Barry was flanked by top city officials and attorney R. Kenneth Mundy. His wife, Effi, whom he thanked for her support, was not on stage as Barry spoke. The mayor was charged in January with one misdemeanor count of cocaine possession after a widely publicized arrest in an FBI ``sting'' operation at a downtown Washington hotel. He was indicted last month on three felony counts of perjury for allegedly lying to a grand jury about cocaine use and five misdemeanor counts of cocaine possession. He is scheduled to stand trial on June 4. Barry's news conference was his first public appearance since his somewhat mysterious return to the capital city after seven weeks of treatment at rehabilitation facilities in Florida and South Carolina. Before Barry began speaking, supporters passed out buttons saying ``I'm with Barry in the 90s.'' As he began to speak, some in the audience, which included a large number of city workers, chanted ``Barry, Barry,'' and ``Four More Years.'' Barry's political situation has deteriorated since his arrest. The most visible evidence came when Fauntroy announced March 3 that he would run for mayor in the Democratic primary. There are four other Democrats in the race, as well as former police chief Maurice Turner, running as a Republican. Barry spoke directly several times to the city's news media, urging them to avoid the temptation of covering his every public move. ``Let me urge you not to treat this lightly. You wouldn't treat cancer, heart disease or diabetes lightly, would you?''

DOC.HEAD: The AP, Washington
Editorial Says Party Needs to Regain Faith of the Masses
DOC.TEXT: China's leading newspaper on Tuesday called on Communist Party members to regain the faith of the masses, indicating the party fears it has lost touch with a populace unhappy with the political and economic climate. The People's Daily editorial followed Monday's announcement of a party Central Committee communique that indicated the same fear with its call for the party to strengthen ties with the masses. The first point in the lengthy document was a call for ``party organizations at all levels to pay special attention to the solution of those problems which the masses are most concerned with.'' ``This has to be done as a practical move to (bring) close the ties between the party and the masses,'' the official Xinhua News Agency quoted the communique as saying. The communique was the only document released by the Central Committee at the end of its semi-annual four-day meeting Monday. The unsigned editorial in the party newspaper said, ``Every communist, especially leading cadres, must read this document (the communique) and carry out a Marxist mass outlook.'' ``The party mass line is the party's lifeline,'' the paper said. The mass line was first outlined by revolutionary leader Mao Tse-tung in 1943 in the principle of ``from the masses, to the masses.'' Party leaders are supposed to mingle with the masses and gain an understanding of their thoughts and concerns, to use that understanding in establishing policy, and to take those policies back to the masses, explaining and popularizing the ideas until the masses embrace them as their own. In the past decade, the importance of the mass line gave way to senior leader Deng Xiaoping's economic reform policies, but it has been resurrected since last spring's massive movement for democracy and other political changes. ``Anytime the party mass line is carried out well, the relation between the party and the masses will become more intimate and our undertakings will develop smoothly,'' the editorial said, implying that failure to follow the mass line was the cause of the pro-democracy demonstrations that occurred in more than 80 cities across China. In addition to calls for democracy and freedom, demonstrators criticized Chinese leaders and officials who enjoy lives of special privileges and use their positions for personal financial gains. The party lost even more respect among the masses after the bloody military attack on June 3-4 that left hundreds and perhaps thousands dead in Beijing and marked the beginning of a nationwide crackdown on dissent. The party is trying polish its tarnished image. During the Chinese New Year holiday, China's top leaders traveled the country, rubbing shoulders with coal miners and factory workers, trading jokes and kissing babies. Party officials at all levels have been bombarded with calls ``to go down to the grassroots level'' to implement the mass line. Cases of corruption among officials have been uncovered with renewed fervor, and in recent days, the official media have reported the arrests of several officials, including a vice minister, for various economic crimes. ``History has proven that as long as the party and the people stick together, all obstacles will be surmounted,'' Monday's editorial said. China's economy, which less than two years ago was afflicted with runaway inflation, has added to the dissatisfaction with the party. After battling skyrocketing prices, Chinese now are told to tighten their belts as the nation begins a three-year austerity program that has resulted in the closures of thousands of enterprises and the layoff of millions of workers. ``Socialist economic construction cannot be carried out without the masses,'' the editorial said.

DOC.HEAD: Retail Sales Take Steep Decline
DOC.TEXT: Retail sales in February took their steepest fall in four months, the government reported Tuesday, but analysts said the decline was due almost entirely to sagging automobiles sales. ``The 0.9 percent decline is very deceptive,'' said Sandra Shaber, an economist with the Futures Group here. ``It's all cars, virtually. Consumer spending (elsewhere) is holding up pretty well.'' ``True, automobiles sales fell, but almost all other sectors experienced nice increases,'' agreed William K. MacReynolds, forecasting director for the U.S. Chamber of Commerce. The Commerce Department said retail sales totaled a seasonally adjusted $146.5 billion. The decline was the biggest since a 1.3 percent drop in October and followed a strong 2.8 percent gain in January. The January number originally had been reported at 1.6 percent. Automobile sales plummeted 6 percent in February after jumping 9.9 percent in January, when sales incentives were restored. It was the biggest drop since auto sales fell 26.5 percent in January 1987. But excluding automobiles, retail sales actually rose 0.5 percent. John Silvia, an economist with Kemper Financial Services in Chicago, said the non-auto spending combined with the substantial upward January revision suggests that consumer spending is going to be fairly strong in the first quarter. Silvia said the level of spending is consistent with other recent consumer economic reports, including employment growth and personal income. ``When you put it all together, you have a package that says that there's no economic recession,'' he said. Retail sales represent about one-third of the nation's economic activity. It also suggests, Silvia added, that the Federal Reserve will not act soon to lower interest rates further to stimulate the economy. The construction and much of the manufacturing sector of the economy have been battered by high rates as the central bank sought to slow inflation, prompting some economists and government officials to urge the Fed to ease its grip on credit. Sales of durable goods _ big-ticket, interest-sensitive items expected to last more than three years _ fell 3 percent in February after gaining 6.7 percent a month earlier. Except for autos, however, the durable categories rose _ building materials, up 3 percent, and furniture and other home furnishings, up 0.5 percent. Silvia contended the volatility in auto sales is a ``pricing problem.'' ``What seems to be happening is that in those months when we don't have incentives, we seem to have stronger than normal non-auto sales,'' he said. ``And when we have the incentives put on, then auto retail sales come up and non-auto retail sales come down.'' Most non-durable goods categories also posted gains. Department store sales were up 2 percent; apparel, 1.6 percent; restaurants and bars, 1.4 percent; and grocery stores, 0.5 percent. Declines were registered in drug store and gasoline station sales, but the latter reflected price declines, not volume, analysts said. Both were down 0.8 percent. For the three months from December through February, overall retail sales were up 1.2 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Paris Opera Architect Garnier Honored at Musee d'Orsay
DOC.TEXT: The splendor of the Paris Opera house and the story of its troubled construction spanning half a century are the focus of an exhibition at the Musee d'Orsay saluting the architectural genius of Charles Garnier. With dozens of paintings, architectural drawings, blueprints, photographs, the show is likely to delight both opera lovers and history buffs. With its ornate facade, sumptuous marble staircase, intricate and gilded mouldings and painted ceilings, the Paris Opera is considered the most successful monument of the Second Empire. The exhibition, which runs through June 10, spotlights another Garnier design: the Opera de Monte-Carlo in the Casino overlooking the Mediterranean. On display are opera memorabilia including costumes, posters and miniature sets of the house's most remarkable productions. Garnier, basking in the glory of the popular Paris Opera, took on the Monte-Carlo project in 1878, completing it nine months later. Opera is no longer performed at Garnier's theater in Paris, as the new, high-tech Opera-Bastille opened in July. Nonetheless, it remains the home of the Paris Opera Ballet Company _ as well as a popular tourist attraction. The idea for a Paris opera house was conceived in 1820, but it took 40 years to organize an architectural competition. There were 171 contestants, including the heavily favored Eugene Viollet-le-Duc. The French music world went into shock when the winner was announced _ a 35-year-old virtual unknown named Charles Garnier. Garnier was born in 1825, the son of a craftsman. A frail, nervous youngster, he excelled in drawing and mathematics and entered the Ecole des Beaux Arts. ``There is no choice among the arts,'' he once said. ``You have to be either the good Lord or an architect.'' His project ran into trouble from the start. Baron Georges Eugene Haussmann, Napoleon III's urban planner who gave Paris its broad, sweeping boulevards, chose the site for the new building _ over a network of underground springs. Construction was halted several times, the project nearly canceled by changing regimes and political intrigue. The Opera finally opened on Jan. 5, 1875. Garnier dreamed of creating a Napoleon III style, much as Kings Louis XIII, XIV, XV and XVI had elaborate designs named for them. But the style was too grandiose _ the emperor had his own entrance ramp wide enough for him to ride straight to the royal box in his horse-drawn carriage _ and never caught on as a school of its own.

DOC.HEAD: Lithuanian Independence Drive Justified, Administration Says
With AM-Lithuania Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The efforts of Lithuania and its Baltic neighbors to regain their freedom are ``fully and uniquely justified,'' the State Department said Tuesday. The statement by Margaret Tutwiler, the department's spokeswoman, was the strongest U.S. endorsement to date of the declaration of independence voted unanimously on Sunday by Nicaragua's new parliament. President Bush said ``we rejoice as people are permitted the free expression that we take for granted in this country.'' But he said the United States was not immediately offering full diplomatic recognition to Lithuania ``because we want to see the evolution of the control of the territory there and ... a peaceful resolution to this question.'' If the Lithuanian situation causes the Soviet Union concern, Ms. Tutwiler said, those worries should be dealt with through ``constructive negotiations with the Lithuanian people.'' The U.S. remarks followed strong criticism of the Lithuanian move toward independence by Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev as he addressed the Congress of Peoples Deputies in Moscow. Gorbachev, who on Monday called the prospect of Lithuanian independence ``alarming,'' told the Congress that the declaration of Lithuanian independence was ``illegal and invalid.'' But Gorbachev also urged patience, saying Moscow's relations with the Baltic republic would continue unchanged for now and that a Soviet commission was studying how to respond to Lithuania's action. Gorbachev made clear that Lithuania's independence drive is likely to encounter strong resistance. ``We cannot talk about negotiations,'' he said. ``You carry out negotiations with a foreign country.'' Although several Soviet lawmakers said it was likely Gorbachev would soften his position, he won applause when he said the Kremlin would not give in to demands to negotiate independence with republics seeking independence, including the other two Baltic states _ Latvia and Estonia. Ms. Tutwiler noted that the United States has never recognized the forcible incorporation of Lithuania and the other two Baltic states into the Soviet Union in 1940 following a secret deal between Josef Stalin and Adolf Hitler. ``That incorporation in our view was taken in violation of international law,'' she said and added: ``We believe that the efforts of these three states _ Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia _ to regain their freedom are fully and uniquely justified by any standard and the wishes of their peoples should be respected.'' ``We urge the Soviet Union to address its concerns through constructive negotiations with the Lithuanian people,'' she said. Earlier, President Bush told a news conference at the White House that ``clearly, I think there's a great deal of interest in this concept of ... Lithuanians working it out with the Soviets to achieve what they want.'' But as for final diplomatic recognition of Lithuania as a sovereign state, Bush said that must follow negotiations to give Lithuania full control of its territory and full authority over all functions of government.

DOC.HEAD: Disabled Demonstrators Arrested in Capitol
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto WX7
EDs: Inserts graf 6, The demonstrators, with charges.
DOC.TEXT: Disabled demonstrators in wheelchairs were arrested in the U.S. Capitol today after confronting House leaders with demands for quick passage of legislation guaranteeing them civil rights protections. A crowd of more than 100 demonstrators threatened civil disobedience and interrupted House Speaker Thomas S. Foley and House Republican Leader Bob Michel as the congressional leaders tried to speak over the din in the cavernous Capitol Rotunda. After the congressmen left, about 70 of the people with disabilities assembled in the center of the Rotunda and began chanting in a planned attempt to provoke arrest. Capitol police, standing nearby, encircled the protesters and began taking them into custody. Outside the Capitol, a line of government-owned vans were lined up, and police began placing the protesters _ most in wheelchairs _ into the vehicles. Some of the protesters chained their wheelchairs together. Police used large snipping tools to break the chains. The demonstrators were being charged with unlawful entry and demonstrating within the Capitol, said a spokesman for the Capitol Police, Officer G.T. Nevitt. The first charge carries a maximum sentence of six months in jail and $100 fine, and the second, six months in jail and a $500 fine. ``It is a priority for passage in this session of the Congress,'' Foley shouted over catcalls from some of the estimated 150 people arrayed before him in their wheelchairs. ``I am absolutely satisfied it will reach the floor, we will have a conference with the Senate and it will become law.'' ``Will it be on the floor in 24 hours? No,'' Foley added, in a statement greeted with a chorus of boos. The speaker said, ``I am not going to set an artificial deadline that prevents the committees from sending a bill to the floor that they can defend.'' It was the second day of lobbying by the disabled. On Monday, dozens of people crawled out of their wheelchairs and up the steps of the Capitol to dramatize their demands. ``I'll take all night if I have to,'' said the youngest, 8-year-old Jennifer Keelan of Denver, as she pulled her small body up the steps. ``Come on, Jenny, you're almost there,'' said Michael Winter of Berkeley, Calif., who was making his own difficult journey up the 83 stone steps of the Capitol's West Front. They were among 60 or so people who put on the demonstration Monday following a rally at the base of the Capitol steps by about 1,000 people supporting legislation to ensure rights to people with disabilities. The focus of the protest was the Americans with Disabilities Act, which passed the Senate last year but has bogged down in the House, despite widespread predictions of its ultimate passage. The measure would outlaw discrimination based on physical or mental disability in employment, access to buildings, use of the telephone system, use of public and private transportation and in other uses. The Capitol building has ramps for wheelchair access to two of its entrances and ramps and elevators inside to enable people confined to wheelchairs to get around. ``We're not asking for any favors,'' said I. King Jordan, president of Gallaudet University and the first deaf person to hold that position at the school for people with impaired hearing. ``We're simply asking the same rights and equality any other American has.'' ``What we did for civil rights in the '60s, we forgot to do for people with disabilities,'' said Rep. Patricia Schroeder, D-Colo. During the midday faceoff in the Rotunda, Foley sought to assure the disabled that House leaders ``want to see that this bill has the greatest possible support and will reach the president's desk in a way that he can sign it.'' Michel told the crowd he had broached the issue earlier today in a meeting with President Bush at the White House. Of the 24-hour deadline presented House members by the disabled, he said, ``That's unreasonable.'' He acknowledged that ``the (disabled) community is getting a little bit impatient because the wheels of Congress are not moving fast enough.'' Although the bill is supported by the Bush administration and congressional leaders, some have begun questioning the administration's commitment in recent weeks. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater denied its support was slipping and said the administration was negotiating with key members of Congress. ``We do support the legislation,'' Fitzwater said. ``We're very supportive of their rights and their cause. President Bush has spoken out on that in the past.''

DOC.HEAD: 11 Killed in Helicopter Crash
DOC.TEXT: A helicopter carrying 13 people crashed in the harbor while on a flight from the international airport, and a navy spokesman said Tuesday that only two people survived. The helicopter went down 2{ miles from Lungi International Airport on Monday night. Rescuers had pulled five bodies from the water before the search was halted for the day Tuesday. The survivors were the co-pilot, a Spanish national whose name was not immediately available, and a passenger of Lebanese nationality. Others on the Spanish-manufactured helicopter included the pilot, a Spaniard, four Sierra Leoneans and six Lebanese. The helicopter was carrying people who had gone to the airport, seven miles across the harbor from a tourist hotel on Lumley Beach, to say goodbye to departing relatives, the navy spokesman said.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: James A. Michener, whose panoramic novels reflect a lifetime of globetrotting, is thinking of settling down each winter in Florida, his editor says. The 83-year-old author has no plans for another epic that would require years of geographical reasearch, so he's hunting for a winter retirement home, coordinating editor James Kings said Monday. Michener will spend his summers at a condominium he bought in Brunswick, Maine, Kings said. For years, Michener has set up quarters in whatever part of the world he happens to be writing about. He spent three years in Miami while writing ``Caribbean,'' his latest best-seller. Last month, Michener visited a group of retired professionals at Eckerd College in St. Petersburg. ``He said they were very interesting people down there, and he was more interested in that than he was in the sun,'' Kings said. ``Eckerd College is the most recent place he's visited and may well be the most promising,'' Kings said. ``Michener wants an academic setting and a living arrangement that includes medical facilities for when you really get sick.'' The college's Academy of Senior Professionals has more than 200 retired professionals and their spouses who attend classes and study groups and counsel students. Michener is a professor emeritus at the University of Texas at Austin, where he lives with his 69-year-old wife, Mari.

Paul McCartney, who is touring Japan for the first time since the Beatles performed there in 1966, has donated $250,000 to fight cancer and help clean up the Earth. Half of the funds will go to the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York and the rest to the Japanese chapter of the environmental group Friends of the Earth, tour publicist Fiona Hurry said Tuesday. ``As we all know, cancer causes great suffering, and I have great respect for all those who try to lessen the pain as best they can,'' McCartney said. ``I also have hope that one day science and medicine will find a way to beat cancer forever.'' The 47-year-old rock 'n' roller has been using his world tour, which began in Oslo in September, to promote Friends of the Earth. ``All I am trying to do on this world tour is to hopefully make people think about how we're wrecking this world and ask them to challenge their politicians to act,'' he said. A planned Japan tour in 1980 was derailed when the singer was arrested at Tokyo's airport for possession of marijuana and later deported. His current band, which includes wife Linda on keyboards and percussion, played the last of six concerts Tuesday at the Tokyo Dome, an indoor baseball stadium. His show features elaborate light and laser effects, more than a dozen Beatle hits including ``Hey Jude,'' ``Let it Be'' and ``Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band,'' and several cuts from McCartney's latest album, ``Flowers in the Dirt.'' The tour will travel to the United States, Brazil, and back to Europe, where it is to end in April.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: For release at 6 p.m. EST, time set by source
DOC.TEXT: Actress Valerie Bertinelli says she is struggling to save her nine-year marriage to rock star Eddie Van Halen while he works to overcome alcoholism. ``He doesn't abuse me; he hurts himself,'' Bertinelli, 30, is quoted as saying in April's Redbook magazine. ``He's got a problem I'm not happy with, but I bring stability to his life. ``And besides, I love him. It's my weakness. Some people are addicted to food. I'm addicted to my husband,'' she said. ``I can't say that we're really great friends _ we don't have a helluva lot in common _ but we'll always be connected like brother and sister. That helps when the romance comes and goes.'' Van Halen, 33, checked into a drug and alcohol treatment program in Burbank, Calif., on Jan. 1. Bertinelli says she gets support from the families of other substance abusers at Al-Anon meetings. ``I'm proud of him. I'll support him in every way I can,'' she said. ``I feel more sorry for Ed than I do for myself. If worse comes to worst, I can always pick up and leave, but he's still stuck with his problem.''

Hotel queen Leona Helmsley says her 81-year-old husband is ``all right'' after tumbling down a flight of stairs and hitting his head, a published report says. Real estate magnate Harry Helmsley fell after exercising with a physical therapist Monday in his Park Lane Hotel apartment. Columnist Cindy Adams wrote in Tuesday's New York Post that Mrs. Helmsley had issued standing orders that someone always precede her husband down the stairs. But no one was in front of Helmsley when he lost his footing, Adams wrote. ``I was waiting for Harry to join me for lunch,'' Mrs. Helmsley was quoted as saying. ``Instead, an ambulance became my lunch.'' She said her husband suffered bruises on his head and face. ``His faculties are fine. He knows everything that's happening,'' Mrs. Helmsley said. ``I'm so scared, but they tell me he's going to be all right. Maybe God is really on my side after all.'' Mrs. Helmsley was convicted on charges of conspiracy, tax evasion and fraud, ordered to pay $7.5 million in fines and to serve four years in prison. She is free pending an appeal. Helmsley was deemed incompetent to stand trial in federal court on charges of income tax evasion.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Rejects Lithuanian Independence But Expected to Soften
LaserPhoto MOSB5
DOC.TEXT: Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev rejected Lithuania's declaration of independence and ruled out talks with the rebellious republic Tuesday, but lawmakers from the region said they were sure he'd soften his stance. Gorbachev told the Congress of People's Deputies he considers the Lithuanian move ``illegal and invalid'' and said the Kremlin would not begin wholesale negotiations with republics seeking independence. ``We cannot talk about negotiations,'' he said. ``You carry out negotiations with a foreign country.'' Gorbachev, however, also urged patience and said Moscow's relations with the Baltic republic would continue unchanged for now in the wake of Sunday's vote by Lithuanian lawmakers to break away from the Soviet Union. Despite the Soviet leader's tough line, several deputies from the Baltic republics of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia said they had strong reason to believe Moscow would nonetheless enter negotiations on independence for the three states, which were annexed to the Soviet Union in 1940. ``Gorbachev is a realist,'' said Lithuanian deputy Algimantas Chekuolis. ``He'll change his stand.'' Estonian lawmaker Endel Lippmaa said Estonia had already formed its delegation for independence negotiations, and Lithuanian deputy Nikolai Medvedev said he had been told talks might begin as early as Saturday. In its attempt to turn Sunday's declaration into reality, Lithuania must work out with Moscow a daunting array of questions, including matters of territory, compensation, the status of thousands of Soviet soldiers, ownership of factories and land, and control of the police and KGB. The Tass news agency said Lithuanian legislators declared Monday that their sons no longer need serve in the Soviet army. They appealed to Gorbachev to ensure the welfare of Lithuanian soldiers until negotiations start on mustering them out. Lithuanian activist Arunya Contautaite said Tuesday that 5,000 young Lithuanian men out of about 15,000 conscripts had refused to enter the army during this spring's draft. With so many issues to decide, Sajudis, the Lithuanian pro-independence movement that now dominates the republic's government, wants to start talks right away, but Lithuanian Communist Party chief Algirdas Brazauskas, who sounded out Gorbachev last week, said he did not believe Moscow would agree. ``I don't think Moscow will go for that,'' he said in an interview Monday on the plane from the Lithuanian capital of Vilnius to Moscow. Gorbachev opened the second-day session of the Congress of People's Deputies on Tuesday by giving the 2,000 lawmakers an update on the government's reaction to the Lithuanian vote. ``I think it is illegal and invalid,'' he said. He won applause from the Congress when he said the Kremlin would not negotiate with republics seeking independence. But he also added that a ``political and judicial evaluation'' was needed, and said Premier Nikolai Ryzhkov and a commission had begun studying the matter. He also proposed charging the Supreme Soviet, the Congress' working legislature, with beginning discussion of the push for independence in Estonia and Lithuania within the next two days. Gorbachev did not appear overly angry at the Lithuanians, and even addressed a light joke in their direction. At one point, he referred to Lithuanians as ``comrades,'' then paused and said: ``I think they are comrades.'' Lithuanian delegates who said they came as mere observers to the Congress asked Tuesday for recognition of their declaration of statehood and for the start of talks on their secession. On Tuesday night, Lithuanian president Vytautas Landsbergis appealed on national TV for understanding of the republic's aims and assured viewers it would use only peacefl means and respect all minority groups within its borders. Among backlash Lithuanians say they expect from Moscow is a partial economic blockade, including of crucial fuel supplies for which Lithuania is dependent on the Soviet Union. Brazauskas said Monday night Moscow officials had told him they would undoubtedly start charging Lithuania normal world prices for fuel, instead of the subsidized price. Brazauskas said he also expected many Soviet factories to use Lithuania's self-proclaimed independence as an excuse to stop supplying it with goods, or to provide them only for hard currency. Gorbachev demanded in talks with Brazauskas a week ago that the republic pay 21 billion rubles _ about $34 billion _ in hard currency for Soviet investment in factories and infrastructure in the past half-century. He also suggested Lithuania might have to hand over the Baltic port of Klaipeda, a key city the independent republic would need to carry out foreign trade. But Chekuolis, a Sajudis leader, said the Kremlin should pay 300 billion rubles _ about $500 billion _ to compensate for 300,000 people killed, imprisoned or exiled by Stalin and his successors, and for economic havoc caused by a half-century of Soviet mismanagement. Lithuania would not insist on convertible currency because the money spent on them was the Soviet Union's non-convertible currency, he said. Chekuolis said the figure takes into account a calculation of what the republic's GNP would now be if it had continued to grow at the pace it had prior its absorption into the Soviet Union. The republic had a 10 percent annual growth rate during independence, and if independent would have an economy as strong as Finland, he said. In Paris, the Bank of France said Tuesday it will return the prewar gold in its vaults to Lithuania if the French government recognizes the new regime. The gold is worth about $28 million at its current value.

DOC.HEAD: Explosions Destroy 10 Homes, Six Injured
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with no one killed, fires out and revises number of destroyed homes to 10, sted 12, and injured to six sted five. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Explosions caused by a leaking liquid propane pipeline destroyed 10 homes today and injured six people, officials said. ``It looks like somebody dropped a bomb,'' a utility spokesman said. The explosions shattered windows in the rural town of Blenheim, about 40 miles southwest of Albany, and knocked out telephone service and electricity. Trees were burned and farmland was singed. The Schoharie County Sheriff's department said no one was killed in the explosions shortly before 8 a.m. ``When it first happened, we thought an airplane had crashed into the side of the hill,'' said resident Liz Mace. After a second explosion, she looked out the window ``and the hill behind my home was on fire.'' The leak in the 8-inch underground pipeline apparently caused propane to seep into a small valley where 10 homes are located, said State Police spokesman Ed Dwyer. Firefighters put out the fires in three hours, but the pipeline was still reported leaking at midday. ``There was a big explosion,'' said Jim Gately, whose home was destroyed. ``Glass flying all over, it landed on the floor. My clothes was afire. I jumped in the shower.'' ``It's quite a scene,'' said Chris Becker of the Middleburgh Telephone Co. Just unbelievable ... The houses in that area are completely devastated. It looks like somebody dropped a bomb.'' '' Two people were taken to Albany Medical Center where they were in critical condition with burns on their face and hands, said hospital spokesman Andrew Foster. Four other people were being treated at other hospitals.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Calls for Early Negotiations to End Mozambique's Civil War
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, trying his hand at African peacemaking, called today for early negotiations to end Mozambique's 10-year civil war. Bush issued the plea after talks with Joaquim Chissano, the president of the former Marxist state. At a departure ceremony after talks in the Oval Office and over lunch, Bush said Chissano's government has taken ``significant steps to heal divisions which threaten your nation. And we urge all parties to talk at the earliest opportunity so as to avoid further suffering.'' He praised Chissano for strengthing ties with the United States and adopting reforms on voting, property rights and religious freedoms, but said more needs to be done. ``We look forward to even further reforms,'' the president said. ``So we talked today of common concerns like refugee issues and Mozambique's humanitarian concerns _ the crisis in humanitarian concerns, I might add.'' Chissano said he assured Bush that his government was ready to enter into direct talks with rebel forces as soon as possible. He also said he expressed appreciation ``for the stand the United States has taken on the war in Mozambique and for the positive role it has been playing in the peace process.'' Chissano appeared taken aback by the crush of television cameras on hand to witness the start of his Oval Office visit. As the crews pushed their long boom microphones toward his face, Chissano asked, ``What do you do with all these photos? It's too many.'' The media people were ushered out as Bush and Chissano, seated in wingback chairs by the fireplace, began their talks in private. A U.S. official who briefed reporters about today's visit said the government of Mozambique and the RENAMO rebels were nearing agreement on starting peace talks. ``I believe they're in a pre-negotiating stage right now to determine the framework for their talks. And we're hoping that they will take the final step to get together,'' said the official, who spoke Monday on condition of anonymity. RENAMO, an organization vilified by human rights groups for its brutality in the civil war, has been demanding that the Mozambique government abandon Marxism-Leninism and establish a multiparty system. Mozambique, which gained independence from Portugal in 1975, has dropped its Marxist ideology and turned to private enterprise and a free-market economy in recent years. As a reward, Bush recently struck the country from the U.S. list of Marxist states, opening the way for lending and trade concessions. ``It is our belief that because so many of RENAMO's demands have been met already, it should not be too difficult to enter into a negotiated settlement in the near future,'' said the official. Attempts at getting the two sides to stop their war began last year, with the presidents of Zimbabwe and Kenya mediating. Assistant Secretary of State Herman Cohen and other U.S. officials also have been trying to help. The United States reportedly has a seven-point plan that would meet both sides' preconditions for talks. ``We have been acting as a facilitator. And we will be wanting to consult with President Chissano at this time to see what more we can do to help the start of direct negotiations,'' said the official. The war has been a costly one. An estimated 3.2 million Mozambicans have been driven from their homes, either to internal or external exile. The international community has had to give Mozambique $300 million to buy food every year. Created originally by the white South African government to counter the Mozambican government's support for the African National Congress, RENAMO has in recent months lost much of its ideological and financial support. When President F.W. de Klerk came to power in South Africa last year, he stopped assistance to RENAMO. He since has dropped the ban on ANC and has made overtures to its leadership designed to lead to talks about the future of the apartheid racial discrimination system. RENAMO still gets money from sympathizers in Portugal and Brazil.

DOC.HEAD: Archbishop Defends Appeal for Volunteers for AIDS Vaccine
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 1st graf to add that only older priests and nuns considered; SUBS 2nd graf to note Mahony's title of archbishop.
DOC.TEXT: The Roman Catholic archbishop of Los Angeles on Tuesday defended his appeal to older nuns and priests to test an experimental AIDS vaccine, saying that ``the common good'' sometimes requires taking risks. Archbishop Roger Mahony also said he had been questioned about his appeal by Vatican officials but that they were not concerned after learning details of the plan. Critics say the prototype vaccine developed by Dr. Jonas Salk, father of the polio vaccine, could accidentally infect the volunteers with the deadly AIDS virus. Acting on a request from a scientist at the Norris Cancer Institute at the University of Southern California, Mahony sent a letter last month to 1,400 priests and 2,400 nuns in his diocese, asking them to consider volunteering to test the vaccine, he said. ``If we wait to try something when every single risk or negative effect has been eliminated or reduced, we would be immobilized as a human society,'' he declared Tuesday. Mahony spoke at a news conference called to discuss the appeal, which has generated controversy. The archbishop was on a visit to Rome on separate Vatican business. He said his request to the clergy was ``reasonable'' and part of the church's ``heroic tradition of outreach'' to the sick. He said, however, that the move seemed unprecedented, at least in the United States. ``I thought this was a special opportunity for the church ... to make a contribution _ even though a small one _ in this battle against this terrible dreaded disease,'' he said. He added that the experimental vaccine seemed to be ``the only window of opportunity'' in fighting AIDS. Mahony said the appeal did not imply a change in the church's teaching that homosexual behavior was wrong. AIDS is most commonly transmitted through sexual activity or the sharing of hypodermic needles by drug abusers, and many victims are homosexuals. The archbishop rejected any suggestion that the church was using the experiment to improve its image on the AIDS' issue, declaring the church would not ``play games with people's lives.'' Archbishop Fiorenzo Angelini, the head of the Vatican's Pastoral Council for Health Workers, contacted Mahony to ask about the level of risk of the experiment, Mahony said. ``There had been some fears this was a highly risky venture,'' Mahony said. He added that experiments with animals had had positive results and the vaccine was ``as safe as one can get.'' Angelini later said that Mahony's appeal was ``a concrete example of solidarity and charity'' and a ``positive initiative.'' California authorities have not yet granted permission for the study involving the prototype AIDS vaccine. A key researcher on the project, Dr. Alexandra Levine, said Mahony acted too quickly in sending the letters to the clergy, and that he should have waited until the project was approved. The archbishop said he had been asked to make the appeal by Dr. Brian Henderson, another leader of the experiment, and had followed ``his request and timetable.'' Mahony, 54, also said he would consider testing the vaccine himself, except that he was too young for the study. The experiment is aimed at testing the Salk prototype vaccine on 10 uninfected individuals over age 65 with long, complete medical records. The scientists asked the clergy since the project involved risk, Mahony said. At least six nuns and one or two priests have contacted Henderson expressing interest in volunteering, the archbishop said. So far, Salk's prototype vaccine, called HIV-immunogen, has been tested only on people with the human immunodeficiency or HIV virus that causes AIDS. The Salk vaccine uses an inactivated virus, which the scientist also used in developing the polio vaccine. Tests on non-infected people are controversial because, critics say, live strains of the virus could contaminate the vaccine, and accidentally infect volunteers.
