Such a thing happened with early tests of the Salk polio vaccine and many Americans were infected. The vaccine eventually saved thousands from the crippling disease. Levine said the tests would hopefully stimulate the immune systems of the healthy volunteers to produce large quantities of antibodies against the AIDS virus. Those antibodies would be removed from the volunteers, purified and injected into the AIDS patients, whose immune systems cannot produce antibodies. The tests could also lay the foundation for use of HIV-immunogen as a vaccine to prevent AIDS virus infection.

DOC.HEAD: Nazi-Era Artifacts Donated to Holocaust Museum
LaserPhoto WX17
DOC.TEXT: East Germany on Tuesday donated a major collection of Nazi-era artifacts and documents to the Holocaust museum being built here, as a museum official warned of a disturbing increase in anti-Semitic incidents in East and West Germany. East German Ambassador Gerhard Herder turned over about 500 objects related to Nazi Germany's slaughter of 6 million Jews during World War II, saying he hoped the gift would remind ``all of us to ensure these kind of events will never happen again.'' The artifacts include medical instruments used for lethal experiments at the Sachsenhausen concentration camp, Judaic textiles recovered from a Berlin synagogue during the fiery ``Kristallnacht'' pogrom of 1938, and German V-2 rocket parts produced in underground tunnels where more than 10,000 slave laborers died. The United States Holocaust Memorial Museum is scheduled to open in the spring of 1993. Miles Lerman, the museum's chief negotiator for Holocaust memorabilia from foreign countries, said negotiations with East European countries for artifacts began about three years ago, long before Communist governments were ousted, and the agreements are being ratified by their democratic successors. ``We deal with history and not with politics,'' Lerman said, ``so it doesn't matter whether we negotiate with one individual or another. The thought of preserving these artifacts transcends politics.'' Lerman congratulated the East Germans for the courage to ``face up to the past and acknowledge the crimes committed by the generation that preceded them.'' He said the world was jubilant over democratic changes sweeping the Eastern bloc. ``Jubilant,'' he said, ``but also concerned with the increasing outbreaks of anti-Semitic acts, with signs of more prevalently expressed wishes to turn the page and implement a historic amnesia.'' Lerman said there had been sporadic incidents of anti-Jewish graffiti, desecration of tombstones and incendiary remarks by neo-Nazis in both East and West Germany. He called the incidents ``highly disturbing'' and especially alarming to the tiny community of 250 Jews living in East Germany. He said the small but vocal resurgence of anti-Semitic sentiment, though denounced by both German governments, threatens to undermine the democratic society the two countries are trying to build as they prepare for reunification. One of the prized acquisitions donated Tuesday by East Germany is an IBM Hollerith machine for sorting and tabulating punch cards. A mechanical forerunner of the modern computer, the machine was used during national censuses of the 1930s to target Jews, gypsies and others for deportation to Nazi death camps. The machine was contributed by the Museum of Technology in Dresden, one of more than two dozen East German institutions and individuals that donated objects. A formal agreement for transfer of the collection was signed in Potsdam in August by museum and East German officials. Museum curators have received more than 10,000 gifts and 6,000 loans of artifacts and documents from Holocaust survivors or the families of victims, and from several European governments. After three years of negotiations, museum officials have signed agreements with Poland, the Soviet Union, East Germany, Czechoslovakia and Hungary to obtain Holocaust materials for display. Talks with Yugoslavia and Bulgaria are nearing completion, they said. The $147 million complex will be the largest Holocaust museum in the world, surpassing the Yad Vashemn national Holocaust center in Jerusalem. Built with private funds, the five-story museum will stand on a 1.9-acre site donated by the U.S. government near the National Mall, within view of the Washington Monument and the Jefferson Memorial. The museum was chartered by Congress in 1980.

DOC.HEAD: Christians Ask Hrawi to Intervene as New Clashes Erupt
DOC.TEXT: By MOHAMMED SALAM=

Renegade Gen. Michel Aoun said Tuesday he was prepared to negotiate with a rival Christian warlord, and the nation's Catholic patriarch called for government intervention to stop the bloodshed. Rival Shiite Moslem militiamen fought street battles in west Beirut, wounding 10 civilians and trapping passengers at Beirut's airport and students in their schools, police said. The battles between the mainstream, Syrian-backed Amal militia and the pro-Iranian extremist Hezbollah, or Party of God, shut the main highway linking Beirut with south Lebanon, trapping hundreds of people at the airport. Police said hundreds of students were forced to take cover in school corridors as the militias dueled with rocket-propelled grenades and machine guns in the dusty alleys of Beirut's southern suburbs. Police also said South Yemen's ambassador was almost killed when four rocket-propelled grenades smashed into his embassy. Police had no other details and repeated telephone calls to the embassy went unanswered. Fighting eased after Syrian troops intervened to separate the two sides. Amal and Hezbollah have been fighting for the past two years for dominance among Lebanon's largest sect, the 1.2 million-member Shiite community. More than 1,030 people have been killed and 3,046 wounded in the clashes. In a newspaper interview, Aoun appealed to his Christian rival, the leader of the Lebanese Forces militia, Samir Geagea, to end their monthlong conflict. ``Let us sit and negotiate without preconditions,'' Aoun said to the conservative daily Ad-Diyar newspaper. Maronite Catholic Patriarch Nasrallah Sfeir and the Christian-run Voice of Lebanon radio station, meanwhile, appealed to President Elias Hrawi's Syrian-backed government to prevent further clashes for control of the 310-square-mile Christian enclave. ``The legitimate government should spread its authority over the whole nation. It should not wait for an invitation from anyone to do so,'' Sfeir told the leftist As-Safir newspaper. Geagea has demanded that Aoun step down as commander of the army and recognize Hrawi's government. ``Recognizing President Hrawi is Aoun's only way to political life,'' As-Safir quoted Geagea as saying. Aoun has refused to recognize Hrawi and is holding out in the battered presidential palace in east Beirut. Hrawi's government controls 70 percent of Lebanon's territory and is backed by 40,000 Syrian troops. It has no influence in the Christian enclave. Syria has pledged to place its armed forces at Hrawi's disposal. Geagea, Aoun and Hrawi are members of the Christian Maronite sect that has dominated Lebanon's politics since independence from France in 1943. The appeals were made as Aoun's army troops and Lebanese Forces militiamen skirmished throughout the Christian enclave, threatening to shatter a wobbly, 10-day cease-fire. Police said three people were wounded by sniper fire in areas controlled by Geagea's militia, raising the overall toll to 756 killed and 2,104 wounded since the clashes broke out Jan. 30. A security committee that brokered the March 3 cease-fire has been unable to work out a political settlement to the conflict, the bloodiest confrontation among Christians in Lebanon's 15-year-old civil war. Aoun, Geagea and Hrawi are Maronites, the Catholic community that has enjoyed the upper hand in Lebanon's politics since independence from France in 1943.

DOC.HEAD: Police Identify Man Run Over by Airliner
DOC.TEXT: Puzzled investigators probing the death of a man who ran into the landing gear of a Boeing 727 jetliner while it accelerated for takeoff say they may never known what brought him onto the runway. Richard Lee Brown, 40, of Phoenix, died Sunday at Sky Harbor International Airport after he confronted Alaska Airlines' Flight 608 as it was taking off for Tucson with 33 passengers and a crew of seven. ``He was waving his arms around like he wanted to stop the plane,'' police spokesman Leo Speliopoulos. The jetliner was moving about 100 mph and might have gone out of control had pilot Michael Townsend tried to take evasive action, airline spokesman Lou Cancelmi said. Although the plane had used up 2,000 feet of runway, Townsend was able to abort the takeoff and stop the plane before it reached barriers at the end of the asphalt, Cancelmi said. ``The captain said it was either the plane or him,'' said a passenger, the Rev. Richard Pollard of Anchorage, Alaska. After the airliner returned to the terminal, Brown's body was found tangled in the landing gear. Cancelmi said the crew was shaken by the incident. ``This is a tragedy _ one we're inexperienced with,'' he said. Cancelmi, based in the airline's Seattle office, said crew members spent Sunday night in Phoenix talking to police and Federal Aviation Administration officials and flew back to Seattle on Monday afternoon. And nobody knows what Brown was doing on the runway. ``We could postulate it was a suicide, but it could also have been a poor guy taking a shortcut,'' said airport spokesman Steve Bigg. ``We simply don't know.''

DOC.HEAD: Bright and Brief
DOC.TEXT: They hit the ceiling at the Internal Revenue Service when somebody smelled a rat. But the stink turned out to be a big, dead snake in the overhead and figuring how it got there is taxing the IRS. Maintenance workers found the decaying body of a 4-foot-long snake in the ceiling Monday, after IRS workers on the sixth floor of the federal building called for help. James Carmody, IRS district director, said the workers first thought the smell was natural gas, then a dead rat. IRS agent Donna Lodholz, who climbed a ladder to investigate, found the snake's body and help was summoned. The multicolored snake appeared to be a boa constrictor, and Carmody said a sinister motive for its presence had been ruled out. The snake apparently was disposed of by the maintenance crew before it could be positively identified. John Groves, curator of reptiles for the Philadelphia Zoo, said the snake could have been a species found in Pennsylvania that got inside to hibernate for the winter. ``They don't make much noise,'' he said. Groves said it is possible for a snake to survive in the building if it could find food and water. ``I've never noticed any rats or mice around the building, so maybe that's the reason,'' Carmody said.

When Hartley Peavey throws a birthday party, he expects a little feedback. Peavey expects more than 1,000 guests from all 50 states and several foreign countries to attend the 25th anniversary party for his Meridian-based company, Peavy Electronics, famed for its rock 'n' roll amplifiers. Company spokesman Jerry Hess said Peavey already has booked half of Meridian's 1,400 hotel rooms for the June 12-14 event, and may need more. The Lauderdale County Tourism Commission estimates the party will put $420,000 into the local encomomy. Most guests will be dealers and distributors of Peavy products, which the privately owned company exports to 102 countries. Peavey also has a plant in Britain and distribution centers in Canada and the Netherlands. For a grand finale, Peavey will throw an outdoor concert featuring two single performers and two groups. Some famous people? ``We can't announce who they are,'' Hess said.

Hundreds of thousands of spring breakers are descending on Florida for beer and bikinis, but 17 American University students are spending the week helping to build houses for the needy. The eight men and nine women who arrived Sunday from Washington, D.C., are putting in eight-hour work days, eating at churches and spending the night in sleeping bags on the floor of the Holy Trinity Episcopal Church. ``This group really wants to work,'' said Joy Willard-Williford, project director for the South Brevard Habitat for Humanity. ``They came with their hammers and tools and their nail aprons on. They were all decked out.'' The university's Habitat chapter has more than 200 members and about 50 are spending spring break building homes in various communities, said Kate Hochberg, 20, a group leader. The students plan on taking a day off Thursday. Half will head for the beach and the others to Disney World. Ms. Willard-Williford said she initially suspected the students' motives when they they asked how far they would be from Daytona Beach, the spring break's hot spot for beery blowouts. As it turned out, she said, they wanted to attend an Amnesty International rally.

DOC.HEAD: Black Judge Named Florida Chief Justice
DOC.TEXT: Florida Supreme Court Justice Leander Shaw was promoted to chief justice Tuesday, becoming the first black to hold that role in the state and the first to head any of its three branches of government. ``Needless to say, it is professionally gratifying to be elevated to serve as chief justice of our fourth largest state,'' Shaw said. ``While I welcome the challenge, I am also aware of the awesome responsibility that accompanies such a promotion.'' Shaw, who will be 60 in September, assumes his new responsibilities July 1. He has served on the Supreme Court since January 1983, when he was appointed by former Gov. Bob Graham. Shaw, who sided with the court's majority last year in striking down the state's parental-consent law on abortions, has been targeted for defeat by abortion opponents. He faces a merit retention fight _ a yes-no question on whether a judge should retain office _ on the November ballot. Shaw's appointment to a two-year term by the rest of the high court comes almost exactly 40 years after the state appointed its first black judge.

DOC.HEAD: Heat Wave Continues In East, Snowstorm In Denver
LaserPhoto NY21
DOC.TEXT: Record high temperatures in the 70s and 80s made Tuesday feel like a day in June across much of the East, drawing winter-weary people outside to sidewalk cafes and lunch-time strolls and boosting sales of outdoor toys. ``That's the end of winter,'' said Danko Orbanich, sitting on the steps of St. Patrick's Cathedral in New York City. Not necessarily. A storm hit Colorado and Wyoming with enough snow Tuesday to snarl traffic and cut air traffic in half. More in keeping in warmer seasons, thunderstorms broke out across Illinois and the southern Plains and generated tornadoes that caused minor damage in Kansas. ``This is just a preview of spring,'' David Koehler, a National Weather Service meteorologist in Ann Arbor, Mich. ``There's still a possibility we can get some snow before the end of winter, but if we do, it won't stay around long.'' Most record high temperatures are reported in the heat of the afternoon, but Grand Rapids, Mich., started out the day with a record-tying 68 degrees at midnight. Some other early records were 85 degrees at New York City, where temperatures a week ago were in the low 30s; Philadelphia and Atlantic City, N.J.; 86 at Newark, N.J.; and Chicago tied its record of 70. New York's reading was 38 degrees above normal, 14 degrees above the record for the date set in 1929. It also was the city's warmest day since Sept. 11, when the high was 91, and the earliest that the temperature has reached 80 degrees in Central Park since record keeping started in 1869. ``It's wonderful, it's great. Only problem is that if it gets cold again everything that's blooming now is going to die,'' said mounted Baltimore policeman David Eastman, 44. The unseasonable heat wave was great for anyone whose business had anything to do with the outdoors, like Eddie Morrocco, whose Morrocco's Italian Restaurant in downtown Washington, D.C., opened up its outdoor tables. On Sunday, Morrocco said, they had no business outside. ``I've been doing outside business for at least 30 years and we've never been able to open (outside) in March. Never,'' Morrocco said. Merchants in South Carolina reported increased sales of Frisbees, volleyball sets, tennis supplies and baseball and softball equipment. ``The way the weather has been lately we've been selling more walking shoes than anything else,'' said Kirk Hackett, assistant manager of a shoe store in Fort Mill. The warm weather had people calling for service on their air conditioning or to get replacement air conditioners in North Carolina. ``We're swamped,'' said Ben Crabtree, in charge of the service department at a heating and air conditioning company in Knightdale, outside Raleigh. But it wasn't good business weather for everybody. ``The heating oil business is a dead soldier. It's deader than George Washington,'' said Dick Jones, warehouse manager at an oil company in Raleigh. And some outdoor activities also suffered. Lenny and Robin Wayne, tourists from Los Angeles visiting New York City, took a few spins around the Rockefeller Center ice skating rink, but left early. ``It's too hot to ice skate,'' Wayne said. The hot air spawned thunderstorms that rained golfball-size hail on northwestern Illinois and posed threats of new flooding in soggy Vermilion County, where 55,000 residents remained without water service because flooding put water pumps out of action. Some of the 200 people forced from their homes because of flooding along the North Fork River north of Danville returned home to check damage. An estimated 19 mobile homes and cabins along the river were destroyed. In the West, 5 inches of wet snow had fallen by midday at Cheyenne, Wyo., just a week after a storm shut down much of southeastern Wyoming. Denver's Stapleton International Airport had 3 inches by morning and 13 inches had fallen at Wolf Creek Pass in southwestern Colorado. Rush-hour traffic was slowed to a crawl, and Stapleton cut its departures by more than half because of winds and poor visibility. On the Plains, thunderstorms battered parts of Kansas, Oklahoma and Texas with rain and wind. Kansas also had tornadoes that damaged some homes and buildings but caused no severe injuries, authorities said. At least 10 homes were damaged near Topeka and power lines were down in other parts of Shawnee and Jefferson counties. ``There were at least two homes that were a total loss and a number with varying degrees of damage, such as roof damage and glass breakage,'' said Ken Burgett, director of emergency preparedness in Shawnee County, Kan.

DOC.HEAD: Shamir Dissolves Alliance, Bush Comments on Israel Blamed
LaserPhotos JRL1,2,3; LaserColor JRL8, NY12
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4 grafs for 5th pvs, `Labor's departure...' to UPDATE with appeals to Supreme Court, Shamir quote. Pick up 6th pvs, `Avi Pazner...'; INSERTS 1 graf after 12th, `The balance...' to ADD background.
DOC.TEXT: JERUSALEM _ Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir on Tuesday dissolved a political alliance with the center-left Labor Party in a crisis brought to a head by President Bush's comments on the status of Jerusalem. Shamir fired Vice Premier Shimon Peres, the Labor leader, and the 10 other Labor ministers submitted their resignations after an impasse was reached on whether to accept U.S. proposals for talks in Cairo with a Palestinian delegation. The two major parties immediately sought allies from among the small ultra-Orthodox religious factions that control the balance of power in advance of a no-confidence vote scheduled Thursday in the Parliament. Labor and the left-wing Citizens Rights Movement appealed to the Supreme Court to change the parliament vote to Wednesday. The appeals were to be considered Wednesday morning. Labor's departure from the government won't take effect for 48 hours, leaving the door open for a compromise to preserve the coalition which has ruled Israel through two stalemated elections since 1984. Shamir, asked if he still wanted to save the coalition, said on Israel Television: ``If I could I would. The whole world knows that the idea of a national unity government is precious for me. But this does not depend on me.'' Avi Pazner, Shamir's spokesman, said that ``as long as there is life there is hope, but I really am not very optimistic about a compromise.'' Peres, who also held out little hope for patching up differences, raised the possibility of avoiding new elections by forming a Labor-led government with ultra-Orthodox and left-wing parties. ``We do hope to continue the peace process. We think there is a chance, but I cannot say this is certain, to form a coalition to continue the peace process,'' Peres said. The balance of power was held by two ultra-Orthodox religious parties who held seven of the 120 seats in the Knesset, or parliament. Labor and its allies control 55 seats, while Likud and its partners control 58. One of the parties, Agudat Israel, announced that it would back Labor in the no-confidence vote. The other, Torah Flag, was undecided. Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin of Labor, who has favored trying to preserve the National Unity government, blamed the crisis on Shamir's refusal to accept a last-minute compromise to join Labor in accepting the proposals put forth by U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker. `I am very sorry about it,'' Rabin said. ``I believe we were close and ... we could have finished a resolution that included a positive answer to U.S. Secretary Baker if the Likud was ready to do so.'' In an interview on Israel radio, Shamir said Jerusalem was the sticking point with Labor and bristled at Bush's equating of Jewish neighborhoods in Arab east Jerusalem with West Bank settlements. ``The Likud stands steadfast that Jerusalem isn't part of Judea and Samaria (the West Bank),'' said Shamir, adding he would not agree to the 140,000 Jerusalem Arabs being involved in elections or a proposed self-rule plan for the occupied territories. Jerusalem, he said, is an issue ``about which we are very sensitive, especially these days when we hear voices from the United States.'' Baker proposed Palestinians from east Jerusalem take part in a Palestinian negotiating team and subsequent elections. Shamir opposed the involvement, saying it would prejudge Israel's claim to east Jerusalem, which was captured from Jordan in the 1967 Middle East War. Aides said Shamir was not adamant on the issue until March 4, when Bush said U.S. aid to Israel would be influenced by whether Israel continued to build ``new settlements'' in the West Bank or east Jerusalem. Pazner, a top Shamir aide, said differences between Labor and Likud over east Jerusalem were brought to a head. ``Suddenly, with President Bush's statement Jerusalem became the central and main issue of the whole peace process. From there things started to snowball,'' Pazner said. ``It's a pity that President Bush raised this issue at this very delicate time.'' Mark Heller, an independent political analyst at Tel Aviv University's Jaffee Center for Strategic Studies, said U.S. officials had mishandled the Jerusalem issue, giving Shamir backing for a hard line on an issue in which Israelis were united. ``In terms of tactics and timing, Bush and Baker were badly advised,'' Heller said. Defying U.S. policy, Likud Housing Minister David Levy laid the cornerstone Tuesday for a new 3,500-unit apartment complex in the new Jerusalem suburb of East Pisgat Zeev, which is being built on war-won land. ``They are preaching to us about Jerusalem, casting doubt on our desire that in our capital another wall will not be erected that divides east and west,'' Levy said. Asked at a news conference in Washington whether he regretted his statements, Bush said, ``No, I don't regret it,'' but said he would not elaborate because the issue was ``so sensitive, and it's so emotional.'' Palestinians, who also adopt a hard line in demanding east Jerusalem as the capital of a proposed Palestinian state, described the Israeli government collapse as a setback for peace. In Cairo, PLO representative Saeed Kamal accused Shamir of ``futile actions aimed only a wasting time.'' Bethlehem Mayor Elias Freij said ``I believe Israel has killed its own peace plan ... and this will have very dangerous repercussions throughout the Middle East.'' Freij alluded to predictions that without an active diplomatic process, Arab-Israeli tensions would increase and result in violence, both in the occupied territories and from radical Palestinian groups abroad.

DOC.HEAD: Trade Deficit Sank to Five-Year Low in 1989, Government Says
DOC.TEXT: The government said Tuesday that the deficit in the broadest measure of U.S. trade sank to a five-year low last year, but the $105.9 billion imbalance still pushed the country deeper into the hole as the world's largest debtor nation. America's current account balance narrowed by 16 percent over a $126.6 billion deficit in 1988, reflecting growth in exports, higher overseas earnings of American businesses and increased spending by visiting foreign tourists, according to the Commerce Department. The year ended on a positive note as the October-December trade deficit declined to $20.57 billion, down 10.2 percent from its third quarter level. It was the smallest quarterly imbalance in almost six years. But private economists were unimpressed, contending that even with the improvement the current account deficit remained above $100 billion for the sixth consecutive year as the United States plunged further into hock to the rest of the world. The current account, also known as the balance of payments, is the most closely watched trade statistic because it measures not only trade in merchandise but also trade in services and investments. It reflects the amount of money the United States must borrow annually from foreigners. America began the 1980s as the world's largest creditor nation. It ran surpluses in its current account as the earnings on overseas investments were enough to offset perennial deficits in merchandise trade. But as Americans handed over billions of dollars to foreigners to pay for imported cars and television sets, the investment cushion eroded and disappeared altogether in 1985, when the United States became a net debtor for the first time in 71 years. The government calculates that the total debt stood at $532.5 billion at the end of 1988. Tuesday's report indicates that it increased to close to $640 billion by the end of 1989, although the official accounting will not be made until June. America's total debt is expected to top $1 trillion in the next few years as the current account deficit remains stuck around the $100 billion level. Foreigners now own more in U.S. assets than Americans own overseas, a development that has triggered debate over whether the United States is losing control of its economic destiny. President Bush, like Ronald Reagan, has insisted that the growth of foreign investment in the United States is a sign of strength, showing that America remains an attractive place for investments. Many private economists fear, however, that Americans' living standards will be lowered in future years as more and more dollars flow into foreign hands to meet interest and dividend payments on the growing debt. ``The United States is the world's biggest debtor and that is a big problem for the country,'' said Allen Sinai, chief economist of the Boston Co. ``Increasingly, the ravages of debt are showing up in this country.'' Sinai said that the need for the Federal Reserve to keep interest rates high enough to attract foreign capital had already translated into slower growth in the United States. David Wyss, an economist with DRI-McGraw Hill, predicted that the current account would actually worsen in 1990, after two years of improvement, reflecting slower growth in exports and a higher U.S. oil bill. ``Most of the improvement in trade occurred in early 1988 and since then things have essentially stalled out and we expect them to stay stalled,'' he said. The 1989 current account deficit was the smallest since a $104.2 bilion deficit in 1984. It was down from an all-time high of $143.7 billion in 1987. The merchandise trade deficit narrowed 11 percent to $113.25 billion as a 13.4 percent jump in exports offset a 6.4 percent rise in imports. The surplus in the services and investment category jumped by 41.3 percent to $21.65 billion, reflecting increased foreign travel in America and higher earnings by U.S. companies operating abroad. The third segment of the current account, U.S. foreign aid and pension payments to Americans living abroad, added $14.28 billion to the deficit last year. In the fourth quarter, the $20.57 billion deficit was the smallest since the first quarter of 1984 and compared to a $22.91 billion deficit in the third quarter. Analysts said much of the improvement in the final three months of the year came from a decline in the value of the dollar, which increases the earnings of U.S. companies operating abroad when the foreign currency earnings are translated back into dollars. In a second report Tuesday, the Commerce Department said that retail sales dropped 0.9 percent to a seasonally adjusted $146.5 billion in February. While the decline was the steepest in four months, analysts said the weakness was confined to auto sales. Other retail establishments reported healthy gains.

DOC.HEAD: Guinness Record Champ Claims Another Peculiar Prize
DOC.TEXT: The record-holding Guinness world record-holder muscled his way through another peculiar pastime Tuesday, cranking out 1,551 squat-thrusts in a single hour. Then he was ready for some exercise. ``I feel fantastic,'' said Ashrita Furman, 35, who lost two pounds and almost fainted while performing before awestruck observers in a Manhattan gym. ``I want to go out running, to kind of loosen up.'' Furman has walked, hopped, run, rowed, pogosticked, somersaulted, bent, balanced and yodeled his way to a dozen entries in the U.S. edition of the Guinness Book of World Records. Squat-thrusts, once certified, will make it 13. ``The guy is amazing,'' said Robert Fuchs, owner of the Natural Physique Centre, who kept count and checked Furman's form as the stuntman sweated out his routine. ``I don't think he's human. It was incredible.'' ``He's phenomenal,'' said David Boehm, U.S. editor of the record book. ``He's only one of a number of what you might call nuts setting these records. But he wanted to have more records than anybody else, and he does.'' Squat-thrusts are produced by squatting with hands on the floor, thrusting the legs out and back, drawing them in, then standing erect. Furman did more than one every two seconds, resting after each 40 squats. ``It looked like every muscle in the guy's body was about to collapse,'' said Fuchs, a 26-year veteran of the bodybuilding business. ``He was lying over the counter on his rests, or hanging on the door to get fresh air. You think he's going to pass out and then, bingo, he starts out fresh.'' ``It was very intense,'' allowed Furman, a health food store manager. ``I almost fainted around 600. ... I have some bloody blisters on my hands. ... It was such an intense thing I didn't feel the blisters until it was over.'' Sound like fun? Consider Furman's earlier feats, which include underwater pogosticking in the Amazon River, somersaulting 12.5 miles, running 50 miles while juggling three balls, yodeling for 27 hours, doing 2,550 deep knee bends in an hour and walking 32.9 miles while balancing an open pint bottle of milk on his forehead. ``When you edit this book, you're never astounded at anything these people do,'' sighed Boehm. ``If you met Ashrita not knowing about the records, you'd say he was quite sane.'' There is a method, in fact, to Furman's peculiar pastimes. ``Sure, some of these things are totally stupid,'' he said. ``But it's the principle of the thing. There's a lot of determination and concentration involved.'' A former couch potato who now boasts 15-inch biceps, Furman credits his prowess to meditation, which he gently urges that others try. ``I'm trying to show people they have much more capacity than they think they have,'' he said. There's personal satisfaction, as well: ``It's such a fulfilling thing. I love the intensity of it,'' he said. ``It's like one of the most pure forms of experience you can have. Sort of like being out on the battlefield.'' There are other wars to come: Furman plans this June to pogostick up the 1,760 stairs of the CN Tower in Toronto. And he's aiming to recapture the Guinness running-while-skipping-rope record he recently lost. Furman also held and then lost the squat-thrust record he claims to have regained Tuesday, and he has no illusions about 1,551 squats _ 51 better than the old record _ standing for long. ``I'm sure this is going to be broken, That's the point of this,'' he said. ``That's the point of humanity. Records were made to be broken.''

DOC.HEAD: 22 Dead, 100 Wounded in Nationwide Clashes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with 22 dead, more injuries, arrests, comments from law and order minister; CORRECTS that KwaZulu legislative body is called legislative assembly, sted Parliament.
DOC.TEXT: Black groups fought with police and each other throughout South Africa, and 22 people were killed, more than 100 wounded and 500 arrested, police said Tuesday. Police listed more than 60 incidents on Monday and Tuesday, the largest number on the daily report since violence erupted last month in black areas across the country. More than 200 blacks have been killed since early February, most of them in factional fighting. In the southeastern province of Natal, the site of four years of fighting between rival groups, police said eight black men were stabbed, shot or burned to death in three separate attacks. Elsewhere, four black men were killed in separate incidents when police fired birdshot to disperse stone-throwers in the Cape and Orange Free State provinces, the report added. Also, seven blacks were killed in a series of attacks in townships around Johannesburg and the bodies of three blacks who had been fatally shot were found in the Orange Free State, police said. Most of the injuries occurred in Natal and the Witbank township east of Johannesburg. Those arrested were picked up at demonstrations in and around Cape Town and in the Orange Free State. The unrest report also listed instances of arson and attacks against black policemen and their homes. Militant activists consider black police collaborators with the white-run government and often target them for attack. Apart from Natal, where about 3,000 blacks have been killed since 1986, there was relatively little unrest prior to last month, when President F.W. de Klerk legalized more than 60 black opposition groups and released black leader Nelson Mandela. ``Instead of bringing responsibility, this freedom is being misused,'' Law and Order Minister Adriaan Vlok told Parliament in Cape Town. Vlok compared the recent unrest to the nationwide violence of the mid-1980s, which led the government to declare a state of emergency in June 1986. De Klerk has said he wants to lift the emergency, but won't do so unless the violence subsides. Some of the battles involve bitter political rivalries, but elsewhere the conflict is between taxi groups battling for control of routes, young gangs with no political affiliations, and ordinary criminals taking advantage of chaotic circumstances. The government has said the violence jeopardizes efforts to open negotiations on a new constitution that will include black-white power sharing. Constitutional Development Minister Gerrit Viljoen on Tuesday urged black leaders to ``fulfill their responsibilities at the negotiation table.'' ``We are waiting for you,'' Viljoen told the legislative assembly in the black homeland of KwaZulu. Viljoen praised homeland leader Mangosuthu Buthelezi for his ``consistent contribution to the facilitation of the negotiation process.'' The relatively conservative Buthelezi, whose supporters have been fighting more militant black groups in Natal Province, says he is ready to begin negotiations with the government. The African National Congress guerrilla movement, the country's leading black opposition group, said last month it would send a delegation ``as soon as possible'' from its exile headquarters in Zambia to hold preliminary talks with the South African government. The ANC still has not set a date for the arrival of its delegation.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Urges End to Mozambique Civil War
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Tuesday saluted Mozambique's march toward democracy and economic reform, urging President Joaquim Chissano to begin talks ``at the earliest opportunity'' to end the 10-year-old civil war. Chissano assured Bush that his government was already taking steps ``to enter into a direct dialogue'' with the RENAMO rebels as soon as possible. Chissano, whose African country has abandoned Marxism and shifted its sights toward the West, congratulated Bush on U.S. efforts ``to promote peace and democracy in southern Africa,'' especially Namibia and South Africa. Bush, at a departure ceremony after talks in the Oval Office and over lunch, offered a strong endorsement of Mozambique's reforms, which he said had also ``buoyed the Mozambique peace process.'' ``For that, Mr. President, I salute you. Yet we look forward to even further reforms,'' said Bush, who expressed concern about the millions of Mozambicans suffering from both the war and drought. ``We urge all parties to talk at the earliest opportunity so as to avoid further suffering,'' he said. Chissano, who became president in 1986 after Samora Machel died in a plane crash, said his government had put forward a draft constitution that would provide for universal sufferage, including direct election of the president and the People's Assembly. Chissano called his reception at the White House ``another giant step forward'' for Mozambique. It came five years after a path-breaking visit by Machel to Washington during the Reagan administration. Chissano, speaking English, said he told Bush ``of the decision of my government to enter into a direct dialogue with RENAMO as soon as possible, and about the measures already taken to bring this decision into effect.'' Chissano expressed appreciation ``for the stand the United States has taken on the war in Mozambique and for the positive role it has been playing in the peace process.'' RENAMO, an organization vilified by human rights groups for its brutality in the civil war, has been demanding that the Mozambique government abandon Marxism-Leninism and establish a multiparty system. Mozambique, which gained independence from Portugal in 1975, formally abandoned Marxism last summer. As a reward for embracing private enterprise and a free-market economy, Bush recently struck the country from the U.S. list of Marxist states, opening the way for lending and trade concessions. Attempts at getting the two sides to stop their war began last year, with the presidents of Zimbabwe and Kenya mediating. Chissano expressed the hope the United States would ``spare no effort until peace, stability and economic prosperity are achieved in the region of southern Africa.'' An estimated 3.2 million Mozambicans have been driven from their homes, either to internal or external exile during the civil war. The international community has had to give Mozambique $300 million to buy food every year. Mozambique, on the southeast coast of Africa, has a population of 15 million. RENAMO was created originally by the white South African government to counter the Mozambican government's support for the African National Congress. However, South Africa's new president, President F.W. de Klerk, has cut off assistance to RENAMO and recognized the ANC.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Says Hoax Telephone Call About Hostages Will Make Fascinating Story
With AM-Bush Rdp Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, declaring that he has gone the extra mile to free American hostages, said Tuesday people will be ``very, very fascinated'' when the whole story comes out about his hoax telephone call from a purported Iranian leader. Bush refused to provide any details about efforts to free the hostages, but said his administration has sought information from everywhere, even ``going around back alleys'' to learn about the captives' plight. He told reporters at a White House news conference that his decision to accept a telephone call from an impostor claiming to be Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani was an example of his willingness to pursue all leads. ``I think the bottom line is, you have to say, would you do it again based on the information you had? And I'd say, yeah, I probably would. ... I will go the extra mile. ``And when the whole story comes out on this, you all are going to be very, very fascinated with the details. Very fascinated.'' The president took the call several weeks ago after a man identifying himself as an Iranaian official contacted the White House to say that Rafsanjani wanted to talk about the American hostages in Lebanon. The captives are thought to be held by pro-Iranian Moslem Shiites. At the State Department, meanwhile, an official with knowledge of the hostage issue said he knew of no recent developments that could signal freedom soon for the eight Americans and 10 others in Lebanon. The official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said, ``We have been told numerous times from the highest levels that there is nothing.'' Asked what he knew about Bush's telephone call, the official said, ``It came from Tehran and it came from a government building but nobody knows who it was.'' Bush's aides have not ruled out the call was instigated by a faction within the Iranian government. Peggy Say, the sister of Terry Anderson, the longest-held American hostage, said she ``wouldn't be surprised'' to see new developments about the hostages. Mrs. Say, who recently went to the Middle East on a mission to gain Anderson's release, said she believes Iran has started on a course that will eventually lead to freedom for the captives. Iran, she said, is under growing international pressure to do something about the hostages before it receives aid from the West to rebuild its country, devastated economically by an eight-year war with Iraq. Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, will mark his fifth year in captivity on Friday. Bush denied rumors spawned in Tehran that he or his aides had tried for a month to get in touch with Rafsanjani. ``He's got some political problems at home and we understand that,'' the president said. The Bush administration's official policy on the hostages is that it will not negotiate with the hostage-holders or their patrons. At the same time, officials say they are willing to talk with anyone about the hostages. Last week, Marlin Fitzwater, the president's spokesman, said the administration was encouraged by Rafsanjani's reported statement that he would like to see the hostages freed soon.

DOC.HEAD: Discovery of Skeleton Apparently Ends Bizarre Case of Wife's Murder
DOC.TEXT: Hikers have found the skeleton of a 70-year-old man who was sought in the September slaying of his wife, a case featured on the television show ``Unsolved Mysteries,'' authorities said. Joe Frisino of the King County medical examiner's office identified the man Monday as Joe Lynn Owens. The cause of death remained undetermined pending an autopsy. ``It's a sad ending to a sad case,'' said homicide Sgt. Joe Ritter. ``I wish he would have at least left something to tell us why he did it.'' Owens disappeared Sept. 7, the day after police questioned him about the disappearance of his 78-year-old wife, Gladys. Her body was found Sept. 14 under a false floor below a compost pile at the couple's west Seattle home after police acted on tips. She died of a gunshot wound to the back of the head. King County police Maj. Jackson Beard said investigators were called to a trail about 30 miles east of Seattle on Sunday after two hikers found a human back bone. Police searched the area Monday and found more bones, clothing, Owens' hearing aid, glasses and a gun. When questioned about Mrs. Owens' disappearance, Owens told relatives his wife was going to school in Canada and told neighbors she had gone to Kansas to visit relatives. He was questioned Sept. 6 after a neighbor told police of the conflicting accounts. Detectives then learned Owens had told his wife's nephew she had taken an overdose of pills and he had buried her on family property. When detectives returned to question him Sept. 7, he was gone. Police got a search warrant and found Mrs. Owens' body a week later. Owens was charged in absentia with first-degree murder.

DOC.HEAD: Aspen Voters Go to Polls on Recall of Mayor, Councilmen
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Polls close at 9 p.m. EST
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Texas Primary Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Voters went to the polls Tuesday to decide whether to recall the mayor who led last month's unsuccessful drive to ban fur sales and three other city councilmen criticized as rude and hostile to growth. The election came exactly one month after a record turnout of voters defeated by a 2-1 margin a proposal to make this Rockies resort the nation's first furrier-free town. Deputy city clerk Jan Carney predicted a turnout of about 60 percent of the city's 3,850 registered voters. The Feb. 13 election drew 71 percent of voters. Morning turnout appeared to be lighter than in February but was difficult to gauge because there were more polling places this time, she said. A heavy snowfall would not deter many voters, she said. ``This is Aspen,'' Carney said. ``They should be celebrating that we have snow. It's not cold or nasty, just a little sloppy.'' The highly publicized anti-fur campaign by four-term Mayor Bill Stirling and three city councilmen attracted animal rights activists from as far away as Sweden and England to the chic mountain town. The targeted councilmen were Steve Crockett, Frank Peters and Michael Gassman.

Those hoping to oust a majority of the five-member council accused the recall targets of being rude and unresponsive to constituents' concerns. But the election involved more than personalities. Some longtime residents believe Aspen has lost its soul in becoming a playground for the rich and famous. But recall supporters said efforts to save Aspen by limiting growth have become exclusionary and nasty. Aspen's population is said to peak at about 20,000 in the winter. Many property owners do not live here full time, and real estate prices have skyrocketed during the past decade. Residents voted last month for growth, defeating by 1,561 to 1,051 a measure to reduce the size of a luxury hotel by 25 percent, and approving measures to widen the highway leading into town and a bond measure to build affordable housing for employees. The winners hailed the results as a victory for free enterprise. Losers said the mood in the town, home of ``gonzo'' journalist Hunter S. Thompson and other eccentrics, had taken a lurch beyond the bourgeois. Aspen was the first U.S. community to pass a tough anti-smoking ordinance and the first to declare itself a nuclear-free zone.

DOC.HEAD: West German Woman Killed in Alps Ski Accident
DOC.TEXT: A West German woman died and her companion was seriously injured Tuesday in a skiing accident at the Alpine resort of Avoriaz, police said. Heidi Kraus, 48, of West Berlin, was killed when she and Birk Heinicke went over a cliff and fell onto a rocky outcropping while skiing off the main ski runs, police in Annecy reported. Heinicke, flown by helicopter to a hospital in Montet, Switzerland, was reported to be suffering from multiple injuries, police said. Other details were not available.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Says He Has No Regrets on Jerusalem Statement
With AM-Bush Rdp Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Tuesday dismissed the idea that his statements on Jerusalem had contributed to the shattering of Israel's governing coalition, while the administration postponed promoting Mideast talks until Israel forms a government ``capable of making these decisions.'' Bush and others in the administration declined to offer judgments on the Israeli situation. But the president held firm to his statements describing East Jerusalem as occupied territory. ``I don't regret it,'' Bush said of his statement that also declared the predominantly Arab section of the city off-limits to Jewish ``settlers.'' ``I was reiterating U.S. policy,'' the president said. He told a news conference his statement had been blown out of proportion by speculation and commentaries. Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney, asked by young Jewish leaders about the U.S. policy on Jerusalem, said the United States believes Jerusalem should remain a united city but that the question of who controls it should be tackled as the last step of Arab-Israeli peace negotiations. Citing the dissolution a few hours earlier of the Israeli government's political coalition, Bush said: ``I will answer no more. ... It is so sensitive, so emotional, any further speculation on this question would not be useful given what has happened in the last few hours.'' The collapse of the Israeli Cabinet followed acrimonious debate about the U.S. formula for talks with Palestinian Arabs and Bush's March 3 statement in Palm Springs, Calif. ``I don't want to look in any way (like) we are trying to mingle in the internal affairs of Israel as they are going through this difficult period,'' Bush said Tuesday. On Sunday, amid acrimonious debate, Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir declined to put the U.S. plan for Israeli talks with Palestinian Arabs in Cairo to a vote by the 12-member inner Cabinet. With the collapse of the government on Tuesday, the State Department acknowledged the U.S. plan, which included roles in the talks for a Palestinian with a home in East Jerusalem and another deported by Israel from the West Bank, could not move ahead. ``Obviously, there is a political crisis in Israel, and until that is sorted out, Israel won't be in a position to make a decision,'' spokeswoman Margaret D. Tutwiler said. ``The government of Israel is now working through its own political process and will sort out its own situation. We obviously will be watching this process closely, and I am not going to make any other comments on internal political developments in Israel.'' Secretary of State James A. Baker III, who worked on the plan for eight months, is committed to promoting negotiations, the spokeswoman said. But, she added, ``it is not our place to make decisions for Israel, and our ability to support and move forward on peace depends upon an Israeli government capable of making these decisions.'' Bush's earlier statement was taken both by the Likud coalition and the Labor party as a challenge to Israel's retention of East Jerusalem, held by Jordan for 19 years until it was won by Israel in the 1967 Mideast war. Asked if the statement contributed to the political crisis in Israel, spokeswoman Tutwiler replied: ``Absolutely not.'' She said Baker would not abandon his effort, and she invited anyone who has a better plan to implement Shamir's proposal for elections on the West Bank and in Gaza to make it known.

DOC.HEAD: Jail Officials Stop Dangerous Practice
DOC.TEXT: Orange County jail officials have ended a practice of hog-tying violent inmates and sandwiching them between mattresses since the death of a prisoner who was restrained for more than three hours. Jail Director Tom Allison said a jail committee had recommended halting the ``mattress sandwich technique'' in August, but that he ignored the advice until inmate Ricky Richardson, 31, died Dec. 30. ``Obviously, with the death of Richardson, we have reconsidered that,'' Allison said Monday. ``We are not using that system right now and probably will not use it in the future.'' His family alleged in a federal court suit against Orange County and the jail that Richardson's death was caused by ``inhumane, unjustifiable ... and grossly disproportionate'' treatment. Jail officials said they acted appropriately in hog-tying and sandwiching Richardson for 3{ hours because he had bitten, scratched and kicked guards during two violent outbursts. He was found unconscious by jail guards and died less than an hour later. An initial autopsy suggests Richardson was not suffocated or beaten to death and did not die from an AIDS-related condition, but was running a potentially fatal 108-degree fever when he died, said Medical Examiner Thomas Hegert. In August, the jail's Planning, Accountability and Control Committee recommended that an alternative method be used to restrain violent inmates. Allison said he did not follow the committee's recommendation at the time because ``we really didn't see enough reason to discontinue the mattresses.'' The alternative method, which involves strapping an inmate's wrists, ankles, midriff and head to a specially designed bunk, is effective only for a short time because the straps can chafe or work loose, he said. Allison said the best way to restrain violent inmates is to sedate them, but only hospitals are permitted to do that. He said he will ask state officials to let jailers forcibly sedate such prisoners.

DOC.HEAD: Experts Say Many Americans Struggle with Tranquilizer Addiction
With AM-Barry, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Marion Barry's statement Tuesday that he is chemically dependent on two tranquilizers _ Valium and Xanax _ would make him a member of a rather large group of Americans who have abused the drugs, experts say. ``It's quite common,'' said Dr. Rudolf Hoehn-Saric, an associate professor of psychiatry at Johns Hopkins University. ``Both are quite addictive drugs.'' Valium and Xanax have a variety of legitimate uses and are prescribed to relieve stress, anxiety, panic attacks and enhance sleep and relax muscles. Barry, who commented after returning Washington after treatment for chemical dependency, did not say if the pills had been prescribed. Aides have said Barry's major problem was alcholism. The mayor, who left Washington seven weeks ago to begin treatment, faces five misdemeanor charges of cocaine possession and three felony charges of perjury before a grand jury. Gene Haislip, deputy assistant administrator for the Drug Enforcement Administration's office of diversion control, says the two drugs are among the pharmaceuticals most frequently diverted from the legitimate market. A total of 9.5 million Americans surveyed in 1988 for the National Household Survey on Drug Abuse said they had used tranquilizers _ including but not limited to Valium and Xanax _ non-medically at least once in their lives, according to Mona Brown of the National Institute on Drug Abuse. In addition, 1.2 million Americans said they had used such drugs non-medically in the 30 days before the survey was conducted, Brown said. In 1988, use of Valium was mentioned in 6,082 emergency room cases and Xanax was reported 3,846 times, according to NIDA. One prominent case occurred in February 1987, when former presidential adviser Robert C. McFarlane, under investigation in the Iran-Contra scandal, attempted suicide with an overdose of Valium. Valium and Xanax are rarely fatal when taken alone, ``but if you mix them with alcohol, they can be deadly,'' Hoehn-Saric said, adding that Valium is the more addictive. ``It gives you a quick high,'' he said. ``People who are addicted are looking for that high.'' Xanax, meanwhile, is ``like a drink here and there to help relieve stress,'' he said. ``But if it's used frequently _ like morning, noon and night _ it becomes addictive.'' Hoehn-Saric said Valium withdrawal can mean sleeplessness and anxiety. If the person has been taking high doses, he said, ``it could cause seizures if you withdraw too fast.'' Dr. Brian Doyle, a clinical professor of psychiatry at Georgetown University Hospital, said it takes six to 12 weeks to get off the drugs for people who have been taking it under medical supervision in appropriate doses. Recreational users taking higher doses need longer, he said. In recent years, physicians have reduced their prescriptions of Valium as they became aware of the addiction potential, Hoehn-Saric said. The use of the tranquilizers were so widespread during the 1970s that it became part of the popular culture and a subject for humor. In a memorable scene from the 1977 movie, ``An Unmarried Woman,'' starring Jill Clayburgh and Alan Bates, a department store crowd is asked if anyone has a Valium. Everyone in sight immediately reaches for his or her personal supply.

DOC.HEAD: Communist Leadership in San Marino Decides to Change Name
DOC.TEXT: The Communist Party leadership in this tiny hilltop republic voted Tuesday evening to change the party name and its hammer-and-sickle symbol. The vote by the party chiefs in this Appenine Mountain country of 22,500 residents marked the latest defeat for communism following the 1989-90 revolutions that coursed through Eastern Europe. The Central Committee voted 13-12 to rename the party the Democratic Progressive Party and replace its symbol with a dove portrayed against the towers on the three main mountains of the world's oldest republic. The 12 dissenters Tuesday night wanted a different name: Democratic Party of Work. The party rank-and-file will vote on the new name and symbol at a congress April 26-28. The Communist Party claims about 1,300 members in this 23-square-mile republic, which is surrounded by Italy near the Adriatic. Although the Communists fared well in the last general elections in 1988, increasing from 24 percent to 29 percent of the vote, the Central Committee was unanimous on changing the name. The Communists are the country's second-biggest party after the Christian Democrats. They have ruled together in coalitions in the past. San Marino, founded in the year 301, depends on tourism, postage stamps and financial services as chief sources of income.

DOC.HEAD: First Policeman Goes On Trial For Assaulting Peaceful Demonstrators
DOC.TEXT: The first of 25 police officers charged in the bloody crackdown on dissent that began Czechoslovakia's November revolution against Communist rule went on trial Tuesday. First Lt. Jaroslav Oudran pleaded guilty before a military court in Terezin, 40 miles north of Prague, on charges of ``abusing power of a public official.'' Oudran faces a prison term of up to ten years. Riot police on Nov. 17 brutally dispersed tens of thousands of protesters peacefully commemorating the 50th anniversary of the death of Jan Opletal, who protested the Nazi occupation of Czechoslovakia in 1939. As the protest drew to a close, about 2,000 people were blocked and beaten by police. The repression triggered the uprising that eventually toppled the hard-line Communist regime of Milos Jakes. Former dissident Vaclav Havel was later elected president. Prosecutors said Oudran beat onlooker Katerina Vavrova _ hitting her in the face, grabbing her by the hair and pounding her head against the stone pillar of an arcade at least four times. When she fell to the ground, he allegedly kicked her in the hip. Vavrova, 29, could not work for three months, the prosecution said. ``I cannot tell you exactly what kind of a sentence he will get until all the evidence is heard,'' prosecutor Miroslav Janzura said. The prosecution said a verdict was expected Wednesday. During the crackdown, about 590 people were injured, including dozens of foreign journalists, according to Josef Stank, head of a security commission investigating the police action. He was quoted by the daily, Lidova Demokracie. The Prague Communist Party boss during the crackdown, Miroslav Stepan, was arrested Dec. 23. Stepan, who faces charges of ``giving orders ... to abuse power of a public official,'' is expected to be tried in March. Stepan is the only civilian in custody in connection with the Nov. 17 events, and Oudran is the first of the 25 police officers to be tried.

DOC.HEAD: Opposition Appeals for Election Delay
DOC.TEXT: Opposition parties Tuesday appealed for a postponement of Romania's first free postwar elections, saying the country is still crippled by oppression and unprepared for democratic balloting. ``Please tell us who is ready to take power today. Take it and go ahead,'' interim President Ion Iliescu responded to opposition delegates at a parliament session to pass an election law for the scheduled May 20 vote. Minutes earlier during a break in the session, Iliescu had been handed a letter asking for the election delay. The letter was signed by 23 opposition parties, including the National Peasants Party and the National Liberal Party, the two largest. Most of the parliament's work Tuesday focused on taking steps to try to prevent a future president from becoming a dictator, including barring candidates who committed abuses under Nicolae Ceausescu's hard-line Communist government. The letter was the boldest move yet by the opposition campaign to postpone the elections, which would be the first free vote in Romania since 1937. Iliescu had told delegates earlier Tuesday that authority to change the election day rested with the government led by interim Premier Petre Roman, not with him. The letter did not propose a new date but Ion Radu Zilisteanu of the National Democratic Party suggested a three-month delay. The opposition has claimed a fair vote was not possible so quickly after the December revolution that toppled Ceausescu, especially with the continuing political dominance of the National Salvation Front. The Front seized power in the chaos of the revolution and formed a provisional government with Iliescu as interim president. It relinquished part of its power last month to the interim parliament, known as the Council of National Unity, after the Front decided to become a full-fledged political party and run in the elections. ``The electorate is not prepared for free and democratic elections because of the climate of insecurity and oppression that is maintained in the country, fueled by ill-meaning elements,'' the letter said. It did not identify those elements or give examples of oppression. ``The process of socially and politically cleansing society from the active elements of the previous dictatorship is at an impasse,'' the letter said. It also said opposition parties had not had access to media to promote their proposals to solve the nation's social, economic and political problems. However, the opposition parties also stressed support for the government's efforts during the transition period to elections. Earlier Tuesday, parliamentary delegates voted to bar certain people in Ceausescu's regime from running for president. They include anyone who committed abuses in political, judicial or administrative functions, violated human rights, or took part in repression by the police or the Securitate, Ceausescu's hated secret police. The draft electoral law provides for candidates to be challenged in court on their record under the former dictator. Another prime concern of the 258-member Council was preventing a future president from becoming a dictator. ``The president does not have the right to become eternal,'' said Mircea Dinescu, president of the Writer's Union and one of the first to announce Ceausescu's overthrow on Dec. 22 after 24 years of repressive rule. Ceausescu and his wife, Elena, were executed on Christmas Day following a secret military trial. The first role of the parliament that will be seated following elections will be to write a new constitution. Within a year from then, Iliescu said, the parliament should pass a permanent election law ``to avoid any suspicion that ... somebody could take power for 25 years.'' The Council delegates _ representing the 51 political parties created since the revolution as well as ethnic groups _ overwhelmingly approved the provision.

DOC.HEAD: House Panel Approves Cabinet Status For EPA
DOC.TEXT: The House Government Operations Committee approved a bill Tuesday that would elevate the Environmental Protection Agency to Cabinet level with creation of a Department of the Environment. Similar legislation earlier had been approved by a Senate committee and now heads for floor action in both the House and Senate. President Bush wants Congress to pass the legislation in the coming weeks so that an announcement on creating a Cabinet-level department for environmental issues can be made in time for the celebration of Earth Day on April 22. The legislation, which passed the committee on a voice vote Tuesday, has widespread bipartisan support in both the House and Senate. Supporters of the House and Senate bills argue that creating a Department of the Environment will put the EPA on equal standing with other agencies and departments in government and give the president's chief environmental adviser more prestige when dealing with other countries. The bills in both houses also would create a center for environmental statistics, which would consolidate and improve the collection of environmental data. Congressional staffers said the legislation otherwise would not envision any sizeable increases in the size of the EPA if it gains department status.

DOC.HEAD: ABC's ``World News'' Wins Ratings Again
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS next-to-last graf to CORRECT that the drop was 16 percent sted 20 percent
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Nielsens
DOC.TEXT: ABC's ``World News Tonight'' led the news ratings for the ninth consecutive week, according to A.C. Nielsen Co. estimates released Tuesday. ``NBC Nightly News'' and the ``CBS Evening News'' tied for second place. An ABC spokesman said the margin of victory for ``World News Tonight'' was the highest in the program's history. Of the three newscasts, only ABC's program, anchored by Peter Jennings, increased its audience. For the week that ended March 9, it averaged an 11.5 rating, up 0.4 point from the previous week. NBC's broadcast and CBS's, which has been slumping in the ratings, each averaged 9.7. Each ratings point represents 921,000 homes. Compared to ratings for the same week a year ago, last week's ratings showed a 16 percent drop for CBS' newscast, according to ABC estimates. Anchored by Dan Rather, the once-dominant ``CBS Evening News'' was third in each of the three weeks preceding the latest Nielsen estimates.

DOC.HEAD: `CBS This Morning' Adds Film Critic
DOC.TEXT: ``CBS This Morning'' has hired film critic Gene Siskel to review movies and videos, the network said Tuesday. Siskel, who will continue appearing with fellow critic Roger Ebert in their syndicated ``Siskel and Ebert'' film-review series, will make his first appearance on the CBS show on Friday. At CBS, Siskel will appear twice a week, reviewing films on Wednesdays, and videos on Fridays. Siskel, who also is a film critic at CBS-owned WBBM-TV in Chicago and a syndicated film columnist, has been nominated three times for an Emmy Award. Last year, the CBS morning show parted ways with director Peter Bogdanovich, its movie reviewer.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS day from Friday to Tuesday in 1st bullet graf
DOC.TEXT: Here at a glance is an outline of the Bush administration's aid proposals for emerging democracies in Central America and Eastern Europe.

_Nicaragua: President Bush on Tuesday, creating a ``Fund for Democracy,'' lifted a five-year trade embargo imposed against the outgoing Sandinista government and asked Congress to provide $300 million quickly to aid economic recovery and spur the transition to democracy. Bush said he will also seek an additional $200 million in economic assistance for Nicaragua in the fiscal year which begins Oct. 1. The money would be taken from the Pentragon budget. _Panama: Bush is asking $500 million in aid to help the government installed after a U.S. invasion last December ousted the country's military strongman, Manuel Antonio Noriega.

_Poland and Hungary: Congress has approved a three-year, $938 million program for both countries with the lion's share going to Poland. _Romania: Secretary of State James A. Baker III has recommended $80 million in emergency food and humanitarian aid, including 500,000 tons of feed grains and 7,500 tons of butter. _Czechoslovakia: President Bush is asking Congress to waive the the trade restrictions imposed by the Jackson-Vanik amendment as soon as the Czech parliament passes a law ending restrictions on emigration.

DOC.HEAD: U.N. Representative Says Contras Can be Disbanded by April 25
DOC.TEXT: A U.N. monitor for Nicaragua said Tuesday he believes the Contra rebels can be disbanded by April 25, when Violeta Barrios Chamorro takes over as president. Elliot Richardson, an observer of Nicaragua's election process for U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar, said a U.N. plan to disarm and resettle the U.S.-backed rebels will guarantee their safety. ``I think that practical safeguards for their demobilization can be provided,'' he said at a news conference. The Contras have said they will remain armed to make sure the leftist Sandinista government of President Daniel Ortega, which they fought, hands over control of the military and police as well as the presidency. But Richardson, a former U.S. attorney general, said he believes ``the prospects are good'' the Contras will be disbanded before the formal transfer of power. He said the incoming and outgoing governments, as well as the United States, are willing to work together to ensure the Contras ``can safely demobilize and re-enter the society of Nicaragua, or for that matter if they choose to, stay outside of Nicaragua.'' Richardson said he could not provide specifics on the plan because ``it would be inappropriate to try to fill in details on a matter that is in fact actively being pursued now.'' Perez de Cuellar plans to report this week to the U.N. Security Council on proposals to expand the mandate of the U.N. Observer Group in Central America to include overseeing efforts to disarm and possibly repatriate the Contras. In November, the Security Council formed the observer group to verify the cutoff of outside aid to rebel movements in the region. It was also created to patrol international borders to prevent guerrillas attacks. The original mandate called for a 625-member force, but U.N. officials say the broader role involving the Contras would require a substantial increase in personnel. There have been estimates a force of 1,000 would be needed. Last week, Ortega threatened to keep control of the military and the security police unless the Contras disbanded before the swearing-in ceremony on April 25. The Sandinistas lost control of the government in Feb. 25 elections. However, Ortega told Vice President Dan Quayle at a Monday meeting in Chile that he would not block the smooth transfer of power. President Bush announced Tuesday in Washington he had lifted a five-year trade embargo against Nicaragua and asked Congress to provide $300 million quickly to help speed the transition to democracy. The president never mentioned the Contras, who received millions of dollars from the United States during the Reagan administration. But his aid request includes about $45 million to help pay costs of relocating about 10,000 Contra rebels and tens of thousands of relatives from camps along the Honduran border to Nicaragua.

DOC.HEAD: Bill Requiring Fish Inspection Going To House Floor
DOC.TEXT: The House Energy and Commerce Committee approved legislation Tuesday that would create a health inspection program for seafood. The legislation, approved by a voice vote, is needed because fish and shellfish are the only flesh food not governed by inspections, according to consumer advocates. The bill would give the Food and Drug Administration control over the program. The Agriculture Department, which runs meat and poultry inspections, has been bidding for control of the seafood program as well. The FDA, under the legislation, would receive $75 million in the first year to start the program.

DOC.HEAD: Congress Establishes New Presidency, Reformers Demand Repeat Vote
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 12th graf, ``Gorbachev opened ...'' with 5 grafs with more color from session;
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto MOSB3
DOC.TEXT: The Congress of People's Deputies on Tuesday approved Mikhail S. Gorbachev's proposals for a multiparty political system, headed by a powerful president, to replace decades of absolute Communist Party domination. But opposition deputies charged that the Soviet leader seriously violated parliamentary rules in ramming the proposals through a procedural muddle, and demanded that the issues be brought up for one more vote. Failing that, they said the Congress likely would balk later this week at naming Gorbachev the new president, forcing him instead to face voters in the country's first nationwide presidential election. Tuesday's vote, if upheld, will mark the definitive movement of the Soviet Union from more than 70 years of party leadership toward a more representative government system closer to that of many Western nations. It came five years after Gorbachev took over power in the Soviet Union _ a tenure marked by growing economic difficulties and sometimes-violent ethnic unrest, but also improved relations with the West. ``I congratulate the Congress,'' Gorbachev said simply after applause greeted the vote of 1,817-133 members of the nation's highest parliamentary body for establishing the new post of president. Moments later, the 2,250-member Congress voted 1,771-164 to approve a wide-ranging bill striking the Communist Party's leading role from the Constitution, legalizing some forms of private property and setting the presidential powers. Gorbachev has said the strong presidency is essential to hold the country together as it goes through economic troubles and ethnic disputes. He picked up votes for his proposals during the day by offering a compromise on some of the most controversial presidential powers. He gave up the right to appeal a veto override and promised that any bid to impose a state of emergency would be preceded by an official warning and prior approval of local authorities. Deputy Fyodor Burlatsky, a top political commentator, said Gorbachev probably picked up 50 to 100 votes with the compromise. Each piece of legislation required 1,501 votes _ a two-thirds majority of all the members of the Congress, present or not. Gorbachev had been threatened by a boycott from some Baltic legislators who consider their republics independent, and opposition from radical reformers who considered the post of president too powerful and demanded a direct election. The bill gives the president the power to propose legislation, negotiate treaties, veto legislation and decisions of the Council of Ministers, appoint a Cabinet, declare war if the country is attacked and impose presidential rule. ``We are standing before the greatest, most meaningful step in the history of our government,'' he told deputies shortly before they voted. ``This is a major step in favor of democracy and the protection of democracy.'' Gorbachev opened Tuesday's session in a relaxed manner, even joking about Lithuania's declaration of independence on Sunday. During the afternoon session, however, he was strongly in control. He tapped a glass with his pencil and stabbed at the air to move the debate toward a vote.He cut off debate at several points with a a curt ``That's enough,'' or ``Just a minute,'' and several times resorted to a voice vote on whether the Congress wanted to continue a particular debate. At one point after the vote was taken on both the presidency and the constitutional amendments, Deputy Arkady Murashev, a leader of the opposition Inter-regional Group of legislators, took the microphone and said deputies were confused by the procedure. Gorbachev responded that each deputy spoke for himself in the Congress and then asked: ``You're talking about yourself, you?'' The Soviet leader then added it was too late to be confused about a vote already taken. ``When a question arises, clarify it,'' he told Murashev in a belittling tone. One reform-minded deputy who is considered an expert on parliamentary procedure told reporters at the close of Tuesday's session that Gorbachev had ``absolutely distorted'' parliamentary procedure, and that reformers would demand the issue come up again for a final ballot. ``I'm not sure our leadership is ready to accept this demand about voting procedure,'' said Moscow deputy Sergei Stankevich. But the official Tass news agency said that while the Congress endorsed the post of president and ended the party's leading role, one more vote would be needed after all amendments are considered. The Congress began considering amendments to the two bills only after it approved them. Since presidential rule and a multiparty system already had been approved as amendments to the Constitution, the new amendments required a two-thirds vote instead of a simple majority. That meant that two amendments presented by radicals were defeated even though they received a majority of votes. Deputies voted 1,067-906 for an amendment that would have struck all references to the Communist Party from the Constitution instead of adding a reference to other parties. They voted by a wider margin, 1,303-607, to make Gorbachev choose between the post of president and a leading role in the Communist Party. But both amendments, like those approved earlier, would have required 1,501 votes to pass. Stankevich said he did not know whether Gorbachev maneuvered the Congress into a tight spot on purpose, but that two of his top aides, Vice President Anatoly I. Lukyanov and Yevgeny M. Primakov, chairman of the parliament's Soviet of the Union, ``understand very well the situation.'' If Gorbachev grants a repeat vote, he is likely to lose support because of frustration over how he handled the procedure, Stankevich said. If he fails to, he may fail to win approval to have the Congress elect the first president this week. Asked for a prediction on Gorbachev's bid to conduct an immediate presidential election in the Congress, Stankevich said: ``I think it will be rejected.'' Gorbachev has said he will run for the post, and he faces no serious opposition in the Congress. However the outcome of a nationwide vote is less certain. Many Soviets are increasingly frustrated with Gorbachev's inability to improve the economy and have expressed their disappointment by turning out top leaders in other competitive elections.

DOC.HEAD: North Response Undercuts Defense Tactic
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with afternoon testimony. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Former White House aide Oliver L. North on Tuesday undercut a defense attempt to show that John M. Poindexter was unaware of a 1985 missile shipment to Iran, saying he kept his boss apprised of the operation. Poindexter's lawyer, Richard Beckler, took North through a half-hour series of questions about how the former National Security Council staff officer helped obtain a CIA aircraft to ship 18 Hawk missiles owned by Israel to Iran. At each stage, Beckler asked if Poindexter participated with North in any of the discussions with Israeli or CIA officials that preceded the November 1985 shipment. North testified that Poindexter, then President Reagan's national security adviser, was not a participant in those discussions. Beckler was trying to show that Poindexter wasn't lying when he told Congress that he learned about the shipment more than a month after it occurred. But his point was undermined when he asked North: ``Adm.
