Poindexter was not assisting you in carrying out this mission, he was not working with you side by side, was he?'' ``I do not recall the admiral being on the phone with me, as you just asked, but I did keep admiral apprised of what I was doing,'' North said. North, meanwhile, disclosed that he urged a trip by a U.S. official, perhaps Vice President Bush, to visit Iran in 1986 as part of the effort to free American hostages. There was no indication from the testimony that the proposal was seriously considered and North testified that Poindexter opposed the idea. Beckler also produced a handwritten note by Poindexter that stated that he had briefed Reagan about a shipment of Hawk missile spare parts that cost the Iranians $15 million. The document is the first indication that Reagan may have been informed at the time of the Iran initiative of the actual prices the Iranians were paying for the weapons. The prices were exorbitant and at least $3.8 million from the Iran arms sales was diverted to the Nicaraguan Contras, according to a report compiled by Congress. Reagan maintains he didn't know there was any extra money being generated from the Iran arms sales. He most recently made that assertion last month in a videotaped deposition for Poindexter's trial. Poindexter is accused of obstructing congressional inquiries into the Iran-Contra affair by making false statements and destroying documents. Among other things, Poindexter is accused of lying by telling Congress he was not aware of the Hawk missile shipment until more than a month after it occurred. He is also accused of concealing the covert assistance to the Nicaraguan Contras and diverting U.S.-Iran arms-sale profits to the rebels. North said he discussed the proposal for a trip by American officials to Iran in a Feb. 27, 1986, memo to former national security adviser Robert C. McFarlane, then working as a White House consultant. The proposal was for ``an advance trip to Iran to arrange for a high-level trip later on by a senior U.S. official, possibly even the vice president, to meet with the leadership of Iran,'' North testified. North said Poindexter was not ``very enthusiastic'' about the idea, so he had written McFarlane to ask him to ``importune the admiral so this trip could be undertaken.'' ``I thought the advance trip was worth the risk and the admiral didn't,'' North said. In May 1986, North and McFarlane traveled to Iran in an unsuccessful attempt to secure the release of American hostages in the Middle East. Beckler produced North's message to McFarlane to try to show that North sometimes went behind Poindexter's back. The memo said: ``Have not told JWP that this note is being sent.'' U.S. District Court Judge Harold Greene voiced concern about the note, saying it undercut North's prior assertions that he always kept Poindexter abreast of what he was doing. ``You are the one who keeps telling us and other tribunals and other juries that all you were doing was following orders. Here you are communicating with an outsider and you say your immediate boss would not be told about this. ``Was this consistent with your general method of operation?'' the judge said. North insisted that he was not trying to hide anything from Poindexter, merely trying to get McFarlane to change Poindexter's mind about undertaking the mission to Iran. Even though McFarlane had left government, he ``still stayed engaged'' in assignments for Reagan, North said. ``You decided when to call him or did somebody tell you?'' Greene asked. ``I don't know who decided,'' North said. ``I believe it was the president.'' ``Were you the one to decide when to send'' the message to McFarlane? Greene asked. ``I don't recall anybody telling me not to,'' North replied. ``Nobody told me I shouldn't talk to him about this.''

DOC.HEAD: Ireland Refuses Extradition of IRA Prisoners
DOC.TEXT: Ireland's Supreme Court on Tuesday refused to extradite two escaped prisoners to Northern Ireland saying there was a risk they would be assaulted by prison staff in the British-ruled province. The two men were freed after the hearing. Dermot Finucane and James Pius Clarke escaped from Belfast's Maze Prison in a mass Irish Republican Army breakout in 1983. Both were serving 18-year terms when they escaped; Finucane, 30, for firearms offenses and Clarke, 34, for the attempted murder of a member of the Ulster Defense Regiment, a mainly Protestant, part-time regiment of the British Army. Ireland's Chief Justice Thomas Finlay said Finucane risked being ``assaulted or injured by illegal action by prison staff at the Maze'' if he were returned. ``I am satisfied that this court has to protect his constitutional rights,'' he said. The chief justice's ruling was unanimously supported by a panel of five judges of the Supreme Court, Ireland's final legal authority. After the decision was read Finucane was ordered released. He was immediately ushered out of the court by supporters and sped away on a waiting motorcycle. Clarke was later released, following a separate court action, but on similar grounds. He walked out of the court calling the ruling ``brilliant.'' Finucane had claimed in earlier hearings that other prisoners involved in the mass IRA breakout from the Maze Prison were later subjected to harsh treatment by prison officers. Kenneth Maginnis, spokesman for the Official Unionists, the main Protestant party in Northern Ireland, said the suggestion that the men risked assault in prison was ``absolute nonsense.'' He said the Supreme Court decision ``spells the death knell'' for the Anglo-Irish Agreement, the 1985 accord which gives Dublin a say in the running of Northern Ireland. ``Irrespective of how the two governments try to give it the kiss of life, it is probably dead on its feet,'' he said. A spokesman for the Northern Ireland Office, a branch of the British government, said: ``We are obviously disappointed that Finucane and Clarke will not be returned to Northern Ireland to complete their sentences.'' The two men were arrested in Ireland in 1987 and have been battling extradition since. Sinn Fein, the legal political wing of the IRA, welcomed the court ruling, calling it ``a victory for all those who have fought so valiantly against the extradition of political dissidents to Britain.'' The IRA is fighting to end British rule of Northern Ireland and to unite the predominantly Protestant province with the mainly Roman Catholic Republic of Ireland.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Investment in U.S. Real Estate Down in 1989
With AM-Economy Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Japanese investment in U.S. real estate, which had been posting huge annual gains, edged down 10.7 percent in 1989, reflecting a higher Japanese interest in Europe, a study said Tuesday. Japanese real estate investment totaled $14.77 billion last year, compared with a record high of $16.54 billion in 1988, according to figures compiled by Kenneth Leventhal & Co., an accounting firm that specializes in real estate. ``The Japanese have started to devote more attention to Western Europe both in terms of real estate as well as other investments,'' the report said. The study attributed the switch to an effort by the Japanese to take advantage of the 1992 target date for the removal of trade barriers inside the 12-nation European Community. Hotels and resorts were the most popular real estate purchase for the Japanese, accounting for 28 percent of the total. Office buildings, which had been No. 1 with 50 percent of the total in 1988, fell to second place, accounting for 23 percent of spending last year. Three states _ California, Hawaii and New York _ accounted for 81 percent of total investment, up from 62 percent in 1988. For the second year in a row, California ranked No. 1, with 36 percent of real estate investment last year, about two-fifths of which was concentrated in Los Angeles. Hawaii accounted for 30 percent of total investment, followed by New York with 16 percent. Nevada jumped into fourth place with $482 million in investment last year, reflecting primarily purchases of hotels and resorts in Las Vegas. The focus of Japanese interest remained in metropolitan areas. By city, Los Angeles accounted for $2.51 billion in investment in 1989, 17 percent of the total, followed by New York with $2.3 billion, 16 percent of the total. Other cities and their percentages of 1989 investment were: San Diego and Honolulu, both at 7 percent; Anaheim, Calif., and Las Vegas, both 4 percent; San Francisco, Washington, D.C., Houston, and Phoenix, Ariz., all at 2 percent. In a separate report Tuesday, the Association for International Investment said that total direct investment put the Japanese in the No. 2 spot at the end of 1989 behind the British. They had begun the decade in fifth place. The association, which represents foreign companies with subsidiaries in the United States and U.S. businesses with foreign operations, said 35 percent of the Japanese investment was in businesses engaged in wholesale trade while 23 percent was in manufacturing and 19 percent in real estate.

DOC.HEAD: Commercial Rocket To Launch Communications Satellite
DOC.TEXT: Martin Marietta Corp. officials say ``all systems are go'' for Wednesday's launch of a commercial Titan rocket that will send an uninsured $140 million communications satellite into orbit. ``We are delighted with the weather. So far, everything looks very good,'' Edward M. Browne, president of Martin Marietta Commercial Titan Inc., told reporters Tuesday. ``We intend to push the button at 6:49 a.m. in one millisecond and get that sucker off the ground.'' It will be Martin Marietta's second commercial launch and only the third by an American company. Martin Marietta entered the commercial launch business Dec. 31 by thrusting into orbit British and Japanese communications satellites with the big Titan 3 rocket, the type scheduled for liftoff Wednesday. The rocket went up on its 10th attempt following delays due to winds and a technical problem. This time, the Titan will be carrying a 5-ton Intelsat VI communications satellite that will replace two satellites over the Atlantic Ocean. The Intelsat VI satellite, nearly four stories tall with its antennas and solar panels deployed, will transmit up to 120,000 telephone calls and three television channels for more than 13 years. The cost of the satellite and launch is estimated at more than $270 million. Barring problems, the rocket was scheduled to blast off between 6:49 a.m. and 7:04 a.m. from the Cape Canaveral Air Force Station. There was a second launch opportunity an hour later lasting 29 minutes. Martin Marietta spokeswoman Judy Stowell said Tuesday there was more than a 95 percent chance of favorable weather. Once the satellite reaches final geosynchronous orbit 22,300 miles above Earth on Sunday, the satellite will be near the first Intelsat VI, which was launched in October by the European Space Agency's Ariane rocket. That satellite is undergoing in-orbit tests before being placed in service April 7. The second Intelsat VI is scheduled to start service in late May. Frederick Ormsby, spacecraft mission director for the International Telecommunications Satellite Organization, or Intelsat, said last month's explosion of an Ariane rocket should not affect plans to launch two more Intelsat VI satellites on Ariane boosters next year. The unmanned Ariane rocket, which was carrying two Japanese communications satellites, blew apart over the Atlantic shortly after taking off from Kourou, French Guiana. The accident prompted Arianespace, which runs the program, to suspend all Ariane launches pending an investigation. The third in the series of five Intelsat VI satellites is scheduled to be launched aboard a Titan 3 by Martin Marietta in June. Ormsby said Intelsat had not insured the satellite being launched Wednesday. Insuring such spacecraft is prohibitively high, especially since the Ariane explosion. The Titan 3, built at Martin Marietta's Denver plant, is the most powerful U.S. commercial rocket and the second big American rocket to enter the commercial market. McDonnell Douglas was the first, with its Delta rocket hoisting a communications satellite for British Satellite Broadcasting last August. General Dynamics plans to enter the competition in June with its Atlas rocket. Intelsat, a Washington, D.C.-based, not-for-profit commercial cooperative of 118 member nations, owns and operates a global communications satellite system used by more than 170 countries. Wednesday's launch will be its 44th. The first Intelsat communications satellite was launched 25 years ago next month.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Says Voters Shouldn't Hold Past Marijuana Use Against Candidate
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Tuesday he does not think past use of marijuana should be held against someone running for political office. He declined further comment concerning other drugs or the Texas governor's race in which questions of drug use have been a major issue. The question arose at Bush's news conference when a reporter asked the president's views on Tuesday's gubernatorial primary in his adopted home state of Texas. Democratic candidate Ann Richards, the state treasurer, said she was a recovering alcoholic and her ``addiction was alcohol'' but lost ground in public opinion polls after repeatedly refusing to say whether she had ever used illegal drugs. Asked if he felt past drug use should be held against a candidate, Bush said, ``That's a matter for the voters to decide.'' But the president added, ``In my view, (if) somebody used marijuana sometime ago and is not into anything of that nature, why, no, I don't think that should be held against them.'' He refused to elaborate when asked if he felt that way about harder drugs, too. ``You're getting me involved in the Texas primary, something I don't want to do,'' he responded. Bush voted by absentee ballot in the Republican primary. ``I will not tell you who I voted for and I hope everybody understands,'' he told reporters. ``Otherwise, we'll have a quiz around here of who we voted for earlier on. It's not a proper question to reveal.'' He promised to be less reticent come the general campaign. ``I'll be involved, but I'm not going to fine-tune that,'' said Bush, whose son, George Walker Bush, once considered seeking the GOP nomination to succeed Gov. Bill Clements. In 1987, during the Reagan administration, Douglas Ginsburg withdrew as a nominee to the Supreme Court after admitting he had smoked marijuana while a law professor. William Bennett, then the education secretary and now Bush's drug policy director, played a role in persuading Ginsburg to withdraw. Ms. Richards gained national prominence as the keynote speaker at the 1988 Democratic National Convention with a speech taking humorous jabs at Republican presidential candidate Bush. In one of the most quoted, she said he had been born ``with a silver foot in his mouth.''

DOC.HEAD: Police Arrest Wheelchair-Bound Demonstrators in Capitol Protest
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS grafs 3-4 to update with 104 arrested, police wear gloves; pick up 5th graf: Those arrested ...
DOC.TEXT: Police arrested disabled demonstrators who chanted slogans and chained their wheelchairs together in the Capitol on Tuesday in a protest demanding quick passage of a bill guaranteeing their civil rights. The arrests came after deliberate acts of civil disobedience by the demonstrators and a confrontation in the Capitol's cavernous Rotunda with House Speaker Thomas S. Foley and Minority Leader Robert H. Michel. Police said 104 people were arrested. Removing the demonstrators and loading them into vans took police about two hours. Those who could walk were handcuffed, and some in wheelchairs were strapped into their seats by police, many of whom wore surgical gloves. Those arrested were charged with two misdemeanors, unlawful entry and demonstrating within the Capitol, said police spokesman G.T. Nevitt. Both carry maximum sentences of six months in jail. In addition, those convicted could be fined $100 for unlawful entry and $500 for demonstrating in the Capitol. The arrests marked the second day of dramatic lobbying by people with disabilities, who are seeking passage of the Americans with Disabilities Act. On Monday, some 60 people crawled out of their wheelchairs and up the West steps of the Capitol to underline their demands. The Senate passed the bill last year but the measure has bogged down in the House despite widespread predictions of ultimate approval. While the demonstration was in progress, the House Energy and Commerce Committee approved the bill 40-3 at a meeting in another building. But the measure still must go to two other committees before reaching the full House. Demonstrators gathered in the center of the Rotunda and began to chant slogans, including some from the civil rights movement of the 1960s. They also chanted ``ADA Now'' and ``Access Now,'' referring to their demand for access to transportation and other accomodations. ``Access is a civil right,'' the last protester, who identified herself only as Gail Love, shouted as she was taken out. Police used large snipping tools to break chains that some of the demonstrators had used to bind their wheelchairs together. Before the arrests, Foley assured demonstrators that he and other congressional leaders were pushing the bill. His words were met with skepticism. ``It is a priority for passage in this session of the Congress,'' the Washington Democrat shouted over catcalls. ``I am absolutely satisfied it will reach the floor, we will have a conference with the Senate and it will become law.'' ``Will it be on the floor in 24 hours? No,'' Foley added. A chorus of boos greeted the remark. A sponsor of the bill, Rep. Steny Hoyer, D-Md., also spoke to the group and urged them to be patient. ``Sixty days is not too long'' to wait, he said. He was met by shouts of, ``We've waited too long already.'' The bill would outlaw discrimination based on physical or mental disability in employment, access to buildings, use of the telephone system, use of public and private transportation and in other uses. It would require ramps or other means of access in all new buildings used by the general public, including private businesses and offices. The Capitol building has ramps for wheelchair access to two of its entrances and ramps and elevators inside. During the midday confrontation in the Rotunda, Foley sought to assure the disabled that House leaders ``want to see that this bill has the greatest possible support and will reach the president's desk in a way that he can sign it.'' Michel, an Illinois Republican, told the crowd he had broached the issue earlier today in a meeting with President Bush at the White House. He called ``unreasonable'' the demand by some of the protesters for passage in 24 hours. Some other protesters said they were seeking passage by May 1.

DOC.HEAD: With End of U.S. Embargo, Aid Could Open Doors
With AM-Bush Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A quick infusion of U.S. aid and the end of a five-year economic embargo will give Nicaragua the confidence to rebuild its war-battered economy, authorities said Tuesday. ``This opens a lot of doors,'' said Ramiro Gurdian, leader of the most important private business organization in Nicaragua, the Superior Council of Private Enterprise. ``Investors will begin thinking about putting money into Nicaragua because it now has access to the biggest consumer market in the world: the United States.'' President Bush on Tuesday lifted trade sanctions on Nicaragua and asked Congress to quickly approve $300 million in aid. Gurdian said those steps should encourage private banks and international lending institutions to begin looking favorably on Nicaragua. ``It's like putting money in the pipeline and waiting for the faucet to open,'' he said. Danilo Lacayo, a spokesman for the U.S.-backed United National Opposition alliance, said the U.S. assistance also could persuade other countries to increase their aid. While UNO looks to the United States to help it fulfill its campaign promises, the leftist Sandinistas blame Washington for their resounding defeat in the Feb. 25 elections. The UNO candidate, President-elect Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, is to take office April 25. The trade embargo imposed against the Sandinista government, their war with the U.S.-backed Contra rebels and poor management have turned Nicaragua into one of the poorest countries in Latin America. About one-third of the work force is jobless and the economy has shrunk steadily the past six years. Vice President Sergio Ramirez told a news conference lifting the embargo is a long overdue ``act of justice.'' The Nicaraguan aid package appears to give the conservative, U.S.-backed UNO almost everything its chief financial adviser, Francisco Mayorga, asked for during his recent trip to Washington. Mayorga, a Yale-educated economist, said he would press for quick aid to help get crops in the ground before the May rains begin. Agriculture is the base of Nicaragua's economy, and Gurdian said the end of the trade embargo means Nicaragua will be able to get tractors, fertilizer, seed and other agricultural products cheaper by buying directly from the United States. It will also be able to sell products like meat or sugar at better prices offered by the American market, he said. Bush also took steps to let Nicaragua resume shipping sugar, a major export crop, to the United States and to make Nicaragua eligible for duty-free treatment for a variety of other products. Nicaragua has 30,000 sugar workers who would be affected by the opening of the U.S. sugar market, said labor leader Alvin Guthrie. ``If we should get preferential prices, it would be easier to attack certain problems like low wages,'' he said recently. Lacayo said the aid package should improve the climate for a peaceful transition of power from the Sandinistas to UNO. The Sandinistas, who are insisting on the demobilization of the Contra rebels before Mrs. Chamorro takes office, have been sharply critical of the United States for not doing more to disarm the 10,000-man guerrilla army. Bush's aid package includes $45 million to help repatriate or resettle the Contras, most of whom are in base camps in Honduras near the border.

DOC.HEAD: Thunderstorms, Snow And High Temperatures
DOC.TEXT: Temperatures hit record highs again Tuesday, reaching the 70s and 80s in the East, and thunderstorms rattled the southern Plains and Illinois. Snow fell in Colorado and Wyoming. A tornado touched down near Jetmore, Kan., during the morning but no injuries or major damage were reported. Tornado watches were posted for parts of Kansas, Nebraska, Iowa, Missouri, Oklahoma and Texas. At midday, showers and thunderstorms extended across northern Oklahoma, central and eastern Kansas, western Missouri, eastern Nebraska, northwestern Iowa, southeastern Iowa and northern Illinois. Hail as big as golf balls fell in Illinois at Mazon and near Elvira, the National Weather Service said. Three-quarter-inch diameter hail fell at Pampa, Texas. Winds gusted to 65 mph at Gage, Okla., and 40- to 50-mph wind was reported in central and north-central Kansas. During the morning in New Mexico, wind gusted to 44 mph at Carlsbad and Roswell, 46 mph at Ruidoso, 49 mph at Clovis and 53 mph at Clayton. Snow fell over the Nebraska Panhandle, southeastern Wyoming, eastern and central Colorado, northwestern New Mexico, central Arizona, north-central and northwestern Montana, and north-central California. Up to a foot of snow fell in southwestern Colorado. Winter storm watches were posted into Wednesday across western South Dakota and southeastern North Dakota. Northern Arizona got 12 inches of snow from 5 p.m. Monday to 6 a.m. Tuesday, and 5 inches fell overnight at Sedona. Temperatures hit record or record-tying highs in Connecticut, Delaware, Georgia, Illinois, Indiana, Maryland, Massachusetts, Michigan, Minnesota, New Hampshire, New Jersey, New York, North Carolina, Ohio, Pennsylvania, Rhode Island and the District of Columbia. On the other hand, temperatures in northern California hit record lows of 31 degrees in Red Bluff and 28 in Redding. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EST ranged from 14 degrees at Yellowstone National Park, Wyo., to 92 at Cherry Point, N.C. Tuesday's low for the Lower 48 states was 7 below zero at Yellowstone.

DOC.HEAD: Nicaragua's Ortega Calls U.S. Proposed Aid Little for Damage Done
With AM-Bush Rdp, AM-Nicaragua-US
DOC.TEXT: Nicaraguan President Daniel Ortega said Tuesday he welcomed the White House proposal to lift economic sanctions and supply $300 million in aid to his country, but he called it little compared with the damage done. ``I celebrate this as a victory of the Nicaraguan people, who have suffered so much. They deserve this and more,'' he said. ``Although it's little, considering Nicaragua's economic circumstances, it shows a willingness to help.'' He said he hoped the $300 million would be followed up by more aid. Ortega spoke in an address to officials of the Santiago-based U.N. Economic Commission for Latin America. He said U.S. aggression against his leftist Sandinista government cost billions of dollars in economic damage. Ortega conversed Monday with U.S. Vice President Dan Quayle. He said Quayle told him Bush would be making an announcement Tuesday about the economic sanctions against his government. He also told reporters before his speech his talks with Quayle had been ``very positive. It gave us an opportunity to arrive at points of agreement about issues that have been difficult to resolve, such as the issue of the Contras.'' In his address, Ortega said he wanted to see the United States apply pressure so the Contra rebels are disarmed and disbanded by April 25. Aides to Quayle had said Ortega promised to peacefully and unconditionally hand over power as scheduled on April 25 to Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, who last month beat Ortega in elections. ``It is time for the United States to begin changing its policy toward Nicaragua, toward the Nicaraguan revolutionary process that still stands and is being strengthened by democracy,'' Ortega said. Ortega arrived in Chile on Sunday to attend the inauguration that day of President Patricio Aylwin, who succeeded Gen. Augusto Pinochet. Quayle also came for the inauguration.

DOC.HEAD: Committee Votes to Seek Immunity for Gilliam
DOC.TEXT: A House committee voted unanimously Tuesday to seek a court order granting immunity from prosecution to compel testimony from a former top official at the scandal-plagued Department of Housing and Urban Development. Dubois Gilliam, now serving an 18-month prison sentence for a HUD-related conviction, is expected to testify in late April or early May before the House panel that has spent more than a year investigating scandals under the Reagan administration's HUD secretary, Samuel R. Pierce Jr. The House Government Operations Committee voted 35-0 to approve a motion to compel the testimony, after its investigations subcommittee voted 8-0 to seek the order from a federal court. Rep. Tom Lantos, D-Calif., chairman of the subcommittee, said Gilliam was being offered no reduction in his current sentence as an inducement or deal for his testimony. Gilliam, formerly deputy assistant secretary and a top aide to Pierce, has been cooperating with the committee and was ``a key player'' in awarding grants under several HUD programs, according to Lantos. A special prosecutor, Arlin Adams, is looking into allegations of fraud and influence peddling in one of the department's programs. If a judge approves immunity, Gilliam could not be prosecuted based on his testimony before Congress or information derived from that testimony. Housing and Urban Development Secretary Jack Kemp, meanwhile, defended his department's $23.7 billion budget and proposed housing bill under critical questioning from Democrats in an appearance before the House Banking Committee. Kemp said the proposal is ``serious and responsible.'' But he acknowledged it does not provide financing for construction of new subsidized housing. Kemp has labeled his housing proposal ``HOPE,'' for home ownership and opportunity for people everywhere, and the bill was introduced with bipartisan sponsorship Monday. As its centerpiece is Kemp's plan for encouraging home ownership among low and moderate-income families. Rep. Charles Schumer, D-N.Y., called the proposal ``more hype than hope'' and ``long on words and short on action.'' ``It's a nice idea, but it's not going to create new roofs over people's heads,'' Schumer said. Rep. Joe Kennedy, D-Mass., said the Bush administration's housing budget is ``woefully inadequate'' and by failing to provide new housing would ``allow and condone homelessness.''

DOC.HEAD: Weather Forces `Die Hard II' North
With AM-Heat Rdp
DOC.TEXT: The unseasonably warm weather being enjoyed in the upper Midwest forced part of Bruce Willis' ``Die Hard II'' production crew out of town and north to Kinross on Michigan's Upper Peninsula. Twentieth Century Fox sent Willis and most of the production crew back to Los Angeles over the weekend when the warm weather melted snow in Alpena needed for the winter action movie. The temperature rose from 5 below zero March 6 into the 60s within four days. Alpena itself was a substitute location for Moses Lake, Wash., where warm weather last month plagued producers. In January, a heat wave interfered with planned filming at Denver's Stapleton International Airport. Location manager Greg Lazzaro said producers shot only about half of the planned winter blizzard scenes at the Alpena County Regional Airport before snow stopped falling. ``We could not film in the rain, and if it continued, we would be sitting around,'' Lazzaro said Monday. Beginning Wednesday, ``Die Hard II'' stunt doubles and a secondary crew will work out of the old Kincheloe Air Force Base at Kinross. There's still at least a foot of snow at the one-runway airport, said Joyce DeWitt, who works for a charter service there. ``It's gonna take a lot of rain to wash all this snow away,'' DeWitt said Tuesday. A few ``Die Hard II'' crew members remained in Alpena, about 230 miles north of Detroit, on Tuesday but the prospect of snow and cold returning anytime soon were not good. Even so, producers told Karen Pettalia of the Alpena Chamber of Commerce that they would be back sometime next week to finish shooting there.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Officials Blame Thai Corruption for Bigger Heroin Exports
DOC.TEXT: U.S. officials told Congress on Tuesday that increased corruption in Thailand is the main reason for greater shipments of heroin to the United States. Melvyn Levitsky, assistant secretary of state for international narcotics matters, said he had raised the matter in private talks in Washington with Thai representatives over the past six to eight months. He said the increased corruption was centered on the border with Burma, now called Myanmar, and that it was connected with Thai logging operations on the Burmese side. Rep. Larry Smith, D-Fla., who heads a task force on narcotics set up by the House Foreign Affairs Committee, was chairman of the hearing. Smith said half the heroin reaching the United States comes from the ``Golden Triangle,'' which includes parts of Thailand, Burma and Laos. Thailand has not been able to stop shipments from Burma, he said. Levitsky called Burma the key problem, saying it had doubled its production of opium and heroin to become the world's largest producer. The State Department's annual report on narcotics, issued earlier this month, said the members of the military who took over Burma in 1988 have given minimum priority to fighting narcotics. It estimated Burma's production of opium, from which heroin is derived, at 2,625 metric tons last year, up from 770 to 1,100 tons in 1986. Levitsky praised the Thai government's cooperation with the United States, but noted that President Bush's listing of Thailand among the countries certified as cooperating was accompanied this year by a special note. ``We need to be honest,'' he said. Afghanistan, Syria, Burma and Iran have been removed from the list.

DOC.HEAD: Rabbi Fears Nazi Resurgence if Germany Reunified
With AM-Germany
DOC.TEXT: East Germany's prime minister believes the fears of Nazi-era survivors about a resurgence of right-wing extremism in a reunited Germany are justified, the dean of the world's leading Holocaust research center said Tuesday. But West Germany's leader says penal laws should allay such worries, said Rabbi Marvin Hier of the Simon Wiesenthal Center for Holocaust Studies. Hier wrote Prime Minister Hans Modrow of East Germany and Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany to ask how they would preserve the memory of Nazi crimes. Modrow agreed that Hier's concerns were ``definitely justified,'' saying there is some basis for fears about a resurgence of nationalism, racism and anti-Semitism in East Germany as the countries move toward reunification. The right-wing Republican Party in West Germany, led by former Waffen SS soldier Franz Schoenhuber, ``is trying to gain a foothold here,'' Modrow said in a letter signed by his adviser, Karl Heinz Arnold. But Kohl dismissed the rabbi's fears, saying in a Feb. 28 letter that West Germans had been ``informed without any taboo of the causes and consequences of the National Socialist tyranny.'' ``It has probably also escaped your notice that in our Penal Code precisely these `crimes of hatred' whose combating you recommend to me are punishable with fines or prison sentences,'' Kohl wrote. ``To my mind, there is no doubt that these provisions will also apply in a united Germany. This certainly does not require any special demand,'' the chancellor added. Modrow's letter also tried to assure that ``students have a remarkable knowledge of the events of the Nazi period which can be conceptualized with the Holocaust.'' But Hier said Jews around the world simply cannot trust such assurances. ``My point is that after Auschwitz the Holocaust should be institutionalized, from cradle to grave,'' he said. ``For the last 40 years it has been forbidden to talk about it. It was completely ignored. ``They may have a remarkable knowledge about the Nazis, but they may not have a remarkable knowledge about the Jews,'' he said. ``There is hardly a word of the Jew as victim.'' Hier said the West must guard against the resurgence of right-wing groups in a united Germany and insist that the memory of Nazi crimes be preserved as a warning to the future. ``We should ask, `What will you do to institutionalize the memory of the Holocaust? Not a single Western leader, not even President Bush, has brought that up to the Germans,'' said Hier. ``The victims of Nazi Germany have a right to ask.'' The Simon Wiesenthal Center, named for the famed Nazi hunter, is the world's leading research institute on the extermination of 6 million Jews by the Nazis during World War II. Hier also condemned the ``two-plus-four'' reunification formula worked out in Ottawa last month. The plan addresses economic and political aspects, then discusses security issues with the United States, Britain, France and the Soviet Union. ``I cannot understand the policy of the leaders of the West who came up with two-plus-four,'' Hier said. ``We are afraid of economic dominance and we are worried about military adventurism. Yet, not a single leader has said to the Germans what they intend to do about the memory of the Holocaust. ``I think we should force this issue on the public agenda. We should ask, `What is the blueprint for the memory of the Holocaust?'''

DOC.HEAD: Baker Sets Talks with Mandela, de Klerk
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with Baker setting talks with de Klerk, Mandela. Picks up 2nd graf pvs `Baker, with ...' DELETES now-outdated last graf pvs.
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III will hold separate meetings next week with South African President F.W. de Klerk and black activist Nelson Mandela, U.S. officials said Tuesday. The location of the talks is not set, the officials told The Associated Press. Baker is going to Namibia on Sunday to attend ceremonies marking that country's independence from South Africa. He will use the trip as a springboard for a round of active U.S. diplomacy. The officials, who demanded anonymity, said an announcement about the talks would be made Wednesday. Baker also may go to Zaire to meet with President Sese Seko Mobutu, and is trying to arrange talks with Angolan President Jose Eduardo dos Santos and Jonas Savimba, the leader of a U.S.-backed insurgent movement in Angola. De Klerk freed the 71-year-old Mandela last month after the black leader had spent 27 years in prison. The African National Congress, a prominent anti-apartheid organization, was legalized. Baker's session with Mandela is an opportunity to compare strategies to end racial segregation in South Africa and to seek the release of nearly 300 political prisoners. Meanwhile, a 3{-year state of emergency in South Africa remains in place. Baker's meeting with de Klerk is a chance to convey the Bush administration's terms for lifting economic sanctions against South Africa. The administration has cautiously praised de Klerk for the steps he has taken while holding out the prospect of an invitation to the White House if he keeps on track. On another African problem, Baker has approached the Soviet Union to join the United States in an appeal for a cease-fire to allow food to reach millions of Ethiopians who face starvation. Baker, with President Bush's approval, wrote Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze recently ``to see what we can do together,'' State Department spokeswoman Margaret D. Tutwiler said Tuesday. A group of prominent black Americans urged Baker on Monday to work with the Soviet Union and others on a cease-fire and a suspension of arms shipments to the Marxist government and to guerrillas locked in a civil war. There was no immediate word on whether Moscow had replied. The black group, headed by Randall Robinson, executive director of TransAfrica, also asked Baker for up to $25 million in U.S. aid for a leading anti-apartheid group in South Africa to help the African National Congress begin planning a new political structure for the country. Baker gave the group no commitment, Ms. Tutwiler said. However, she praised the ANC, headed by Oliver Tambo and Nelson Mandela. ``We share many of its political objectives, such as ending apartheid and establishing a non-racial South Africa,'' she said. To that end, she said, the Bush administration is prepared to assist South African refugees as they return to the country. Also, Ms. Tutwiler said, the United States is contributing $31.6 million this year to prepare South Africans for leadership in a post-apartheid democracy. Ms. Tutwiler said the program is administered through private organizations.

DOC.HEAD: Military Slows Transition to Civilian Rule
DOC.TEXT: The military government Tuesday delayed by one month political conventions to be held ahead of elections to return Nigeria to civilian rule. A government statement said it was postponing the conventions by one month, to July 7. No reason for the action was given. The ruling Armed Forces Council has created two parties to choose candidates to run in national elections, and the winners are to take over the government by October 1992. The military president, Gen. Ibrahim Babangida, has said the military will make sure former politicians will not lead the new parties. Babangida also has said members of his government, including soldiers, will be barred from leading parties or running for office. The general seized power in a military coup in 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Spanish Prison Employee Shot, Basque Militants Blamed
DOC.TEXT: Two suspected Basque terrorists shot a prison worker in the head in this northern city Tuesday hours after the Basque separatist group ETA said it may agree to halt attacks, officials said. Angel Mota Iglesias underwent surgery in the Red Cross Hospital, 200 yards from where he was ambushed as he got into his car, a government official in this Basque provincial capital said. No immediate word came on his condition. No group claimed responsibility, but police found a spent cartridge of the type normally used by ETA, the official said, speaking on condition of anonymity. Mota worked at a provincial prison in San Sebastian which holds some ETA members. ETA, whose initials stand for Homeland and Liberty in the Basque language, has killed more than 600 people since 1968 in its campaign for independence for the three-province Spanish Basque region. In a statement published Tuesday in the Basque daily Egin, ETA said it would halt attacks if the government agreed to honor commitments allegedly made during talks in Algeria nearly a year ago. Interior Ministry Jose Luis Corcuera said the government stood by its anti-terrorist policy, which calls for ETA to stop attacks before further talks.

DOC.HEAD: Shuttle Atlantis Back Home
DOC.TEXT: Space shuttle Atlantis, traveling atop a modified Boeing 747, arrived back at Kennedy Space Center on Tuesday, ending a cross-country journey delayed several days by bad weather. The jet touched down at 5:51 p.m. EST about five miles from where it took off 13 days earlier on a secret military mission to send a $500 million spy satellite into orbit. ``After several delays, it's good to have the bird back in the nest again,'' said National Aeronautics and Space Administration spokesman Bruce Buckingham. Both Atlantis' launch and its trip back from Edwards Air Force Base, Calif., to Kennedy were plagued by uncooperative weather. The shuttle blasted off Feb. 28 on its sixth attempt, one short of tying a record for launch postponements. All but one of Atlantis' delays was attributed to weather. Buckingham said the delays would not affect Atlantis' next flight in July, another secret Pentagon mission. The shuttle was expected to undergo several days of post-flight deservicing, beginning Wednesday, after being removed from the jet. Earlier Tuesday, forecasters reported rain, poor visibility and low clouds along much of the route. Rain is a threat to the shuttle's exterior heat-insulating tiles. The weather apparently cleared, enabling the Boeing 747 to leave Columbus Air Force Base, Miss., at 3:56 p.m. EST after a two-hour refueling stop. The shuttle and jet had arrived at Columbus almost three hours after leaving Biggs Army Airfield in western Texas, where they had been grounded since Sunday because of bad weather. A military cargo plane took off about a half-hour ahead of the shuttle transport to check weather along the route. The military plane also took off from Columbus ahead of the shuttle transport to ensure a safe last leg, Buckingham said. Atlantis and its transport had landed at Biggs on Sunday for refueling after leaving Edwards. The shuttle and its five-member crew landed at Edwards on March 4, concluding its 4{-day mission. Atlantis' astronauts successfully deployed the spy satellite on the second day of the mission. The satellite's orbit is taking it over parts of the Soviet Union never before photographed by a shuttle-launched spy satellite.

DOC.HEAD: Precede ASUNCION, Paraguay
Quayle Urges Argentine Leader to Press for Halt in Arms Shipments
DOC.TEXT: Vice President Dan Quayle on Tuesday asked Argentine President Carlos Menem to press Cuba for a halt in arms shipments to leftist rebels in El Salvador, a Quayle aide said. Menem told the vice president that he and other latin presidents would encourage Cuban President Fidel Castro to ``find a democratic way out'' of the island nation's Marxist system, said the official traveling with Quayle on his weeklong trip to South America. Quayle told reporters earlier Tuesday that with the Democratic elections last month in Nicaragua, Castro ``will get a very clear message.'' ``It will show the extreme isolation he's in ...'' Quayle said. ``He is the lone holdout in this hemisphere.'' ``Castro is all by himself. He is a very intelligent individual and I'm sure recent events will not be lost on him, but we see no indication he's going to change,'' Quayle said. Menem indicated he would speak to Castro at Thursday's presidential inauguration in Brazil, which Quayle also will attend. During their one-hour meeting at the Government House, Quayle and Menem also discussed Argentina's economic problems. Menem renewed his vow to take the hard austerity measures needed to get his country's skyrocketing inflation under control, said the Quayle aide who briefed reporters on condition of anonymity. Quayle repeated U.S. asssurances of support for Menem and encouraged such austerity measures. There were no indications the United States would come up with an aid package to help Argentina. A slide in Argentina's currency against the dollar, drastic price markups in stores and strikes by public workers have disrupted the country's banks, federal courtrooms and oil fields. The country has been beset by demonstrations and strikes in protest over inflation, which has soared more than 8,100 percent in the last year. Quayle met earlier Tuesday with Paraguayan President Andres Rodriguez and they pledged greater cooperation between their governments in the fight against illegal drug trafficking. Quayle said he also spoke to Rodriguez about human rights, labor and U.S. trade sanctions against the country. Rodriguez and Quayle held their talks while sailing on the Paraguay River in a small yacht when the vice president made a brief stop in Asuncion en route to Buenos Aires. Rodriguez said at a news conference with Quayle that his government was pledged to cooperate with the United States against drug trafficking. Paraguay is a major transfer point for cocaine smuggling from Bolivia. Rodriguez told Quayle he would increase interdiction efforts in the nation's Chaco region, where traffickers have dozens of private airstrips, said the official traveling with Quayle. Rodriguez, the official said, also promised to work closely with the Drug Enforcement Agency and asked for training and technical assistance that might help Paraguay's newly reorganized anti-drug agency become more effective. Quayle said Paraguay would send a delegation to Washington in June to discuss the U.S. economic sanctions imposed because of labor rights suppression under the 34-year regime of military dictator Gen. Alfredo Stroessner. Quayle aides said the vice president raised concerns about labor rights protection and that Rodriguez said such criticism by the AFL-CIO was unjustified. Asked if he pressed Rodriguez on human rights issues, Quayle told reporters: ``We got into a number of areas. They know what requirements are necessary. ... There is a good appreciation of what needs to be done.'' In 1987, the United States excluded Paraguay from the Generalized System of Preferences trading because the Stroessner reigme did not comply with GSP worker rights' standards. Rodriguez, a military general, overthrew Stroessner in a violent coup in February 1989. Rodriguez won the presidential election in May. While he has made reforms in human rights, problems still remain, according to the 1990 State Department report on human rights in Paraguay. The report cited police violence against demonstrators and detainment of leaders, slow movement on investigating former police torturers and failure to protect collective bargaining rights. Quayle said he was ``deeply impressed with President Rodriguez's commitment to democracy.''

DOC.HEAD: Passenger Train Rammed by Freight Cars at Depot
DOC.TEXT: A switch engine towing a line of empty freight cars banged the rear of a halted Amtrak train early Tuesday, setting off a chain reaction that left 31 passengers injured and three cars derailed. ``It was just so unexpected; there was no warning,'' said Amtrak employee Paul Jones, who was treated for whiplash at Nash General Hospital. ``The car just jolted and things went flying around.'' None of the injuries was serious. Three cars of the 19-car Silver Meteor from Tampa to New York were bumped off the rails. Several of the 471 passengers said they were sleeping when the collision threw them from their seats. ``I had just started to wake up when it hit,'' said Mary Lou Henley of Lackawana, N.Y. ``It slammed me into the seat in front of me and then threw me back in my seat. eople were screaming and hollering and laying in the aisle.'' ``I had just dropped off to sleep, then there was this awful boom,'' said Viola Smiley of Syracuse, N.Y. ``I remember screaming and then my neck and back were hurting. The man told us the freight train was only going 3 miles an hour. If he'd have been going any faster we would have all been killed. We were blessed by God, is the best way that I can say it. Blessed, blessed, blessed.'' CSX Transportation spokesman Linday Leckie, whose company owns the tracks, said 31 injuries were reported. The three-man freight train crew was unhurt. Nursing supervisor June Williams at Nash General said 21 patients were treated, most of them for sprains, strains and bruises. None was admitted. The passengers included college students returning from Florida vacations and a high school French club headed for Canada. ``We just had a student who was terrified of train rides and we assured her nothing would happen,'' said Elma Averitte, headmistress of the Flora McDonald Academy in Fayetteville. ``We've got another group leaving for London today, but they're flying.'' The passengers were put on chartered buses. The tracks were expected to be cleared by Tuesday night.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Ready to Negotiate Return of Australian Spy Base
DOC.TEXT: The United States is ready to give Australia total control of a spy base in the Australian Outback that is used to communicate with U.S. submarines in the Indian Ocean, Foreign Ministry officials said Tuesday. Prime Minister Bob Hawke said late Monday he discussed handing over North West Cape base in the far reaches of Western Australia state with U.S. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney. Officials, who demanded anonymity, said Tuesday it was ``pretty well agreed'' that Australia regain control of the base, which began operating 27 years ago. They gave no details. Hawke said the base, one of three operated jointly by Australian and U.S. personnel, was increasingly important to Australia's defense security. Military analysts said the base was of less importance now to the U.S. because the Pentagon uses longer-range missiles that do not need to be deployed from the Indian Ocean, which washes the North West Cape. Hawke made the announcement toward the end of campaigning for a record fourth consecutive term for his Labor government. Elections are March 24. His opponents said the change amounted to a political ploy. ``The government knew the U.S. was planmning to pull out last year,'' said Bill Smith, whose Trade and Labor Council represents the 200 Australian workers at the base. Australia Defense Association chairman Bill Harding said the United States no longer needed North West Cape because it had satellite-based submarine communications systems. He said Australia had no choice in taking over the base _ at an annual cost of $30 million _ and that the announcement was timed as a political gimmick to attract more environmentalist votes.

DOC.HEAD: Former Mexican Police, Accomplices Charged in Eight Killings
DOC.TEXT: Six former police officers and five accomplices have been arrested in the killings of eight people who tried to stop drug running to the United States, authorities said Tuesday. The attorney general's office said in a statement that Miguel Angel Felix Gallardo, known as the godfather of the drug trade in Mexico, ordered the killings, which occurred between November 1988 and March 5. Felix Gallardo was arrested in April 1989 and is in jail in Mexico City, awaiting trial on cocaine trafficking and other charges. The eleven people Felix Gallardo allegedly contracted with for the killings are residents of the northwestern state of Sinaloa. Authorities said band members were arrested this week after a shootout in a Culiacan suburb and are accused of murder, drug trafficking and possession of illegal arms. he day of the arrests was not given. Authorities said the band killed a narcotics trafficker known as ``El Lobito'' and another person identified only as Felipe in November 1988. A former state commander of the Federal Judicial Police, Armando Barraza, is wanted on suspicion of participating in those killings, authorities said. The slayings were carried out in the Sinaloa town of El Naranjo, according to testimony the attorney general's office took from former judicial police agent Jose Guadalupe Graciano Aguilar. He has been arrested, authorities said. One week after the El Naranjo deaths, the band killed a judicial policeman from Sinaloa on the highway between the Pacific resort of Mazatlan and the state capital Sinaloa, the attorney general's office said. It said band members also killed two narcotics traffickers in January this year on a Culiacan ranch. Graciano Aguilar testified the band killed a city policeman and his brother on March 3 and another man on March 5, authorities said. In a related case, the attorney general's office announced on Monday that three Venezuelan men and one Mexican attorney were kidnapped Feb. 22, then tortured, killed and buried in Culiacan by 10 people in an act of revenge against Felix Gallardo. Union representatives at Culiacan University, where the Venezuelans were studying and working, on Tuesday protested the recent violence in the state, the independent news service Excelsior reported.

DOC.HEAD: Panama's President Endara Ends Hunger Strike
DOC.TEXT: President Guillermo Endara ended on Tuesday the hunger strike he began March 1 to press for U.S. money to help Panama's troubled economy and ease unemployment. In Washington, President Bush renewed his request to Congress for $500 million in assistance to help rescue Panama's battered economy. Endara said he ended the fast to protect his health. A medical report released Tuesday said he showed ``signs of exhaustion and dehydration.'' ``Even though I feel in perfect condition ... I think that the responsibility of the job indicates that I should suspend this deprivation,'' Endara said. ``I should not endanger my health and abilities to govern and direct the government.'' Looting that followed the Dec. 20 U.S. invasion to oust Manuel Antonio Noriega destroyed many businesses. Unemployment is above 30 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Nine Gunmen Killed After Failed Kidnapping
DOC.TEXT: Nine men intent on kidnapping the sister of a drug trafficking suspect who was extradited to the United States were killed in a gun battle Tuesday with police on Colombia's north coast, authorities said. The gunmen broke into the beach home of Marta Abello Silva in the Caribbean tourist city of Santa Marta, national police Col. Hugo Alberto Pulido said in a live interview with the radio network RCN. Miss Abello was not home, however, and the men were killed as they fled with goods stolen from the house, Pulido said. He did not say how authorities had determined the men planned to kidnapped Miss Abello, who was elected to congress in Sunday's elections. Her brother is Jose Rafael Abello Silva, extradited to the United States on Oct. 29. He faces trial on drug trafficking charges in Tulsa, Okla. A federal senator, Hugo Escobar Sierra of Santa Marta, had said before the election that drug traffickers had paid voters to cast ballots for specific candidates. He did not elaborate.

DOC.HEAD: Indian Court Acquits Two in Spy Case
DOC.TEXT: A court Tuesday acquitted an Indian businessman and his employee of passing defense secrets to the United States, West Germany and Taiwan. Businessman Ram Swaroop was arrested in October 1985 on spying charges. His employee, Javed Siddiqui, was arrested and charged two months later. Judge P.R. Thakur of New Delhi court said he was acquitting the two for lack of evidence. ``In the evidence on record, finding a criminal conspiracy between the two accused was like finding a black cat in a dark room where there was none,'' he said in his judgment.

DOC.HEAD: Nine Suspected Kurdish Guerrillas Killed in Clash
DOC.TEXT: Fourteen suspected Kurdish guerrillas were killed in fighting with security forces Tuesday in this southeastern township, the semiofficial Anatolia news agency reported. The agency said the clash occurred when security forces acting on a tip surrounded the guerrillas in two houses near Serenli, a village about 50 miles from the Syrian border. The guerrillas opened fire to calls to surrender and at least 14 insurgents were killed in the shootout, Anatolia said. It did not say to what organization the suspects belonged. Rebels operating in the region are linked with the Kurdish Labor Party, a Marxist group with headquarters in the Syrian-controlled Bekaa valley in Lebanon. The group seeks an independent state in southeastern Turkey. More than 2,200 people have died since the rebels started their attacks six years ago. Ethnic Kurds make up about one-fifth of Turkey's population of 55 million.

DOC.HEAD: Widow: Doctors Said Sen. East's Problems Were Psychological
DOC.TEXT: John East's widow testified in her lawsuit Tuesday that the U.S. senator's health gradually worsened while Navy doctors who were unaware he had a serious thyroid disorder insisted his problem was psychological. The North Carolina Republican committed suicide in 1986, 11 months after being cured of the disorder. Priscilla East, 58, of Greenville, N.C., contends her husband believed the doctors' failure to diagnose his condition for several years had caused his mental and physical powers to deteriorate. He left a suicide note blaming the doctors. In 1984, East regularly saw a psychiatrist recommended by Rear Adm. Freeman Cary, the U.S. Capitol's attending physician at the time, Mrs. East said. East ``told me, `I kept telling the admiral my problem is physical,' and he kept telling John it was a mental problem,'' she testified. Her $3.5 million claim is believed to be the first wrongful death claim against the government by the family of a U.S. senator. The government contends that Mrs. East lacks medical proof that East's decision to end his life resulted from the late diagnosis of hypothyroidism. East killed himself in June 1986 by filling his garage with carbon monixide. Doctors told East that his thyroid problem should have been detected sooner and that they had never seen such an advanced case as his, Mrs. East testified. In hypothyroidism, the thyroid gland does not produce hormones necessary to keep the body's metabolism working properly. East, suffering insomnia and slowness of speech, became upset when newspapers in North Carolina began to raise questions about his capabilities. ``He was hopeful that he would snap out of this in time to run for re-election,'' Mrs. East said. ``But there began to be articles ... (saying) that North Carolina needed two senators. I remember one of them said, `Is he dead? Is he gone? Where is Sen. East?' Those hit below the belt.'' East was hospitalized at the Bethesda Naval Medical Center in April 1985, after collapsing at the couple's home. He was put under a suicide watch on the psychiatric ward, but when blood tests detected hypothyroidism, he was transferred to an internal medicine ward, with no watch. A few days later, he tried to kill himself by jamming a chair leg down his throat, Mrs. East testified. She said no one at the hospital could explain to her why East had been left unguarded. He was hospitalized several more times in succeeding months for other health ailments, and became deeply depressed, she said. He had always been vigorous and athletic despite being confined to a wheelchair by polio, she said. East was particularly unhappy about his lack of ability to concentrate and to understand written and spoken words. ``He said, `You remember the old John East?' I said sure. He said, `I'm not the old John East I used to be. I'm just a shell of my former self,''' she testified. Her attorney, James Hourihan, showed U.S. District Court Judge Walter Black Jr. videotapes of East's appearances on news shows in 1981, 1983 and 1984. In the 1981 clip, East seemed articulate and self-possessed. The later interviews showed him speaking more slowly and with less animation. Assistant U.S. Attorney Susan Ringler said in opening arguments Monday that the anger East felt against Navy doctors before he committed suicide was unjustified. Ringler also disputed the claim that hypothyroidism dulled East's mental abilities, saying he led an active life until his death.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Says White South Africa Has Elected Last Government
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela told Swedish lawmakers Tuesday that South African whites have elected their last apartheid government. The black leader, on an international crusade for his anti-apartheid organization, also appealed for ``massive amounts'' of foreign aid to bolster his group. Asked earlier if he thought the next South African president would be black, Mandela said: ``That is a possibility, but we must leave that to the future.'' Speaking to the Swedish parliament, Mandela said there is not a climate yet in South Africa for black-white power sharing, but a negotiated settlement to the conflict is not far off. ``The road we still have to traverse will not be long,'' Mandela said. ``It may not be smooth and easy, but clearly the racist tyranny is on its way out.'' ``White South Africa has elected its last racial parliament and its last apartheid president,'' said Mandela, deputy president of the African National Congress. He was freed last month after more than 27 years in South African jails. Mandela was in Sweden to visit African National Congress president Oliver Tambo, who is being treated for a stroke he suffered late last year. He arrived Monday and was expected to stay five days. Mandela told the Swedish legislators that the possibility of a negotiated settlement in South Africa depends on the government of President F.W. de Klerk. ``As yet, it has not even completed the process of creating a climate conducive to negotiations,'' he said. ``We shall be meeting President F.W. de Klerk and his colleagues to address this issue as soon as the necessary arrangements have been completed.'' Mandela's ANC has demanded the government free all political prisoners, remove soldiers from black townships and lift the state of emergency before talks begin. ``We have a vision of South Africa as a united, democratic, non-sexist, non-racial country,'' Mandela said. ``We see ourselves as not aligned to any military blocs.'' Mandela said the international community should provide more aid to the ANC and tighten sanctions against South Africa. He stopped short of a direct rebuke to British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, whose Conservative government became the first to ease economic sanctions following conciliatory steps by de Klerk. Mandela said it was up to ANC leaders to decide whether he should meet Mrs. Thatcher, who has invited him to visit Britain. ``We expect all countries to intensify sanctions against South Africa,'' Mandela said. He said countries should also cut diplomatic ties with South Africa. Mandela is scheduled to meet in Stockholm on Thursday with Neil Kinnock, leader of the British opposition Labor Party, which supports anti-apartheid sanctions. In a two-hour meeting with Swedish Prime Minister Ingvar Carlsson on Tuesday, Mandela said he reported on the need for ``massive amounts of assistance'' from Sweden and the international community. Carlsson said Swedish aid to the ANC would continue. Sweden has allocated $45 million to the ANC this year. Since being freed from jail, Mandela has kept an exhausting schedule. His current trip has also taken him to Tanzania, Zambia, Zimbabwe and Ethiopia for public rallies and conferences with government and African leaders.

DOC.HEAD: Defense Witness Testifies It Was Impossible to Determine Hazelwood Drunk
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with another defense expert questioning determination that Hazelwood was drunk, EDITS to conform; no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: An expert defense witness testified Tuesday that a delay in a blood-alcohol test made it virtually impossible to determine whether Exxon Valdez skipper Joseph Hazelwood was drunk when his tanker ran aground. The test wasn't performed until 10{ hours after the 987-foot tanker ran aground March 24 in Prince William Sound, spilling nearly 11 million gallons in the nation's worst oil spill. The prosecution contends that Hazelwood was drunk. Michael Hlastala, a physiology professor at the University of Washington in Seattle, rebutted a prosecution expert's claim that he could tell Hazelwood was drunk when his ship ran aground by doing calculations based on the blood test. ``Once you are beyond a few hours, it's impossible to make any sense of an extrapolation,'' Hlastala testified in Hazelwood's Superior Court trial. The professor said he was familiar with the technique of retrograde extrapolation, which seeks to establish blood alcohol levels at a time distant from when blood tests are taken. He said there would be numerous variables in Hazelwood's case, such as the rate at which the body absorbs and eliminates alcohol and the times the captain started and stopped drinking. Testimony hasn't established conclusive numbers for any of the variables. Hlastala showed jurors a graph in which he calculated a wide range of possible blood-alcohol levels that could be deduced from the test. They ranged from .10, the Alaska standard for drunken driving, to .50, where the expert said a person would be near death. He said the calculations are further complicated because, to reach these levels, a person would have to consume 7.7 standard drinks, which he defined as one-ounce shots of 80-proof liquor. No one has alleged Hazelwood drank that much. Hlastala said his calculations proved only one thing: ``It's virtually impossible to go back and get meaningful information about blood-alcohol levels.'' Earlier, Judge Karl Johnston cleared the way for the prosecution to suggest Hazelwood was a heavy drinker and was able to hide the effects of alcohol, despite objections from the defense. Johnstone said he felt the prosecution had the right ``to explore all the possibilities of blood alcohol and its effect on the defendant.'' In remarks to Assistant District Attorney Brent Cole, Johnstone warned, ``It's thin line that you're walking here,'' and added that he wasn't yet giving permission for Cole to present such a theory in final arguments. Under cross-examination by Cole, defense expert Thomas Burr said experienced drinkers were better able to hide the effects of alcohol, but added the person would have to be used to drinking routinely to become adept at it. ``Some people do it better than others?'' asked Cole. ``Yes,'' said the witness, an alcohol and drug testing consultant from Minneapolis. Cole asked whether an intoxicated person who didn't want others to observe his drunken state might go somewhere nobody could see him. ``I guess so,'' the witness said with a laugh. ``Like go below?'' Cole asked, referring to the captain's quarters on the Exxon Valdez. The answer was blocked by a defense objection. According to earlier testimony, Hazelwood left the bridge in command of his third mate and went to his cabin before the tanker ran aground. Burr also disputed the validity of calculating the amount of blood in Hazelwood's system by calculating backwards. ``If there was any alcohol consumption during this period of time, there's absolutely no validity ... no validity whatsoever,'' Burr said. There have been suggestions during the lengthy trial that Hazelwood drank some low-alcohol beer in his cabin after the grounding. Hazelwood, 43, of Huntington, N.Y., was the only crew member of the Exxon Valdez charged criminally in the accident. He is accused of criminal mischief, reckless endangerment, operating a vessel while intoxicated and negligent discharge of oil. If convicted, he faces a maximum penalty of 7\ years in prison and $61,000 in fines. On questioning by defense attorney Dick Madson, Burr said a person showing no visible signs of intoxication was unlikely to have a blood-alcohol reading as high as the one calculated for Hazelwood by the prosecution expert. Burr added he never has seen anyone with a blood alcohol level of 0.15 who did not show some signs of intoxication. Burr's expertise in the field was challenged by Cole, who noted the witness had no advanced degrees and is not a toxicologist. Burr said his 22 years in the St. Paul, Minn., police crime laboratory gave him ample knowledge.

DOC.HEAD: Memo From DOE Inadvertently Disclosed: Lists Rash of Reactor Problems
DOC.TEXT: The Department of Energy on Tuesday defended an inadvertently leaked memo about nuclear contamination problems at weapons plants nationwide as proof it is keeping on top of operations. ``It indicates we're taking the trouble to find out what's going on and fixing it,'' said DOE press secretary Mary Joy Jameson. The memo, a briefing paper for DOE Secretary James Watkins, was mistakenly sent by fax machine to governors around the country on Monday. The Associated Press obtained a copy. Three hours after the briefing paper was sent out, a note addressed to ``all state governors'' urged them to disregard and destroy the document. It wasn't known how many governors' offices had received it. The two-page summary described various problems at the government's nuclear complex, including ``widespread low-level contamination'' at a tank farm at the Savannah River Site in South Carolina; the discovery of three live wires at Savannah River that posed ``imminent danger'' and an effort to halt the activities of anti-nuclear protesters. The document originally said the low-level contamination leak was at a tank farm in Hanford, Wash., but the DOE corrected it Tuesday to Savannah River. Ms. Jameson said she knew of no actual danger to workers or other people as a result of any of the incidents. ``If there was any danger, we would have issued a press release,'' she said. Tom Clements, southeast nuclear campaigner for Greenpeace, said he was ``shocked but not surprised'' by the memo. ``This just reflects that the Department of Energy has a lot more to hide than has been revealed, and I would call on them to release information about all the problems and all the contamination that they have not released to this date,'' Clements said. Among other things, the document said a radiation survey in the control room of a reactor at Oak Ridge, Tenn., found that four chairs and a stool were contaminated with cobalt-60. Two chairs were disposed of and the other furniture was decontaminated. Another item in the document said a cleanup of last week's ``widespread low-level contamination'' in the tank farm at Savannah River was continuing. The efforts included cleaning all paved roads and a radioactivity survey. Ms. Jameson said there was a recent spill of contaminated water in the tank farm but ``it wasn't hazardous to the health of anyone. It could have been if it had not been detected and cleaned up.'' At Hanford, the memo said a fire in a weapons cleaning trailer Friday had destroyed the trailer, but no injuries were reported. Other reports in the briefing paper: _ Sandia National Laboratories management and the DOE's Albuquerque, N.M., office agreed to suspend operation Friday of a particle beam fusion accelerator after ``numerous safety concerns'' were identified. _ An annual safeguards and security survey at Sandia showed a shortage of classified parts at a microelectronics operation. The memo said the problem had been reported in January and that a complete inventory would be conducted. _ A Sandia subcontractor being escorted into the laboratory was denied access when guards using sniffer dogs found six live rounds of handgun ammunition and traces of marijuana in the person's vehicle. The subcontractor's badge was pulled and the employer notified. _ The DOE's Savannah River operations office said the Westinghouse Savannah River Co. had discovered that seismic support U-bolts were missing from some supplementary safety system injection lines on a reactor. _ Also at Savannah River, DOE and OSHA inspectors found three live, bare wires in a reactor building. The wires were fixed and an investigation is being conducted into what was described as an ``imminent danger,'' Watkins was advised. The memo contained no other details. _ A DOE truck convoy was followed and photographed in Texas and Oklahoma on Thursday by anti-nuclear protesters in two cars. The note indicates that authorities looked into the police records of the cars' owners but found no outstanding warrants. _ A security inspector at the DOE's Rocky Flats, Colo., weapons plant was arrested Sunday in Aurora, Colo., on suspicion of burglary, assault and rape. The employee was suspended. The memo was signed by Stephen Ronshaugen in the office of the DOE undersecretary. Sandia spokesman Nigel Hey said the Sandia problems cited in the document were housekeeping matters and had nothing to do with scientific or engineering aspects of the accelerator. Officials with both the Savannah River Site near Aiken, S.C., and the plant's operator, Westinghouse Savannah River Co., referred questions about the memo to the DOE in Washington.

DOC.HEAD: Six-Month British Ambulance Dispute Is Over
DOC.TEXT: A six-month pay dispute that crippled British ambulance services ended Tuesday when the 22,500-member workforce accepted a new government offer. The dispute began Sept. 7, when ambulance crews started refusing to work overtime. It worsened within a month when they stopped using their radios and many crews walked out on strike. Army and police vehicles, taxis and Red Cross volunteers were organized to take emergency cases to hospitals. The five unions involved said Tuesday their members favored the offer by a vote of 81 percent to 19 percent. The government proposal increases the annual pay of a qualified ambulance worker by 17.6 percent, from $16,148 to $18,992. The government runs the National Health Service. Roger Poole, the unions' chief negotiator, said service would be back to normal by Friday. ``Our members have won a substantial improvement on the government's 6.5 percent original offer, and this success vindicates their industrial campaign,'' he said. The health department stressed that it had not given in to the unions' demand for a formula guaranteeing future raises. ``The public owe a great debt of gratitude to the voluntary services, police and armed forces who helped to maintain accident and emergency services in many parts of the country,'' said Health Secretary Kenneth Clarke. During the dispute, ambulance crews refusing to work normally were suspended without pay. But the crews are popular and widely recognized as low paid, and the public rallied behind them by contributing money and signatures to a petition signed by four million people.

DOC.HEAD: Psychologist Bruno Bettelheim Commits Suicide
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with death called suicide, quotes, background; no pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Bruno Bettelheim, a psychologist and prolific author who studied under Sigmund Freud and gained fame for his work with emotionally disturbed children, killed himself Tuesday in a Maryland nursing home, a medical examiner said. He was 86. Maryland's chief medical examiner, Dr. John E. Smialek, said Tuesday night that one of his deputies who examined Bettelheim had determined the cause of death was suicidal asphyxiation. Smialek declined to give details. Bettelman lived at The Charter House nursing home in Silver Spring, Md. A secretary who did not give her name referred calls Tuesday night to Bettelheim's family, but declined to provide a telephone number. Bettelheim, who was also known for his Freudian interpretations of fairy tales, ran The Sonia Shankman Orthogenic School for disturbed children at the University of Chicago from 1944 to 1973, and was a professor of psychology and psychiatry at the university. ``He was like such men, great men, a whole combination of things. He could be extraordinarly charming, but very authoritarian so that one could easily tremble at the sight of him,'' said Jacquelyn Sanders, who took over the school in 1973. ``He also was fascinating, very cultured.'' Perhaps his most famous book, ``Love is Not Enough,'' related the ideas he practiced at the school. He advocated giving disturbed children round-the-clock attention from professionals instead of leaving them to a caretaker staff after a few hours of therapy, said Benjamin Wright, a professor of education and psychology at the university. Bettelheim was at the school from early morning to after midnight nearly every day, said Wright, who worked at the school from 1950 to 1957. ``It was a miracle of devotion to the cause of providing a better life for these childen. He was superhumanly devoted to it,'' Wright said. ``I think that his greatest moment were those years at the school.'' Dr. Raymond Fowler, chief executive officer of the American Psychological Association in Washington, said ``Love is Not Enough'' influenced his decision to become a psychologist. ``He was an incredibly articulate person,'' Fowler said. ``Much of his impact was simply because of his writings because he wrote so brilliantly.'' Bettelheim was born Aug. 28, 1903, in Vienna, Austria. He was educated in Vienna, where he studied under Freud, the famous psychoanalyst. In 1938, the Nazis arrested Bettelheim, a Jew, and sent him to the Dachau and Buchenwald concentration camps. He was released in 1939 and came to the United States. He gained early fame for his study of death camp prisoners. He took over the Orthogenic School in 1944, and brought it to world prominence. ``To me his most significant work was at the Orthogenic School, where he created a kind of environment for kids, for very complete failures,'' Sanders said. Wright said the school's success stories included several college professors, two successful authors and a stockbroker. Many schools have been formed on the principles Bettelheim used at the Orthogenic School, but none have duplicated his success because no one has been willing to put in the time he did, Wright said. Bettelheim became professor emeritus at the University of Chicago in 1975, but continued to write. Rudolf Ekstein, a longtime colleague and friend, spent weekends with Bettelheim after he moved to California during his retirement years. ``In a way it was my good luck that he spent the last couple of years herem, so we would come together on weekends to discuss not only treatment of children but the way the world turns, you know Russia and Eastern Europe, because we were both refugees,'' Ekstein said in a telephone interview. In addition to ``Love is Not Enough,'' which was published in 1950, Bettelheim's workds included ``Dynamics of Prejudice'' (1950), ``Truants from Life'' (1955), ``The Informed Heart'' (1960), ``The Children of the Dream'' (1969) and ``The Uses of Enchantment (1976), with Karen Zelan.

DOC.HEAD: Williams leads on GOP side; Richards Ahead in Close Democratic Race
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates returns, Hightower ahead in ag commissioner race, Parmer leading for Democratic Senate nomination
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto AT1, AT2, MID2, Others Upcoming
DOC.TEXT: Millionaire oilman-rancher Clayton Williams jumped to a wide lead in early returns from the Republican gubernatorial primary Tuesday.
