State Treasurer Ann Richards led in a battle among three mud-slinging Democrats that appeared likely to end in a runoff. With 1 percent of precincts counted, Williams, a political newcomer who spend $8 million on the race, led a seven-way GOP field with 57,511 votes or 63 percent. Railroad Commissioner Kent Hance, a former Democratic congressman, was a distant second with 12,363 votes or 14 percent, followed by Tom Luce, a lawyer for billionaire H. Ross Perot, with 10,151 votes or 11 percent. Former Secretary of State Jack Rains of Houston was fourth with 9,214 votes or 10 percent. On the Democratic side, Richards led with 42,615 votes or 42 percent, followed by Attorney General Jim Mattox, with 31,097 votes or 31 percent, and former Gov. Mark White, with 24,358 votes or 24 percent. Four other candidates divided the remaining vote. Richards, who dodged repeated questions during the campaign about whether she had ever used illegal drugs, accused Mattox and White of profiteering from public service. She was bidding for a chance to become the state's first woman governor since Miriam ``Ma'' Ferguson left the office in 1935. White and Mattox called Ms. Richards a liar, and the bitterness appeared likely to continue until April 10. If none of the three polled more than 50 percent of the vote, the top two would meet then in a runoff. Williams, who calls himself ``just a country boy'' and admits to occasional fistfights, spent $6 million from his own pockets in the campaign. A confident Williams, wearing cowboy boots, voted at Saddle Club South Clubhouse near his Midland home. ``There's a good chance we can win without a runoff,'' Williams said. He said earlier that if that happened and the opposition was forced into a runoff, he would relax and ``have some fun watching each of the Democrats murdering on each other.'' Election officials reported brisk turnout throughout the day around the state. The secretary of state's office predicted a turnout of 2.1 million to 2.6 million of the 8.3 million eligible voters, who can vote for either party. Absentee balloting was expected to account for up to 25 percent of the vote. It was the first gubernatorial race in Texas since the state allowed people to vote absentee without stating a reason. Also on the GOP ballot were Ed Cude of Houston; W.N. Otwell, a Fort Worth preacher, and Royce X. Owens, an elementary school custodian from Merkel. Other Democrats running were: Stanley Adams of Austin, a former executive with a failed savings and loan; Theresa Hearn-Haynes of Spring, who described her occupation as doctor of law; Hawkins retiree Earl Holmes, and Ray Rachal of Stafford. Texans also voted on the U.S. Senate seat held by Republican Phil Gramm, who has no GOP opponent in his bid for a second term. State Sen. Hugh Parmer, a 50-year-old Fort Worth lawyer, sought the Democratic nomination and was piling up a better than 3-1 margin against his only opponent, Harley Schlanger, a Houston follower of extremist Lyndon LaRouche. Jim Hightower, the state agriculture commissioner who raised controversy at every turn, was pulling in 69 percent of the vote in early returns as he defended himself against six Democratic opponents supported by the Texas Farm Bureau. Hightower bills himself a friend of the small, independent farmer, but brought the wrath of some ranchers with his support of hormone-free beef. Republicans last year failed in their bid to have the Legislature abolish Hightower's job. Three Republicans also were competing for it in the primary.

Spending in the gubernatorial races topped $25 million, a state record. Ms. Richards won prominence as the keynote speaker at the 1988 Democratic National Convention, where she said President Bush was born ``with a silver foot in his mouth.'' She saw an early lead in polls slip amid charges of racism and for her refusal to say ``yes or no'' when asked during three televised debates whether she'd ever abused drugs. A recovering alcoholic, she said her ``addiction was alcohol'' and she didn't want to discourage others from seeking treatment. Her opponents said they never used illegal substances and called on Ms. Richards to answer. Mattox warned that the Republicans would ``bust our party'' if she wouldn't answer as the Democratic nominee. Ms. Richards, in turn, asked how White could ``move from a government salary to a $1.3 million mansion in Houston right after leaving the governor's office?'' Mattox, she charged, took campaign contributions from people doing business with the state. White called her charges ``a pack of lies.'' Mattox said her attacks had ``become rather scurrilous.'' Williams attracted some criticism early in the campaign when opponents said he'd been in two fistfights during the past eight years. But he said both fights were justified, and turned the criticism to his advantage by saying Texans would prefer a governor who fights for what's right. Republicans are especially determined to hold onto the governorship this year because of reapportionment, in which Texas is expected to gain three or four Congressional seats based on the 1990 census. The Legislature _ almost certain to remain in Democratic control _ will draw the new lines, but a GOP governor could veto the plan. The current governor, Republican Bill Clements, is retiring.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Lifts Nicaragua Sanctions, Asks for Quick $300 Million in Aid
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS 26th graf: ``The Nicaraguan,'' with embassy statement
DOC.TEXT: President Bush lifted trade sanctions against Nicaragua on Tuesday and asked Congress to swiftly approve a $300 million down payment for rebuilding the nation's ravaged economy and speeding a transition to democracy. He said the money would come from the Pentagon. Rushing to shore up the incoming government of President-elect Violeta Chamorro, Bush also pledged to seek an additional $200 million in fiscal 1991 which begins Oct. 1. Bush coupled the request for Nicaragua with a challenge to Congress to approve a stalled aid package of $500 million for Panama, where the United States installed a new government after deposing Manuel Antonio Noriega last December. Bush also is seeking $70 million in refugee assistance in Panama. The president urged Congress to complete work by April 5 on money for both countries. All the funds would be diverted from the Pentagon's budget, perhaps the first real ``peace dividend'' from the receding Cold War. ``These nations need our help to heal deep wounds inflicted by years of strife and oppression, years of loss and deprivation,'' Bush said. ``And we must act and act soon.''' Congress appeared receptive. Rep. David Bonior, D-Mich., a member of the House leadership and among the foremost foes of past U.S. policy in Nicaragua, predicted Congress would approve the aid before recessing next month for Easter. ``For years we've been hearing speeches about what America could do if only Noriega and Ortega were gone,'' said Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., referring to the former Panamanian ruler and to Nicaraguan President Daniel Ortega who lost the election to Mrs. Chamorro last month. ``Well, Ortega and Noriega are history. It's time for Congress to deliver,'' Dole said. Senate Appropriations Chairman Robert C. Byrd, D-W.Va., promised quick consideration of Bush's request but pointed out that Congress is still in dispute over the president's ability to channel Pentagon funds into the package. Byrd, in a letter to Secretary of State James A. Baker III, noted that the General Accounting Office has contested the administration's authority to delay spending $2.2 billion in defense funds that had been approved by Congress. Bush announced his requests in a 41-minute news conference, during which he also fielded questions on topics ranging from the budget and foreign policy to baseball's labor dispute that threatens to delay the season's opener. He made these points: _He does not support a tax increase or a freeze in Social Security benefits as proposed in a deficit-reduction package offered by Rep. Dan Rostenkowski, D-Ill. Nevertheless, Bush said he did not want to appear inflexible and was willing to negotiate with the Democrats. _He is ``not happy with the status quo'' in China, where a crackdown remains in force against advocates of democracy. Even so, Bush said he had no regrets about U.S. policy toward Beijing. _It would be ``very inappropriate'' for him to comment on the Soviet parliament's approval of a new powers for President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. ``I think we have a reasonably good relationship there, a respectful one and I'm going to continue to work with him,'' he said. _There is ``no bubbling war'' with Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan despite differences over interest rates. ``Look, every president would like to see interest rates lower,'' Bush said. _He did not regret getting involved in a telephone call with a person he believed to be Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani but who turned out to be an impostor. ``What's wrong with reaching out and touching someone when the hostages are at stake?'' he said. He said a long-ago use of marijuana shouldn't disqualify a political candidate. The question arose in the context of a political flap in Texas where Ann Richards, who is seeking the Democratic gubernatorial nomination, has refused to say whether she ever used illegal drugs. Opening his news conference, Bush announced he had lifted the five-year-old economic embargo against Nicaragua, one of the tools used by the United States to undermine the leftist government of Ortega. The president also took steps to allow Nicaragua to resume shipping sugar to the United States and to make that nation eligible for duty-free treatment for a variety of other products. While acknowledging some concern about the reluctance of the U.S.-backed Contra rebels to demobilize in Nicaragua, Bush said, ``I'm less concerned than I was about the peaceful transfer of power, including the military.'' Money for Panama and Nicaragua will be drawn from money allotted to the Pentagon, requiring a decision on which defense programs will be cut. Bush said that if Congress can't make up its mind about cutbacks by March 27, it should let him do the job himself. Of the money for Nicaragua, $75 million would be earmarked for economic restructuring, $60 million for critical agricultural supplies, petroleum and medical supplies, another $60 million for development projects and $50 million to help with foreign debts. Some $10 million would help pay for ``emergency employment programs,'' including ones designed to help turn soldiers into farmers. In addition, $45 million would go toward helping speed the repatriation and resettlement of the U.S.-backed Contra forces and other refugees. The Nicaraguan Embassy issued a statement in the name of Mrs. Lenor A. Huper, charge d'affaires, saying ``we express our support for both' the end of sanctions and the aid package, and inviting U.S. experts to inspect Nicaragua's economic situation at first hand. On another subject at his news conference, Bush was asked about the baseball dispute and the decision by owners to lock players out of spring training camps. He said he didn't want to have the federal government intervene but instead ``would simply appeal to both sides to get the matter resolved so the American people can hear that cry, `Play ball,' again.'' He refused to retract his description of East Jerusalem as occupied territory _ a statement that has caused a political uproar in Israel. ``I don't regret it,'' Bush said, adding that he was merely reiterating U.S. policy. He said his statement had been blown out of proportion and said that further comment would not be helpful. Asked if the administration would recognize a drive for independence by the Soviet Republic of Lithuania, Bush said, ``We want to see the evolution of the control of the territory there.'' He said the U.S. government might not use the words ``captive nations'' to describe Lithuania and other Baltic states, as it has in the past.

DOC.HEAD: New President Promises to `Clean Face' of Haiti
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to ADD six deaths in village land dispute, CLARIFY that Haiti also had other civilian leader, details, minor editing. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos PAP1,3
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) _ President Ertha Pascal-Trouillot pledged at her inauguration Tuesday ``to clean the face of Haiti'' with a provisional civilian government that will lead this country to its first free elections. Mrs. Pascal-Trouillo, who took a leave of absence as Supreme Court justice, is the first female president in the 186-year history of this impoverished Caribbean island nation. She was sworn in a day after military ruler Lt. Gen. Prosper Avril fled following a week of violent demonstrations against his 18-month regime that left at least 24 dead in Haiti. Late Tuesday, radio stations reported the deaths of six people in a coastal village following a land dispute. ``I have accepted this heavy task in the name of Haitian women,'' she told hundreds of political and civic leaders, diplomats and army officers at the National Palace ceremony. ``My government will be what you want it to be.'' Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot, 46, will govern along with a 19-member advisory council until elections are held, possibly in three to six months. ``In the short time I have, I will work to clean the face of Haiti,'' she promised. She spoke in both French and Creole, the island patois. ``Mrs. President of the Republic, the armed forces of Haiti are at your command,'' said Maj. Gen. Herard Abraham, who led a caretaker government for 72 hours after Avril resigned Saturday. ``The army is returning and staying in the barracks.'' The audience wildly cheered Abraham's words. After the ceremony, thousands of Haitians outside the domed, white-stone palace filled Champ de Mars Plaza and cheered when she came outside. A strike and fear had left this capital of 1 million people deserted for days. Businesses reopened Tuesday and Port-au-Prince was calm, except for northern Delmas sector, where gunfire sent hundreds fleeing indoors in the early morning. It was not clear who did the shooting. An hour after the ceremony, mobs stormed the two-story suburban home of a prominent land owner. They stole furniture, destroyed belongings and shattered windows. ``There were hundreds of them, they came and destroyed everything,'' said Candelon Lucas, who was a deputy in the National Assembly from 1957-80, through most of the 29-year Duvalier dynasty dictatorship. Six people meanwhile were killed in Deluge, a village 37 miles north of Port-au-Prince, according to Roman Catholic Radio Soleil and Haiti-Inter, a private TV station. They said the deaths occurred when sheriffs tried to evict peasants squatting on the property of an absentee landowner. The reports said four peasants, a sheriff and his deputy were killed. In addition, 400 huts were reportedly burned, leaving 2,000 people homeless. After Avril flew into exile Monday on a U.S. Air Force jet, the Bush administration urged ``all Haitians (to) work together in a spirit of reconciliation'' to achieve free elections and respect for human rights ``as rapidly as possible.'' Unity Assembly, an opposition coalition comprising 11 political parties and one civic organization, chose Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot as interim president on Monday. The coalition was instrumental in leading nationwide protests against Avril, who came to power in a soldiers' coup in September 1988. Since a slaves' revolt ended French rule here in 1804, establishing Haiti as the first independent republic in Latin America, most of Haiti's 38 presidents have been military. The new president will lead the first government controlled by civilians since Jean-Claude ``Baby Doc'' Duvalier fled to exile in France in February 1986. His departure ended the 29-year dictatorship begun by his father, the late Francois ``Papa Doc'' Duvalier. Haiti's last civilian president, Leslie Manigat, came to power in January 1988 in elections widely regarded as fraudulent. But the army controlled his administration, and he was eventually toppled by Lt. Gen. Henri Namphy in June 1988. Namphy was ousted three months later in the coup that brought Avril to power. ``This government is the product of the unanimous will of all political parties and social sectors,'' Rene Theodore, leader of the Communist Party and a major player in the military transition of power, said of the new government. Abraham, the major general, agreed Monday to accept Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot as provisional president. The opposition refused the army choice of Supreme Court President Gilbert Austin, an Avril appointee. The State Council that will help Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot govern is comprised of civic, church, labor and rights groups, as well as one army member appointed by the opposition until elections are held. The council will approve the president's Cabinet and reportedly will have veto power over her decisions. Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot said she would ``hold the reins during the electoral period until the installment of a definitive government that the people will choose in complete freedom.'' Members of the State Council include Dr. Louis Roy, main author of the 1987 constitution, who returned Monday from exile in Montreal. Avril sent him there in a harsh crackdown against the opposition in January. ``Even if the Haitian people haven't decided exactly where they want to go, they have clearly said what they no longer want: dictatorship,'' Roy said. Coalition co-leader Victor Benoit said the group chose Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot because other justices declined. He said the Army High Command ``has promised us that the Presidential Guard will be kept under control.'' ``But there are still Duvalierist death squads who oppose change. They're armed, and we know they're very angry about this change,'' he said. Avril commanded the loyalty of much of the 1,100 Presidential Guard throughout last week's unrest.

DOC.HEAD: Cheney Says Patriot Missile Being Considered for Israel
DOC.TEXT: The United States is considering sale of a new air defense missile to Israel, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said Tuesday. Answering questions after a speech at a youth conference of the United Jewish Appeal, Cheney said sale of the Patriot missile system was ``under discussion.'' The Patriot is a 17-foot long missile used by the U.S. Army to defend ground units. It has been deployed with troops in Europe. The missile, made by Raytheon Corp., is designed to replace an earlier air defense missile, the Hawk. Hawks have been supplied to Israel for years. Cheney gave no details of the discussion, such as how many missiles might be supplied or how they would be paid for.

DOC.HEAD: West Germany, France Agree to Include Poland in Unification Talks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with France and Britain agreeing to allow Poland to participate in unification talks, EDITS throughout to tighten; no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: West Germany said Tuesday that it will allow Poland to participate in international talks on German unification so that it can argue the issue of maintaining its current border with East Germany. Chancellor Helmut Kohl said meanwhile that East Germans with moderate savings will be able to exchange their money for West German marks on a one-to-one basis, according to media reports. A Foreign Ministry statement issued in Bonn indicated France and West Germany had settled their differences over giving Poland a place in unification discussions. The talks begin Wednesday between the two German states and the World War II victors _ the United States, Soviet Union, France and Britain. The Foreign Ministry statement said France and West Germany agreed that Poland should participate ``when the question of Poland's western border is discussed.'' France backed Poland's demand to be included. West Germany had said the concerns of all interested nations would be addressed, but had resisted widening the so-called ``two-plus-four'' six-nation talks. It was not clear, however, whether Poland would actually have a seat at the discussions or be consulted in some other way when the border question arises. Poland has demanded a role to protect its border with East Germany formed by the Oder and Neisse rivers. About one-third of present-day western Poland belonged to Germany before World War II. French President Francois Mitterrand declared after meeting Polish leaders Friday that unification could not go forward unless both Germany signed binding accords recognizing the border and its inviolability. It was a rebuke of Kohl, who had stopped short of making a firm recognition of the border, stating that only a unified Germany could do so. Mitterrand termed ``insufficient'' a declaration passed by the West German parliament Thursday that promised to respect the border but failed to mention the Oder-Neisse line. The leader of Kohl's Conservative Party acknowledged Tuesday that international concerns are slowing German unification, and said the process could take three years to complete. Volker Ruehe, general secretary of Kohl's Christian Democratic Union, said unification cannot be completed ``as long as the external questions ... are not settled.'' He was referring to how German unification will affect the European balance of power and other nations' security. Kohl has come under intense international scrutiny for trying to push unification at a pace that has worried the Soviets, as well as some of West Germany's friends and neighbors. But Kohl's handling of unification has worried European nations that their security interests could be overlooked during the process, and the Soviets have made it clear they think Kohl is being too hasty. One of the most complex unification issues facing the German states is how to protect the estimated $10 billion in East German savings once the German economies are joined. ``Federal Chancellor Kohl said this evening at a campaign gathering in Cottbus that moderate savers in East Germany will get a one-to-one exchange rate,'' the ZDF television network said, without elaborating. West German Economics Minister Helmut Haussmann made similar comments at an international trade fair in Leipzig. The report came as a German commission met in East Berlin to hammer out recommendations for forming a monetary union. Horst Koehler, a state secretary in West Germany's Finance Ministry, and finance expert Walter Romberg, a minister in the caretaker government of Communist Premier Hans Modrow, led the meeting. The two sides have met twice before, in Bonn and East Berlin, to discuss forming a monetary union. But no decisions on unification are expected until after the East German elections on Sunday. A statement issued after the monetary talks gave no indication of whether the commission reached agreement. ``An economic union can be completed quickly with the corresponding will of the partners,'' the statement said. The current official exchange rate is three East marks for one West mark for tourists and visitors, but one-to-one for commercial transactions. The East German State Bank has called for a parity exchange rate. There are concerns, however, that if West Germany were to buy up savings at a one-to-one rate, the huge increase in money supply would increase inflation. In Frankfurt, the West German central bank said that starting Wednesday, East Germans could freely deposit and withdraw deposits in West German marks from their bank accounts in both East and West. East Germans had been limited to withdrawing not more than 5,000 West German marks at a time in the West, and 300 West German marks per month in East Germany, said East Germany's official ADN news agency.

DOC.HEAD: Bulgarian News Agency Chief Dismissed
DOC.TEXT: The government on Tuesday fired Boyan Traikov from his longtime job as director general of the state news agency BTA and also dismissed his deputy, Nencho Hranov. It named Georgi Todorov, 56, a veteran foreign correspondent and editor-in-chief of BTA's international news department, to succeed Traikov. Traikov was a trusted ally of Todor Zhivkov, ousted as Communist Party chief last November, and up to last year was also a member of the party's policy-making Central Committee. The official announcement said Traikov was relieved ``due to another appointment.'' However, knowledgeable sources in Sofia _ speaking on the condition of anonymity _ had long predicted his departure and said BTA editors had grown angry and restless over government failure to replace Traikov and Hranov. Zhivkov left during a wave of popular protest that led to pledges of reform from the Communist leadership.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS 4 grafs with detail on aid to Panama.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Bush Rdp Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are major elements of President Bush's aid package for Nicaragua and Panama. OVERALL FUNDS: Bush coupled a $300 million aid package to help Nicaragua speed the transition to democracy with a renewed request for $500 million in aid to Panama. He requested the Panama money earlier this year, but it got sidetracked in Congress on other issues. The Nicaragua and Panama money would be diverted from unspecified Pentagon programs. An existing $21 million would be used for emergency aid to Nicaragua, including food. Some of it would be used to help re-integrate the Contra rebels.

TRADE: The president lifted a five-year-old trade embargo against Nicaragua. He also took steps to allow Nicaragua to resume shipping sugar to the United States and to make that nation eligible for duty-free treatment for a variety of other products. SUPPLIES: Some $60 million would be earmarked for providing critical agricultural supplies, petroleum and medical supplies. EMPLOYMENT PROGRAMS: $10 million would help pay for ``emergency employment programs,'' including ones designed to help turn soldiers into farmers. RESETTLEMENT: Some $45 million would go toward helping speed the repatriation and resettlement of the U.S.-backed Contra forces and other refugees, and an additional $1 million would be used for technical assistance in restructuring the economy. INTERNATIONAL FINANCE: Some $50 million would be used to help Nicaragua pay off debt to the International Monetary Fund and other international financial institutions. An additional $75 million would go toward helping to prop up the Nicaraguan currency to help restructure the economy and aid the country with its balance-of-payments imbalance. PROJECTS: About $60 million would help pay for such projects as bridge, road and highway repair and refurbishing schools and hospitals. FURTHER AID: Bush said he would later propose an additional $200 million to be used in the fiscal year that begins next Oct. 1, with details to be announced later.

FINANCE: $185 million to provide liquidity needed for private banks to make loans, and another $130 million to help pay up Panama's overdue payments to international development banks so the country can become eligible to borrow more. EMPLOYMENT PROGRAMS: $145 million for a government program to generate public investment and create jobs. TRADE: $20 million for private sector export promotion. LAW AND ORDER: $20 million for continued police training and judicial reform.

DOC.HEAD: Indian Troops Withdraw from Trincomalee Town
DOC.TEXT: Indian troops pulled out of an eastern town Tuesday under a withdrawal that is scheduled to be completed by the end of this month, officials said. ``The troops have moved out of Trincomalee town to China Bay,'' 5{ miles away, an Indian High Commission, or embassy, official said. The official, speaking on condition of anonymity, did not say how many troops were stationed in Trincomalee, 150 miles northeast of Colombo, before the withdrawal and gave no other details. China Bay, a Sri Lankan naval base with a deep-water port, is one of the three points being used by Indian troops to leave Sri Lanka. Sri Lankan military officials in Colombo said Trincomalee had been taken over by guerrillas of the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam, the largest rebel group that fought the Indian troops for more than two years. Indian troops were stationed in Sri Lanka's northern and eastern districts to enforce a July 1987 accord that aimed to end a Tamil separatist campaign by giving the ethnic minority limited autonomy. The soldiers were supposed to supervise an arms surrender by the dozens of Tamil militant groups. But the Tamil Tigers, after an initial acceptance, resumed the guerrilla war and the accord collapsed. India sent more soldiers to put down the rebellion and at one point more than 70,000 troops were deployed in the northeast. The Tamil Tigers started their own peace talks with the Sri Lankan government in May 1989, and a month later President Ranasinghe Premadasa asked India to withdraw all troops by July 27, 1989, the second anniversary of the India-Sri Lanka accord. After bitter disagreements and a prolonged diplomatic deadlock, the two countries agreed in January on the latest pullout deadline of March 31. The withdrawal had sparked fears of fighting between the Tamil Tigers and a former rebel group, the Eelam People's Revolutionary Liberation Front, which gave up arms in 1987 to join mainstream politics. The front was elected to head the Northeastern Provincial Council in November 1988. A prominent Tiger leader, Stanley Dominic, said Tuesday there will be no factional fighting. ``The Indians have taken their boot-lickers, the EPRLF, with them. So we do not have to fight them,'' Dominic, commander of the northern Jaffna area, said in an interview in the town. There have been reports that EPRLF members were fleeing to India fearing reprisal killings by the Tamil Tigers. Vartharajah Perumal, the Northeastern Provincial Council chief minister, also was reported to have fled to India on Sunday. Trincomalee residents said Perumal and his family left aboard an Indian air force plane. Residents in Jaffna said Indian troops were leaving every day. Indian officials have refused to say how many troops remain in Sri Lanka. Tamil militants began fighting for a separate homeland in 1983, alleging discrimination by the majority Sinhalese in jobs, education and the use of Sinhala language. About 18 percent of Sri Lanka's 16 million people are Tamils, most of whom live in the northern and eastern regions. Sinhalese make up 75 percent of the population. At least 11,000 people, including 1,100 Indian soldiers, have been killed in the Tamil rebellion. Also, at least 6,000 more people have been killed in a left-wing Sinhalese extremist campaign. The movement, which centered in the southern and central districts, was launched in 1987 to protest the peace accord and the presence of Indian troops in Sri Lanka.

DOC.HEAD: Bullets Hit Bus, Greyhound to Meet Union
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with bus fire in Fresno, quote from union official, ADD that driver in Chicago incident wasn't hurt; picks up 5th graf, `Greyhound's executive...'
DOC.TEXT: A sniper opened fire Tuesday on a moving Greyhound bus in Chicago, marking the seventh bus-shooting incident nationwide since drivers went on strike, officials said. Neither the 13 passengers nor the driver were injured. In Fresno, Calif., a Greyhound-owned Trailways bus parked in a storage yard was set on fire, police said. Someone entered the unlocked bus Monday night and used a road flare to torch the interior. No injuries were reported, and authorities did not know if the fire was strike related. In another development, Dallas-based Greyhound Lines Inc. said it would resume taks with union leaders on Saturday in Phoenix at the request of federal mediators. ``There's no point in our speculating what may happen,'' said Greyhound spokesman George Gravley said. ``We are going back to the bargaining table and that speaks for itself.'' Gravley said he did not know if the Phoenix-based union had a new proposal and was unsure if the company would modify its stance. ``We are delighted that the company is returning to the table,'' said union spokesman Jeffrey Nelson. ``We sincerely hope that they will negotiate in good faith.'' Greyhound's executive vice president and chief labor negotiator, P. Anthony Lannie, will still meet in Washington on Wednesday with Bernard DeLury, head of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, Gravley said. DeLury met with union officials Monday. The strike began March 2 when 6,300 drivers and about 3,000 office and maintenance workers walked off the job in a dispute over wages and job security. Ohio Gov. Richard Celeste's office said Greyhound had agreed to equip company buses traveling through his state with citizens-band radios and provide route lists to the State Highway Patrol to help ensure public safety. Celeste recommended both actions last week. In the Chicago shooting, two bullets hit the bus's front end, one hit the door and one went through a window and ``just missed a fellow's head by a couple inches,'' said Master Sgt. John Meduga of the Illinois State Police. ``When a shot came through the glass, everybody started to scream,'' Meduga said. Passengers were transferred to another bus bound for Memphis, Tenn., after the 1:15 a.m. CST shooting, officials said. A company official indicated the shooting could be strike-related, but a union leader said he would never believe one of his members could be involved. Gravley said the shooting was the seventh since the drivers' strike began. He said he had no evidence to connect the latest shooting to the strike, but added, ``We don't have buses shot at when we're not negotiating a contract.'' William Pearsall, vice president of the Amalgamated Transit Union's Local 1303, which represents the Chicago area, said he did not believe the union was involved. ``I will never believe any union member that's on strike is doing this,'' Pearsall said. ``I would turn in anybody I knew who was shooting those buses. My argument with Greyhound is not with the public, it's the working conditions.'' The strike has been marked by scattered violence, including a striker crushed to death by a bus operated by a replacement driver in Redding, Calif. Gravley said the shooting was the third in Chicago since the walkout began. Two occurred on the first day of the strike, with a bus and a terminal the targets. Since then, there have also been shootings in Ohio, Arizona, Florida and Connecticut. Greyhound spokeswoman Liz Hale said a $25,000 reward remained in effect for information on a sniper who shot a bus in Jacksonville, Fla., injuring eight passengers with shrapnel and other debris. Greyhound, which serves 9,600 U.S. communities, is operating with replacement drivers and breakaway union members. Greyhound has said it cannot afford more than the $63 million, three-year pact already turned down by more than 90 percent of union members. But in previous negotiations, the company says it agreed to drop incentive pay and to ban subcontracting or franchising of routes. It valued the union's last offer at $207 million, although the union says it would cost much less.

DOC.HEAD: President Pumps Petrol At Dave's Sunoco
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS antepenultimate graf to give $1.88 price on energy-equivalent basis
DOC.TEXT: The White House limousine pulled up to a gleaming service station Tuesday and out popped President Bush to pump a little methanol fuel and pitch his clean air program. Bush, surrounded by auto and oil executives, helped inaugurate the new methanol fuel pump at Dave's Sunoco. Dave's boasts it is the first commercial gasoline station outside California to sell the cleaner-burning fuel, a mix of 85 percent methanol and 15 percent unleaded gasoline. Bush, as part of his plan to clean America's air, originally proposed requiring use of alternative fuels in 1 million vehicles by 1997 in the nine cities with the worst pollution. In a compromise with Senate leaders, he recently backed away from that requirement, opting instead for allowing cars to use a variety of fuels, not specifically non-gasoline type fuels. Environmentalists charge that compromise weakened the clean air package; the White House disagrees. While Bush spoke, demonstrators a block away carried placards spelling out ``CLEAN AIR HYPOCRISY.'' Bush defended his compromise, saying, ``Nobody ever does it exactly the way I want it done. But what we have is a sound, strong environmentally secure compromise.'' ``We're never going to placate those on the extreme side of the equation that want to do nothing or want to just shut down this country and throw every American who's got a job out of work,'' said Bush. Only specially equipped cars can burn the methanol fuel. The White House had one at the ready in the form of a commodious Ford Crown Victoria normally used to chauffeur W. Henson Moore to work as deputy secretary of the Energy Department. Bush, after pumping the fuel into Henson's car with an assist from station owner David Robinson, turned the key in the ignition, then listened to the Sun Oil Co. Chairman Robert McClements and Ford Motor Co. Chairman Harold Poling explain how the alternative fuel worked. A chart indicated that the methanol mix cuts smog-causing hydrocarbons and nitrous oxides in half. Poling said ``flexible fuel vehicles'' such as the Crown Victoria can burn methanol, ethanol, gasoline or any mix. The president's picture-taking session at the gas station coincided with an announcement by Ford and a Sun Oil subsidiary of a joint testing program to study use of methanol fuel outside the mild climate of California. Ford will provide a fleet of 30 mid- and full-size cars and full-size vans to be powered by a mixture of 85 percent methanol and 15 percent gasoline, called M85, provided by Sun Refining and Marketing Co. Bush said cleaner-burning fuels ``can help to reduce urban smog and toxic air emissions'' and still ``reduce the regulatory burden'' on small businesses. ``The availability of methanol in a metropolitan area like Washington is an important step toward the widespread use of clean fuels,'' he said. Environmental Protection Agency Administrator William Reilly said the compromise ``is a better deal for the environment'' because it will lead to less overall auto pollution in the nine cities. Robinson, 56, said he is ``very high'' on his new offering, which will sell for $1.07 a gallon at Dave's Sunoco, a penny less than regular and two cents more than his cheapest fuel. Methanol contains less energy per gallon than gasoline, and the $1.07 price works out to about the equivalent of $1.88 for the same energy contained in a gallon of gasoline. Its advantage? ``Clean air, very clean air,'' the station owner said.

DOC.HEAD: Cunningham Dance Company Opens
DOC.NOTE: Eds: No PMs Planned
DOC.TEXT: You can tell the dancers in ``August Pace'' because there's a scorecard in the program and each dancer has a number on the back of his or her running suit. The local premiere of ``August Pace,'' which consists mainly of duets, opened the March 13 through 25 season of the Merce Cunningham Dance Company at the City Center on Tuesday night. Cunningham used new collaborators on ``August Pace.'' The music, titled ``Peace Talks,'' is by Michael Pugliese, who has been a musician with the company since 1985. He often performs at contemporary music festivals. He and four musicians made pops, bongo drum and Oriental stringed instrument sounds, heard from speakers at the back of the City Center. Sometimes, when music was the fastest and most excitable, Cunningham slowed down the dancers and played against the music's mood. Afrika, a 24-year-old Soviet painter, did decor and costumes. ``August Pace'' isn't striving for thrills; its organization pushes the boundaries of ways bodies can stretch while dancing. It's a hypnotic dance, partly because of the non-melodic music, but there are definite changes of mood. In the first duet, Victoria Finlayson lifts one leg and bends as far to her side and back as she can while Robert Swinston, at a distance from her, moves in unrelated patterns. Carol Teitelbaum stretches in fascinatingly athletic, angular ways. Kimberly Bartosik and Chris Komar dart quickly. Several make big jumps around the stage. Helen Barrow and Robert Wood exhibit solemn and serious body language as they reach and stretch. Patricia Lent trustingly falls forward and Alan Good catches her. All dancers looked inspired. The work was commissioned by Cal Performances-University of California at Berkeley and the Cunningham Dance Foundation. Its first performance was last September in Berkeley. Also danced during the evening were ``Fabrications,'' which had its premiere in Minneapolis in 1987, and ``Cargo X,'' first danced in Austin, Texas, in 1989. Cunningham danced in ``Fabrications.'' There will be two more premieres here. After the season, the company will perform April 14 to 16 in Amsterdam and from April 19 through May 2 in Italy, in Cremona, Modena, Bari, Reggio Emilia and Ferrara. In June, the company will dance in Bobigny, France; the Canary Islands; Florence, Italy, and Seville, Spain.

DOC.HEAD: Five Children Killed in Apartment; Officials Search for Cause
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with chief saying firefighters did not hear children screaming, color, quotes from mother, Robinson saying smoke detector didn't go off. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: An apartment fire killed five children Tuesday, and neighbors accused police of stopping civilians from attempting to rescue them even though one youngster was seen screaming at an upstairs window. ``The whole neighborhood is upset,'' said Christine Lashore, a resident of the Sommerset Circle low-income housing complex. ``The police should've let them try. I would've tried. I would've died if I had to, to save my kids.'' Police Chief Wayne Romeis defended his officers' actions. ``People don't have any idea how intense it gets. I think the response time was appropriate and the actions were appropriate,'' he said. ``If those people would have gone in there, there probably would have been more victims.'' Romeis said at a news conference that authorities received no reports of screaming children from the first officers and firefighters on the scene. ``I would bet you those kids were dead before we even got there,'' Romeis said. The five brothers and sisters, ranging in age from 5 months to 9 years, were alone in the townhouse and were found in two second-story bedrooms, officials said. The blaze started in the first-floor kitchen, Fire Chief Keith Tveit said. The fire was in an end apartment of six two-story units in the government-subsidized housing complex, which police said was often a hang-out for people who didn't live in the complex. The fire didn't spread to other apartments. Witnesses who gathered on the front lawn while firefighters attempted to rescue the children said they could see the oldest boy pounding on a bedroom window. ``That little boy was standing in the window. He was burning and he was yelling, `Help me, help me,''' said neighbor Angela Briggs. Children also screamed from the top of a stairway, said Dessie Cloak, who lives in an adjacent apartment. ``They were all at the top of the stairs hollering, `Here I am Mommy, here I am, Mommy,''' she said. The victims' mother, Cheryl Robinson, told reporters she put the children to bed about 9:30 p.m. Monday, went to sleep on a couch and awoke to flames in the kitchen. She said the last time she saw her oldest son, he was standing at the top of the staircase yelling for help. A police officer who spotted the fire when he drove past the building about 2:30 a.m. and at least two other men tried to rescue the children but were stopped by flames and heavy smoke, authorities said. ``There were a couple the officers had to physically restrain from going in,'' said Romeis. ``I believe one resident had already tried and he was driven back.'' Town records showed smoke alarms in the complex were working during a Feb. 8 inspection. But fire department Lt. Fred Erickson said reports from firefighters at the scene indicated the smoke detectors weren't sounding during the blaze. Ms. Robinson said she had a smoke alarm, but it did not go off until after she left the burning apartment. Lysundra Alawiye, a friend of the family, said the victims were children of Cheryl Robinson, 28. Romeis said Ms. Robinson refused to talk to officers Tuesday. Tveit identified the victims as Derek Robinson, 9; Kenneth Jones, 5; Ebony Jones, 2; Cynthia Jones, 1; and Mark Robinson, 5 months.

DOC.HEAD: Heat Wave Continues in East, Snowstorm in Denver
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout to move up reports on tornadoes, with 1 dead, 15 hurt; record high temperatures in Chicago, Raleigh, wind damage in Illinois; no pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY21
DOC.TEXT: Record high temperatures in the 70s and 80s made Tuesday feel like a day in June across much of the East, drawing winter-weary people outside to sidewalk cafes and lunch-time strolls and boosting sales of outdoor toys. ``That's the end of winter,'' said Danko Orbanich, sitting on the steps of St. Patrick's Cathedral in New York City. Not necessarily. A storm hit Colorado and Wyoming with enough snow Tuesday to snarl traffic and cut air traffic in half. The heat generated tornadoes in Kansas, Nebraska and Oklahoma that killed a 6-year-old boy, injured 15 other people, damaged scores of homes and derailed a 24-car freight train in Nebraska. Thunderstorms broke out across Illinois and the southern Plains ``This is just a preview of spring,'' David Koehler, a National Weather Service meteorologist in Ann Arbor, Mich. ``There's still a possibility we can get some snow before the end of winter, but if we do, it won't stay around long.'' Temperatures hit record or record-tying highs in Connecticut, Delaware, Georgia, Illinois, Indiana, Maryland, Massachusetts, Michigan, Minnesota, New Hampshire, New Jersey, New York, North Carolina, Ohio, Pennsylvania, Rhode Island and the District of Columbia. Most record high temperatures are reported in the heat of the afternoon, but Grand Rapids, Mich., started out the day with a record-tying 68 degrees at midnight. It later reached 72. Record reports from the weather service included 63 degrees at Rochester, Minn.; 72 at Chicago and Cleveland; 78 at Pittsburgh; 88 at Raleigh; 84 at Philadelphia; 85 at New York City; 86 at Newark, N.J.; 86 at Washington, D.C., and 69 at Concord, N.H. New York's reading was 38 degrees above normal, 14 degrees above the record for the date set in 1929. It also was the city's warmest day since Sept. 11, when the high was 91, and the earliest that the temperature has reached 80 degrees in Central Park since record keeping started in 1869. Just a week ago, the city had temperatures in the low 30s. ``It's wonderful, it's great. Only problem is that if it gets cold again everything that's blooming now is going to die,'' said mounted Baltimore policeman David Eastman, 44. The unseasonable heat wave was great for anyone whose business had anything to do with the outdoors, like Eddie Morrocco, whose Morrocco's Italian Restaurant in downtown Washington, D.C., opened up its outdoor tables. On Sunday, Morrocco said, they had no business outside. ``I've been doing outside business for at least 30 years and we've never been able to open (outside) in March. Never,'' Morrocco said. Merchants in South Carolina reported increased sales of Frisbees, volleyball sets, tennis supplies and baseball and softball equipment. ``The way the weather has been lately we've been selling more walking shoes than anything else,'' said Kirk Hackett, assistant manager of a shoe store in Fort Mill. The warm weather had people calling for service on their air conditioning or to get replacement air conditioners in North Carolina. ``We're swamped,'' said Ben Crabtree, in charge of the service department at a heating and air conditioning company in Knightdale, outside Raleigh. But it wasn't good business weather for everybody. ``The heating oil business is a dead soldier. It's deader than George Washington,'' said Dick Jones, warehouse manager at an oil company in Raleigh. And some outdoor activities also suffered. Lenny and Robin Wayne, tourists from Los Angeles visiting New York City, took a few spins around the Rockefeller Center ice skating rink, but left early. ``It's too hot to ice skate,'' Wayne said. At least six tornadoes veered through Kansas and one made a direct hit on Hesston, Kan., a town of 3,000 people. The tornado killed a boy, wrecked nearly half the town and sent 13 people to the hospital, said Newton Medical Center spokeswoman Chris McKellip. Most had scratches, cuts and bruises. At least 10 homes were damaged near Topeka, Kan., and power lines were down in other parts of Shawnee and Jefferson counties. ``There were at least two homes that were a total loss and a number with varying degrees of damage, such as roof damage and glass breakage,'' said Ken Burgett, director of emergency preparedness in Shawnee County, Kan. One-third of Lawrence, Neb., a village of 350 people was damaged by a twister. There were two minor injuries, the weather service reported. The hot air spawned thunderstorms that rained golfball-size hail on northwestern Illinois, generated winds that blew down power lines and a barn at Malta, and posed threats of new flooding in soggy Vermilion County, where 55,000 residents remained without water service because flooding put water pumps out of action. Some of the 200 people forced from their homes because of flooding along the North Fork River north of Danville returned home to check damage. An estimated 19 mobile homes and cabins along the river were destroyed. In the West, 5 inches of wet snow had fallen by midday at Cheyenne, Wyo., just a week after a storm shut down much of southeastern Wyoming. Denver's Stapleton International Airport had 3 inches by morning and 13 inches had fallen at Wolf Creek Pass in southwestern Colorado. Rush-hour traffic was slowed to a crawl, and Stapleton cut its departures by more than half because of winds and poor visibility. On the Plains, thunderstorms battered parts of Kansas, Oklahoma and Texas with rain and wind.

DOC.HEAD: Television Photographer Shot While Shooting Storm Video
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with sheriff saying shooting was random violence, four suspects arrested, details on shooting, chase; no pickup.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Kansas Tornado
DOC.TEXT: A television cameraman photographing severe weather was shot and critically wounded Tuesday night in apparently random violence, authorities said. Four people were arrested. Bill Merickel, a photographer for Oklahoma station KWTV-TV, was in critical condition at Lindsay Hospital following the 7:05 p.m. shooting, said hospital administrator Rhonda Smith. KWTV spokesman Rich Buchanan said Merickel and reporter Dave Balute had apparently stumbled on a drug deal, but McClain County Sherff Dwayne Anderson later said that wasn't the case. ``There is no reason for the shooting that I can think of,'' said Anderson. ``A random shooting is what it looks like to me.'' Anderson said the shooting occurred as Merickel and Balute were out filming stormy weather. They had stopped at a highway intersection when a car pulled up across from them, and two shots were fired from the vehicle, the sheriff said. One shot penetrated the journalists' van and hit Merickel, who was driving, in the chest, Anderson said. Balute was not hurt. The suspects' car left the scene, and was pursued by a second KWTV car, which contacted police by radio, the sheriff said. The four suspects were arrested after a short chase by Lindsay police, and were taken to the McClain County Jail, Anderson said. Their identities were not immediately available. Lindsay is about 30 miles south of Oklahoma City.

A briefing paper for Energy Secretary James Watkins was inadvertently leaked and lists various problems involving radiation contamination and reactor safety at weapons plants around the nation. The daily briefing for Monday's operations was obtained by The Associated Press after it was sent by mistake to governors' offices by fax machine. The two-page summary contains reports by Department of Energy operations to Watkins that were assembled by his office and were being sent back to the DOE offices. The problems at the government's nuclear complex included ``widespread low-level contamination'' at a tank farm at Hanford, Wash.; the discovery of three live wires at a Savannah River reactor building that posed ``imminent danger,'' and an effort to halt the activities of anti-nuclear protesters.

Testing of an experimental vaccine on California AIDS patients will be expanded and extended to individuals who are infected with the AIDS virus but have not developed symptoms of the disease. The Food and Drug Administration on Monday granted permission for further testing of the vaccine developed by Dr. Jonas Salk. The vaccine, which uses an inactivated virus, is being tested as a treatment for AIDS rather than as an agent to prevent someone from acquiring the fatal disease, which destroys the body's ability to fight infection. Researchers are trying to find out whether the inactivated virus will cause the body to produce specific cells, called T cells, that destroy other cells infected with the human immunodeficiency virus, or HIV.

Three Democrats waged a bare-fisted struggle for the gubernatorial nomination in today's primary, while a millionaire oilman making his first run for office was expected to win the GOP nomination outright. The final pre-election poll showed former Gov. Mark White, Attorney General Jim Mattox and Treasurer Ann Richards in a dead heat for the Democratic nomination, with Clayton Williams gaining more than half the Republican vote. The secretary of state's office predicted a turnout of 2.1 million to 2.6 million of the 8.3 million eligible voters, who can vote in either primary. Each party's choice needs more than 50 percent of the vote to avoid a runoff. Williams said if he wins outright and the Democrats are forced into a runoff April 10, he will relax and ``have some fun watching each of the Democrats murdering on each other.''

This is the city that says it knows how, the one where tourists love to leave their hearts. But while most of the physical damage from the Oct. 17 earthquake has been repaired, community leaders are not sure how to fix the damage done to San Francisco's reputation for warm if eccentric hospitality. From cable cars to Chinatown, Fisherman's Wharf hotels to theaters and museums, commercial and cultural business has been reported way down since the quake. That may be changing, thanks to time and fading memories, promotions, ad campaigns and a realization by the business community that it must also deal with skyrocketing air fares, recession fears and increasing competition. ``The earthquake is a very good excuse for everything,'' said John Marks, president of the San Francisco Convention and Visitors' Bureau. ``But there are many other factors that are causing the momentary bump'' in tourism. Many tourist-oriented cities across the country are experiencing similar sluggishness, he said.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Adds Barry brief to package.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush lifted trade sanctions against Nicaragua on Tuesday and asked Congress to swiftly approve a $300 million down payment for rebuilding the nation's ravaged economy and speeding a transition to democracy. He said the money would come from the Pentagon. Rushing to shore up the incoming government of President-elect Violeta Chamorro, Bush also pledged to seek an additional $200 million in fiscal 1991 which begins Oct. 1. Bush coupled the request for Nicaragua with a challenge to Congress to approve a stalled aid package of $500 million for Panama, where the United States installed a new government after deposing Manuel Antonio Noriega last December. Bush also is seeking $70 million in refugee assistance in Panama. The president urged Congress to complete work by April 5 on money for both countries. All the funds would be diverted from the Pentagon's budget, perhaps the first real ``peace dividend'' from the receding Cold War.

CARE, the relief group renowned for parachuting food to the starving, is now packaging a more complex type of Third World aid: seed money to start businesses and debt-for-equity securities swaps. The New York-based non-profit organization has formed a subsidiary to assist debt-ridden developing countries in devising innovative ways to reduce dependence on foreign loans. It also seeks to help creditors recover some of the money they thought they'd never see again. CARE's Small Business Assistance Corp. invests in small and medium-size businesses, from fruit canners in Honduras to shrimp farmers in the Philippines, when invited to do so by the host country. It also is exploring business ventures in countries undergoing profound political change, including Poland and Nicaragua. Philanthropy experts said the organization is the first investment banking venture formed by an international relief group to help developing countries become more self-reliant.

The government said Tuesday that the deficit in the broadest measure of U.S. trade sank to a five-year low last year, but the $105.9 billion imbalance still pushed the country deeper into the hole as the world's largest debtor nation. America's current account balance narrowed by 16 percent over a $126.6 billion deficit in 1988, reflecting growth in exports, higher overseas earnings of American businesses and increased spending by visiting foreign tourists, according to the Commerce Department. The year ended on a positive note as the October-December trade deficit declined to $20.57 billion, down 10.2 percent from its third quarter level. It was the smallest quarterly imbalance in almost six years. But private economists were unimpressed, contending that even with the improvement the current account deficit remained above $100 billion for the sixth consecutive year as the United States plunged further into hock to the rest of the world.

Mayor Marion Barry returned to the nation's capital Tuesday after six weeks of substance abuse treatment, declaring ``I feel good about myself'' and saying he has no plans to resign. Barry, who appeared relaxed and fit, said he was addicted to alcohol and two prescription drugs, Valium and Xanax. He didn't mention the federal cocaine possession and perjury charges he faces. He reacted with a broad smile to supporters' chants of ``Four more years'' in the municipal building where he delivered his remarks but declined to say whether he will seek a fourth four-year term in November. ``My political organization is still intact, not withstanding some defections'' Barry said. ``We will announce some plans in the very near future.''

DOC.HEAD: Rapping Hits and Controversy
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Skyywalker is cq throughout
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto MH3 of March 3.
DOC.TEXT: Lyrics from the notorious 2 Live Crew album ``As Nasty As They Wanna Be'' tell the story: ``When they say 2 Live ``your mama gets worried. ``When they speak of us ``the negatives get mentioned.'' Negatives abound with the popular rap group, whose sexually explicit and misogynist songs have inflamed parents, church groups and legislators. Some stores refuse to stock the album, or carry only a sanitized version _ ``As Clean As They Wanna Be.'' It contains eight fewer songs than the other album, and only one of them is a version of a song from the unexpurgated LP _ the hit ``Me So Horny.'' And a committee in the Florida state legislature is considering a bill that would require retailers to label records deemed to have so-called offensive material, and restrict sale to those over 18. About a dozen other states are considering similar measures. Luther Campbell, a member of 2 Live Crew as well as the group's producer and owner and president of its record label, Luke Skyywalker Records, resents what he sees as attempts to censor his work by keeping it out of the record stores. ``You don't have to buy it,'' he said. ``You just walk right on by. It's sad to see walls coming down, letting people out of jail in South Africa, and we're starting to tell people what they can listen to and look at. If they stop that, I mean, what's next? This is America.'' However, Campbell, who calls himself Luke Skyywalker in the rap group, said the company would offer retailers a sticker to warn about language and offer parental discretion. There are 18 dirty, sassy tunes on ``As Nasty As They Wanna Be.'' As lewd and disrespectful of women as many of the lyrics are, production values are equally high. The sound is crisp and clear, the sampling and scratching expert. ``We made our own style up,'' Campbell said. ``It is raunchy, but it's really funny. ... It's no different than what Andrew `Dice' Clay does, no different from Redd Foxx, Eddie Murphy.'' The three stand-up comics are known for their off-color and sometimes offensive material. In 1988, Tommy Hammond, a record store owner in Alexander City, Ala., was convicted of violating the city's obscenity ordinance for selling an earlier 2 Live Crew effort, ``Move Somethin'.'' The conviction was overturned on appeal Feb. 22. Three days later, a Broward County judge ruled ``As Nasty As They Wanna Be'' is probably obscene, but would have to consider a specific case involving the LP to determine if it is obscene according to state laws. The platinum double-album ``Nasty'' attracted the attention of a judge in Lee County, Fla., who found probable cause to consider the lyrics obscene. The album was pulled from store shelves. Dade State Attorney Janet Reno also is checking to see if minors are being allowed to buy the album. She was the subject of a record by female rappers Anquette _ also on the Miami-based Luke Skyywalker label _ praising her office's efficiency in obtaining child support payments from reluctant fathers. ``They don't recognize us for the clean stuff that we do,'' said Campbell, who doesn't smoke or drink. Though the Crew has a well-deserved reputation for raunch, the group is not without concern for its fans. Since 1988, they have endorsed Homeboy brand condoms _ an arrangement they initiated, according to Skyywalker spokeswoman Debbie Bennett. ``They figured since they were talking about sex so much they should talk about safe sex,'' she said. While some are up in arms about the possible effect 2 Live Crew's work may have on the young, Campbell is proud of his efforts as an entrepreneur and the example he sets for black youngsters. ``A lot of black kids know of me and a lot of them want to be like me,'' he said. ``They see some light down the tunnel. Very seldom do they see the business blacks because those people aren't widely known.'' The Miami-born Campbell, 29, went from spinning records at high school dances as a youngster to a corner office with a view of Biscayne Bay, and a staff of 25. He established Luke Skyywalker Records in 1985 after not getting paid for an earlier record. Several rappers record for Skyywalker, including Professor Griff of Public Enemy. Campbell also owns the Skyyline label, which records a few rhythm and blues artists. ``It's 50-50,'' he said of his dual life as record company executive and rap star. ``I work at night as an artist and in the day time I'm a businessman.'' Today, he still seems a bit awed by his own success. ``Knowing the business as I know it now and seeing as many people fail _ but I guess that's how I do a lot of things,'' he said. ``I just decide to do them.''

DOC.HEAD: CBS' ``Peanuts'' Special on Leukemia
DOC.TEXT: ``Are you going to die?'' asks Charlie Brown when Janice, his little friend in the hospital bed, says she has leukemia. ``Good grief, Charlie Brown!'' cries Linus. ``What kind of question is that?'' A blunt one, asked in a different kind of ``Peanuts'' special that CBS is showing Friday night. Rest assured, though, that the ending is upbeat, in keeping with medical fact and the nature of Charles M. Schulz. Schulz, who has drawn the wise and whimsical characters of his ``Peanuts'' cartoon strip since 1950 and did his first TV special in 1965, hadn't thought of making his next one about a child who develops leukemia. What became Friday's ``Why, Charlie Brown, Why?'' began, he says, with an idea from Sylvia Cook, a nurse in California who works with young cancer patients at Stanford Children's Hospital. She proposed a five-minute film for them in which cancer and its treatment were explained by the ``Peanuts'' gang. He recalls that he pointed out a few problems, including that animation is expensive. That didn't stop Cook, Schulz says. ``Gradually, her idea changed, and she finally decided that it'd be more important if we could do a film that would show the people around the person who was ill just what is going on,'' he says. Wth the aid of the American Cancer Society, that's ultimately what happened. It helped that Schulz came to believe the film would make a good ``Peanuts'' special for TV and shouldn't be limited to hospital showings. The gentle lessons of Friday's show include the early symptoms of leukemia and what can be expected in treatment of the disease. A key part of the program _ the survival rate of children stricken with leukemia _ is only obliquely noted, mainly because a mass of statistics would be as out of place in a ``Peanuts'' special as a visit from The Simpsons. Little Janice, in chemotherapy treatment that she notes will cause her temporary hair loss, quotes her doctors as saying she should get well. The survival rate for children is high, according to ACS spokesman David Lehmann. He says the society estimates 2,500 children will be stricken with leukemia this year, 1,900 of them with its acute form. However, thanks to advances in treatment, 71 percent are expected to survive, he says. Schulz, who worked with the society in preparing Friday's special, downplays his role in it. ``I didn't go into making this thing because I wanted to teach the world all about this,'' he says. ``This was the idea of the cancer people. It was their project. My only job was to make it palatable, to give it some kind of story and try to tell the things they wanted told, yet make it so that people wouldn't turn it off.'' Schulz, 67, who lives in Santa Rosa, Calif., about an hour's drive north of San Francisco, estimates Friday's is his 25th TV special since ``A Charlie Brown Christmas.'' He still draws the seven-day-a-week ``Peanuts'' strip that by CBS' estimate appears in more than 2,200 newspapers worldwide. He reckons he's drawn 15,000 of the strips since he began them 40 years ago. More than a few cartoonist have groused that the constant pressure of a daily strip at times has put them up against the wall, if not under it. No such gripes are heard from Schulz. ``No, quality is the only thing that worries me,'' he says. ``I don't worry about getting them done. I'm always worrying that I'll just end up doing the same things over and over. ``Just to try to keep the thing alive, and be trying new things, that's the hard part. Just getting it done is nothing. I think cartoonists who say it's hard to keep up the schedule are just lazy, that's all.''

Elsewhere in television ... IT`S NOT EASY BEING GREEN: Cable TV's Nick at Nite has a special St. Patrick's Day treat afoot Saturday night. It will show four episodes of ``My Three Sons'' _ with each episode tinted green. The idea is to celebrate St. Patrick's Day, a day on which many lads in New York, to the disgust of the real Irish, drink themselves into a terrible state, punch each other in the beak and also turn green.

DOC.HEAD: Farm-Machinery Industry Rebounds, Reflecting Improved Outlook for Farmers
DOC.NOTE: Eds: John Cunniff is on vacation.
DOC.TEXT: Years of plummeting land values, low grain prices and a scorching drought made tractor dealer Dick Rupiper uneasy about his chances for survival after 10 years in farm-machinery sales. But Rupiper gambled last year and moved his business. Now he is planning to expand his staff to handle steadily increasing demand. ``The drought of '88 set everybody back,'' Rupiper said. ``In 1989, we had decent crops. Farmers had a decent year and it was the first year in a long time they felt comfortable spending money. ``I think 1990 will be even better. I expect things to pick up a little more.'' Rupiper's experience parallels that of the tractor and farm-machinery industry, which is earning solid profits and hopes to increase sales this year. Last year, Rupiper was struggling to keep afloat. In Illinois, 1,500 tractor dealers have gone out of business since 1949, leaving about 400, according to figures compiled by the Illinois Retail Farm Equipment Association. ``There's just too many dealers in this area and I was worried about our survival,'' Rupiper said. So he liquidated his inventory _ which included equipment from four smaller manufacturers _ closed the farm dealership he owned in Henry and bought a Deere & Co. dealership across the Illinois River in this town of 2,100, about 25 miles north of Peoria. Business prospects are looking up. ``We're thinking about hiring a couple people to help out in the shop,'' Rupiper said. ``I expect things to continue to improve.'' He also expects farmers to show increasing concern about soil conservation and environmental protection. But the process of changing to meet those concerns will be slow and expensive. No-till farming, for example, a soil-conservation method that involves shallow plowing and leaves more crop residue in fields _ requires an investment in costly new tilling, planting and mulching equipment. Farmers must be convinced they'll still get maximum yields and will be able to pass along the higher equipment costs to consumers before they'll invest, Rupiper said. Moline-based Deere, the nation's leading producer of tractors and farm machinery, is promoting a line of minimum-tillage equipment. But the traditional moldboard plow is far from obsolete, and implements designed for no-till farming remain a small part of Deere's product line. ``Conservation in farming is here to stay,'' says Deere spokesman Robert Combs. ``But we're not even close to replacing the tractor or combine.'' The evolution to more conservation-minded, ecologically aware farming is not expected to hurt sales of farming equipment in 1990. The U.S. Department of Commerce says higher crop prices, improved land values and reduced farm debt will combine with the need to replace aging equipment for a 6 percent increase in sales this year. A 7 percent sales increase was predicted by both the Farm and Industrial Equipment Institute in Chicago, an industry-supported think tank, and Stark's Off-Highway Ledger, a Chicago-based newsletter that analyzes the industry. Combs said Deere projects solid sales increases, noting production schedules are 5 percent higher than last year. Deere recorded $380 million in profits in 1989, its second consecutive record-breaking year. Steve Koep, marketing director for Case IH of Racine, Wis., said his company's 1989 rebound should continue into the '90s. Koep said Case reported earnings of $288 million in 1989, its first profit since 1981, when the company earned $70 million. Factors pointing to higher sales include pent-up demand among farmers who kept old equipment during the farm crisis of the 1980s rather than risk going deeper in debt to buy tractors, which average $60,000, or combines, which average $110,000. ``We see a generally improving economic picture for farmers across the board,'' said Emmett Barker, president of the Farm and Industrial Equipment Institute. End Adv PM Wed March 14

DOC.HEAD: A Symphony of Rage and Remembrance
LaserPhoto planned
DOC.TEXT: Composer John Corigliano planned to use his Chicago Symphony Orchestra commission to write a virtuoso piece showcasing its musicians. But when his best friend was diagnosed with AIDS, he found new inspiration. Corigliano's tragic First Symphony, incorporating remembrances of musicians who have died from disease brought on by AIDS, will have its world premiere Thursday at the Chicago Symphony, with Daniel Barenboim conducting. ``The difference between the Concerto for Orchestra I was going to write and the symphony I did write is largely a question of emotional depth and content,'' Corigliano said in a recent telephone interview from his home in Carmel, N.Y. ``The deaths of friends _ the loss, the frustration and anger _ inspired me to write it ``I just turned 52, and my mother lives in a retirement community. ... To me, it's a major upset in the natural order that my friends should be dying off faster than hers. ``It took me two years to put the symphony together, and I wrote the end of it first,'' he said. ``I had to find where I was going _ find peace, perhaps _ before I could describe the journey.'' Barenboim, who is succeeding Sir Georg Solti as music director of the Chicago Symphony, praised Corigliano's work. ``I'm very pleased to be doing the world premiere of a substantial American piece so early in my time in Chicago,'' Barenboim said. ``It is wonderful that composers such as John Corigliano write music that is not disassociated from our society but reflects our everyday life and the problems we face as human beings.'' Chicago composer William Russo, whose jazz- and rock-influenced works often touch on social themes, cited it as probably the first AIDS symphony. ``Many other people have written works inspired by the epidemic, but no one of John's scope, musically, has done anything like this,'' he said. Central to the symphony is the image of the AIDS Quilt, which Corigliano first saw in Washington several years ago. ``I was overwhelmed,'' he said. ``It managed to combine vastness with extreme intimacy. Each of the thousands of squares was crafted individually by the loved ones of the victim.'' To create his own patchwork effect for the third movement, Corigliano gave the names of acquaintances who had died to William H. Hoffman, librettist of Corigliano's opera, ``The Ghosts of Versailles.'' Hoffman wrote ``brief poetic epitaphs'' for the symphony. ``I took the epitaphs, composed melodic fragments for each of them, discarded the words and wove the melodies together,'' the composer explained. ``They are played against one of the main themes of the movement.'' Corigliano, composer-in-residence at the Chicago Symphony since 1987, fit his main themes to several close friends from the New York musical world who died from AIDS-related diseases. ``I knew each of them for more than 25 years,'' he said. Although the music refers to real people, their full names are never given. ``Unfortunately, there is still a stigma attached to AIDS,'' Corigliano said. ``Even when people die of its complications, the obituaries often give the cause of death as something else. There's a bitter irony that that still has to be the case.'' The first movement, ``Of Rage and Remembrance,'' reflects Corigliano's distress over the death of a concet pianist friend and begins in a manner he describes as ``ferocious.'' Midway through, though, an off-stage piano plays a turn-of-the-century tango that was a favorite of the dead musician. ``The rest of the movement alternates between the tension of anger and the bittersweet nostalgia of remembering,'' Corigliano said. The second movement, ``Tarantella,'' recalls a gifted amateur musician who became an executive in the music industry, and is based on ``a jaunty little piece'' Corigliano wrote for him in 1970. ``There's savage irony and nightmare in it,'' said the composer. ``My friend was a brilliant, witty man, but he concealed the fact that he had AIDS until dementia set in just before his death. You would sit at lunch with him and realize that he was slipping off into insanity. ``In Italian folklore, the tarantella is a dance that is supposed to cure the insanity caused by the bite of the tarantula _ but in this case, it's a dance that descends into madness,'' said Corigliano, who earlier used nightmare material in his score for the 1985 movie ``Altered States.'' The third movement, ``Giulio's Song,'' takes one of its main themes from an improvised melody used by ``Giulio,'' an amateur cellist, while playing with Corigliano in 1962. The ``Giulio'' theme eventually leads to memories of his cello teacher, another AIDS victim, and then into the ``Quilt'' material for other departed friends. Eventually, the underlying rhythm is revealed as that of a funeral march. The symphony ends peacefully, Corigliano said, with repeating waves of chords from a brass choir that partly encircles the orchestra. ``To me, the sound of ocean waves conveys an image of timelessness,'' he said.
