DOC.HEAD: THE OSCARS 1990: And the Winner Is ...
The Foreign Invasion: Foreign Films Popular at Oscars
DOC.TEXT: Sir David Lean can only laugh at how calmly Hollywood is taking this year's ``foreign invasion'' of the Academy Awards: ``My Left Foot'' from Ireland, five nominations including best picture; Camille Claudel'' from France, two nominations including best foreign film; ``Henry V'' from England, three nominations including best director. Yet, it's business as usual at the Oscars. There are, of course, the usual arguments over who made it and who didn't, but nothing like the press conference called by Samuel Goldwyn in 1946, when Lean's ``Brief Encounter'' and Laurence Olivier's ``Henry V'' were among several foreign films enjoying critical and commercial success. ``Hollywood is facing a challenge,'' said Goldwyn, producer of such films as ``Wuthering Heights'' and ``The Little Foxes.'' ``Today it is by the British, tomorrow it may be the French or the Italians or the Russians. To maintain it's place, Hollywood must set aside the old formulas. It must find honest stories, stories with something important to say, stories that reflect these disturbing times in which we live.'' Lean was amazed by Goldwyn's warning because he was sure ``Brief Encounter'' would flop. After all, the film had closed down after three days in one Italian city because, the British filmmaker had heard, leading man Trevor Howard was too ugly. So when ``Brief Encounter'' was previewed at a tiny screening room in Manhattan, Lean did his best to slip in and out unnoticed. It didn't work. ``I waited until the lights went out and snuck in the back because I just wanted to see what sort of print would be there,'' Lean said in a recent phone interview from Los Angeles, where he received the American Film Institute's annual Life Achievement Award. ``When the lights went up, I sneaked out. I got a few steps down the passage, and a voice said, `Hi, excuse me.' It was the critic from Time. `He said, `Tell me, did you direct that?' And I said, `You're right, I did,' thinking he was going to say God knows what. He said, `Let me shake your hand, that was marvelous.' ``And that was the first time I knew I was going to get a break in America.'' ``Brief Encounter'' received three nominations (but won no Oscars) and Lean eventually felt right at home at the Academy Awards, totaling 56 nominations and 27 awards for such films as ``Great Expectations,'' ``A Passage to India,'' ``The Bridge on the River Kwai'' and ``Lawrence of Arabia.'' Since 1932 when Charles Laughton won best actor for the title role in a British production of ``The Private Life of Henry VIII,'' Oscar has had an ambivalent relationship with foreign movies. Hollywood preferred American products to win, but constantly recognized worthy foreign efforts. Foreign films, especially British, have won various prizes from cinematography (``Black Narcissus'') to best picture (``Hamlet''), from screenwriting (``The Search'') to costume design (``La Dolce Vita''). In 1956, foreign language film became a separate category. Italy's ``La Strada'' won that year. But that didn't stop the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences from nominating foreign films and filmmakers in other categories. In 1966, the French film ``A Man and a Woman'' won a screenplay Oscar and was also named best foreign film. In 1973, Sven Nykvist won the cinematography award for Sweden's ``Cries and Whispers.'' The British have dominated the Oscars on several occasions, including ``Lawrence of Arabia'' in 1962, ``Tom Jones'' in 1963, ``Chariots of Fire'' in 1981 and ``A Room With a View'' in 1986. ``The Academy Awards in some ways is the absolute tops for a moviemaker; you can't do better,'' Lean said. ``It's terrific to get and I never thought I would get one.'' Lean's favorite of his own films is ``Lawrence of Arabia,'' which was released in 1962 and earned seven Academy Awards, including best picture and director. An ``adventure of a lifetime'' is how Lean remembered the 19 months of location work for the film. ``Anybody who can go out and live in the desert for a year is a lucky man,'' he said of the title character. For the starring role, he wanted Albert Finney, one of Britain's hottest young actors at the time, but after four days of testing, Finney turned him down. Lean took a chance and cast a then unknown Peter O'Toole. ``I was desperate because I didn't have a leading man,'' Lean said. ``I went to a theater in the West End and I saw a film called `The Day They Robbed the Bank of England,' and in it was Peter playing a small part. I had never seen him before. As he came on the screen, I thought, `Wait a minute, that's a star.''' But it's not as much fun anymore, insists Lean, who has made just two films in the past 20 years: ``Ryan's Daughter'' and ``A Passage to India.'' There's too much talk about money, and ever since ``Easy Rider'' in 1969, producers have been looking for hit films that cost little to make. The director even longs for the return of bosses such as Goldwyn, tirades and all. ``Hollywood was something special,'' Lean said. ``Those chaps like Goldwyn, they were uneducated, but all of them, however tough, whatever they were, they just loved movies and sought quality. Now, it's, `How much?''' Lean spoke of a recent dinner with Billy Wilder, another Oscar-winning director and AFI honoree who has struggled to find work. They talked about the problems of being part of Hollywood history in a business that's always looking ahead. ``When you get over 80 the pressures are worse than they ever were,'' said Lean, who turns 81 on March 25, the day before the Academy Awards presentation. ``Billy's bright as a button, really entertaining and really quick. You would think by the way he's treated, he's just beginning. Anybody who makes `The Apartment' and `Some Like It Hot' should be up in the highest position.'' Fortunately, Lean said, he likes the young directors who greeted him so warmly on his recent trip. He is especially enthusiastic about Oliver Stone and predicts that Stone and other directors will eventually take control of Hollywood from the agents and lawyers. Stone recently won the Directors Guild award for his ``Born on the Fourth of July,'' which has received eight Oscar nominations including best picture. ``The filmmakers in Hollywood I think are very special. They're really keen and they're all bright and intelligent and they've got a sense of humor. They are full of enthusiasm that doesn't seem to be at all envious of others,'' Lean said. ``They just give it to you on a plate. It's very nice for an old bird to get that.''

DOC.HEAD: Syrians Soldiers Watch for Attempts To Move Hostages Out of Beirut
DOC.TEXT: Syrian soldiers guard gateways of two Shiite Moslem slum districts in south Beirut in case kidnappers try to smuggle out Terry Anderson or other Western hostages, police say. ``I am sure they are all alive,'' Sheik Mohammed Mehdi Shamseddin, spiritual head of Lebanon's Shiite community, said recently. ``That much I can safely ascertain.'' Other senior Shiite sources who claimed to know also said that the captives were alive and that most were in south Beirut. All agreed to talk about the situation only if granted anonymity. Police said Syrian troops had tightened control around the Hajjaj and Hay Madi districts. Syria has 40,000 soldiers in Lebanon under an Arab League peacekeeping mandate issued in 1976, the year after the sectarian civil war began. ``They are searching everything coming out from both neighborhoods, where most of the hostages are thought to be imprisoned _ even funeral processions and caskets,'' said a police spokesman, whose name cannot be used under standing regulations. Syrian soldiers have not tried to storm any suspected hideouts of kidnappers, apparently for fear of killing hostages. Seventeen Westerners are missing in Lebanon and believed to be hostages, including eight Americans. Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent of The Associated Press, has been held longest. He was abducted five years ago, on March 16, 1985. The captives have been moved often, in car trunks or coffins, either to escape fighting among Shiite factions or to avoid detection. French journalist Jean-Paul Kauffmann, freed in 1988, said he nearly suffocated in a box that was slung beneath a truck. Anderson, 42, was said to have been chained to a basement wall of a ruined Beirut hotel during his early days as a captive. Freed hostages have said they, too, were held in basements, or sometimes in upper-floor apartments with no access to windows. All said they heard jet planes landing and taking off, which supports the belief that most hostages are in the southern slums near Beirut's airport. Shiites claiming to be close to the kidnappers often have approached news agencies in Beirut offering to help free Anderson or Anglican Church envoy Terry Waite, in return for as much as $1 million for each hostage. None of the offers was believed to be legitimate. Waite, 50, disappeared Jan. 20, 1987, after leaving his hotel in Moslem west Beirut to negotiate for the freedom of Anderson and other Americans. President Hashemi Rafsanjani of Iran has asked pro-Iranian factions in Lebanon grouped under the umbrella of Hezbollah, or Party of God, to free the hostages. But the Shiite sources in Beirut believe Rafsanjani has little influence with the militant Hezbollah wing that controls the hostage-holders. Hezbollah militants are loyal to Ali Akbar Mohtashemi, the hard-line former interior minister of Iran, who helped found Hezbollah while he was Iran's ambassador to Syria in the early 1980s. Anderson is held by a group calling itself Islamic Jihad, or Islamic Holy War. ``Rafsanjani's hostage behests are a cry without an echo,'' said a senior Shiite source. ``Rafsanjani wants a deal with the United States to unblock Tehran's frozen assests to cope with Iran's economic crisis, which is generating anti-government public sentiment. ``Mohtashemi and other hard-line opposition leaders have a stake in maintaining the crisis so they can agitate against Rafsanjani, so no hostages are likely to be released in the near future.'' The United States holds billions of dollars in Iranian assets that were frozen after the storming of the U.S. Embassy in Tehran in 1979. Fifty-two Americans were held 444 days. Rafsanjani and other Iranian leaders have said Iran would help get the hostages in Lebanon released if the United States freed the assets. This week, Mohtashemi said some of the captives were spies and argued against freeing any of the ``mercenary U.S. hostages.'' Support for the hard-liners came March 6 when a group holding American hostages Joseph Cicippio and Edward Austin Tracy broke a seven-month silence to say no captives were about to be freed. ``There is no intention to release hostages,'' said the Revolutionary Justice Organization, which also threatened suicide attacks on U.S. interests. Shiite sources said the next hostage release might come from Islamic Jihad for the Liberation of Palestine, which holds American college teachers Robert Polhill, Alann Steen and Jesse Turner. Hussein Mousawi, a pro-Syrian activist based in the Bekaa Valley of east Lebanon, now controls the group. The sources said Mohtashemi loyalists recently removed Mousawi from the Hezbollah leadership.

DOC.HEAD: One Year Later, Nation's Worst Oil Spill Is Hidden But Not Gone
An AP Extra
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhotos
DOC.TEXT: From a helicopter, the wave-washed beach looks as if the worst oil spill in U.S. history had never touched it. Silvery sticks of driftwood poke through a deep blanket of snow, and smooth gray pebbles roll in the surf under the gaze of a bald eagle perched in a shoreside spruce. But the view doesn't impress Joe Bridgman of the Alaska Department of Environmental Conservation. Dashing out as the chopper lands, he digs into the cobble beach and quickly finds what he knew he would. ``Oil,'' he says. ``Smell it?'' The pungent odor of petroleum wafts through the air as the hole turns black with crude oil, an oozing remnant of the 10.8 million gallons spilled into Prince William Sound last March 24 by the tanker Exxon Valdez. Bridgman scoops up a shovelful of gravel, lugs it to the water's edge and dumps it in. A rainbow sheen of oil spreads across the water. ``Hundreds of gallons of oil are locked up under this beach,'' he says. ``And this isn't isolated. There are hundreds of beaches all over the sound that are still oiled, and the oil is slowly bleeding out. ``The beaches can look beautiful at the surface, but you can dig down, in this case just a few inches below the surface, and find lots of oil. Now, is that a threat or isn't it?'' A year after the wreck of the Exxon Valdez, the question clings like the oil under this Perry Island beach. Certainly, the worst is over; thousands of dead birds no longer wash up on shorelines as they did last summer. But assessing the continuing damage wrought by the nation's most extensive _ and expensive _ oil spill has just begun. As a growing slick of lawyers haggles over who is to blame, Exxon Corp. and government agencies debate how to clean up what's left and scientists track wildlife populations' first steps on the long road to recovery. Any hope of a quick solution faded last summer as oil from the Exxon Valdez spread across 1,100 miles of Alaska's wild southern coast. A cleanup army of 12,000 workers polished rocks by hand, blasted beaches with hot water and sprayed fertilizer to promote the growth of oil-eating microbes. But when Exxon suspended its $2 billion cleanup in mid-September, it had recovered only 5 percent to 9 percent of the oil spilled, state officials estimate. About 20 percent to 40 percent is believed to have evaporated. That leaves 50 percent to 75 percent of the oil in the water, on the ocean bottom or on beaches. Some was soaked up by unwilling sponges: the seabirds, eagles and sea otters whose carcasses now lie frozen in five vans in an Anchorage storage yard, awaiting their day as physical evidence in court. Workers found more than 1,000 dead otters, a sizable chunk of the spill area's total population of 15,000 to 22,000. Many of Prince William Sound's 3,000 bald eagles also suffered; at least 151 died, most poisoned by scavenging the oily remains of some of the 34,400 dead seabirds recovered. Those numbers alone make the Valdez spill the most lethal ever, but scientists say the actual death count is much higher, estimating that up to 90 percent of the seabirds caught in oil sank from sight or drifted out to sea. Exxon notes the spill did not wipe out any species and says surviving animals and birds will rebuild populations. But that may take up to 70 years for some hard-hit seabird colonies, U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service researchers say. ``We never claimed that the spill put any animal on the endangered species list, but that's missing the point,'' said Fish and Wildlife spokesman Bruce Batten. ``It's still the greatest human-caused wildlife disaster that this agency knows about.'' Oily carcasses were an obvious measure of the spill's impact, but victims also included less visible members of the ecosystem, such as young salmon and tiny intertidal creatures. Assessment studies for these populations are not finished, and even preliminary findings are hard to come by _ researchers have been told by lawyers to save their findings for court, where it seems nearly everyone involved in the spill is headed. Capt. Joseph Hazelwood, skipper of the Exxon Valdez, is on trial this month in Anchorage on charges including criminal mischief and drunken driving of his vessel, and a federal grand jury recently issued criminal indictments against Exxon, starting a case that could take years to finish. Exxon already faces more than 150 civil lawsuits. Fishermen sued because of lost seasons. Tour-boat operators sued because fewer people wanted to cruise an oiled sound. The state sued, claiming the company was negligent in responding to the spill, only to be countersued by Exxon, which claimed state officials hindered the use of chemical dispersants that could have broken up large quantities of oil early on. Information about the spill is filtered through this litigious atmosphere, making much of it suspect. Exxon distributes before-and-after pictures of cleaned beaches; Bridgman and other state officials, accusing Exxon of ``myth-making,'' eagerly make room for journalists on flights to oiled beaches. State officials cite an October survey that showed 117 miles of shoreline remained moderately or heavily oiled, with oil more than two feet deep in some spots. They say observers flying over the sound still report 15 to 20 oil sheens bleeding off beaches daily. Exxon officials, meanwhile, say their winter monitoring of 64 sites shows wind and waves have scoured away, on average, more than half the surface oil left in September, and up to 80 percent of the buried oil. ``From a layman's point of view, what's left out there is really insignificant,'' said Exxon scientist Andy Teal.
DOC.NOTE: MORE
$adv18
For Release Sunday, March 18, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: PERRY ISLAND: Andy Teal.
DOC.TEXT: Both the state and Exxon figures may be accurate, but even the best studies of the spill's effects are mere snapshots of a rugged, sparsely populated region the size of New Jersey, Maryland and Delaware combined. The Coast Guard has declared some sort of cleanup must resume May 1, but nobody has committed to how much or what kind. Decisions will be made after another survey of beach conditions next month. In general, exposed beaches eroded by winter storms appear to have fared the best, but surface oil remains thick in many sheltered coves and estuaries. Areas with oil hidden beneath the surface, such as the Perry Island beach Bridgman visited, may prove the most troublesome. State officials believe many of those beaches would benefit from intensive work, such as digging up gravel, tumbling it in rock-washing machines and replacing it. While that would kill nearly all living organisms, it would provide a clean slate for populations to rebuild, said Steve Provant, the Department of Environmental Conservation's spill coordinator. But Exxon officials say such intrusive techniques could do more harm than good. Some federal authorities are inclined to agree, recalling last summer's heavy-handed invasion of the Alaska wilderness. Frightened animals had to flee repeatedly from buzzing helicopters, and cleanup crews left behind tons of plastic boom material, absorbent pompons and other litter on previously pristine beaches. Even scientists made their mark, painting rocks with flourescent paint and tying orange plastic flagging to trees. ``You can see these things a mile away, and they're in areas where people otherwise would be having a quality wilderness experience,'' said Nancy Lethcoe, a sailboat-tour operator in Valdez. Lethcoe remembers a Prince William Sound where you could stand on a lonely beach and feel you were the first human ever there. It was a place where the world still felt big. Now the world seems suddenly smaller, civilization's reach extended by the greasy fingers of an oil spill. Lethcoe said she'll leave the blaming to the lawyers. When she goes out on the sound these days, she focuses on nature's recuperative powers. It works until she discovers that oil has found another of her favorite hideaways. ``When I know an area is oiled, I can brace myself,'' she said. ``But when I find an area that wasn't supposed to be oiled, it brings back the whole trauma of the spill. It brings back the pain.''
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: David Foster is the AP Northwest regional reporter, based in Seattle.

DOC.HEAD: Guns, Drugs, Fractious Politics Trouble Pakistan's Largest City
DOC.TEXT: Guns, drugs, ethnic violence and fractious politics have infected the largest city in Pakistan. Some fear the new democracy will not survive. Political parties fight pitched battles in the cramped alleyways; 60 people were killed and hundreds wounded Feb. 7. Paramilitary forces still patrol Karachi and a curfew continues in some districts. The universities are closed and gangs of student extremists have turned them into armed camps. Kidnappings and torture are commonplace. Unemployment is rampant. Government officials say they have no way to count the people looking for work. A gram of heroin costs less than $2. A decade ago the drug was hardly found in Pakistan. Now Karachi has 300,000 addicts, one-third of the nation's total. Automatic weapons used to be rare in Karachi; today you can rent a Kalashnikov assault rifle for $5 a day. Bands of robbers roam the countryside and car thieves operate throughout the city. Many residents say the police are either corrupt or incompetent. Police say they are outnumbered and outgunned wih one officer to 458 citizens, one of the lowest ratios in South Asia. ``Karachi, once a city of peace, tranquility and affluence, has turned almost into Beirut,'' Mahmood Ali Malik, a noted psychologist, wrote in The Pakistan Times. ``The army is certainly waiting in the wings,'' said Ahmed Ali Khan, editor of the Dawn, the largest English-language newspaper. ``Increased chaos could threaten our democracy.'' Eleven years of martial law ended two years ago after Gen. Mohammed Zia ul-Haq, the president, was killed in a plane crash. Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto, elected in November 1988, presides over a shaky government. Any problem Pakistan has, Karachi appears to have in greater measure. Because of its size and importance, Karachi's problems have national scope. Eight million people live in the city, which sprawls on the sun-baked coast of the Arabian Sea. It is Pakistan's economic center and the only major port. Three layers of interwoven troubles weigh on the city and the rest of Sind province, which surrounds Karachi: ethnic strife, social breakdown and a newer phenonmenon called ``the heroin and Kalashnikov culture.'' Guns have been plentiful in Pakistan ever since Soviet military forces entered Afghanistan in December 1978 and the U.S.-supported Afghan rebels moved their bases to Pakistan. Millions of dollars in U.S. aid to the rebels helped finance a huge arms trade in northern Pakistan. Simultaneously, the making of heroin became an important source of income for Afghan refugees and indigenous tribes in the area. Weapons accompanied the narcotics south to Karachi, a main conduit for heroin to Western Europe and the United States. About 6,000 pounds of heroin were seized in Karachi in the last half of 1989, more than double the total for 1986 and 10 times the amounts of earlier years. Shootings of law enforcement officers are frequent. A ranking customs agent was shot six times in the face and leg as he left his home last June on what was to be a secret raid. He survived. Drugs and guns in the city combine with increasing crime in the surrounding countryside. Disputes formerly resolved by a village headman now are settled with guns, historian Hamida Khoura said. ``We face an institutional breakdown throughout the province,'' said Fakhruddin Ibrahim, governor of Sind province. ``Chaos is ruling,'' and police can do little to stop it. ``The police in Pakistan have always been a political tool,'' he said in an interview. ``Years of martial law taught them that. I don't see it changing.'' Add ethnic strife and the situation becomes increasingly volatile. Ever since the subcontinent was divided into India and Pakistan in 1947, at the end of British colonial rule, Karachi has been Pakistan's closest thing to a melting pot. Pathans and Punjabis moved south to make a fast rupee in the port city. Sindhis came from the countryside to sell their produce. Immigrants called Mohajirs, flooded into Moslem Pakistan from predominantly Hindu India. Nothing melted in the pot, however, and trouble between rival ethnic groups began in the 1950s. Ethnic strife acquired political overtones in 1985 with formation of the Mohajir Qaumi Movement, which sought to represent the interests of immigrants from India. Mohajirs say they are discriminated against by the provincial government, which Sindhis dominate. They want more jobs and official recognition of their ethnic group. Their movement has become an important political force because Mohajirs are more numerous than any other group in the cities of Sind province, including Karachi. Altaf Hussain leads the movement. The former pharmacy student, known for strirring speeches, ever-present sunglasses and opulently ringed fingers, has adopted ``Sell your TV and buy a gun!'' as his battle cry. ``We are a new phenonmenon, a party of destiny,'' Hussain said in an interview. ``We are the first party to represent the oppressed and suppressed masses. I am the chosen leader.'' Karachi politics went national when Hussain united with the national opposition in an attempt to bring down the Bhutto government. Ms. Bhutto's Pakistan People's Party, based in Sind, had an alliance with Hussain during the campaign but tended to ignore Mohajir interests after winning the election. In November, she barely defeated a no-confidence vote in the National Assembly when the 14 members from the Mohajir movement voted against her. On Feb. 7, Hussain called for a general strike in Karachi to protest what he described as persecution by her party. Scores of people were killed in clashes between police and gunmen of both parties. More than 200 kidnappings were reported. Victims were tortured with electric drills, castration and multiple cigarette burns. On March 2, talks began between Hussain's group and the Bhutto party. ``We all realize that things have gotten as bad as they can get,'' said Nafees Siddiqi, a top official of the Pakistan People's Party in Sind. ``If things get worse, the army could roll back in.'' Structural problems stand in the way of political peace. Pakistan has been under martial law for 20 of the last 30 years and now has an extremely centralized system. Many observers say violent politics will continue until some authority devolves to cities and provinces. ``Now everybody can be an extremist because none of them has real authority,'' said Ibrahim, the provincial governor. ``Give them a budget and they'll become moderates.'' Ansar Burney, who fights for prisoner rights and against drug abuse in Karachi, says few residents have the national interest at heart. ``No one in Karachi thinks about the public good,'' he said. ``They're just obsessed with power and guns.''

DOC.HEAD: New Motto in Pakistan: `Sell Your TV and Buy a Gun'
With BC-War in Karachi, b0718
DOC.TEXT: An angry college dropout has formed a strong political movement in the streets of Pakistan's biggest city and taken as his battle cry: ``Sell your TV and buy a gun!'' Altaf Hussain, a 36-year-old former student of pharmacy, has maneuvered into a key position in Pakistan's politics, tapping ethnic anger and alienation among the lower and middle classes of Karachi. ``We are the new phenonmenon,' Hussain said in an interview at his headquarters. ``We are the new revolution.'' The ``great leader,'' as he is known, is a charismatic man famed in the cities of Sind province as a stirring speaker. Hussain also is known for the sunglasses he always wears, opulently ringed fingers and volcanic temper. His main weapon is the ability to shut down Karachi, which has more than 8 million people and is Pakistan's economic center. He ordered a citywide strike Feb. 7. Scores of people were killed and hundreds injured in street battles between his supporters, rival political group and police. ``We represent the oppressed and suppressed masses,'' he said. ``We work only for their interests.'' Hussain leads the Mohajir Quaim Movement. Mohajirs immigrated from predominantly Hindu India to Moslem Pakistan after 1947, when the British turned the subcontinent into two nations and granted them independence. The Mohajir movement claims its people are discriminated against by Sindhis, the majority in Sind province. Sindhis dominate the provincial assembly and hold most of the top government jobs. Mohajirs generally are better educated than the Sindhis, and many feel they have been denied opportunities to advance. ``I give expression to my people's feelings,'' Hussain said. ``I know what they want.'' A Clint Eastwood classic, ``The Outlaw Josie Wales,'' played on a videocassette recorder behind him. Hussian fingered a huge yellow sapphire on his middle finger. Like many leaders of ethnic political movements, Hussain does not follow a strict ideology. ``We are not socialists or capitalists,'' he said. ``We believe in practicalism and realism.'' He did not elaborate. His well-armed men are known as ``the black shirts of Karachi,'' testimony to the strict discipline imposed by his lieutenants. Western diplomats estimate Hussain has about 8,000 men under arms in Karachi and 4,000 more in Hyderabad, Sind's second largest city. The movement's headquarters dominates the Azizabad section of Karachi, a lower middle class area of cement block houses and serpentine alleys. Hussain's bodyguards, armed with automatic rifles, stand at the huge steel gates. Hussain is the son of a laborer and dropped out of college in the early 1980s to be a full-time political organizer. He allied himself with the Pakistan Peoples Party of Benazir Bhutto duirng the November 1988 election campaign, supplying the future prime minister with important votes, but Ms. Bhutto's party generally ignored Mohajir interests after winning. Late last year, Hussain joined the opposition. In November, Ms. Bhutto barely defeated a no-confidence motion in the National Assembly, because the Mohajir movement's 14 members voted against her.

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
Music Makers: The Other Neville
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Charmaine Neville isn't bitter, but she admits she hasn't forgotten those bad old days before her father and uncles were famous, when her family was broken up and she was fighting for survival in one foster home after another. ``Being a Neville is great now. But it was a hard trip getting here for the Neville Brothers, the Neville nieces and nephews and especially this Neville. I think one reason our music is so important to all of us is because we had such a hard, hard time hanging on to it,'' she said. Long before the Neville Brothers became Grammy winners, long before Aaron Neville teamed up with Linda Ronstadt, long before Charmaine began working clubs and making movies and commercials, the family was poor and scattered. Neville, 34, doesn't remember meeting her father, Charles Neville of the Neville Brothers, until she was about 5 years old. From the time she was 2 until she was 12, she spent her life in a series of foster homes. ``I was abused just about every way you can be during that time _ sexually, mentally, physically,'' she said. ``I was bitter for a long time. A very long time. I'm not anymore. I know now my parents couldn't help it. They were young, they didn't have any money or any way to take care of us.'' In those days the Neville Brothers were scratching for gigs and singing for next to nothing. ``They were young and inexperienced. Getting known outside of New Orleans wasn't easy then. It's still not, but it's easier now than it was them,'' she said. Little by little, the Neville family came back together. She met one of her four sisters in school, another when they took the same bus to her aunt's house and arrived together. Her four brothers turned up over the years. As a teen-ager she also got to know her father and uncles. ``I adore my father. Always did. I love my family, including my last set of foster parents and all 52 of my foster sisters and 48 of my foster brothers. Now that we're back together it's OK,'' Neville said. Through it all, music was a part of her life and her family, she said. ``I'd always sung in the church choir. My family always made music together. I didn't really get serious about it until I was about 17, though,'' Neville said. ``My dad hurt my feelings. We had been playing in New York when he said, `Call me when you get serious about your music _ because music is very serious to me and you're not being serious about it.' '' That's when she went to work, learning to read music, learning to control her voice, learning to put her own mark on a song, she said. ``Up until then I just opened my mouth and sang,'' Neville said. Now she jumps on stage in a swirl of motion and music. Hands clap, hips sway, long, slim fingers pop, the mass of thin braids whip back and forth. ``I don't like to classify my singing,'' Neville said. ``If I say I'm a jazz singer then people ask why I do pop, or rock or country and western, and I do all of those. I prefer to think of each song as a little one-act play. I think of myself as an entertainer and not just a singer.'' Like the Neville Brothers, Neville's musical blend of New Orleans rhythms mixes in jazz, Cajun, rock and old time blues. Particularly popular with audiences is her impersonation of Louis Armstrong. ``It's really not that hard,'' she said of the gravel-voiced ``Satchmo'' she does for several numbers. ``It's just like singing falsetto, really. It started as a joke; someone asked me if I could do Louis Armstrong and now people request it all the time.'' Her music is different from that of the Neville Brothers but it is a product of their teaching, she said. From Aaron she learned voice control. ``He's just phenomenal _ his range, the things he can do. He really showed me how to use my voice and get more from it,'' she said. From Cyril she learned her stage presence. ``He's the wild Neville Brother. He taught me to not just stand there but to open up and have fun with the audience,'' she said. From Art she learned music. ``He showed me the parts of music that you can use when you know what you're doing. How to take it apart and put it together again,'' she said. And from Charles she learned to work. ``Dad's the coolest of the Neville Brothers. He's the one who just stands there on stage. But he's also the one who showed me how much work you have to do to be that cool.'' Neville works about 360 days a year, mostly in clubs, although she is a regular at the New Orleans Jazz and Heritage Festival and has made numerous commercials and appeared in several movies and at least one television pilot. In June she will perform in Moscow, in July she'll be in Paris, in the fall she hopes to return to Milan, Italy. She doesn't often work with her famous family these days, she said. ``We've all gotten too busy now. It seems like we are always passing each other in airports. When we do get together it's a trip. I was in a club called Delta 88 in New York and Dad and Uncle Aaron and Uncle Arty came in. We really tore up the club. It was great,'' she said. With her own career building, and the sudden interest in New Orleans artists such as her uncles, Harry Connick Jr. and Dr. John, Neville said things look great now. ``I just hope this isn't a fad like blackened redfish,'' she said. ``I mean, why now? The music has been here forever. People in the rest of the world may not know about New Orleans music but they're about to get lessons. I just want to be one of the teachers.''

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
Books and Authors: On Fiction and Stories Good to Tell
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Stephanie Vaughn would like to point out that her short stories are fiction: She made up the good parts. Her real father would have never walked on a frozen pond in the middle of the night. Her grandmother is much nicer than the one depicted in ``Able, Baker, Charlie, Dog.'' The stories about winter were written during heat waves; the summer stories came in cold weather. But she really did grow up in a military family. As a teen-ager the author actually mistook puberty for a fatal disease. And she was encouraged to speak carefully as a child and be precise, a style she eventually mastered in written form. ``I don't think it's natural for anybody to write,'' insists Vaughn, whose first collection of stories is called ``Sweet Talk'' (Random House, $16.95). ``I think it's natural to speak, and everybody's a storyteller. You go through your life telling stories. It's hard to write. Sometimes things come out funny when you don't want them to at that moment. You're always in danger of destroying your story and turning it into a joke.'' The laughter comes in different shades. ``I grew up in the Army,'' Vaughn writes at the start of ``Kid MacArthur.'' ``About the only kind of dove I ever saw was a dead dove resting small-boned upon a dinner plate.'' The theory of the universe shares space with a local car crash. Premature death is just a few pages from a sales pitch for the Triple Gripper Vegetable Ripper. Having lived around the world as a child, Vaughn is an authority on the unexpected. She knows writing is as predictable as driving on an icy road, that a straight line is not the quickest path between two points. ``Dog Heaven'' begins on a New York City sidewalk, a women dreaming of her dog's death 25 years ago, and ends with the narrator remembering her childhood at Fort Niagara, saying the following incantation: ``It was a good day. It was a good day. It was a good day.'' ``Yeah, I didn't know it was coming,'' Vaughn said. ``I knew what was going to happen to the dog but I didn't know how I was going to get out of the story. You often don't know how you're going to get out of the story until you get there. I think if you're not surprised by your writing, you should probably get out of it.'' Vaughn was born in Millersburg, Ohio, but also lived in New York, Oklahoma, Texas, the Philippines and Italy. Writing first interested her in Australia in the 1970s and she eventually attended the University of Iowa. ``I liked living near cornfields. The town itself (Iowa City) was just full of writers, full of painters, full of filmmakers. It's a good place because there are so many other people doing art and you talk about everything all the time with those people.'' Vaughn notes that ``Sweet Talk'' is crammed with advice that isn't always useful. Theories on love, language and disease are all offered, but only sometimes accepted. In ``Kid MacArthur,'' a boy's father imposes his own code of honor, advice for a world that only some experience. ``The father is trying to give his son masculine skills,'' the author said. ``He values language and gossip and he also values guns. He wants him to be a good marksman and not show his vulnerabilities when he's out shooting. ``I suppose being a good marksman is useful if you're on your way to Vietnam, but it's not necessarily useful at home.'' From other writers, Vaughn learned the importance of revision, sentence rhythms, to sacrifice favorite lines if they don't fit the story. And the words have to flow, as relaxed as conversation, but as formally structured as a high school term paper. ``You have to invent,'' she said. ``You have to discover, on the page, a voice. It's very difficult to define what a voice is, but you know it when it's speaking back to you from the page. You just hit something that sounds comfortable.'' Vaughn is now working on a novel, but firmly declines to discuss it, presenting a theory she wouldn't dare offer to any writer but herself: Don't discuss a story until it's finished. The surest way to lose your literary voice is to talk about it. ``If you talk about something that's not finished, than you're giving it a spoken form and therefore there's no reason to give it a written form. Since I never talk about them, they come out better. Now, with these short stories, it's almost as if someone else has written them.''

Nashville Sound: Sawyer Brown Watches the Numbers
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Mark Miller of the pop-country band Sawyer Brown feels reassured when he looks out at concert crowds and sees people holding up signs with numbers like ``70'' and ``52.'' The figures represent the number of Sawyer Brown concerts the fan has attended. ``I've seen some in the hundreds, but no 200s yet,'' Miller said. ``A lot of them are over 50.'' Miller said the signs are a tradition started soon after the band began touring. Fans who were proud of the number of concerts they had attended would hold up a sign. Sawyer Brown, which has five members, has developed a legion of loyal fans since the group won on the syndicated TV show ``Star Search'' in 1983. The fans keep returning to the concerts, as evidenced by the signs, even though the band has weathered a monumental problem: little radio air play. The group, named after a Nashville street, is too pop for country music stations and too country for rock 'n' roll stations. So the five have relied on their frenzied, pulsating, unpredictable stage shows to maintain their popularity. They ignite audiences by dancing, jumping and whirling across the stage with supercharged energy. They play upbeat, ``good-time'' music with a driving rhythm and tight vocals _ all set off by brightly colored clothing. After winning ``Star Search'' and splitting the $100,000 prize money five ways, the group began recording for Capitol Records a year later. Shortly after that, they were the opening act at Kenny Rogers' concerts for 1{ years, performing live for millions. The Nashville-based band has had hit records along the way, including ``Step That Step,'' ``The Race Is On,'' ``Shakin''' and ``Leona.'' They have released six albums, including the current ``The Boys Are Back.'' Miller, reflecting on the band's career, said winning ``Star Search'' was their breakthrough but the aftermath posed a formidable challenge. ``When you hit that big that quick, people start asking whether you are a flash in the pan. It was like when the Beach Boys first came out, some people thought they were a fad. In our case, some people felt we would be, too, so there were some serious storms we had to weather. ``I think everybody wants you to succeed until you succeed, and then they start gunning for you. And the guns came out real quick on us,'' he said. ``We are a legitimate act that drew people month after month and year after year regardless of whether we had a hit record out. People knew they would see a show as entertainment value. Basically, we sold our records going door to door, doing 250 dates a year.'' He described their concerts as ``intense, very intense. A friend of mine said it's like being part of an event, like a huge party. That's what we try to make it.'' Before winning ``Star Search,'' the group polished its act for two years as a ``bar band'' at various nightclubs throughout the country. On good nights they played five sets and on bad nights they did seven. They often had a ``rowdy table'' contest where the most uproarious table won a pitcher of beer. For Miller, it was a new experience and a valuable one. ``I had never been in a bar until I played one,'' he recalled. ``You learn that you can be a jukebox or you can demand their attention by entertaining them.'' Exposure on a much wider basis came when they joined Rogers on his concert tours. ``When we first got the call, I was so excited,'' Miller said. ``It was a dream come true. I was also scared to death. ``I remember the crowd going crazy and on the second night Kenny came out to see what all the commotion was about. He came in the dressing room and said we had a job as long as we wanted one.'' Sawyer Brown is one of the few bands that sign autographs after every show. ``We do them as long as it takes,'' Miller said. ``We feel like we owe it to the fans as the least we can do. People remember things like that.''

DOC.TEXT: In his first motion picture project for Walt Disney Studios, Bill Murray will star in Touchstone Pictures' ``What About Bob?'' The new comedy is written by Tom Schulman, who has been nominated for an Academy Award for ``Dead Poets Society.'' The movie is scheduled to begin production this summer. Murray plays Bob, an excessively neurotic man who resorts to desperate measures when his psychiatrist takes off on an extended family vacation. ``Bill is a gifted actor and Tom Schulman's script is tailor-made for his unique comedic talents,'' said David Hoberman, president of Touchstone Pictures. Murray recently made his directorial debut (with co-director Howard Franklin) on the Warner Bros. caper comedy ``Quick Change,'' co-starring Geena Davis, Jason Robards and Randy Quaid. ``Quick Change'' is to be released this summer.

The Pennsylvania Ballet will open its spring season with a premiere production of John Cranko's ``Romeo and Juliet.'' Cranko's version retains the story's dark emotional tone while showcasing dance and drama. This production will be presented June 6-13 at the Academy of Music. ``Giselle,'' ballet's most celebrated romance story, will also be performed in June. In April, ``Carmina Burana,'' the company's signature piece, will be presented at the Shubert Theatre, accompanied by ``Bournonville Divertissements.''

At the Movies: `Love At Large'
DOC.TEXT: Ever since John Huston, with more than a little help from Dashiell Hammett, invented the private eye movie with ``The Maltese Falcon'' in 1941, the genre has thrived in many manifestations. Raymond Chandler added a cynical note with his Philip Marlowe, best portrayed by Dick Powell in ``Murder My Sweet.'' Comic gumshoes have rarely succeeded, though Steve Martin tried in ``Dead Men Don't Wear Plaid'' and Peter Falk in ``The Cheap Detective.'' Now comes ``Love at Large,'' which proves that a private eye satire can be funny and involving at the same time. The feat was accomplished by the most improbable of filmmakers, Alan Rudolph. A disciple of Robert Altman, Rudolph has made films (``Welcome to L.A.,'' ``Made in Heaven,'' ``The Moderns'') that seemed quirky, remote and humorless. In making ``Love at Large,'' he seems to be saying, ``OK, I'll make a movie that'll grab 'em.'' Rudolph's hero Harry Dobbs (Tom Berenger) is a dense Philip Marlowe with a Columbo voice. Harry can't seem to get anything right. He agrees to an investigation for a sultry lady of mystery (Anne Archer), then follows the wrong man. Dobbs uncovers an interesting though irrelevant case: a successful man with two families, one in the city and one on a ranch. He is followed on his quest by another private eye (Elizabeth Perkins), hired by his jealous girlfriend (Ann Magnuson). The wayward detective finally gets back on track, and the film reaches a violent though unexpected finale. The plot is rambling and inconclusive, but the enjoyment comes from the characters, most of them cast against type. Berenger, the demonic sergeant of ``Platoon,'' is a comic delight with his sandpaper voice and well meaning klutziness. Anne Archer, the wronged wife in ``Fatal Attraction,'' plays a humanoid Jessica Rabbit, a gorgeous parody of a 1940s femme fatale. Elizabeth Perkins, the sharp executive of ``Big,'' is sympathetic as Dobbs' fallible partner. The strong cast also included Annette O'Toole, Ruby Dee, Neil Young and Kate Capshaw. Rudolph gives all his actors a chance to shine. Inflation note: Harry Dobbs charges $500 a week retainer plus expenses. Wouldn't Sam Spade and Philip Marlowe be envious? The Orion Picture was produced by David Blocker and is rated R for language, violence and sexual byplay. Running time: 110 minutes.

Video View: Home Video News and Reviews
DOC.TEXT:
``Chocolat'' (Orion. VHS-Beta, $79.98. Rated PG-13)
France and Protee have a special relationship. They communicate spiritually, silently; their imaginations intertwine. But they are adrift in a political and social stew: It is the ebbing days of French rule in Cameroon. France is white. Protee is her family's black houseboy. Their world is shattered when a group of white travelers with plane problems arrive and become house guests. There is betrayal and a painful coming of age. Isaach de Bankole is excellent as Protee, bringing just the right reserve to the role. Mireille Perrier is haunting. The French movie is directed by Claire Denis. Though her pacing is sometimes slow, she moves her story with feeling.

``An Innocent Man'' (Touchstone. VHS-Beta, $89.95. Rated R)
What's the story every convict tells? I'm innocent. Only this time, it's true. Tom Selleck stars as Jimmie Rainwood, an ordinary guy who services aircraft, whose ordinary life becomes a horror show when two corrupt cops frame him for drug dealing in order to cover up their mistake. He, of course, pleads not guilty at his trial, is convicted and shipped off to the big house where he meets the usual herd of prison animals. There's the usual prison challenges and violence seen in just about all jail movies. Only this time, an innocent man must prove himself in order to survive. He does this by murdering another prisoner. When he's released, he seeks his vengeance. ``An Innocent Man,'' directed by Peter Yates who did so well years ago with ``Bullitt,'' is a good idea and plays just fine as far as it goes. But it's missing a toughness, an edge _ the drama and tension that could make it a far more compelling movie. The problem, unfortunately, might be Selleck. Although he gives a fine performance as the wronged citizen, he's simply too nice a guy. The two cops are predictably sleazy and telegraph their moves. But what the movie lacks in excitement, is made up for in its realistic prison scenes and prison lingo. F. Murray Abraham is a delight as the prison's respected lifer. The video is worth a look.

In the Groove: Record Reviews
DOC.TEXT:
``The Cactus Album'' (Columbia-Def Jam) _ 3rd Bass
Yeeoww! Rap for the new generation. On 3rd Bass' ``The Cactus Album,'' there are beats more effective than Mike Tyson's uppercut, and rapping more fresh than a daisy. But hold on now. 3rd Bass is white. And they leave the Beastie Boys in the dust. The Beasties come off as a bunch of middle-class white brats trying to pull one over on the record-buying public. However, 3rd Bass' MC Serch (22-year-old Michael Berrin) and Prime Minister Pete Nice (22-year-old Peter Nash) grew up in the New York borough of Queens and hung out in all-black housing projects and city parks, getting bashed around but learning to rap hard. Their debut album is a slammin' mix of vocals, quirky recordings and sampled music that, like De la Soul's ``3 Feet High and Rising,'' will have you playing Name That Tune. They take bits from Pink Floyd's ``Time,'' the '70s hit ``Dream Weaver'' and mutate the melody from Blood, Sweat and Tears' ``Spinning Wheel.'' While some rap music is just tedious thump-thumping with shout-talking vocals, ``The Cactus Album'' shows rap's power to create post-rock, post-pop, hybrid music. This record is a stew cooked in the melting pot of New York, with a load of ingredients as large as the Empire State Building. Words. They got words. Lots of them. And yeah, some of those words aren't too nice. But MC Serch and Pete Nice also have ``wordz of wizdom'' like ``Black cat is bad luck, bad guys wear black, must've been a white guy who started all that,'' on ``The Gas Face.'' On ``Product of the Environment,'' they comment, ``Pushin' a drug, I can't understand, destroying a life with a buck in the hand.'' These boys have fun, too. The album opens with a bit of ``The Little Rascals'' theme, and closes with Abbott and Costello doing a scratchin' version of their ``Who's on First?'' routine _ only they're asking who's on 3rd. 3rd Bass punches a knockout, dense form of rap that goes way beyond their peers. _ By Giselle Price, Associated Press Writer.

``Boys in Heat'' (Columbia) _ Britny Fox
Another metal story: Long-haired, leather-clad rockers assault eardrums with battering guitars and banging drums. Singer sounds like beefalo in distress. Head-bangers happy, hundreds of thousands of records sold. _ By Giselle Price, Associated Press Writer.

``Jim Croce Live: The Final Tour'' (Saja) _ Jim Croce
Nostalgia for the 1970s appears inevitable, so we might as well learn to deal with it. One simple way would be to avoid ripoffs, such as the new disc ``Jim Croce Live: The Final Tour.'' Singer-songwriter Croce died in a plane crash in 1973. This new live recording doesn't serve his memory at all well, despite Ingrid Croce's role as executive producer. For one thing, the package is cheap. There's one picture of Croce and no liner notes. There's a whole generation of music buyers out there who weren't born when Croce died; they should be told a little about his life and music. Basic facts are ignored. Who played with Croce? Where was the performance recorded? When? Was this an entire show or just a portion? The 16-cut disc includes an appalling 18 minutes of Croce talking to the audience. He's mildly amusing, though occasionally dated: When was the last time you heard jokes about the Maharishi? One stretch is remarkably ghoulish. Croce _ apparently months, weeks or days from dying in a burning plane _ talks about trips on Allegheny Airlines, which later became USAir. He jokes about a ``white-knuckle flight.'' The worst thing about the dialogue, of course, is it's much better to hear Croce sing than talk. Unfortunately, you won't hear him sing some of his best-known songs, including ``Bad, Bad Leroy Brown,'' ``Time in a Bottle'' or ``I Got a Name.'' Couldn't a few minutes of talking be sacrificed? A couple of songs could be sacrificed, too. One potential victim is the dated ``Roller Derby Queen,'' with the 5:28 minutes of ``Roller Derby Queen Dialogue'' preceding it. The lewd limerick ``Ball of Kerrymuir'' is tasteless. ``Operator (That's Not the Way It Feels)'' and the poignant ``These Dreams,'' which bookend the disc, are Croce's best musical moments. Elsewhere, a lack of balance in the recording _ the voices too loud and guitars too soft _ is an annoyance. With so many well-researched and well-documented reissues coming out these days, it's disheartening to see such a shabby package. Vinyl buyers can take heart, though: ``Jim Croce Live: The Final Tour'' is available only on cassette and compact disc. _ By David Bauder, Associated Press Writer.

Star Watch: An Old Role Takes on New Meaning
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Sunday in 9th graf is March 25.
With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: In the late 1950s, George Stevens decided to make a movie version of the Tony award-winning play ``The Diary of Anne Frank,'' based on the stirring journal of a teen-ager's loss of innocence and the destruction and horror wrought by the Holocaust. Only one actress, he thought, could breath life into young Anne Frank's words of hope and self-knowledge: Audrey Hepburn. She was a fresh face for American audiences and had captured the best actress Academy Award for her 1953 Hollywood debut in William Wyler's ``Roman Holiday.'' She was fragile, yet strong; innocent, yet worldly; elfin, childlike, sensual and quietly elegant. She was the indestructible waif. Like Anne, she had lived in the Netherlands during the Nazi occupation. Hepburn had first read the diary in 1946 when she was 16. ``I was deeply affected by it when I first read it,'' she recalled in a recent interview. ``It paralleled so much what I had experienced. ``Anne Frank and I were the same age, and she recorded everything she had heard about, which I had experienced on the outside, plus her own deep feelings, the development of her adolescence and her relationship with her parents and her feelings about life, all of which were very typical of a sensitive girl of that age.'' Hepburn reread the diary when Stevens made his offer. It brought back a flood of memories, and she turned him down. The part went to Millie Perkins. ``I was so destroyed by it again that I said I couldn't deal with it,'' Hepburn said. ``I suppose, it's very hard to explain. It's a little bit as if this had happened to my sister. I couldn't play my sister's life. It's too close, and in a way, she was a sister soul perhaps. I could not exploit for what I considered entertainment, the suffering and experience she had gone through.'' Anne Frank died at the Bergen-Belsen concentration camp in 1945 after contracting typhoid fever. Today, she would be 60 _ like Audrey Hepburn. And today, Hepburn is finally ready to read Anne's words. She will do so on Sunday at the world premiere performance of Michael Tilson Thomas' musical based on ``The Diary of Anne Frank.'' The concert is a special benefit for UNICEF, for which Hepburn is the goodwill ambassador. ``Now I'm very happy to read her words,'' Hepburn said from her home in Switzerland. ``I'm thrilled to do so because I think it's something very important. ... They're very deep and they're pure becuase she was a child and she wrote them from her heart, and I think it's a lovely opportunity to relay her thoughts once again, her spirit. ``Anne Frank's words _ she herself a child _ will be used to bring solace to children, it would have made her very happy.'' Since leaving the film business about two decades ago to concentrate on being a mother to her two sons, Sean, now 29, and Luca, 20, Hepburn has spent some of her time working with UNICEF. The international organization didn't suddenly float into Hepburn's life because she needed some sort of social cause. As for politics, she describes herself as ``totally unpolitical.'' ``I've never known anything about politics,'' she said. ``I just care terribly because I saw so much as a child about suffering and the suffering of children.'' Rather, she first encountered the organization that would grow into UNICEF shortly after the Germans surrendered, when she and others who had survived the harsh winter months of 1944-45 with little food and inadequate clothing received relief. ``I somehow feel I've been connected with UNICEF all my life,'' she said. ``They were there right after liberation, so I benefitted from their help, like millions of other children. Then over the years, I've been constantly in contact for some reason or another.'' Hepburn was born in Belgium. Her parents divorced when she was 6 and she went to live with her mother, the baroness Ella van Heemstra, in Holland. As a youngster, she studied ballet. She later went to London to pursue dance and eventually found herself in British films (``Lavender Hill Mob,'' ``Young Wives' Tales''). She first got the attention of Broadway and Hollywood while filming ``Monte Carlo Baby'' at the Hotel de Paris in Monaco. She was spotted by the French writer Colette who thought she would make an excellent ``Gigi'' for the play based on her novel. Hepburn, an unknown, opened as the lead at the Fulton Theater in November 1951. She jumped from Broadway to star in ``Roman Holiday'' with Gregory Peck. Hepburn quietly glided out of film work in the late '60s after ``Wait Until Dark'' and ``Two for the Road.'' She reappeared with Sean Connery as the aging Robin Hood and his maiden in ``Robin and Marian'' in 1976 and shocked fans with her graying hair and hint of wrinkles. She appeared in the thriller ``Bloodline'' with its all-star cast in 1979 and made a TV movie with Robert Wagner in 1987. Then, late last year, she popped up on the screen in Steven Spielberg's ``Always'' as an angel guide. ```Always' was such a surprise,'' she said. ``I got a divine phone call from Steven Spielberg, and I was just thrilled to death. It took me one second to decide. It was such wonderful fun and therapy and Montana was so beautiful. ... It was a marvelous experience.'' And yes, she would definitely do another movie _ if it's Steven Spielberg. Holly Golightly meets E.T.? Holly in ``Breakfast at Tiffany's'' was one of Hepburn's most memorable roles. She was endearing, extreme and elegant. All of Hepburn's characters mirrored the actress herself: There was always a humanity and quiet grace, and bursts of elfin charm. In ``Sabrina'' with Humphrey Bogart and William Holden, she was charming as the chauffeur's daughter who falls in love with the wealthy playboy. In ``The Nun's Story,'' she demonstrated her talent for drama. And she matched Albert Finney line for line as the young lovers who become a troubled married couple in ``Two for the Road.'' But Hepburn never thought of herself as a star or a talented artist. ``I never had this huge talent or a great technique,'' she said. ``But somehow I may have had something that contributed ... this extraordinary run of fortune. ``I don't know, it's something about personality ... an enormous joy perhaps that I had in doing what I was doing and being able to convey that, and a sort of affection for what I was doing, and for the people around me, and the story I was doing, and the parts I was playing and the people who would be watching me. ``It was all sort of a big love affair.''
