The Artists: Venezuelan Art Boom
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Venezuelan artists once labored in obscurity, gaining recognition only after their deaths. Today, however, such artists as Reveron, an eccentric who lived in a shack he built along the Venezuelan coast, Francisco Narvaez, whose monumental sculptures grace many public parks and plazas, the kineticist Jesus Soto and abstract sculptor Marisol are attracting investors from around the world. Venezuelan and Latin American art is hotter now than it has ever been. Last November, world records were set in auctions of Latin American art at the two largest art auction houses in New York. Christie's sold 262 works for an unprecedented total of $9.5 million, while sales at Sotheby's netted $5.5 million. ``I can definitely say there is a boom in Venezuelan art,'' said Axel Stein, Sotheby House representative in Venezuela and Colombia. ``Before 1975, people only talked about Latin American art. We thought a painting by Reveron, for example, `Mujer con Mantilla,' would fetch about $100,000, and it sold for $300,000 in November. There is a growing interest on the part of informed collectors.'' Artists in Venezuela have usually been relegated to a second tier on the international scale, with only a few breaking into the ranks of the greats. But all that is changing, as differences in world culture rapidly shrink and art work becomes a commodity, a calculated gamble on its future financial worth. One person who has done her share in promoting world art within Venezuela and Venezuelan art abroad is Sofia Imber, founder of the Caracas Museum of Contemporary Art. The museum, which opened in 1974, has an international reputation for the quality of its expositions and permanent collection that includes such artists as Picasso, Braque, Moore, Herbin, Chagall and Calder. ``Nothing is easy. Sometimes I'm amazed when I look back and see where we've come from,'' Imber said in an interview in her offices below the museum. Besides her museum work, Imber is host of a popular TV talk show and writes regularly about cultural affairs in Venezuelan newspapers. She was also married to Carlos Rangel, the conservative intellectual and writer who died three years ago. Imber's interest in art came as an adolescent. She recalled seeing one of Armando Reveron's paintings on display when she was about 11 or 12 years old. ``In those days he was an unknown. I sat and cried in front of the painting. I don't remember which one now. It was then I discovered my vocation _ to work for art,'' she said. Imber sees no essential differences between Latin American and European art. ``The best horses run with the herd of the great ones. I don't believe in regionalism,'' she said. However, one of the problems confronting Latin American artists is a lack of regional unity, not only in art, but in culture generally. Just as Latin American economies must integrate in order to survive in the modern marketplace, Latin American artists must strive to know each other's work better, she said. ``We know less of what happens in Bogota (Colombia) than what happens in Paris or New York,'' Imber said. But contemporary artists are doing much to polish Venezuela's international art reputation. ``It's a good moment for the younger generation, people like Jesus Soto, Jacobo Borges and Arturo Cruz-Diez,'' she said. But contemporary artists still suffer from slow acceptance on the part of European and North American art lovers. ``Sure, there is some chauvinism,'' said Stein. ``But it's just as difficult for a North American contemporary artist to be accepted here. There's too much competition. There are many people trying to break the barriers, but it's hard.'' Stein said it was important that private foundations, artists and collectors get together in order to promote contemporary Latin American art. ``The Colombians did an outstanding job promoting their younger artists in the '70s,'' he said. ``There were many Colombian artists in New York and Paris. With the help of the government, the Colombian embassies, businesses and foundations, they tried to identify artists and move them along. With oil-rich Venezuela, on the other hand, the tendency was to be satisfied with the internal market.'' But local collectors, of which there are a select few in Venezuela, can also be important in sustaining and promoting local art, Stein said. ``In the '60s and '70s, you could buy young artists' work for 10,000 bolivars (about $2,325 at the exchange rate then). You couldn't get anything today for less than 200,000 bolivars (about $4,000 at current exchange rates), but it still might be a good investment,'' he said. One young Venezuelan sculptor, Carlos Mendoza, shares his contemporaries' enthusiasm. ``I think the local market is a good one and it will keep growing, despite the economic crisis we are living through, but I want to break through internationally as soon as I can. It doesn't happen overnight, but people are buying more art, not just because of their taste, but because they see it as an investment,'' said Mendoza, who is installing a piece of sculpture outside a Caracas Metro station.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Weekend Editions, March 23-25

DOC.TEXT: Rorer Group Inc. and France's Rhone-Poulenc SA signed a $1.7 billion agreement to create one of the world's largest pharmaceutical companies, the companies jointly announced. Monday's agreement would combine the surbuban Philadelphia-based Rorer with the Paris-based Rhone-Poulenc's human pharmaceutical operations in a new firm called Rhone-Poulenc Rorer Inc. The merger is the latest example of consolidation in the drug industry and is aimed at lowering research costs and gaining global markets.

Walt Disney Co. plans to build a massive upscale shopping mall, commercial office space and homes over the next 25 years on land it owns in Central Florida. Disney Attractions President Dick Nunis said Monday that construction could be under way within five years at the 4,000-acre site, which is located about halfway between downtown Orlando and Tampa.

AT&T signed an agreement to share a key ingredient used to make advanced semiconductors under the auspices of Sematech, the consortium of computer chip makers formed to boost U.S. semiconductor competitiveness. Under the agreement Monday, American Telephone & Telegraph Co. will allow a division of Olin Corp. to make and sell a chemical used to etch extremely detailed electronic circuitry on chips. The chemical, called ``deep UV resist,'' allows chip designers to pack a greater number of circuits on chips than current technologies.

A Greyhound bus in Connecticut was hit by sniper fire and the chairman of the strike-crippled bus line offered a $25,000 reward for information about a weekend shooting in Florida that injured eight passengers. No one was injured in the Connecticut shooting Monday, which occurred as a New York-to-Boston Greyhound bus headed into Hartford with 19 passengers. Passengers reported hearing a small pop that some thought was a blown tire. The union, which represents 6,300 drivers and more than 3,000 office and maintenance workers, went on strike March 2. There have been scattered violent incidents since then.

Senate Republican Leader Bob Dole warned President Bush of a political backlash from voters unless the administration speeds up work on the savings and loan bailout. The Resolution Trust Corp., the new agency created to dispose of failed thrifts, has sold only 50 of the more than 380 S&Ls under government control and ``is not living up to expectations,'' Dole said Monday. He said the delay is driving up the cost of the bailout, estimated at $160 billion over 10 years.

The government announced orders that airlines modify all DC-10 jetliners so they can be controlled when hydraulic systems are damaged. The tentative orders Monday came eight months after a United DC-10-10 crashed in Sioux City, Iowa, killing 112 of the 295 people aboard. An investigation into the crash continues, but pilots said they lost hydraulic steering control after the plane's tail engine exploded. The Federal Aviation Administration's proposal follows changes recommended in the airliner by its manufacturer, McDonnell Douglas Corp.

The Bush administration said there's ``room to talk'' about a far-reaching budget plan by Democrat Rep. Dan Rostenkowski that calls for higher taxes and a one-year Social Security freeze. But White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said Monday the president's decision to consider the radical proposal by the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee doesn't mean he's abandoning his oft-stated opposition to new taxes or Social Security changes.

Lawrence K. Fish, who last week became chairman of Bank of New England Corp., said he plans to reduce the work force, continue selling off assets and may sell subsidiaries as part of his plans to rescue the troubled bank. But Fish offered few specifics Monday about his blueprint for change, except to say the bank, now valued at $25 billion, would be significantly smaller when he gets through with it.

The NYNEX Corp. has asked the Federal Communications Commission to dismiss more than $36 million in fines and refunds its subsidiaries have been ordered to pay as a result of alleged overcharges by an affiliated equipment supply company. NYNEX said that telephone ratepayers were not overcharged as a result of transactions between Materiel Enterprises Co., an unregulated NYNEX affiliate, and New York Telephone Co. and New England Telephone and Telegraph Co. In legal papers filed Monday, NYNEX said the prices paid to Materiel were generally lower than the phone companies would have paid in the open market.

The stock market meandered to a modestly higher close Monday in the slowest session of the year. The Dow Jones industrial average, which drifted in a narrow range throughout the session, eked out a gain of 3.38 points to end at 2,686.71. The dollar rose against most major currencies. Bond prices were mixed in light trading. Futures prices for frozen pork bellies rose sharply; grains were mixed, precious metals and energy products slid lower.

DOC.HEAD: Acquisition of Textile Giant Proves Troublesome for Bill Farley
DOC.TEXT: William Farley is seeing his share of troubles as he puts the finishing stitches on his $3 billion acquisition of West Point-Pepperell. It's been a little more than a year since the Pepperell board agreed to his $58-a-share offer for the Georgia-based maker of such popular products as Martex and Lady Pepperell sheets and towels. But Farley has faced multiple obstacles to acquiring the last 5 percent of the textile giant and unloading some of Pepperell's assets to reduce the debt he incurred in the takeover. Because of Farley's failure so far to complete the financing, two major credit rating agencies have downgraded the debt of Farley Inc. and Pepperell. And there is speculation that Farley may be forced to sell Fruit of the Loom, one of the crown jewels of his corporate empire, to cut debt further. Farley's troubles have come amid _ and some say have reflected _ the waning of the junk bond and debt-financed takeover era in which he and others prospered during the 1980s. ``With the retrospective of 12 months, it is clear he paid too much for West Point,'' said Kay C. Norwood, a textile industry analyst with Interstate-Johnson Lane in Charlotte, N.C. ``Certainly, he paid way too much.'' Ms. Norwood, however, isn't ruling out the chance that Farley, a former encyclopedia salesman who has talked about running for president, will come out on top. And she is not alone in that view. Things looked better for Farley last year when he outlasted then-Chairman Joseph L. Lanier Jr. in a four-month battle for control of Pepperell. Despite an undercurrent of anxiety over possible mass layoffs at local mills, West Point, Ga., and the surrounding communities near the Alabama line welcomed the man who during the takeover battle had been derided as a carpetbagger out to get a company that for generations was locally run. ``Welcome to a New Beginning. Farley Town, USA,'' read a banner hung at the entrance of a West Point bank at the time. Farley paid $1.6 billion in April 1989 for 95 percent of Pepperell, assuming more than $1 billion in debt in the process. His problems with debt magnified his problems financing the buyout, said Joseph E. McCann, an associate professor at Emory University's Business School in Atlanta. ``So you've got a situation where you don't have just one deal. You've got to make a lot of deals to consummate (the original) one,'' McCann added. ``The more complex the deals, the easier it is to fall apart. ``He needed to do a `one-stop-shopping' financial transaction, and he did not.'' Contributing to Farley's problems was his association with Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., which raised $905 million for the acquisition through the sale of junk bonds. Since Drexel's recent bankruptcy court filing, Farley has hired new investment bankers to restructure the Pepperell financing. Farley also has a $1.03 billion bridge loan, which has been extended through the end of this month. The proposed sale of three of Pepperell's Cluett Peabody & Co. divisions to Bidermann Industries USA, a subsidiary of a French company, was considered crucial to cutting Farley's takeover debt. But the deal, announced in October, has not been closed and the sale price reportedly has dropped to $430 million from the original $600 million. Farley officials did not return telephone calls. Ms. Norwood said she thinks Farley will complete the Pepperell deal, but he may not like the results. ``Some divisions are going to be sold at prices he doesn't like,'' she said. ``The banks are going to want the sales very quickly. ... The banks don't want to end up owning a textile company.'' Despite his predicament with the buyout, Farley has gotten high marks for some of the things he's done as Pepperell chairman. Many of Lanier's executive allies left with the former chairman. Farley has hired the respected Charles A. Lieppe, a veteran executive with Procter & Gamble Co., as Pepperell's new president and chief operating officer. Also, Pepperell has pruned the executive suites and added 800 people at five plants in the past year. More than $80 million has been invested in plant improvements.

DOC.HEAD: Simmons Outlines Lockheed Plans
DOC.TEXT: NL Industries Inc. Chairman Harold Simmons, waging a proxy battle for control of the Lockheed Corp. board, contends he can increase the firm's returns by concentrating on its core defense and aerospace businesses. Simmons, the company's largest stockholder with a 19 percent stake, told securities analysts Monday that if he wins control of the Lockheed board at the firm's annual meeting March 29, he also would force the company's smaller divisions to turn an acceptable level of profits. The Dallas-based investor shrugged off reminders that many proxy fights by prominent takeover specialists have ended in failure, calling himself a manager, not a corporate raider. Simmons also has a $1.1 billion takeover bid outstanding for Georgia Gulf Corp. Simmons pointed to his successes with NL and other companies as proof he is qualified to run _ and improve _ Lockheed. However, he had no answers about how he would go about redeploying Lockheed's assets and reducing its overhead, and said he would not know until after he had control of the board. ``You don't snap your fingers overnight,'' he said. Simmons and NL President J. Landis Martin criticized Lockheed management for placing more than $2 billion in assets in its technology services and electronic systems divisions that produce little profit. They portrayed Lockheed Chairman Daniel M. Tellep as unable to get a handle on the firm's problems and use its assets properly. Tellep, hearing a description of the analysts' meeting, responded that the assessment ``reflects a lack of understanding of Lockheed'' and said Simmons and Martin were stating Lockheed's record ``in a way to make their case.'' Martin criticized Tellep for calling Lockheed's 1989 performance _ when the company's earnings fell to $2 million from $624 million in 1988 _ the results of a transitional year as the company took a number of large write-downs. Even without the writedowns, which included $300 million for unexpected design changes on a Navy plane, Lockheed's earnings were down except for its missile and aerospace business, Martin said. Martin also disputed a statement by Tellep that Lockheed's stock price, which closed Monday at $35.50 a share on the New York Stock Exchange, reflected an industry-wide malaise. During the session with analysts, Martin said Lockheed sales growth was running behind other defense contractors and that the firm's stock price, which is down from a high of $54.75 over the past year, was running behind the Standard & Poor's index of defense and aerospace firms. Analysts showed some skepticism of NL's arguments. One analyst, noting that the Standard & Poor's index includes the atypical performance of Boeing Co., said Lockheed is running on a par with other defense contractors, including Northrop Corp. Others pressed Simmons and Martin for more specifics on how they would accomplish their goals if they won their fight. Martin called the company's 1988 restructuring plan a failure, saying Lockheed has been unable to complete the planned sale of four of its non-core businesses, has not disposed of the real estate it wanted to sell and suspended its stock buyback plan. Tellep responded in a telephone interview that after selling three divisions, Lockheed withdrew its Calcomp unit when it did not receive fair offers. Now, however, the division ``has more value at present time retained as part of Lockheed'' and is returning to profitablity, Tellep said. The real estate sales have not been completed because of environmental concerns, and Lockheed suspended its stock buyback in response to Simmons' stock purchases, Tellep said.

DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.HEAD: Bank Of New England's New Chairman Plans For Future
DOC.TEXT: The new chairman of Bank of New England Corp. says he will cut the work force, sell off more assets and consider selling subsidiaries as part of his rescue plan for the troubled bank. But Lawrence K. Fish offered few specifics Monday about his blueprint for change, except to say the bank, now valued at $25 billion, would be significantly smaller when he gets through with it. ``In time, I hope we'll be thought of by how good we are, not how big we are,'' Fish said. ``But that will take time. Larry Fish can't make all of this happen in weeks or months.'' On Friday, Fish, a former Bank of Boston executive, was named chairman and chief executive officer of the bank holding company and its Boston-based subsidiary. He replaces Walter J. Connolly Jr., who was ousted this year after the bank suffered massive losses, mostly in real estate lending. Analysts have largely approved of Fish's appointment, citing his aggressive image and his management experience, which includes 15 years with the Bank of Boston. He spent last year as president and chief operating officer at Columbia Savings & Loan Association in Beverly Hills, Calif. But Fish begins his new job hampered by the troubles at Bank of New England, which last year was the region's second-largest bank. Federal consent orders have restricted how the bank can do business, and the bank has struggled under huge debt and a flood of outgoing depositors. Fish said his priority is to complete the planned sale of $6 billion in assets. He said the bank was in the process of selling its home equity lines for over $1 billion. The bank also is selling its lease assets and other commercial lending assets. The sale of the bank's affiliates in Maine and Rhode Island is also being considered. There are no immediate plans to sell the Connecticut Bank and Trust Co., which Fish called a ``part of the core franchise.'' Fish said personnel cutbacks were inevitable, although he said he did not know how many layoffs would be necessary. Last month, the Bank of New England announced its 1989 losses were $1.11 billion. Non-performing assets are estimated at more than $2 billion. The bank has also lost some $5 billion in deposits in recent months, but Fish said the bank still retained about 98 percent of its depositors. The losses in deposits have forced the bank to borrow an estimated $1 billion-plus from the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston. Many of the bank's troubles stem from real estate loans were made during the region's construction boom in the 1980s and turned sour when the market softened. The federal consent orders, which cover the bank holding company and its Boston-based affiliate, require the bank to tighten lending practices as well as get federal approval to declare stock dividends and conduct financial transactions with its subsidiaries. Fixing the bank may not be wholly under Fish's control, however, said Gerard Cassidy, an analyst with Tucker Anthony Inc. ``It depends on how many loans go bad,'' Cassidy said. ``Each step down the economic ladder we go down as a region, more and more loans go bad, and Bank of New England does not have the room or the flexibility to withstand continued decline in their loan portfolio.''

DOC.HEAD: NYNEX Asks FCC To Dismiss Record Fines and Refunds
DOC.TEXT: The NYNEX Corp. has asked the Federal Communications Commission to throw out more than $36 million in fines and refunds to be paid by two subsidiaries because they did not pass along to ratepayers the inflated cost of equipment. In legal papers filed Monday, NYNEX said telephone ratepayers were not overcharged as a result of transactions between Materiel Enterprises Co., an unregulated NYNEX affiliate, and New York Telephone Co. and New England Telephone and Telegraph Co. Last month, the FCC levied fines totaling $1.4 million against New York Telephone and New England Telephone and Telegraph and ordered them to refund about $35 million to customers. The fines were the largest federal penalty ever imposed on a telephone company and involved $118.5 million in alleged overcharges made to the two subsidiaries by Material Enterprises, which was established in 1983 to provide equipment and services to the two phone companies. But NYNEX said the prices paid to Materiel were generally lower than the phone companies would have paid in the open market. Plus, the telephone companies were not required to buy from Materiel, and spent less than half their purchasing dollars with it, NYNEX said. NYNEX also said it followed FCC accounting practices regarding how telephone companies recorded purchases from affiliates. ``Prior to 1988, the only requirement was that carriers be able to demonstrate, if requested to do so in a ratemaking proceeding, that affiliate transaction charges were reasonable,'' NYNEX wrote in its response to the FCC. ``The NYNEX telephone companies have always been prepared to do this.'' The FCC had no immediate reaction, said spokeswoman Maureen Peratino. The commission will review NYNEX's response and issue a further order, which could uphold, reduce or do away with the fines, she said. NYNEX, if it is still dissatisfided, may seek court review, she added. The FCC said the three companies engaged in a series of transactions from 1984 to 1988 designed to increase the overall profits of NYNEX at customer expense. The commission conducted an audit which found that New York Telephone and New England Telephone purchased supplies and equipment from Materiel at prices that were inflated by $118.5 million. Approximately $35 million of these extra costs were passed along to interstate customers, the FCC said. But on Monday, NYNEX said its subsidiaries earned some $350 million less than they were authorized under applicable federal tariffs. ``Thus interstate ratepayers have suffered no overcharges as a result of the (Materiel) transactions,'' NYNEX said. Thus, the refunds can only be viewed as further penalties, said Morrison DeS. Webb, NYNEX's vice president for government affairs.

DOC.HEAD: Disney Plans Huge Mall, Residential Project
DOC.TEXT: Walt Disney Co. hopes to use its talent for enchantment by turning 4,000 acres of swampland and cow pastures in Central Florida into the planned community of adult dreams. The giant entertainment and theme park company unveiled plans Monday to build a massive upscale shopping mall, office complexes and thousands of single-family homes and apartments as part of a development project that could take the next 25 years to complete. Outlining the company's plans at an annual public meeting, Disney Attractions President Dick Nunis said the project would be as ``new and innovative as the opening of Disneyland and Walt Disney World,'' adding that construction could be under way within five years. The development, which would be Disney's first on property it owns in Osceola County, is located about halfway between downtown Orlando and Tampa and is surrounded by 6,000 acres of greenbelt, Nunis said. Details, however, were sketchy. The mall, expected to be Central Florida's largest at about 1.5 million square feet, would house exclusive department and specialty stores. But the number of housing units and the amount of commercial office space to be developed were not disclosed. County officials said last week that Disney told them it plans to build up to 6,000 middle-income and executive-type houses with a starting price of $90,000. But Nunis said, ``I don't have a crystal ball that those other guys do.'' He also declined to comment on reports of office space totaling 7 million square feet _ the equivalent of ten 35-story buildings. In addition to that space, local officials said they were told the plans include more than a million square feet of light-industrial office and manufacturing space, one or two golf courses and recreation areas. The property would be de-annexed from Disney's 27,400-acre resort in Central Florida and turned over to Osceola County, which would be a partner in its development, Nunis told an audience of government officials, businessmen and local residents. That way Disney would pay _ for the first time _ county impact fees for water, sewers, roads and other services. So far all Disney development has been controlled by the company's own Reedy Creek Improvement District, a special district created by the 1969 Florida Legislature that gives the company much autonomy over its acreage. Disney has been criticized by local government officials, who contend the company's property taxes are not enough to pay for the impact it is having on mushrooming growth surrounding its theme parks, hotels and resort sites. Nunis figures a regional impact review would take about a year and a half. After that, ``We will make an announcement on groundbreaking and proceed from there.'' Most county officials were enthusiastic when they first heard of the plans last week. ``This allows us to plan for development now, instead of 20 years from now ... And to be sure that we can pay for the services that are going to be needed,'' said County Commissioner Jim Swan. Nunis also said the project would have plenty of room for ``a multi-modal transportation station, that can include a high-speed train planned by the state, and other forms of transportation.'' He said Disney was a strong supporter of higher gas taxes and tolls to pay for Florida roads and said he did not believe that this would hurt tourism.

DOC.HEAD: Cabinet, Business Community Rally Behind Trade Reforms
DOC.TEXT: Japan's most powerful business group on Tuesday echoed Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu's call for sweeping Japanese economic reforms, as U.S. Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher arrived in Tokyo for trade talks. Meanwhile, the Finance Ministry reported Japan's overall trade surplus fell to $5 billion in February, down from $7.23 billion a year ago _ the 10th straight monthly decline. Japan's surplus with the United States fell to $2.97 billion from $4.15 billion a year earlier, it said. The Federation of Economic Organizations, which represents Japan's largest corporations in a wide range of industries, said it suported Kaifu's efforts to meet U.S. demands for economic reforms aimed at reducing the $49 billion overall U.S. trade deficit with Japan. ``It is necessary to tackle (these reforms) to the extent that they constructively aid the sound development of the economies in both countries,'' the group, known as Keidanren, said in a statement. Keidanren officials said the annoucement reflected the opinion of the group's entire membership. As Mosbacher arrived with other top Commerce Department officials for talks on trade disputes, a consensus of support for structural reforms aimed at reducing the trade imbalance appeared to be building. Foreign Minister Taro Nakayama, Finance Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto and Minister of International Trade and Industry Kabun Muto said the changes being discussed in trade talks called the Structural Impediments Initiative were Japan's most important political task. ``We should realize that this issue amounts to crisis management in Japan-U.S. ties. Discontent within the U.S. Congress is surging and is on the verge of explosion,'' Nakayama said. Both U.S. and Japanese officials agree that the trade imbalance is gradually falling, but Washington faces election-year pressures from Congress and is seeking faster progress in reducing its deficit with Japan. Mosbacher, who traveled to Tokyo at the request of President Bush, was to meet with Kaifu, other government officials, and industry leaders to discuss specific trade issues and promote U.S. exports and investment in Japan before returning to Washington Friday. Kaifu is struggling to show substantive progress in promised economic reforms before early April.

DOC.HEAD: Otaiba For Maintaining 18-dollar OPEC Reference Price
DOC.TEXT: Oil Minister Mana Saeed al-Otaiba called Tuesday for maintaining OPEC's current $18-a-barrel reference price. ``Current oil prices are now fluctuating between $18 and $20 and that is the ideal level I myself like to see,'' the United Arab Emirates minister told an oil seminar in Abu Dhabi. The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, of which the U.A.E. is a member, has been adjusting production ceilings for its 13 member states to stabilize prices around $18 a 42-gallon barrel. Some OPEC member states, led by Iraq, favor an increase of the reference price to $20. But Iraqi Oil Minister Issam al-Chalabi also said in a recent interview that the issue was unlikely to come up at the March 16 OPEC market monitoring committee meeting in Vienna. Otaiba said that fixing price levels at current rates, along with respecting OPEC's production quota, would give the market the chance to consolidate and allow OPEC after 1991 to raise prices to ``a very reasonable level,'' Otaiba said. The U.A.E., however, is the only country that rejected its daily quota of 1.095 million barrels for the first half of 1990, and has pledged to produce at the rate of 2 million barrels per day. The cartel's production level of about 23.5 million barrels per day is above the OPEC target.

DOC.HEAD: London Shares Slightly Lower at Midday
DOC.NOTE: Eds: will be led after closing
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices fell slightly in sluggish trading at midday Tuesday. At about noon local time, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index was off 2.8 points at 2,220.0. It was above its morning low of 2,213.4 but below its peak of 2,224.1. Midday volume totaled 177.9 million shares, up from 152.6 million the same time Monday. Caution over the budget, sterling's decline and the political uncertainty gripping Britain continues to sideline investors, dealers said. Investors are ``waiting to see what happens next week before piling in,'' a trader said.

DOC.HEAD: Grand Met Announces Deal With Elders
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inntrepreneur 6th graf and following grafs cq
DOC.TEXT: Grand Metropolitan PLC, the British food and drinks group, confirmed Tuesday that it was selling most of its breweries to Elders IXL Ltd. and that the two companies would jointly operate about 5,000 pubs. The deal will make Australia-based Elders Britain's second largest brewer after Bass PLC. Elders, the world's fourth largest brewer and best known for its Fosters beer brand, disclosed Friday that it had reached an ``understanding'' with Grand Met and that an announcement was due shortly. The company also had announced it was selling or spinning off its agribusiness, finance, natural resources and other interests to focus on its brewing business. Elders, through its British unit Courage Holdings PLC, is to pay $586 million for four Grand Met breweries. Elders is also due to obtain Grand Met's local brewing and distribution rights to several non-British brands, including Carlsberg and Budweiser. At the same time, the two companies plan to merge their pub businesses into a single company, to be called Inntrepreneur Estates. The new company, to be owned equally, will combine Elders' 4,940 pubs and Grand Met's 3,570. But Inntrepreneur plans to sell 1,500 Elders pubs to raise $480 million. Another 2,000 pubs will be released from their obligations to buy beer supplied by the parent companies over the next two years. These moves will drop the number of pubs under Inntrepreneur's control to 5,000, a level in line with the recently modified British brewing industry regulations. The regulations were changed last year to encourage the country's biggest brewing groups to focus on one side of the industry or the other. Grand Met has said it wanted to sell its brewing business to concentrate on beer retailing. The company, which owns Pillsbury Co. of the United States, said its strengths lie in the sale of branded food, drinks and retail goods internationally.

DOC.HEAD: Retail Sales Fell 0.9 Percent in February
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf pvs, The incentives ..., to CORRECT statement that sales fell in January. A version moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Retail sales fell 0.9 percent in February, the sharpest decline since last October, the government reported today. The Commerce Department said sales totaled a seasonally adjusted $146.5 billion after rising a revised 2.8 percent in January. Sales dropped off 1.3 percent last October, rose 0.7 percent in November and then slipped 0.3 percent in December. Much of January's strength, which originally was reported to be a 1.6 percent gain, came from a 9.9 percent jump in automobile sales after cash rebates and low-interest financing were restored to attract prospective buyers to dealer showrooms. The incentives remained in effect in February, but nevertheless sales fell 6.0 percent. It was the biggest drop since auto sales fell 26.5 percent in January 1987. Automobiles represent about 20 percent of retail sales. Excluding autos, retail sales rose 0.5 percent in February. Retail sales, representing about one-third of the nation's economic activity, are watched as a barometer of economic growth. The construction and much of the manufacturing sectors of the economy have been battered by high interest rates as the Federal Reserve kept a tight rein on credit to cap inflation. Sales of durable goods _ big-ticket items expected to last more than three years _ dropped 3.0 percent last month after advancing 6.7 percent in January. Building materials rose 1.4 percent after a 2.2 percent gain a month earlier. Furniture and other home furnishings rose 0.5 percent following a 3.6 percent increase in January. Sales of non-durable goods such as food and clothing rose 0.4 percent, down slightly from a 0.5 percent increase in January. Gains were posted by department stores, up 2.0 percent; apparel stores, up 1.6 percent; restaurants and bars, up 1.4 percent, and grocery stores, up 0.5 percent. Declines included gasoline stations and drug stores, both down 0.8 percent. For the three months from December through February, overall retail sales were up 1.2 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Roberts Returns to GM from Navistar
DOC.TEXT: Roy Roberts, who left General Motors Corp. to run Navistar International Corp.'s truck operations for 19 months, is returning to the automaker as general manager for Cadillac manufacturing. Roberts, 50, joined GM in 1977 and rose through manufacturing operations to become plant manager at GM's North Tarrytown, N.Y., assembly plant in 1985. For the year before he left for the Navistar job in 1988, Roberts was GM's vice president in charge of personnel administration. At the time, he was the automaker's highest ranking black. GM currently has no black vice presidents.

DOC.HEAD: Folcini Resigns From Central Bank
DOC.TEXT: Central Bank President Enrique Folcini has resigned after less than three months on the job, a spokesman for the bank confirmed Tuesday. Folcini, who replaced Rodolfo Rossi on Jan. 23, was the bank's fourth chief in the eight months since Carlos Menem took over as president. During his tenure, interest rates soared to near 30 percent a day, and the austral was devalued from about 1,800 per $1 to $6,000 per $1. Folcini offered his resignation to Economy Minister Antonio Gonzalez on March 7, and stepped down on Monday after a week passed with no ruling from Gonzalez, bank spokesman Alvaro Otero said. The man who may replace Folcini, according to the most respected newspapers in the capital, is Javier Gonzalez Fraga, Menem's first Central Bank president.

Prices fell in early trading on Wall Street today as stock traders took their cues from the bond market. The Dow Jones industrial average was off 2.93 to 2,683.78 as of 10 a.m. EST. Declining issues were ahead of advancers by a margin of more than 2 to 1, with 323 stocks rising, 657 falling and 508 unchanged on the New York Stock Exchange. Volume on the Big Board came to 21.28 million shares after the first half-hour of trading. Analysts said Wall Street was following the lead of the bond market, which slumped after the Commerce Department reported that retail sales skidded 0.9 percent in February. DOC.HEAD: Bush Says He'll Negotiate With Democrats On Deficit Reduction
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs; no pickup. A version moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush declared today he is ``prepared to negotiate'' with congressional Democrats for a comprehensive package to cut the federal deficit, but insisted he won't abandon his opposition to tax increases. Bush praised Rep. Dan Rostenkowski, D-Ill., for making a ``very broad proposal'' in coming out with a far-reaching package that would include both higher taxes and a freeze on Social Security. The administration surprised some Democratic lawmakers Monday by being unexpectedly receptive to the proposal by the Democratic chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee. ``I was, in being receptive, somewhat colored by the way in which chairman Rostenkowski approached this, the evident good will on his part to break the ice and move the process forward,'' Bush said today. Congressional Democrats had welcomed the White House's conciliatory words about Rostenkowski's dramatic deficit reduction plan while claiming outright administration support is what is really needed _ something they didn't get from Bush. The president told a news conference in the White House briefing room he would not embrace Rostenkowski's plan for new taxes. ``I'm not for a tax increase,'' he said, adding that there were many other parts of the Rostenkowski package he also did not support. Asked if he could assure the American people that taxes would not be raised as part of a deficit-reduction scheme, Bush said: ``I'm only one player. But you know my position. I have no intention of changing that position.'' When pressed and asked under what circumstances he might support a tax increase, the president retorted: ``Too hypothetical. Nice try.'' ``I don't want to appear inflexible, but I'm not about to stand here and give him, Dan, or the Congress, the idea that I'm going to accept everything in their approach,'' Bush said. Still, he added, ``We're prepared to negotiate.'' Summing up action on the deficit, Bush noted that Rostenkowski had proposed his plan, ``we've thrown our idea out'' with the fiscal 1991 budget, and now ``we'd like the budget leaders on the Hill to throw theirs out.'' White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater on Monday said, ``We want to consider this plan.'' Richard Darman, President Bush's budget director, called the package ``a courageous initiative, a serious initiative.'' Speaking on public television's ``MacNeil-Lehrer NewsHour'' Monday night, Darman said, ``At least there's a whole package here to start a serious debate with.'' The White House reaction to the Illinois Democrat's proposal produced the first glimmer of hope that real progress could be made this year in shrinking the budget deficit. The Congressional Budget Office projects the shortfall in fiscal 1991 _ which begins Oct. 1 _ will be $161 billion. The administration's words left a hopeful but wary feeling among Democrats, who have been sensitized to the dangers of leading the way in advocating tax increases by three consecutive presidential election defeats. Citing Bush's ability to veto Rostenkowski's package and embarrass Democrats who backed it, House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., said, ``Without assurances it will be signed, it will be difficult to pass.'' Rep. Leon Panetta, D-Calif., chairman of the House Budget Committee, said two components of Rostenkowski's proposal _ tax increases and a one-year freeze on cost-of-living increases in Social Security benefits _ would be ``very huge political barriers'' to overcome. ``Those are very sensitive political issues that would be very difficult to accomplish within Congress unless there's a clear recognition that the president will join hands with them on the issue,'' Panetta said. Nonetheless, lawmakers of both parties said they hoped this could eventually lead to serious efforts to reduce the federal deficit. ``Dan Rostenkowski has correctly challenged Congress, the administration and the American people to face up to public enemy No. 1: the federal deficit,'' said Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan. ``In testimony ... this year, the president's representatives have suggested that there may be room to negotiate on deficit reduction,'' said Sen. Lloyd Bentsen, D-Texas, chairman of the tax-writing Senate Finance Committee. ``If that's right, now's the time for them to come forward.'' On Sunday, Rostenkowski _ whose committee oversees taxes, Social Security and other federal benefit programs _ suggested a package he said would reduce next year's deficit to $106 billion and lead to a $2 billion surplus by fiscal 1994. Over the five years ending in 1995, he said, the plan would save $512 billion from currently projected deficits. ``There are some political mine fields here, there's no question about it,'' acknowledged Rostenkowski, who appeared on the same program as Darman. Rostenkowski would shrink the defense budget by 3 percent annually, about 1 percent more than current administration plans. He would freeze domestic spending for one year, including cost-of-living increases for the 39 million recipients of Social Security, but exempt many benefit programs for the poor. The 33 percent income tax rate would be extended to the nation's 600,000 wealthiest taxpayers, who now pay a 28 percent rate. Federal taxes on cigarettes, beer, wine and gasoline tax would increase, among other steps. Darman conceded that the administration differed with elements of Rostenkowski's plan, especially its tax increases and Social Security reductions. But he added, ``This plan has only been out here 24 hours now, and I don't think it's constructive on our part to sit around and pick at parts.'' Others weren't reluctant to be negative. Sen. James Sasser, D-Tenn., chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, chided the administration for its ``unserious'' $1.24 trillion budget released in January. ``This newfound desire on the part of the White House to negotiate on the basis of a lone Democrat's call for tax increases and domestic spending cuts should be taken for what it is: political opportunism,'' Sasser said. Sen. William V. Roth Jr., R-Del., a member of the Finance Committee, called Rostenkowski's plan ``dead on arrival,'' adding, ``It's just more or less a warmed-over version of what's been proposed in the past.''

DOC.HEAD: Trade Deficit Declines
Combines pvs; no pickup. A version moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The deficit in the broadest measure of U.S. trade declined to $105.89 billion last year, the smallest in five years, aided by higher merchandise exports and increased foreign travel, the government said today. The Commerce Department said that the current account deficit shrank 16.3 percent from a $126.55 billion imbalance in 1988. However, even with the improvement, the current account deficit remained above $100 billion for the sixth consecutive year. The 1989 total was the lowest since a $104.19 billion deficit in 1984. The year ended on a positive note as the October-December deficit declined to $20.57 billion, down 10.2 percent from the third quarter, and the smallest quarterly imbalance in almost six years. The current account, also known as the balance of payments, is the most important trade statistic because it measures not only the flow of merchandise across borders but also trade in services and investments. The United States ended the 1980s in a far different position than it began the decade. In 1980, there was a small surplus in the nation's current account. America was the world's largest creditor country and its earnings on overseas investments were enough to offset perennial deficits in merchandise trade. However, as Americans transferred billions of dollars into foreign hands to pay for merchandise imports, the investment cushion shrank rapidly and disappeared altogether in 1985, when the United States became a net debtor for the first time in 71 years. America's debtor position stood at $532.5 billion at the end of 1988 and today's report indicates that it grew to around $630 billion last year. The exact accounting of this figure will not be released until later in the year. The growing foreign ownership in America has triggered a heated debate over whether America is losing control of its economic destiny to foreigners. Some economists predict that the current account deficit could actually begin rising again this year, reflecting a higher dependence on foreign oil and more sluggish sales of U.S. exports. That development would spell bad news for the Bush administration, which is counting on further improvements in trade to bolster America's flagging industrial sector and add to domestic economic growth this year. For 1989, the merchandise trade portion of the current account shrank by 11 percent to $113.25 billion as growth in U.S. exports outpaced a continued rise in imports. The surplus in the services and investment category jumped by 41.3 percent to $21.65 billion, up from $15.32 billion, reflecting increased foreign travel in the United States and higher earnings by U.S. companies operating abroad. The third segment of the current account,U.S. foreign aid and pension payments to Americans living aboard, added $14.28 billion to the deficit last year. In the fourth quarter, the $20.57 billion deficit compared to a $22.91 billion deficit in the third quarter. The 10.2 percent improvement reflected a slight improvement in merchandise trade, where the deficit narrowed by 0.9 percent to $28.81 billion. There was a big 39.2 percent increase in the surplus in the services and investment category, which climbed to $12.71 billion. This increased reflected in large part a drop in the value of the dollar during the quarter, which boosted the foreign earnings of American companies operating abroad when that income was translated back into dollars. Foreign aid and pension payments were up 28 percent in the quarter to $4.48 billion. Despite the improvement last year and in the fourth quarter in particular, many economists believe that the U.S. net debtor position will climb above $1 trillion sometime in the 1990s. Analysts fear that this will cause a decline in U.S. living standards as financing the growing foreign debt burden will make less money available in this country for productive investment.

DOC.HEAD: Maurice and Charles Saatchi Take 30 Percent Salary Cuts
DOC.TEXT: Saatchi and Saatchi Co. PLC today announced 30 percent salary cuts for founders Charles and Maurice Saatchi and several other steps designed to help turn around the troubled British advertising agency. Maurice Saatchi, who is chairman of Saatchi's board of directors, and, Charles Saatchi, a director, will see their annual salaries cut to about $699,000 from $1 million. Other board members are to take a 10 percent cut to help raise cost-consciousness at the company, Saatchi said at its annual shareholders meeting. Saatchi also announced the appointment of two Americans to its board of directors, Harvard University business professor Theodore Levitt and Tom Russell, chairman of Applied Bioscience International Inc. of New Jersey. Saatchi also said it was close to completing the sale of its major consulting businesses, and announced it agreed to sell the U.S. agency McCaffrey and McCall to its management for an undisclosed price. Madison Avenue has been speculating about the McCaffrey and McCall sale for the past several months. Saatchi also confirmed its strategy of focusing on its communications business and disposing of those consulting businesses, which it has been trying to do for about a year. So far, its has sold four small firms for $38 million. Saatchi said dismantling the communications group, with the exception of the McCaffrey and McCall sale, would not be in the interest of shareholders. There has been speculation in the British press that Saatchi might reluctantly sell off chunks, perhaps its U.S. ad agency Backer and Spielvogel, which it bought in 1986 for $56 million. Maurice Saatchi told shareholders, ``This is a difficult time. In any difficult situation one has a choice: fight or flight. We are determined to win.'' Saatchi lost $94 million in its fiscal year ended Sept. 30, and its share price has fallen sharply in recent months. Saatchi shares were trading at around $2.30 on London's Stock Exchange by late Tuesday, down sharply from its 12-month high of $6.74. Analysts blame the company's problems on its expensive diversification into consulting during the mid-1980s, weak financial controls and a period of slow growth in the advertising industry.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Trade Surplus Falls 30 Percent in February
With BC-Japan-US Trade
DOC.TEXT: Japan's trade surplus fell 30 percent in February to $5 billion from $7.23 billion a year earlier, the Ministry of Finance reported Tuesday. It was the 10th consecutive month of year-on-year declines in Japan's trade surplus, but was substantially higher than January's revised surplus of $338 million. Japan's surplus with the United States shrank 28.5 percent to $2.96 billion in February from $4.14 billion a year earlier, the ministry said. In recent months, higher international oil prices and strong domestic demand have boosted the value of imports while growing overseas production by Japanese manufacturers has helped hold back export growth. In February, exports fell 1.9 percent from a year earlier to $21.9 billion for the fifth consecutive decline, the ministry said. Imports rose 11.9 percent to $16.9 billion, it said. Officials of the Ministry of International Trade and Industry attributed the rise in imports largely to increased purchases of food products, raw materials and industrial products. The decline in Japan's trade surplus with the United States resulted from a 5.9 percent drop in exports to the United States, to $7.12 billion, and a 21.4 percent rise in imports, to $4.15 billion, the ministry said. Japan's surplus with the European Community edged down to $1.88 billion from $1.89 billion a year earlier. Japan measures its trade balance on a customs-clearance basis, in which freight and insurance costs are included in import figures but not in exports.

DOC.HEAD: Bus Hit By Gunfire in Chicago, Greyhound Chairman Rides Bus
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads throughout to UPDATE with Bush comments, CORRECT Gravely to Gravley, and UPDATE with union comment, edits to trim. No pickup. A version moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The chairman of strike-crippled Greyhound visited hospitalized passengers, offered a $25,000 reward for information on a sniper and rode a bus to prove it safe, but early today more bullets hit a Greyhound bus in Chicago. No injuries were reported in today's shooting on Interstate 57 on Chicago's far South Side. A company spokesman said it was the seventh such incident since a drivers' strike began March 2. Greyhound executive Fred G. Currey crisscrossed Florida on Monday, seeking to calm fears about bus travel after a sniper's bullet Sunday hit a Greyhound bus operated by a replacement driver in Jacksonville, Fla., injuring eight passengers. President Bush, while answering a question about baseball's labor dispute, said today that he was reluctant to have the federal government intervene in collective bargaining matters. He said that approach was not proper for the baseball talks but ``on some issues that could well serve to be a prospect.'' A Labor Department official, however, said there were no plans for direct government intervention in the Greyhound talks. In Chicago, four shots hit the bus and one bullet, believed to be from a 9mm handgun, was recovered, said Trooper Brian Williams. The 13 passengers aboard continued their journey on another Memphis, Tenn.-bound bus. Company spokesman George Gravley said it was the third shooting incident in Chicago since the first day of the strike, when shots were fired at a bus and a terminal. Other shootings occurred in Ohio, Arizona, Florida and Connecticut. Gravley said there was nothing to connect the the shooting to the strike, ``but we don't have buses shot at when we're not negotiating a contract.'' Gravley said the union has rejected a call from Greyhound officials ``to join with us in a joint effort to deplore the violence and restore peace.'' A union official today said he didn't think strikers were to blame. ``I have told (striking workers) thousands of times that we do not, will not, and never will condone this kind of violence,'' said William Pearsall, vice president of the Amalgamated Transit Union's Local 1303, which represents the Chicago area. Currey rode a Greyhound bus from Jacksonville to Orlando, Fla., then took a plane to Miami, where he said he was pessimistic about the chances of a settlement any time soon. The union, representing 6,300 drivers and more than 3,000 office and maintenance workers, went on strike over pay and job security. ``We will not bend or move because of intimidation and violence,'' said the chairman of America's only nationwide bus service. The strike has been marked by scattered violence, including a striker crushed to death by a bus operated by a replacement driver in Redding, Calif. A Greyhound bus heading into Hartford, Conn., with 19 passengers was hit by sniper fire Monday. No one was hurt. In Jacksonville, passsengers were hit by shrapnel and other debris. Greyhound officials quickly responded to prevent a public relations fiasco. Currey, Greyhound chairman and chief executive officer, and Frank Schmeider, its president, flew to Jacksonville early Monday from Dallas, visiting the three passengers still hospitalized. They also visited bus riders who were put up by the company in a Jacksonville hotel overnight. One hospitalized passenger, Michael Rogers of Atlanta, was critical of the company. ``I don't think they should run their lines while they're having a situation like this going on,'' he said. ``Or at least warn the general public that a situation like that might occur.'' In Orlando, Currey criticized union leaders for not speaking out against intimidation. ``Their silence is deafening,'' he said. Asked why he rode the bus, he said: ``I took the trip because I thought it was important for Greyhound people not to be intimidated.'' In Washington federal mediators met for three hours Monday for ``an exploratory, informal meeting'' with union officials. Jim Power, a spokesman for the Federal Mediation Service, said the union ``agreed to the possibility of additional meetings with the mediation service and management to start the collective bargaining process again.'' Greyhound, which serves 9,600 U.S. communities, is operating with replacement drivers and breakaway union members. It said its number of passengers Sunday amounted to nearly 36 percent of the same day last year.

DOC.HEAD: Survey Says Small Manufacturers Expects 1990 Sales Drop
DOC.TEXT: Executives from small manufacturing companies expect a sales decline and flat profits this year, according to a trade group survey released Tuesday. The executives, who head firms with 500 or fewer employees, also anticipate tighter credit and expect to reduce their investment spending, the National Association of Manufacturers said. ``For most members, it appears that sales are starting to move downward,'' said J. Walter Kisling, chairman of the group's Small Manufacturer's Forum. Kisling heads Multiplex Company Inc., a manufacturer of drink dispensing equipment in Ballwin, Mo. The survey of 2,531 executives showed that 40 percent expected flat or declining sales, up from 25 percent who were pessimistic a year ago. Sixty-two percent anticipated steady or falling profits, up from 47 percent. Sixty percent looked ahead to investing the same or less to improve their business, up from 44 percent. Fourteen percent said it was more difficult to obtain financing, up from 8 percent a year earlier. The association also said 72 percent of the executives reported that less than 5 percent of their companies' revenues came from exports, a modest improvement from 78 percent last year. ``It is clear that small manufacturers aren't entering the global economy as fast as they ought to be, or as fast as they can,'' Kisling said. Jerry Jasinowski, president of the trade group, called on the federal government to do more to help small firms export. Federal spending on export assistance is ``so modest ... it's almost off the chart,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Supreme Court Approves Interim Relief to Bhopal Gas Victims
DOC.TEXT: India's Supreme Court on Tuesday approved a government plan to pay interim compensation of $12 per month to each of the 500,000 people living near the site of the 1984 Bhopal gas disaster. The Supreme Court also ruled that the government must pay $44 per month to the 3,110 people left totally disabled by the toxic gas leak. The government decided March 5 to pay interim compensation to the victims of the gas leak at the Union Carbide Corp.'s Bhopal pesticide plant pending the outcome of legal battles with the U.S.-based multinational. The December 1984 toxic gas leak killed 3,598 people and injured 20,000.

DOC.HEAD: Promotional Campaign Includes Cash for Reporters
DOC.TEXT: Seeking to get the word out about its latest promotion _ soft drink cans stuffed with prizes _ Coca-Cola Co. this week sent 200 reporters the real thing: samples containing $5 bills. Newsrooms are frequent recipients of promotional items sent from companies trying to get a little publicity. But cash from a major corporation is unusual. The ``Magic Summer'' campaign to promote Coca-Cola Classic will include 750,000 randomly distributed cans, which appear to be regular cans of Coke but when opened reveal a mechanism holding up to $200 in cash or a certificate for a variety of other prizes. Bob Bertini, a spokesman for Coca-Cola USA, said the company on Monday sent the reporters cans with $5 bills _ the smallest denomination in the campaign _ merely to demonstrate the promotion. ``We sent it to a very small group of national writers. The reporters can't write about it without seeing it,'' Bertini said. Many news organizations have policies against reporters receiving gifts of value from news sources. Bertini said the company is urging reporters who received the money to donate it to charity.
