DOC.HEAD: Asarco Challenges Sale of Freeport-McMoran Gold
DOC.TEXT: Asarco Inc. has filed a suit challenging the proposed sale of Freeport-McMoran Gold Co. to South African-controlled Minorco SA for $705 million, or $17 a share. In its suit filed in New York Supreme Court, Asarco said its interest in a joint venture with Freeport-McMoran could be violated by the sale. New York-based Asarco said it is asking the judge to halt completion of the sale until Asarco's interests have been fully protected. Minorco's tender offer for Freeport-McMoran expires March 23. Asarco and Freeport-McMoran each have a 50 percent interest in the Santa Cruz copper mining research project near Casa Grande, Ariz. The federal government is funding 75 percent of the project, which is designed to test a method of extracting copper from a deep underground formation. Freeport-McMoran said Asarco's suit is without merit and will be vigorously contested. On Feb. 20, Freeport-McMoran announced the sale of Freeport-McMoran Gold Co. to Minorco, which is controlled by De Beers Consolidated Mines Ltd. of South Africa and the associated Anglo American Corp. Proceeds from the sale would be used to develop a sulfur discovery in the Gulf of Mexico, the company said. Minorco failed last year in a hostile takeover bid for Consolidated Gold Fields PLC, a British mining company. The proposed sale of Freeport-McMoran Gold is part of a far-reaching asset sale by its parent, New Orleans-based Freeport-McMoran. The parent is ridding itself of operations purchased in the 1980s to pay off debt and to focus the company on phosphate fertilizers, metals and Gulf of Mexico oil and natural gas.
Stock prices moved broadly lower today as Wall Street took its cue from a sharp decline in bond prices. Five minutes before the close, the Dow Jones industrial average was down 12.61 to 2,674.10.

DOC.HEAD: Ad Conglomerate Takes Steps to Reassure Shareholders
DOC.TEXT: Saatchi & Saatchi Co. PLC took steps Tuesday to reassure its shareholders that it was working to overcome its recent financial problems, announcing 30 percent salary cuts for its founders, naming two Americans to its board and saying it was close to selling its consulting businesses. Maurice Saatchi, who founded the company with his brother Charles and serves as its chairman, told some 400 shareholders at their annual meeting, ``This is a difficult time. In any difficult situation one has a choice: fight or flight. We are determined to win.'' Analysts' reaction to the strategy was mixed, with some saying the company was weak and others saying it was taking proper steps. The company has been battered by an expensive diversification into consulting during the mid-1980s, weak financial controls and a period of slow growth in the advertising industry. For its fiscal year ended Sept. 30, Saatchi suffered an after-tax loss of 58.5 million pounds, or $94 million. Saatchi already has taken measures to turn itself around, including naming a new chief executive and finance director and slashing hundreds of jobs. Founders Maurice and Charles Saatchi, who serves as a director, will see their salaries cut to about 437,000 pounds, or $699,000, from 625,000 pounds, or $1 million, a year. Other members of the boards of directors also are to take 10 percent salary cuts as part of the effort to raise cost-consciousness at the company, Saatchi said. The two Americans appointed to the board are Harvard University business professor Theodore Levitt and Tom Russell, chairman of Applied Bioscience International Inc. of East Millstone, N.J. Robert Louis-Dreyfus, who replaced Maurice Saatchi as chief executive at the beginning of the year, said Saatchi's attempts to sell the Hay Group, its largest consulting division, and CPC Corporate Planners and Coordinators Inc. were ``well on the way to completion.'' Saatchi also is ``in serious negotiations on all of the consulting companies,'' he said. Total proceeds from the sales are expected to be about 80 million pounds to 100 million pounds _ $128 million to $160 million _ this year, he said. Saatchi confirmed its strategy of focusing on its communications business and disposing of its consulting businesses, which it has been trying to do for about a year. So far its has sold four small firms for $38 million. Saatchi also said it has reached an agreement to sell the U.S. ad agency McCaffrey and McCall to the agency's management for an undisclosed price at an undetermined time. The sale has been rumored for months. In New York, Robert Cherins, McCaffrey's chairman and chief executive, said ``some issues'' remain to be resolved before the sale can be completed. He declined to elaborate. The agency, based in New York, handles about $300 million a year in ad billings and employs more than 300 people. It was acquired by Saatchi in 1983 and its clients include Mercedez-Benz automobiles, Air Canada, Tiffany jewelry, Bacardi rums and the consumer products division of Burroughs Wellcome Co. Saatchi said dismantling the communications group would not be in the interest of shareholders, except for the McCaffrey and McCall deal. There has been speculation in the British media that Saatchi might sell other parts of its ad empire. The new chief executive also said: ``I want to stress that we are not looking for an injection of new equity from a friendly outside party.'' Southeastern Asset Management Inc., a Memphis, Tenn.-based investment company, has built up an 11.2 percent stake in Saatchi.

DOC.HEAD: Stock Prices Follow Bond Market Lower
DOC.TEXT: Prices closed broadly lower on Wall Street today, depressed by a new round of interest rate concerns. The stock market opened lower and then tried to shake off a decline in the bond market, which skidded following a Commerce Department report that retail sales fell 0.9 percent in February. But when the credit market's slide steepened, stock prices followed suit. The Treasury's bellwether 30-year bond was down $11.25 for each $1,000 in face amount by the time trading ended on Wall Street, while its yield shot up to 8.71 percent from 8.61 percent late Monday. The retail sales drop was the steepest in four months, but analysts said the decline was due almost entirely to sagging automobiles sales and that other segments experienced healthy increases. The report was seen as a sign of economic health, and as such a signal that the Federal Reserve was unlikely to move interest rates lower anytime soon. Stock traders were also uneasy about the rise in credit market yields, which affect other interest rates.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Trump Shuttle Offering Guarantees of On-Time Flights
DOC.TEXT: Trump Shuttle announced Tuesday it is offering an ``unconditional'' guarantee that its hourly flights will arrive promptly, or customers will be compensated. Trump Shuttle, the northeast airline service named after the real estate tycoon who bought it last spring, said the guarantee will be available starting Wednesday through March 31. If a flight arrives more than 15 minutes later than scheduled arrival, passengers will have a choice of three premiums: 5,000 bonus frequent-flier miles for their next Trump Shuttle flight, a free companion ticket for their next weekend shuttle flight or a $20 American Express restaurant certificate. The guarantee also covers late arrivals due to weather conditions or other factors beyond the airline's control. ``We are able to make this unusual offer to our customers because we have an outstanding on-time arrival record,'' Trump Shuttle President Bruce Nobles said in a statement. He said the airline's flights, which link New York with Boston and Washington, arrive within 15 minutes of schedule more than 90 percent of the time, despite difficult weather and crowded airports. Billionaire developer Donald Trump bought the shuttle service from Eastern Airlines for $365 million last June. Pan Am Corp., which operates a rival shuttle service, doesn't plan to match the guarantee offer, said spokeswoman Elizabeth Manners. ``We feel that passengers expect that Pan Am flights will arrive on time,'' she said. So far this month, 95 percent of Pan Am's shuttle flights have arrived within 15 minutes of schedule, Ms. Manners said. Both shuttle services, which are geared mainly to business travelers, raised their one-way weekday fares by 20 percent, from $99 to $119, on Jan. 3.

DOC.HEAD: Former GM Rising Star Returning After Stint At Navistar
DOC.TEXT: A year and a half after leaving a career as one of General Motors Corp.'s brightest stars, Roy S. Roberts is coming back. Roberts, who left the automaker to head Navistar International Corp.'s truck manufacturing operations, returns to GM April 1 as general manager for manufacturing at the Cadillac Division. Roberts, 50, left GM in August 1988after an 11-year career in which he earned a reputation as a dynamic leader with respect for human values and a position as the highest-ranking black executive at the industrial giant. At Navistar, Roberts was the No. 3 executive of the Fortune 500 manufacturer, in charge of a truck division that was the North American leader. But he couldn't bypass the opportunity presented at GM. ``My business roots are at GM,'' Roberts said. ``When I was there, I spent most of my time in operations, that's where most of my abilities are concentrated. ``When this job came open, I realized it was where I wanted to be,'' he said Monday from Navistar headquarters in Chicago. Roberts did not return a telephone message left for him Tuesday at Navistar headquarters. GM reportedly is considering consolidating all manufacturing of its luxury cars at its plant in the Detroit enclave of Hamtramck. All Cadillacs now are assembled there except the Brougham, which is made in Arlington, Texas, and the De Ville and Fleetwood sedan, which are made near Pontiac, Mich. As director of manufacturing, Roberts would be centrally involved in any move of Cadillac production to one location. ``All my life I've wanted to make sure I was doing a job that had challenges,'' Roberts said. ``You look at the luxury car business and it's getting to be one of the most competitive turfs in this country, and we want to take that on.'' Roberts joined GM in 1977 as a salaried employee in training at the former Diesel Equipment Division in Grand Rapids, Mich. In 1981, he was promoted to plant manager in Grand Rapids and two years later, was transferred to Rochester, N.Y., as Rochester Products Division's eastern operations manager. He rose through plant management ranks to take charge of GM's North Tarrytown, N.Y., assembly plant in December 1985. He has been credited with saving that plant and about 4,000 jobs by convincing upper-level management to build GM's new plastic-body minivans there. On April 1, 1987 he was named vice president for personnel administration, at a time the company was in the process of laying off 40,000 white-collar workers. That promotion, largely at the urging of GM Executive Vice President Elmer Johnson, jumped him across half a dozen management levels and made him the highest-ranking black at GM. Roberts became vice president for truck operations at Navistar in August 1988, a few months after Johnson quit GM to go into private law practice. GM spokeswoman Patricia Malloy said Tuesday that as general manager of Cadillac manufacturing, Roberts will be among the highest-ranking blacks in the company, but will not be an officer of the corporation as he was while one of more than three dozen GM vice presidents. ``It doesn't make any difference,'' Roberts said. ``What I care about is the challenge and the opportunity. The title has nothing to do with it.'' Roberts was one of 10 children born to a family in Magnolia, Ark. His mother died when he was 2 and his father moved the family to Michigan, where Roberts began his career on the factory floor at Grand Rapids auto parts supplier Lear Siegler Inc. in 1959. Roberts worked nights so he could go to school and earn a business administration degree while also supporting a family.

DOC.HEAD: Rostenkowski Plan Could Help `Break the Ice'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 22 grafs to UPDATE with later comments by Darman, Foley. Picks up 10th graf pvs `That would ... Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Tuesday that an ambitious deficit-cutting plan by Democratic Rep. Dan Rostenkowski could help ``break the ice'' toward reaching a long-range budget pact with Congress. Neither Bush nor Budget Director Richard Darman offered much encouragement that the administration would support the plan's two most controversial elements _ a Social Security freeze and a tax increase. But Darman appeared to open the door a crack to a possible compromise that might include some form of higher excise taxes. Rostenkowski proposed an increase in taxes on the highest-paid Americans, along with a boost in excise taxes on gasoline, tobacco and alcohol. ``We are willing to discuss any proposals on the merits,'' even tax increases, Darman told reporters. Darman said the administration still believes deficit-reduction ``can be achieved without having to go to income tax increases.'' But, he added, ``you can't go into a negotiation and say it's absolutely, totally, completely, forever inconceivable that your view of the merits wouldn't change.'' At a White House news conference, Bush asked: ``Are we prepared to negotiate?'' He then answered his own question: ``Absolutely.'' On another economic policy matter, Bush denied he was considering replacing Alan Greenspan as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board in a dispute over interest-rate policy. ``There's no bubbling war with Alan Greenspan,'' Bush said. ``I'm not in a Fed-bashing mode.'' He said he and Greenspan have had differences over how high interest rates should be, adding: ``Every president would like to see interest rates lower.'' The Los Angeles Times reported last week that Bush was so unhappy with Greenspan's tight-credit policies that he likely would replace him when his term as chairman expires in 1991. ``There is no discussion of that nature at all,'' Bush said. Both Bush and Darman seemed to go out of their way to praise the deficit-reduction plan put forward several days ago by Rostenkowski, the Democratic chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee. ``It is the first serious proposal that has been put in the public domain by Democrats,'' Darman said. The administration, Darman said, has ``serious disagreements'' with parts of the plan, including the Social Security freeze and call for higher taxes. But he generally praised its proposal for a freeze on other programs, for using defense savings to trim the deficit and for restraining Medicaid payments. He denied the administration was trying to short-circuit the congressional process by reacting to Rostenkowski's plan before the House and Senate budget committees come up with their own proposal. The committees, he said, are ``just not close to being able to put together a budget resolution and it's important that there be something there to negotiate with.'' Darman said that, while the administration remains steadfast in its opposition to higher income taxes, it does not categorically reject higher excise taxes _ so long as the increase can be justified as a ``user fee'' in which the person paying the higher tax benefits from the spending. However, he said Rostenkowski's suggestion of a gasoline tax of 20 or 25 cents a gallon was too high to merit administration support. House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., said he thought some of the administration's kind reaction toward Rostenkowski's proposal was because of their personal friendship. ``That doesn't speak of any substantive change on the part of the president to consider new taxes,'' he said. Foley declined to endorse Rostenkowski's plan, although he repeated his assertion that any serious deficit reduction program would have to include both spending restraint and new taxes. Rostenkowski's plan, which would replace the Gramm-Rudman Act for chopping the deficit in stages, would raise taxes on the highest-income wage earners from 28 percent to 33 percent and increase taxes on cigarettes, alcohol and tobacco. It would also freeze most federal programs, including Social Security, at present levels for one year. That would deny some 39 million Americans a Social Security cost-of-living increase scheduled for next January. The Illinois Democrat's plan would also rechannel some of the ``peace dividend,'' defense money saved because of reduced East-West tensions, into further reducing the deficit. While making it clear he was not embracing the package in its present form, Bush praised Rostenkowski for putting forward the bold initiative with ``evident goodwill and determination to try to break the ice and move the process forward.'' Asked if he was for a tax increase at this time, Bush said: ``No, I'm not for a tax (increase).'' But he stopped short of making the same pledge on Social Security. When asked if he would oppose a freeze on Social Security benefits, Bush said: ``Well, there are a lot of things I'm not for in his proposal _ a lot _ including taxes.'' Bush, who in the past has threatened to have his veto pen ready for any proposed tax increase passed by Congress, on Tuesday offered a much milder response when asked if he could assure Americans that there would be no new taxes this year. ``I'm only one player, but you know my position, and I have no intention of changing that position,'' Bush said. When a reporter pressed further and asked Bush under what circumstances he might support a tax increase, he shot back: ``Too hypothetical. Nice try.'' Summing up action on the deficit, Bush noted that Rostenkowski had proposed his plan, ``we've thrown our idea out'' with the fiscal 1991 budget, and now ``we'd like the budget leaders on the Hill to throw theirs out ... and then perhaps we can talk.'' The Congressional Budget Office projects the budget shortfall in fiscal 1991 _ which begins Oct. 1 _ will be $161 billion; the White House Office of Management and Budget says it will be $100.5 billion if existing programs are left unchanged. Rostenkowski _ whose committee oversees taxes, Social Security and other federal benefit programs _ says his package would reduce next year's deficit to $106 billion and lead to a $2 billion surplus by fiscal 1994. Rep. Leon Panetta, D-Calif., chairman of the House Budget Committee, has said that Rostenkowski's proposal for tax increases and a one-year freeze on Social Security increases would be ``very huge political barriers'' to overcome.

DOC.HEAD: Rorer And Procter & Gamble Form Alliance
DOC.TEXT: Rorer Group Inc. announced Tuesday it will work jointly with the consumer products giant Procter & Gamble to develop and market prescription and over-the-counter pharmaceutical products. The move comes one day after the suburban Philadelphia-based company announced a $1.7 billion agreement to merge with the pharmaceuticals operations of Rhone-Poulenc SA of Paris. The alliance between Rorer and Cincinatti-based Procter & Gamble gives Rorer a major worldwide distribution system for its main product, the antacid Maalox. In addition to Maalox, Procter & Gamble obtains exclusive U.S. marketing and distribution rights to Rorer's line of over-the-counter pharmaceuticals, which include Ascriptin and Perdiem. Rorer, which will continue to manufacture the drugs, will gain rights to develop and market De-Nol, an anti-ulcer drug, and other prescription gastrointestinal compounds that Procter & Gamble has been developing. Procter & Gamble is still negotiating for international rights to market and distribute some of Rorer's over-the-counter pharmaceuticals. Rorer will retain ownership of its brands, while Procter & Gamble will receive royalty payments for the prescription products. Both companies will share in the growth of the business. ``P&G gains entry into a core over-the-counter category with a leading antacid brand with no major upfront capital investment,'' Procter & Gamble Chairman Edwin L. Artzt said in a statement. Rorer Chairman Robert E. Cawthorn said the alliance ``further promotes Rorer's strategic objective of becoming a world-class pharmaceutical company through research, internal growth and business alliances.'' ``This agreement maximizes the potential of Maalox,'' he said. ``Maalox and our other over-the-counter products will gain wider distribution by utilizing Procter & Gamble's extensive distribution system.'' Samuel D. Isaly, of Mehta & Isaly pharmaceutical specialists, said the deal ``is a lovely transaction'' for both companies. ``In the hands of Rorer, Maalox had a pretty bad future,'' he said. New Brunswick, N.J.-based Johnson & Johnson has heavily advertised a competing antacid, Mylanta, he said, and the government is considering allowing a variety of prescription ulcer drugs to be sold over the counter. With Procter & Gamble's better distribution system, Maalox will be more competitive, he said. As for Procter & Gamble, ``this gives them an extra brand name they can promote,'' said Isaly, who noted the company already distributes Metamucil and Pepto-Bismol. Under Tuesday's agreement, Procter & Gamble also has received the rights to purchase Rorer's over-the-counter pharmaceutical company if Rorer decides to sell it. ``That's pretty important,'' said Ron Nordmann of PaineWebber Group Inc. ``It is perhaps an indication that the newly-formed Rhone-Poulenc Rorer might want to focus more on prescription drugs and research.'' Igor Landau, president of Rhone-Poulenc's health sector, said the agreement with Procter & Gamble is consistent with the newly combined Rhone-Poulenc Rorer Inc.'s strategy of developing and strengthening its U.S. market. Access to U.S. markets was considered a major reason for the merger with Rorer. Although Rhone-Poulenc is in the top 10 in the European pharmaceutical market, it had no direct marketing in the United States or Japan. Procter & Gamble, with sales of $21.4 billion last year, manufactures and markets health care products as well as a wide range of laundry and cleaning products, personal care products, food and beverage products. Rorer Group Inc. had $1.2 billion in 1989 sales. Rhone-Poulenc Rorer Inc. is expected to have annual sales exceeding $3 billion. That merger will progress in stages, with Rhone-Poulenc eventually obtaining 68 percent of Rorer by June 1990. In exchange, Rorer will take on $265 million of Rhone-Poulenc debt and acquire the French group's existing U.S. pharmaceutical subsidiary for $20 million.

DOC.HEAD: Energy Futures Continue Decline
DOC.TEXT: Crude oil futures prices were down slightly Tuesday after a late round of selling. Analysts said crude had rallied higher after five straight days of declines, helped by a surge in gasoline futures prices, but traders sold off after crude hit $20.50 a barrel. The contract for April delivery of West Texas Intermediate, the key grade of U.S. crude oil, ended 2 cents lower on the New York Mercantile Exchange at $20.22 a 42-gallon barrel after a 19-cent drop Monday. Subsequent contract months ranged from down 1 cent to up 3 cents a barrel. ``It seems to have been primarily technical in nature because there was no fresh fundamental news that I caught,'' Peter Beutel, analyst with Elders Futures Inc., said of the trading activity. Trading also was cautious in advance of the American Petroleum Institute's weekly report, which was released after the close Tuesday. It showed crude oil inventories increased about 7 million barrels in the week ending last Friday compared to the previous week, a negative sign for futures prices. Gasoline stocks fell 2.5 million barrels, supporting that market. Distillate fuels were down 3 million barrels, the API report said. Unseasonably warm temperatures continued to depress heating oil prices. The contract for April delivery of home heating oil fell 0.02 cent to 53.51 cents a gallon on the New York Merc, after falling 0.33 cent on Monday. Subsequent contract months also declined Tuesday. The April contract for unleaded regular gasoline jumped 0.54 cent to 54.87 cents a gallon after a 0.66 cent loss on Monday. The May contract declined by 0.08 cent while later contract months were higher.

DOC.HEAD: Strong Dollar Holds Gold Futures Down Near $400
DOC.TEXT: Gold futures dropped again Tuesday and analysts said the price could fall $385 an ounce before enough buyers surface to offset the negative effects of the strengthening dollar. On other commodity markets, silver futures rose; copper plunged; coffee and cocoa futures surged; grains and soybeans slumped; cattle futures gained; pork futures retreated; and energy futures were mixed. Gold futures settled 40 cents lower to 50 cents higher on New York's Commodity Exchange with the contract for delivery in April down 40 cents at $400.70 a troy ounce. Silver futures finished 1.5 to 1.7 cents higher with March at $5.059 a troy ounce. April gold traded as low as $396.70, a four-month low, during the session but bounced back shortly before the close as the stock market and the dollar weakened. Analysts said the dollar's strength has become the dominant factor in the declining gold market, which traded near $430 for April delivery as recently as Feb. 7. The dollar recently has risen to its highest levels in nearly three years against the Japanese yen and has been gaining against the West German mark, largely due to market worries about the economic prospects for those two countries. ``The market is paying virtually no attention to anything but the dollar at the moment and that is likely to continue as long as the dollar continues to strengthen,'' said William O'Neill, commodity research director for Elders Futures Inc. in New York. Analysts said significant buying of gold could appear in the range of $385 to $390 an ounce. Copper futures plunged on the Comex late in the session as the stock market retreated. The copper market had been quiet for most of the day amid uneasiness about a strike that began Monday at the Southern Peru Copper Corp. Copper futures settled 1.5 cents to 2.3 cents lower with March at $1.19 a pound. Coffee and cocoa futures rose sharply on New York's Coffee, Sugar & Cocoa Exchange amid fears of supply disruptions due to political unrest in the Ivory Coast, a major exporter of both commodities. The coffee market also was supported by the return of hot, dry weather to Brazil, the world's biggest coffee producer, where poor growing conditions have already prompted government agencies to lower their yield predictions for the new coffee crop. Coffee settled 2.17 cents to 3 cents higher with March at 96.25 cents a pound; cocoa futures finished $31 to $38 higher with March at $1,113 per ton. Grain and soybean futures fell on the Chicago Board of Trade due to rainy weather, increased farmer selling of corn and indications of adequate soybean oil supplies. Wheat futures settled 1 cent to 4 cents lower with March at $3.81 a bushel; corn was 1 cent to 3\ cents lower with March at $2.43} a bushel; oats were 1} cents to 2} cents lower with March at $1.45{ a bushel; soybeans were 4\ cents to 6} cents lower with March at $5.78{ a bushel. Stronger cash markets supported cattle futures on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange while pork futures fell sharply late in the session amid expectations for a large weekly increase in supplies of frozen pork bellies. The exchange's weekly storage report, issued after the close, showed a net increase of 2.18 million pounds of bellies in cold storage, a figure that was even larger than expected. Cattle futures settled .10 cent to .62 cent higher with April at 78.12 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .33 cent to .72 cent higher with March at 83.15 cents a pound; live hogs were unchanged to .60 cent lower with April at 52.82 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .50 cent to 1.37 cents lower with March at 52.45 cents a pound. Petroleum futures ended mixed on the New York Mercantile Exchange ahead of the American Petroleum Institute's weekly inventory report, which showed greater-than-expected U.S. supplies of crude oil and larger-than-expected declines in supplies of both gasoline and distillates. West Texas Intermediate crude oil futures finished 2 cents lower to 3 cents higher with April at $20.22 a barrel; heating oil was .02 cent to .22 cent lower with April at 53.51 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .08 cent lower to .54 cent higher with April at 54.87 cents a gallon.

DOC.HEAD: Macy Reports $39 Million Loss After Disppointing Christmas
DOC.TEXT: R.H. Macy & Co. Inc. on Tuesday reported a $39 million loss in its most crucial quarter following a disappointing Christmas shopping season, increasing the financial pressures on the debt-burdened retailing chain. Macy, which went private in a leveraged buyout in 1986, said markdowns the company was forced to take to compete with price cutting at Campeau Corp.'s department stores took a heavy toll on its balance sheet. The second-quarter loss, which translated to $27.67 per share, compared with the $72.6 million, or $39.85 per share, Macy earned in the same period a year earlier. Sales during the quarter ended Jan. 27 totaled $2.44 billion, up from $2.28 billion a year earlier. Pamela Stubing, a retail industry analyst with Moody's Investors Service Inc., said many of Macy's stores in the Northeast had stiff competition from Campeau's Federated Department Stores and Allied Stores units. Macy, choosing to defend market share rather than profit margins, cut prices to keep its customers, she said. Federated and Allied, which were on the brink of a Chapter 11 bankruptcy court filing, slashed their prices during the holiday season to bring in cash. The loss could not have come at a worse time. Macy's second quarter _ the fourth quarter for most other major retailers _ is when the company hopes to earn half its annual profits. The company also is dependent on its cash flow to pay down the remaining debt from its leveraged buyout. Macy's earnings statement reported nearly $4.54 billion in long-term debt as of Jan. 27, and $189 million in interest charges during the second quarter. Walter Loeb, a retail consultant and analyst, said Macy also was hurt by overstocking its private label merchandise. To reduce inventory, the company again was forced to cut its prices, he said. But the company succeeded in cushioning the shock about the dismal quarter, having signaled to investors and its suppliers some time ago that it expected to report a sharp loss, Loeb said. Loeb said Macy's will continue to have problems in the near term, but he said there were signs the retailer would fare better during the spring because of warmer weather and because the company is going into the season with a leaner inventory. In a letter to its investors dated Monday, Macy said it was prepared for the economy to remain flat during the spring and fall seasons, indicating the retailer does not expect a burst of consumer spending. Ms. Stubing predicted the retail environment would be less promotional _ meaning fewer markdowns to draw customers _ during Macy's second half, although the company still faces tough competition. For the first six months of its fiscal year, Macy lost $72.2 million, or $51.58 per share, compared to earnings of $53.6 million, or $24.75 per share, in the same period a year ago. Sales for the first half rose to $4.15 billion from $3.9 billion. Loeb said the financial and retail industries have confidence in Macy Chairman Edward Finkelstein, who shaped the company's buyout and its retailing strategy. Besides its flagship Macy stores, located mainly in the East and Texas, the company owns I. Magnin and Bullock's stores in California and the West. It also owns specialty stores including Charter Club and Aeropostale, which are stocked with Macy's private label apparel brands.

DOC.HEAD: Experts: Politics Will Guide Future of Nicaraguan Economy
DOC.TEXT: A proposed Nicaraguan aid package and the lifting of a U.S. trade embargo will help awaken the nation's decimated manufacturing and agricultural economies, but political stability is the key to a full recovery, business leaders and economists said Tuesday. The $300 million aid request announced by President Bush may give Nicaraguans needed hard currency to upgrade factories and purchase parts for machinery and farm equipment, which have fallen into disrepair during the five-year trade embargo. But experts predict foreign investors will not likely return until the Sandinistas prove they will not violently oppose the government of president-elect Violeta Chamorro, winner of last month's elections. ``The aid is the first critical step to bring Nicaragua back from near bankruptcy,'' said Manuel Lasaga, a senior economist at Southeast Bank in Miami. ``The long-term prospects for the country depend heavily on the political situation. There will be no big investment until Nicaragua proves it's a place where business can be done.'' The embargo, established by President Reagan against the Sandinista government, cut off Nicaragua from lucrative U.S. markets for products such as sugar, coffee and bananas. It also effectively blocked the nation from receiving loans from aid organizations such as the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank. Lack of money and investment _ coupled by high inflation and the costs of fighting the U.S.-backed Contras _ caused the economy to founder. Nicaraguan exports, which reached $650 million in the 1970s, are presently less than $200 million. Meanwhile, the nation's foreign debt has grown four-fold to $8 billion since 1980. Bush said Tuesday he will ask Congress to appropriate $300 million immediately for Nicaragua, and said he will also seek an additional $200 million in economic assistance in fiscal year 1991, which begins Oct. 1. In Miami, home to 50,000 to 100,000 Nicaraguan exiles, there is optimism among business leaders that commerce with Nicaragua will resume soon. Carlos Perez, a former U.S. House candidate and well-known GOP supporter, said he may re-establish his banana import business. ``We have to take advantage of this to show that there is an atmosphere in in Nicaragua where business can thrive,'' said Perez, who was cited by Reagan as an immigrant success story. ``It will be a slow process, but at least it's beginning.'' Ties with Miami-based Nicaraguans should also help integrate Nicaragua into the global marketplace, said Roberto Arguello, founder of the Miami-based Nicaraguan Banker's and Businessman's Association. Arguello, however, does not foresee many Nicaraguans returning permanently to open businesses. ``I see a strong link between Miami and Managua,'' said Arguello. ``There are a lot of people here who have made money in America and know how the system works. We can be an invaluable assistance to those starting up in Nicaragua.'' But several major obstacles stand in the way of Nicaragua's full economic rebound, several experts say. The embargo destroyed the North American distribution network for most Nicaraguan products, particuarly highly perishable crops. Also, Nicaragua is not part of the Caribbean Basin Initiative, which provides member nations with duty-free entry into the U.S. market for most products. ``It's obvious that Nicaragua could not compete unless it's a member of CBI,'' said Gordon Studebaker, director of the U.S. Department of Commerce office responsible for Caribbean business development. ``But I think it's in everyone's best interest to work quickly to bring Nicaragua into the program.'' Panama will officially return to the 7-year-old CBI next week, bringing the total to 23 nations. ``The decision to offer direct loans to Nicaragua has a psychological effect on private lenders and international businessmen,'' said Dario Moreno, an assistant professor at Florida International University who specializes in U.S.-Nicaragua affairs. ``It shows the Bush administration is giving its approval to the new regime and says, `This is a regime we can trust.' Business people watch this closely. Private money tends to follow public money.'' A more cautious tone is sounded by Ambler Moss, a former U.S. ambassador to Panama and dean of the University of Miami Graduate School of International Studies. ``You have to look behind all the `happy talk' and see what really is going to happen with the aid and how quickly the sanctions will be lifted,'' he said. ``Nicaragua still has a long way to go.''

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Falls, Gold Prices Soften
Precede LONDON-BC
DOC.TEXT: The dollar finished slightly lower in moderate trading Tuesday amid confusion about a plan for German monetary unification, reversing earlier gains in overseas markets, traders said. Gold prices also slipped. Republic National Bank of New York quoted a late bid of $398.70 a troy ounce, down 55 cents from late Monday. On New York's Commodity Exchange, gold for current delivery settled at $399 a troy ounce, down 80 cents. Traders said the dollar opened higher in New York, boosted by its rise overseas. It advanced to its high for the day against the West German mark on a midday report that West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl said East Germans would be able to convert their savings to the West German currency at a rate of one East German mark for one West German mark, traders said. Economists say converting the currency at that rate could cause inflation in West Germany, which would devalue the West German mark. However, the market later learned that the one-for-one currency swap under consideration would apply only to small savings accounts, traders said. The news sparked a sharp selloff in dollar. ``I've never seen anything like it and I've been in the market 11 years,'' said Abigail Cook, a dealer with Hongkong and Shanghai Banking Corp. She said the dollar drop lasted a few minutes before the currency stabilized at a lower level. The dollar closed in New York at 1.7120 West German marks, down from its high of the day of 1.7218 and from Monday's late figure of 1.7135 marks. Earlier, in Europe, the dollar closed at 1.7165 West German marks, up from 1.7110 Monday. The market had little reaction to government reports showing the deficit in the broadest measure of U.S. trade sank to a five-year low last year, and that retail sales in February took their steepest fall in four months. The figures were about what the market expected, said Robert Hatcher, a dealer with Barclays Bank PLC. In Tokyo, the dollar rose to a closing 152.67 Japanese yen _ the lowest level for the yen against the dollar in exactly three years _ from 152.00 yen Monday. Later, in London, it fell to 152.52 yen. In New York, the dollar fell to 152.20 yen from 152.63 yen late Monday. In London, the dollar rose against the British pound. It cost $1.6005 to buy one pound, cheaper than $1.6100 late Monday. Later, in New York, it closed at $1.6097, down from $1.6115 late Monday. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday, included: 1.5215 Swiss francs, down from 1.5258; 5.7850 French francs, down from 5.7915; 1,264.50 Italian lire, down from 1,265.50; and 1.1761 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1787. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Monday: 1.5275 Swiss francs, up from 1.5235; 5.7915 French francs, up from 5.7800; 1.9312 Dutch guilders, up from 1.9190; 1,267.00 Italian lire, up from 1,263.75; and 1.1775 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1787. Gold fell in London to a late bid of $396.55 a troy ounce from $400.65 bid late Monday. In Zurich, gold fell to a closing bid of $396 an ounce from $401.10 Monday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell $1.94 to close at a bid $399.08 an ounce. Silver bullion fell in London to a late bid of $5.05 a troy ounce from $5.15 Monday. In New York, silver closed at $5.059 a troy ounce on the Commodity Exchange, up from $5.042 late Monday.

DOC.HEAD: AT&T and Tandem Team Up
DOC.TEXT: AT&T and Tandem Computers Inc. announced Tuesday they are joining forces under a cooperative research and marketing accord, a deal that analysts said provides a major endorsement of Tandem's computer technology. American Telephone & Telegraph Co. is acquiring worldwide rights to market Tandem's ``fault-tolerant'' computers, which have built-in redundancies to prevent accidental crashes or shutdowns. The computers use a modified version of the Unix operating system software developed by AT&T. The alliance provides for joint development aimed at speeding up the availability and acceptance of fault-tolerant hardware and software based on Unix, the companies said. ``This agreement combines AT&T's strength in open systems and networking with Tandem's leadership in fault-tolerant platforms,'' said Richard A. McGinn, president of AT&T Computer Systems, based in Morristown, N.J. Industry analysts praised the pact. ``It's obviously good for Tandem,'' said Peter Rogers, an analyst with the Robertson & Stevens brokerage in San Francisco. ``It's a major endorsement for their architecture and a strong endorsement for their Unix offerings.'' ``It gives Tandem another source of pretty powerful marketing,'' said Robert Kidd, an analyst with Dataquest Inc., a San Jose-based market research firm. ``AT&T and the federal government fit together like yin and yang. This certainly serves to strengthen Tandem's ties to the government market.'' AT&T strongly denied suggestions by some industry observers that it might be phasing out its own line of minicomputers and instead rely on remarketing those made by other firms, such as Tandem. ``Hogwash! It's not true, absolutely not true,'' said James Clark, an AT&T Computer Systems vice president. The deal with Tandem ``simply expands the range of systems we have,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: President Leaves Restaurant Chain
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5-6th grafs pvs, Gibbons will ... to UPDATE with 3 new grafs of Burger King spokeswoman comments. Picks up 7th graf pvs, Burger King ...
DOC.TEXT: Burger King Corp. announced Tuesday that C. Ronald Petty, president and chief operating officer of Burger King USA, is leaving the worldwide fast-food chain after 12 years. Petty, who returned from Burger King's international division to run the domestic side of the corporation just before Burger King was taken over by Grand Metropolitan in January 1989, decided only recently to leave the firm, said Barry J. Gibbons, chief executive officer of Burger King Corp. ``We both decided we would get right down to the urgent tasks at hand (after the acquisition) and take a year or so to decide whether we wanted to work together long term,'' Gibbons said in a statement Tuesday. ``We have had that review and decided to change. I would like to pay open tribute to Ron for his contribution to Burger King over the years, and in particular to our progress over the last 12 months,'' he said. Gibbons will assume the responsibilities of chief operating officer for the U.S. division pending a further announcement, said Cori Zywotow, a spokeswoman at Burger King's Miami headquarters. Petty's departure was unrelated to a lawsuit announced Thursday by Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole accusing Burger King of violating child labor laws by assigning workers under 16 to late-night shifts and too many hours, she said. ``It was not related. Their shared decision was made prior to the Dole announcement,'' Ms. Zywotow said. Burger King and its franchisees operate more than 6,000 restaurants in 34 countries worldwide. In fiscal year 1989, the company had systemwide sales of $5.7 billion. Grand Metropolitan is one of the United Kingdom's largest international companies and a world leader in the food, drinks and retailing businesses.

DOC.HEAD: Ford, Sun Oil Subsidiary in Alternative Fuel Research Program
DOC.TEXT: Ford Motor Co. and a subsidiary of Sun Oil Co. on Tuesday announced a joint research program to study use of a methanol-based automotive fuel outside California. Most street testing of alternative fuels by the nation's Big Three automakers has taken place in California, which has the strictest air pollution laws in the United States. Ford will provide a fleet of 30 mid- and full-size cars and full-size vans to be powered by a mixture of 85 percent methanol and 15 percent gasoline. The mixture, called M85, will be provided by Sun Refining and Marketing Co. The vehicles will be driven mostly by Ford employees and the fuel will be supplied beginning next week by a Sunoco service station in Dearborn, near Detroit. Automakers have been looking into powering automobiles and trucks with fuels other than gasoline as they try to reduce tailpipe emissions in anticipation of stricter government regulations. Last December, Ford delivered a fleet of 210 vehicles powered by M85 to California and currently operates a 30-vehicle fleet elsewhere. ``All of our previous retail station experience has been in the mild climate of California,'' said Donald Buist, director of automotive emissions and fuel economy for Ford. ``This program with Sun will allow us to learn even more about methanol storage, delivery and use as a real-world fuel before we move to any widescale efforts to put such vehicles into our customers' hands,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Multimedia Sells Its Two Florida Papers to Kansas City Company
DOC.TEXT: Multimedia Inc. announced Tuesday it will sell its two newspapers in Florida to Stauffer Communications Inc. for an undisclosed price. The sale of The News Chief of Winter Haven, a daily, and The Auburndale Star, a weekly, is mutually beneficial to Multimedia and Stauffer, said Walter E. Bartlett, chairman of the board of Multimedia. ``Stauffer has made a significant investment in print media in Polk County and the Winter Haven area,'' he said. ``This acquisition would add substantially to their presence there.'' The purchase price of the two papers was not disclosed, and the sale was contingent upon completing the purchase agreement, which was expected by April 1, officials said. Multimedia Inc., which is based in Greenville, publishes 14 daily and 50 non-daily newspapers, owns and operates four television and seven radio stations, and operates more than 100 cable television franchises in four states. The company also produces and syndicates television programming, including the Phil Donahue and Sally Jessy Raphael shows. Stauffer, which is based in Topeka, Kansas, owns 22 daily and eight weekly newspapers, and six television and five radio stations in 15 states. The company also publishes two periodicals, Grit and Cappers, and operates the Kansas City Royals radio network. The News Chief, an afternoon paper with a circulation of about 20,000 ``will be Stauffer Communications' flagship Florida newspaper,'' chairman of the board Stanley H. Stauffer said. ``Moreover, the Winter Haven and Auburndale publications will greatly enhance our other Florida operations.'' Donald R. Hatley, publisher of The News Chief, will remain with Multimedia Newspaper Co. in a corporate role. Hatley will continue to manage the paper until the transaction is completed. Kenneth C. Bronson, vice president of newspapers for Stauffer, said when his company takes over operations of the two papers, he will announce a new publisher for each. No other personnel changes are planned, he said.

DOC.HEAD: AT&T Reorganizes Financing Unit
DOC.TEXT: American Telephone & Telegraph Co. announced Tuesday the breakup of its financing unit into a group of separate entities under a new umbrella, AT&T Capital Corp. The reorganization puts the former AT&T Credit Corp. into a family of holdings that will provide financing and equipment leasing services at different levels for the AT&T parent and other companies. Growth at AT&T Credit into different areas prompted the restructuring, said AT&T spokesman Charlie Wade. The unit in 1989 accounted for $442 million of the company's $36.11 billion in revenue, he said. AT&T Capital will preside over five companies, including AT&T Credit. The new units will finance equipment purchases by AT&T customers and lease equipment for internal AT&T uses and to outside customers. The reorganization is expected to be completed by the end of the month.

DOC.HEAD: Stock Market Follows Bond Prices Lower
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 17th graf bgng The NYSE's to CORRECT closing index to 185.25.
DOC.TEXT: Prices slumped on Wall Street Tuesday as the stock market, taking another cue from the bond market, succumbed to concerns about rising interest rates. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 12.16 to 2,674.55. Declining issues outnumbered advancers by a margin of about 7 to 4 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 557 up, 913 down and 498 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 145.44 million shares, up from 114.79 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 172.68 million shares. The stock market began the day on the down side after bond prices fell in response to the Commerce Department's report of a 0.9 percent drop in retail sales in February. The sales drop was the steepest in four months, but analysts said it was due almost entirely to sagging automobiles sales. Other segments of consumer spending experienced healthy increases, they said. The report was seen as a sign of economic health, and as such a signal that the Federal Reserve was unlikely to move interest rates lower anytime soon. Wall Street tried to shake off the news and the bond market's decline, but when Treasury prices fell further, stocks joined the sell-off. Stock traders were also uneasy about the rise in credit market yields, which affect other interest rates. By the end of trading on Wall Street, the yield on the Treasury's bellwether 30-year bond had shot up to 8.71 percent from 8.61 late Monday. The bond's price was down $11.25 for each $1,000 in face amount. Concerns about interest rates have dominated Wall Street since the beginning of the year and forced stock traders to pay close attention to the credit markets. The most actively traded issue on the NYSE was Unisys, up { to 15|. Among blue chip stocks, which had led the brief recovery, IBM was off 1{ to 106\, Exxon was down ~ to 45|, and Philip Morris was off ] to 37|. Selective airline stocks outperformed the market. AMR was up 1] to 64~, Delta picked up 1| to 71} and UAL rose 3] to 139~. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market lost $20.525 billion, or 0.63 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks fell 1.26 to 185.25. Standard & Poor's industrial index fell 3.10 to 388.15, and S&P's 500-stock composite index was off 2.67 at 336.00. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market slipped 1.98 to 434.58. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 360.79, down 1.98.

DOC.HEAD: New Chairman Elected at Commodity Exchange
DOC.TEXT: Martin Greenberg, head of Sterling Commodities Corp., was elected Tuesday to a two-year term as chairman of New York's Commodity Exchange. Greenberg, 50, has been a member of Comex since beginning his commodities career as an independent floor trader in 1976. Prior to that he worked in the brokerage business, predominantly in common stocks and underwriting. He succeeds Robert Fink as chairman of Comex, the world's leading precious metals exchange. Fink had been appointed last summer to fill a vacancy created by the resignation of John Hanemann. Fink did not seek another term. Greenberg is chairman of Comex's margin and supervisory committees and also serves on the exchange's new products committee. Comex, which has been involved in talks about merging with the New York Mercantile Exchange, also filled nine of 25 board seats.

DOC.HEAD: Hazardous Materials Bill Clears Committee Hurdle
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: A House committee approved Tuesday an overhaul of the nation's hazardous materials transportation law, including controls on using the same vehicle to ship both wastes and food. The measure won approval from the Energy and Commerce Committee on a voice vote. A key provision would place controls on ``backhauling'' _ carrying food, drugs or cosmetics in vehicles used to ship wastes or hazardous materials. Lawmakers introduced the backhauling provision after learning that shippers with food products from the Midwest were picking up garbage on the return trip from the East, where landfill space is scarce. The same vehicles would then ship food again without proper cleaning. The panel approved the backhauling measure as a separate bill and also attached it to its broader hazardous materials legislation before voting that out of committee. It would require federal officials to set standards for which materials could be shipped in the same vehicle. A backhauling bill applying only to highway vehicles and not railroads has been passed by the Public Works and Transportation Committee. The Energy and Commerce version embraces the key provisions of that bill and extends its coverage to railroads. The Energy and Commerce version, sponsored by Rep. Thomas A. Luken, D-Ohio, also gives standard-setting authority to three government agencies: Transportation Department, Department of Health and Human Services and the Environmental Protection Agency. The overall hazardous materials bill approved by the committee seeks to tighten controls over an estimated 4 billion tons shipped annually. The bill calls for: _ New regulations governing the marking and registration of hazardous shipments, with ready availability of emergency information. _ New regulations on training requirements and response procedures for fire department crews and others who deal with hazardous materials. _ Detailed registration statements by those involved in shipping hazardous materials. _ New standards for determining permissible routes and an updated list of those routes. _ Higher penalties for violations. _ Requiring air-brake equipment supports on older rail tank cars. _ A state-by-state study of emergency response capability. _ A Transportation Department study of railroad tank car safety.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Eases, Stock Prices Fall Moderately
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. dollar eased slightly in early trading against the Japanese yen Wednesday, while share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange fell. The dollar opened at 151.90 yen, down from Tuesday's close of 152.67 yen, which was the Japanese currency's lowest level against the dollar in three years. ``It seems that the dollar is in a stage of adjustment'' following its sharp rise the previous day, said a dealer with the Bank of Tokyo. Market sentiment toward the dollar remains firm because of a demand for the American currency by Japanese investors planning to invest in the United States, he noted. On the stock exchange, the Nikkei index of 225 selected issues, which lost 747.66 points Tuesday, shed another 91.94 points, or 0.28 percent, moving to 32,528.63 shortly after the market opened. Investors were discouraged by an overnight decline on Wall Street, securities dealers said. The stock market in Tokyo is normally not active in March, when many Japanese companies settle their accounts.

DOC.HEAD: Simmons Says He Would Put Employee Representative On Lockheed Board
DOC.TEXT: Dallas investor Harold Simmons said Tuesday he would put an employee representative on the Lockheed Corp. board of directors if he wins his proxy fight for the defense contractor. Simmons, Lockheed's largest stockholder with 19 percent, has proposed replacing the company's entire 14-member board with his own nominees, including former Sen. John Tower and former Chief of Naval Operations Adm. Elmo Zumwalt. In a statement, Simmons said if he succeeds at Lockheed's March 29 stockholder meeting, he will move to create an additional board seat for a representative of the employee stock ownership plan, created last year after Simmons first began accumulating shares in the Calabasas, Calif.-based company. ``We believe the employees in the Lockheed ESOP deserve board representation,'' Simmons said. ``If we are successful, it would be our plan to meet with ESOP participants to get their input and recommend a director who fairly reflects the ESOP employees' vision of Lockheed's future.'' The ESOP controls about 1 million shares, Simmons said. Simmons began the proxy fight after Lockheed officials refused to grant him seats on the board. Meeting with analysts in New York Monday, Simmons said he would increase Lockheed's returns by concentrating on its core defense and aerospace businesses.

DOC.HEAD: 3-Day Bank Holiday Ordered to Calm Markets Before Emergency Decree
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with cruzado devalued, details, no pickup, also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Brazil's Central Bank late Tuesday closed the nation's banks for the rest of the week in an attempt to calm markets before President-elect Fernando Collor de Mello announces an emergency economic package. The Central Bank, the equivalent of the U.S. Federal Reserve, also announced the cruzado, the national currency, would be devalued 10.7 percent effective Monday, when the banks re-open. The three-day bank holiday was decreed by Zelia Cardoso de Mello, the nation's new economic minister, who is to take office Thursday with the new president. She said in a brief statement, ``The bank holiday was declared to preserve the stability of markets until the whole package of measures is announced. In the past few days, there has been a great deal of speculative activity and we wanted to calm the market down.'' Ms. Cardoso de Mello, no relation to the president-elect, offered no further information about the new economic proposals, which are expected to be announced when the president-elect addresses Congress Friday morning. The move took many locals and economists by surprise because only a day earlier Ms. Cardoso de Mello had said, ``A bank holiday is absolutely not necessary.'' Analysts said the bank holiday was in response to large-scale withdrawals from the $60 billion that rolls over every day on the ``overnight'' _ short-term deposits paying interest rates of up to 100 percent that the government uses to finance its burdensome $31 billion public deficit. Its public deficit contributes a large portion to Brazil's $114 billion foreign debt, which is the developing world's largest, followed by Mexico and Argentina. Most of its debt is to U.S. and European banks. Investors, uneasy about Collor de Mello's economic plans, have used withdrawals from the ``overnight'' to speculate in gold and the illegal but widely tolerated black market for dollars, causing wild swings in their values in recent weeks. Collor de Mello, Brazil's first directly elected president in almost 30 years, has promised free-market economic reforms to try to bring down the debilitating inflation rate _ 2,700 percent the past 12 months. February's inflation was 73 percent. Collor de Mello is to replace Jose Sarney, who took office in 1985 but by law could not run for re-election. The new economic package is rumored to include privatizations of inefficient state companies, layoffs of thousands of public employees and widescale spending cuts. Business leaders have expressed concern about a possible wage-and-price freeze, the basis of four failed anti-inflationary plans by the Sarney administration. Bank holidays are not common in Brazil. The last was Jan. 15, 1989, when Sarney decreed his fourth austerity package, popularly known as the ``Summer Plan,'' which froze wages and prices on basic goods. Both the president-elect and Ms. Cardoso de Mello have denied they will implement a freeze. By Tuesday evening, lines stretched for blocks at automatic bank machines in major cities with people trying to get cash for the next several days. Withdrawals were limited to $47 per person per day. ``The population can remain calm. There will be enough money for the entire weekend,'' said Getulio Mota, manager of a Bradesco bank branch in Rio de Janeiro, quashing rumors of cash shortages. Privately owned Jornal do Brasil radio in Rio reported the new administration was planning to create a new currency but Central Bank spokesman Petro Kleinberg said he knew nothing of such a plan. The devaluation was much larger than normal. Officials have been devaluing the cruzado about 2 percent daily to keep up with inflation. Brazil, with about 150 million residents, has been wracked for years by persistently high inflation and an active labor movement that wages debilitating strikes for higher salaries and benefits. The unions in particular are strong. Of Brazil's 60-million-member work force, the leftist Central Workers Union and the more moderate General Workers Center claim to represent close to 35 million workers. Waves of strikes _ from schools to hospitals _ have rocked the economy in recent months, including February when 60,000 Petrobras oil workers staged an eight-day strike, paralyzing oil production and refineries. Brazil's per capita income in 1986, the latest figures available, was about $1,740 but real wages have declined for several years due to raging inflation.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Rules Against UPI in Photo Exchange Lawsuit
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with comment, details, UPI filing legal papers asking for return of service; no pickup; on general news wires also.
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge on Tuesday refused to order Reuters to continue a picture exchange agreement with United Press International. The judge said UPI had not shown it would be irreparably harmed if the arrangement were discontinued. U.S. District Judge Peter K. Leisure made the finding in denying UPI a preliminary injunction that would have barred Reuters from carrying out its plan to pull out of the contract between the two news services. The judge extended until Monday an earlier order that bars Reuters from canceling the contract, so UPI can appeal his decision. ``Obviously, we're disappointed we didn't get the preliminary injunction,'' said Milt Capps, UPI's senior vice president of corporate affairs. ``However, we do take some encouragement from the fact that the judge feels UPI will not be irreparably harmed, and we are going to do everything possible to prove him right.'' Lawyers for UPI said at a hearing Monday that they would appeal if Leisure denied the injunction. ``The simple loss of customers ... is not sufficient to justify the action sought,'' Leisure said in a written opinion. ``While there may be some injury to UPI's business due to the loss of Reuters' service, the court finds that such a loss could be compensable in monetary terms.'' The request for the injunction stemmed from a counterclaim by UPI to a Reuters federal lawsuit that seeks to void the picture exchange. Reuters said the agreement was not living up to expectations. The contract was entered into in 1984 and called for UPI to supply Reuters with pictures from the United States while Reuters provided UPI with pictures from other countries. The international pictures were to come from a global service that UPI had set up and sold to Reuters. The agreement was to run for 10 years beginning in 1985. In legal papers filed Tuesday, UPI asked the court to return the international photo service to UPI, Capps said. Leisure cited testimony Monday by the UPI chairman, Dr. Earl Brian, who said some newspapers indicated they would drop the UPI photo service if the Reuters contract is canceled. Brian also said UPI had been negotiating a photo exchange with the French news service, Agence France-Presse, but that AFP only agreed to give UPI a supply of photos for three months. ``While the court does find it likely that some UPI customers may not be content with the replacement of Reuters by AFP, and may choose to disconnect UPI, the loss of these individual customers is simply not sufficient for the drastic relief sought by UPI,'' Leisure said.
